column1: The '''PDSA Certificate for Animal Bravery or Devotion''' is an animal bravery award that acknowledges the extraordinary bravery and devotion to duty of animals.<ref>{{cite web
column6: format=PDF}}</ref>   It was created by the [[People's Dispensary for Sick Animals]] (PDSA) in 2001.<ref name=dottypdsa/> So far all of the recipients have been [[dog]]s except for Dotty, a [[donkey]].<ref name=dottypdsa/>

column2: A black [[Labrador Retriever]] from [[Lancashire]] who was stabbed four times in the chest and legs by an armed [[burglar]], but still successfully chased him from the property.

column3: German Shepherd]]-cross who aided his owner's son when he had an [[Epilepsy

column4: title=Brave dog Wicker receives a PDSA Certificate for her life-saving action

column2: A [[Miniature Schnauzer]] who attracted attention to his elderly owner when she slipped and fell in her garden late one evening.

column4: title=Hero dog Orlando is honoured for his life-saving devotion

column2: A [[donkey]] that came to her stablemate's aid, a [[sheep]], when it was attacked by a [[Pit Bull]].

column4: title=Brave donkey honoured for saving sheep from dog attack
column8: title=Kick ass! How Dotty the donkey saved her friend Stanley the sheep from mauling by a pitbull

column2: A [[Yorkshire Terrier]] army mascot from [[World War II]] that was the first [[therapy dog]] on record, and pulled communication cables through a seventy foot long drainage culvert under a recently captured airstrip.
A [[Stray Dog]] from [[Helmand Province]] [[Afghanistan]] who accompanied [[United Kingdom
column3: British]] troops on patrol for [[Improvised explosive device

column4: title=Brin the Afghanistan Bomb Dog Gets New Life

column2: A [[Labrador Retriever]] [[guide dog]] that defended his blind owner when she was attacked, before walking her home while injured.

column4: title=Hero dog Orlando is honoured for his life-saving devotion

column2: A Border Collie cross who barked to wake up her owner to alert her to a house fire.

column4: title=Faithful dog Peggy is honoured by PDSA for her bravery in a house fire

column1: *The [[Dickin Medal]], a separate award also administered by the PDSA, which was established by [[Maria Dickin]], founder of the PDSA, in 1943, to acknowledge acts of outstanding bravery by animals serving with military forces in theatres of war, and is considered the animal equivalent of the [[Victoria Cross]].<ref name=""pdsa"">{{Cite web
{{DEFAULTSORT:Pdsa Certificate for Animal Bravery or Devotion}}

column2: the partial removal of the ears of animals

column3: A [[Guatemalan Dogo]] with cropped ears]]'''Cropping''' is the removal of part or all of the [[pinna (anatomy)
column4: pinnae]] or auricles, the external visible flap of the ear, of an animal; it sometimes involves taping to make the ears pointy.  Most commonly performed on dogs, it is an ancient practice that was once done for perceived health, practical or cosmetic reasons. In modern times, it is banned in many nations, but is still legal in a limited number of countries. Where permitted, it is seen only in certain breeds of dog such as the [[Pit bull]], [[Miniature Pinscher]], [[Doberman Pinscher]], [[Schnauzer]], [[Great Dane]], [[Boxer (dog)

column1: The veterinary procedure is known as cosmetic otoplasty. Current veterinary science provides no medical or physical advantage to the animal from the procedure,<ref name=slatter>Slatter, Douglas H. (2002) [https://books.google.com/books?id=B_nh6zSr4wUC ''Textbook of small animal surgery''] 3rd edition. Philadelphia: W.B. Saunders (imprint of Elsevier Health Sciences), 2896 pages, {{ISBN
column5: title=Ear Cropping: Is it right for your dog?}}</ref> leading to concerns over [[animal cruelty]] related to performing unnecessary surgery on the animals. In addition to the bans in place in countries around the world, it is described in some veterinary texts as ""no longer considered ethical.""<ref name=slatter/>

column1: Cropping of large portions of the pinnae of other animals is rare, although the clipping of identifying shapes in the pinnae of [[livestock]], called [[Earmark (agriculture)
column2: earmark]]s, was common prior to the introduction of compulsory [[ear tag]]s.<ref name=manade>[http://www.manade-en-camargue.fr/manade-en-camargue-lexique.html Lexique Camarguais] (in French) Manade Devaux. ""Lexicon of Camargue terms"" Accessed September 2011</ref>  Removal of portions of the ear of [[laboratory mice]] for identification, i.e. ear-notching, is still used.  The practice of cropping for cosmetic purposes is rare in non-canines, although some selectively bred animals have naturally small ears which can be mistaken for cropping.

column5: Duncombe Dog]], a 2nd-century AD Roman copy of a [[Hellenistic]] bronze, probably of the 2nd century BC and from [[Epirus]], showing cropped ears]]

column1: Ear cropping has been performed on dogs since [[Classical antiquity
column2: ancient]] times.<ref name=Broughton>Broughton, Amy L. (2003) [http://www.animallaw.info/articles/dduscroppingdocking.htm#V Cropping and Docking: A Discussion of the Controversy and the Role of Law in Preventing Unnecessary Cosmetic Surgery on Dogs] Michigan State University - Detroit College of Law. Accessed September 2011.</ref>

column1: Historically, cropping was performed on working dogs in order to decrease the risk of health complications, such as ear infections or hematomas. Crops were also performed on dogs that might need to fight, either while hunting animals that might fight back or while defending [[livestock]] herds from predators, or because they were used for pit-fighting sports such as [[dogfighting]] or [[bear-baiting]].<ref name=Briar/><ref name=murgai>Murgai, Major R.P. (1996) [https://books.google.com/books?id=cPPTZvzNNHMC ''Handbook on Dogs''] New Delhi: New Age International, p.46</ref>  The ears were an easy target for an opposing animal to grab or tear.<ref name=Briar>[http://www.briarleabouvier.com/ear_cropping.htm Ear Cropping: Correct or Cruel?] Briarlea Bouvier Kennel. Accessed September 2011.</ref>

Cropping the ears of [[livestock guardian dogs]] was, and may still be, traditional in some pastoral cultures. The ears of working flock-defense dogs such as the [[Caucasian Shepherd Dog]] (Kavkazskaïa Ovtcharka)<ref name=kavk>Samsonova, Anna [http://www.fci.be/uploaded_files/328g02-en.doc Caucasian Shepherd Dog (Kavkazskaïa Ovtcharka)] Fédération Cynologique Internationale FCI-Standard N° 328, 2 February 2011. Accessed September 2011</ref> and the [[Maremma Sheepdog
column2: Pastore Maremmano-Abruzzese]] were traditionally cropped to reduce the possibility of wolves or aggressor dogs getting a hold on them.<ref name=breber>Breber, Paolo (1983) ''Il Cane da Pastore Maremmano-Abruzzese'' (in Italian) 2nd edition. Firenze: Olimpia ""The Maremmano-Abruzzese shepherd dog"" pp.98–99</ref> According to one description, cropping was carried out when puppies were weaned, at about six weeks. It was performed by an older or expert shepherd, using the ordinary blade shears used for [[Sheep shearing
column3: shearing]], well sharpened. The ears were cut either to a point like those of a fox, or rounded like those of a bear. The removed auricles were given to the puppy to eat, in the belief that it would make him more ""sour"";<ref name=breber/> the ears were first grilled.<ref name=anne>MacDonell, Anne, Amy Atkinson (ill.) (1907) [https://archive.org/stream/inabruzzi00macdrich#page/n7/mode/2up ''In the Abruzzi''] New York: F.A. Stokes p. 18</ref> An alternative method was to remove the ears from newborn puppies by twisting them off; however, this left almost no external ear on the dog.<ref name=breber/>  More than three hundred years ago, both ear-cropping and the use of [[Wolf collar
column4: spiked collars]] were described as a defense against wolves by [[Jean de la Fontaine]] in Fable 9 of Book X of the ''Fables'', published in 1678.<ref name=wright>Wright, Elizur (trans.), Jean de la Fontaine (1862) [https://books.google.com/books?id=CDSEvJ41PpMC ''The fables of La Fontaine, translated [in verse] from the French''] London: Miller p.74</ref>

column1: Dogs may have their ears cropped, legally or not, for participation in dogfights, themselves illegal in many jurisdictions.<ref name=curtis>Curtis, Patricia (2002) [https://books.google.com/books?id=0ndd3eAnzpcC ''City dog: choosing and living well with a dog in town''] New York: Lantern Books {{ISBN

Historically, ear cropping has been advocated as a health benefit for certain breeds with long, hanging ears. There is some evidence that dogs with standing ears may suffer from fewer ear infections than dogs with hanging ears.<ref name=Briar/><ref>Fossum TW. Surgery of the ear. In: Fossum TW, ed. Small Animal Surgery. 3rd ed. St.Louis; Mosby Elsevier, 2007;289-316.</ref> It has also been hypothesized that standing ears are less prone to damage and subsequent medical complications, especially in working dogs. Some claim that cropped ears enhance Boxers' hearing.<ref name=Boxer>{{cite web
column5: publisher=American Kennel Club Gazette, American Boxer Club
column7: title=Sad lesson learned}}</ref>  Long, hanging ears can not function the same way as erect ears which can swivel toward a sound source.  The erect shape directs sound waves into the [[ear canal]] and additionally amplifies the sound slightly.  Long, hanging [[Auricle (anatomy)
column8: pinnae]] also impose a physical barrier to sound waves entering the ear canal.<ref>

column4: Boxers]] with natural and cropped ears and docked tails]]

column1: In the last 100 years or so, ear cropping has been performed more often for cosmetic purposes.<ref name=murgai/><ref name=CFHS/> In nations and states where it remains legal, it is usually practiced because it is required as part of a breed standard for exhibition at [[Conformation show
column2: dog shows]].<ref name=CFHS>[http://cfhs.ca/athome/ear_cropping_and_tail_docking Ear cropping and tail docking] The Canadian Federation of Humane Societies/Fédération des sociétés canadiennes d'assistance aux animaux (CFHS/FSCAA). Accessed September 2011.</ref>

column3: A [[Doberman Pinscher]] puppy with its ears taped to train them into the desired shape and carriage after cropping]]

column1: The veterinary procedure is known as ""cosmetic otoplasty"".<ref name=""slatter""/> It is usually performed on puppies at 7 to 12 weeks of age.<ref name=doggies>[http://www.doggiesparadise.com/earcropping-dogs.shtml Practice of Dogs Ear cropping] [sic] Doggie's Paradise. Accessed September 2011</ref>  After 16 weeks, the procedure is more painful and the animal has greater pain memory.<ref name=Briar/> Up to 2/3 of the ear flap may be removed in a cropping operation, and the wound edges are closed with stitches. The ears are then bandaged and taped until they heal into the proper shape.<ref name=doggies/> The procedure is recommended to be undertaken under general anaesthesia; opponents' primary concerns revolve around post-operative pain.<ref>https://www.avma.org/KB/Resources/LiteratureReviews/Documents/dogs_ear_cropping_bgnd.pdf</ref>

American veterinary schools do not generally teach cropping and docking, and thus veterinarians who perform the practice have to learn on the job.<ref name=Broughton/> There are also problems with amateurs performing ear-cropping, particularly at [[puppy mill]]s.<ref name=Broughton/>

column3: dewclaw removal]], and [[neutering]] procedures remain common, ear-cropping is declining, save within the dog show industry.<ref name=CFHS/> However, many show ring competitors state they would discontinue the practice altogether if they could still ""win in the ring.""<ref name=USAtoday>Weise, Elizabeth [http://www.usatoday.com/news/nation/2009-07-30-dog-tails_N.htm 'Banfield pet hospitals ban tail docking, ear cropping on dogs'] ''USA Today'', 30 July 2011. Accessed September 2011.</ref>

column1: The practice is illegal across most of Europe, including all countries that have ratified the [[European Convention for the Protection of Pet Animals]], and most member countries of the [[Fédération Cynologique Internationale]].<ref name=stop>Fogle, Bruce. [http://www.stopthecrops.com/ K-I-S-S Guide to Living with a Dog] Stop the Crops. Accessed September 2011</ref> It is illegal in parts of Spain and in some Canadian provinces.<ref name=CFHS/> The situation in Italy is unclear; the ban effective 14 January 2007 may no longer be in force.<ref name=rep>[http://www.repubblica.it/2007/01/sezioni/cronaca/cani-ordinanza-turco/cani-ordinanza-turco/cani-ordinanza-turco.html Cani pericolosi, l'ordinanza della Turco ""Stop al taglio di orecchie e coda""] (in Italian) ''La Repubblica'', 15 January 2007. Accessed September 2011. ""Dangerous dogs, the ordinance of Turco: 'stop the cutting of ears and tails' ""</ref>
Ear-cropping is still widely practiced in the United States and parts of Canada, with approximately 130,000 puppies in the United States thought to have their ears cropped each year.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Cropping and Docking: A Discussion of the Controversy and the Role of Law in Preventing Unnecessary Cosmetic Surgery on Dogs
column7: American]] and [[Canadian Kennel Club]]s both permit the practice.<ref name=CFHS/> The [[American Kennel Club]] (AKC) position is that ear cropping and tail docking are ""acceptable practices integral to defining and preserving breed character and/or enhancing good health.""<ref>[http://www.akc.org/canine_legislation/position_statements.cfm#earcropping Ear Cropping, Tail Docking and Dewclaw Removal] American Kennel Club Canine Legislation Position Statements</ref> While some individual states have attempted to ban ear-cropping,<ref name=NY>{{cite web
column9: title= NEW CALL TO ACTION FOR AMENDED NY STATE CROP/DOCK BILL
column12: accessdate= 2007-12-31}}</ref> there is strong opposition from some dog breed organizations, who cite health concerns and tradition.<ref name=Boxer/>

column1: The American Veterinary Medical Association ""opposes ear cropping and tail docking of dogs when done solely for cosmetic purposes"" and ""encourages the elimination of ear cropping and tail docking from breed standards"".<ref name=avma>[http://www.avma.org/issues/policy/animal_welfare/tail_docking.asp Ear Cropping and Tail Docking of Dogs] {{webarchive
column3: date=January 25, 2010 }} American Veterinary Medical Association, November 2008. Accessed September 2011</ref>  Specifically, the AVMA ""has recommended to the American Kennel Club and appropriate breed associations that action be taken to delete mention of cropped or trimmed ears from breed standards for dogs and to prohibit the showing of dogs with cropped or trimmed ears if such animals were born after some reasonable date"".<ref name=slatter/> Some national chains of veterinary hospitals have voluntarily ceased to perform cosmetic surgeries  on dogs.<ref name=""USAtoday""/> The [[American Humane Association]] opposes ear-cropping ""unless it is medically necessary, as determined by a licensed veterinarian"".<ref name=AHA>[http://www.americanhumane.org/about-us/who-we-are/faqs/ear-cropping.html Ear cropping] The American Humane Association. Accessed September 2011.</ref>

column1: While it has been suggested the cropping may interfere with a dog's ability to communicate using ear signals, some also argue that cropping increases a dog's ability to communicate with ear signals. There has been no scientific comparative study of ear communication in cropped and uncropped dogs.<ref name=coren>Coren, Stanley (2001) [https://books.google.com/books?id=DeyzQI_a8EsC ''How to speak dog: mastering the art of dog-human communication''] New York: Simon & Schuster {{ISBN

column2: 1 January 2005<ref name=ypaat>[http://www.opengov.gr/ypaat/?c=2188 Δικτυακός Τόπος Διαβουλεύσεων (Website consultation)] (mostly in English) Υπουργείο Αγροτικής Ανάπτυξης και Τροφίμων (Ministry of Rural Development and Food, Athens, Greece), April 2011. Accessed September 2011.</ref>

Canada has no federal law banning pet cosmetic surgery. The [[Canadian Veterinary Medical Association]] opposes all cosmetic alterations.<ref>https://www.canadianveterinarians.net/documents/cosmetic-alteration</ref> Two provinces have provincial legislation prohibiting ear cropping, tail docking, and most cosmetic surgeries: Prince Edward Island (☨1) <ref>http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/prince-edward-island/animal-welfare-act-outlaws-animal-ear-cropping-and-tail-docking-1.3301418</ref> and Newfoundland and Labrador (☨2).

column1: Three provinces' veterinary associations ban all veterinarians from performing cosmetic surgeries on pets:

New Brunswick (☨3),<ref name=ypaat/> Nova Scotia (☨4),<ref name=CBC2>CBC News (March 25, 2010)[http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/nova-scotia/story/2010/03/25/ns-veterinarians-cosmetic-surgeries.html N.S veterinarians ban tail docking] Accessed February 10, 2012.</ref> and Quebec<ref>{{cite news
column2: title=Quebec's order of veterinarians bans pet cosmetic surgery

column1: Three provincial veterinary associations have bans on ear cropping alone: Manitoba (☨6),<ref name=CBC>CBC News (February 10, 2012)[http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/manitoba/story/2012/02/10/mb-dog-ear-cropping-illegal-manitoba.html Ear cropping of dogs banned in Manitoba] Accessed February 10, 2012.</ref> British Columbia,<ref>http://www.cvbc.ca/CVBC2/LatestNews/Veterinarians_Ban_Ear_Cropping.aspx</ref> and Saskatchewan (☨8).

column2: title=Cosmetic ear cropping banned by B.C. veterinarians

1899<ref name=johnston>Johnston, Beatrice L. (1970) [https://books.google.com/books?id=SRLuAAAAMAAJ ''For those who cannot speak: a history of the Canadian Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, 1869-1969''] City of Laval, P.Q.: Dev-Sco Publications p.13</ref>
1 July 1996 <ref name=""eslaki"">[http://www.finlex.fi/fi/laki/ajantasa/1996/19960247 Finnish Animal Protection Law (in Finnish)]</ref>

1 January 2010<ref name=""legif"">[http://www.legifrance.gouv.fr/affichCodeArticle.do?cidTexte=LEGITEXT000006071367&idArticle=LEGIARTI000006588965&dateTexte=&categorieLien=cid French Animal Protection Law (in French)]</ref>

Banned<ref name=""defra"">[https://web.archive.org/web/20070626075746/http://www.defra.gov.uk/animalh/welfare/domestic/awbillconsulttaildocking.pdf A review of the scientific aspects and veterinary opinions relating to tail docking in dogs]</ref>

Previously restricted, currently unrestricted <ref name=""sura"">[http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2013-04-14/chandigarh/38529054_1_tail-ears-kennel-club] Now, you can dock dogs' tail</ref>
Unrestricted - Morocco has no animal protection laws{{Citation needed

column9: df= }} Slovene Animal Protection Act (in Slovene language)</ref>

column2: Banned in autonomies of [[Catalonia]] and [[Andalucia]]<ref name=ypaat/>
Unrestricted (some states, including New York<ref name=""NY""/> and Vermont, have considered bills to make the practice illegal)

column1: Some animals, such as the [[American Lamancha goat
column2: Lamancha goat]], have ears which are naturally small as the result of selective breeding, and some people mistakenly believe their ears to be cropped.<ref name=Woods>{{Citation
column3: title=The American Lamancha, and its Ears.
column10: url=http://www.lamanchas.com/ears.htm}}</ref><ref>[http://www.goats4h.com/none.html ""What did we do to its ears?""Accessed September 19, 2011.]</ref>

column1: In other animals, small ears may result from a genetic mutation or the emergence of a [[dominance (genetics)
column2: genetically recessive trait]], such as in [[Highland cattle]], where the appearance of small ears, appearing to have their pinnae cropped, is viewed as a defect.<ref>[http://www.cruachan.com.au/bairnsley.htm Crop Ear. what does it look like?] Cruachan Highland Cattle. Accessed September 2011.</ref>

column1: *[[Overview of discretionary invasive procedures on animals]]
*[http://www.appd.ca Association for the Preservation of Purebred Dogs]
<!--these are links of what appear to be reliable sources, but with different viewpoints that could be used to expand this article if others wish to do so-->

column7: title=Tail docking and ear cropping — A reply}}

column1: '''Pet Check Technology''' is an online [[software]] and [[mobile application]] for [[dog walking]] companies and dog walking customers. Using [[QR codes]], mobile apps, [[e-mail]] alerts and [[GPS tracking]], [http://www.petchecktechnology.com Pet Check Technology] allows customers to see when and where their dogs went with their walkers.<ref>http://dsc.discovery.com/gear-gadgets/pet-check-ensures-you-fido-is-getting-walked.html</ref> Pet Check Technology launched in the [[Los Angeles]] area in August 2011 and has plans to expand to major cities in the upcoming months.<ref name=""FastCo"">http://www.fastcompany.com/1777570/in-the-us-the-qr-code-shouts-im-not-dead-yet</ref>

Pet Check Technology was created in 2011 by Doug Simon, founder of [[Chicago]]-based dog walking company, [http://www.walkthedogchicago.com Walk the Dog].<ref>http://www.walkthedogchicago.com/about-us</ref> Pet Check Technology was created by Walk the Dog to ensure that dogs were being walked for the time allotted on the dog walker's schedule.<ref name=""BSun"">http://www.baltimoresun.com/features/pets/unleashed/bal-is-your-dogwalker-cheating-you-20110824,0,2480982.story</ref>

Pet Check Technology provides dog walking companies with online tools for scheduling clients, billing, and tracking dog-walking employees.<ref name=""CNET"">http://news.cnet.com/8301-17938_105-20098849-1/qr-codes-and-gps-track-dog-walking-services/</ref> For customers, Pet Check allows them to see exactly when their dog was taken out for a walk, where they went, and what time they got back.
The dog walker scans a [[QR code]] with the Pet Check mobile app for [[iOS]] or [[Android (operating system)
column2: Android]] when arriving to pick up a dog.<ref name=""Gizmodo"">http://gizmodo.com/5835577/pet-check-stalk-your-dog-and-dog-walker-with-gps</ref> The app displays their schedule as well as any notes (such as number of stops and interaction with other dogs) for customer walk reports.<ref>http://www.petchecktechnology.com/about-us</ref> [[GPS]] tracks the walk and another QR code scan lets the customer know when the walk ends.<ref name=""BSun"" /> Pet Check sends an e-mail alert each time the customer's QR code is scanned. The customer can then watch the walk happen on an [[online map]]. Completed walk reports are stored for future reference. Dog walking companies using Pet Check Technology  have the ability to choose a customer payment method that works best for their business.<ref>http://www.petchecktechnology.com/how-it-works</ref>

column1: <!--- See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Footnotes on how to create references using <ref></ref> tags which will then appear here automatically -->
[[File:Running in the grass yard@Affectionate Pet Care.JPG
column3: alt=@ Dogs running in the yard at Dog Daycare.
column4: Dogs running in the yard at a dog daycare.]]

column1: '''Dog Daycare''', often known as ""Doggy Daycare,"" refers to a short-term daytime care for dogs. It shares many similarities with a regular [[daycare]] for children, with the exception being that a dog daycare is for [[domestic dog
column2: canine]]s.<ref name=""times06"">Baranauckas, Carla (24 September 2006). [https://www.nytimes.com/2006/09/24/business/yourmoney/24dogs.html?pagewanted=all A Dog’s Life, Upgraded], ''[[The New York Times]]''</ref> It fills a niche between multi-day kennel boarding and [[pet sitting]], where the sitter comes to the pet's home.<ref name=""time"">{{cite news
column4: title= The Doggie Day Care Owner - How Americans Spend Now - TIME

column1: The two share the same [[philosophy]]. Parents, or in the case of the dog daycare, owners, have a busy schedule and the often prolonged hours at work drastically reduce the time that could be spent with their children or pets.<ref name=""workaholics"">(29 August 1999). [https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=pptHAAAAIBAJ&sjid=YH8MAAAAIBAJ&pg=1042,252919&dq=dog-day-care&hl=en Dog day care center cares for pets of workaholics], ''Victoria Advocate'' (New York Times News Service copy)</ref>

The popularity of such establishments in the [[United States]] and elsewhere has grown greatly since the early 1990s, and arose out of the more traditional [[kennel]] industry.<ref name=""start1"">Strasburg, Jenny (4 November 2000). [https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1815&dat=20001104&id=w8UcAAAAIBAJ&sjid=nlkEAAAAIBAJ&pg=5328,698954 Longer work days lead to need for doggy day care], ''Today's New Herald'' (reprint of article originally published in ''[[The San Francisco Examiner]]'', distributed broadly)</ref><ref name=""1998art"">Lee, Jean H. (20 August 1999). [https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2457&dat=19990820&id=dKRJAAAAIBAJ&sjid=hg0NAAAAIBAJ&pg=2742,1757605 Dog owners lining up for day care services], ''Bangor Daily News'' (Associated Press story)</ref><ref name=""26sept99"">Knight, Rebecca M. (26 September 1999). [https://www.nytimes.com/1999/09/26/business/personal-business-day-care-for-the-dog-peace-for-the-owner.html?scp=1&sq=%22dog%20day%20care%22&st=cse Day Care for the Dog, Peace for the Owner], ''[[The New York Times]]''</ref><ref name=""1973art"">(9 September 1973). [https://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F00A12F9395D127A93CBA91789D95F478785F9&scp=4&sq=%22dog%20day%20care%22&st=cse A Day-Care Center For the Lonely Dog], ''[[The New York Times]]'' (noting the unique ""day care"" for dogs concept in a 1973 article)</ref><ref name=""newsday"">(3 November 1996). [https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/newsday/access/17071811.html?dids=17071811:17071811&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Nov+03%2C+1996&author=BY+ROBYN+SELMAN.+Robyn+Selman+is+the+author+of+%22Directions+to+My+House%2C%22+a+book+of+poetry.+She+has+a+cocker+spaniel%2C+Lizzie%2C+named+for+the+poet+Elizabeth+Bishop.&pub=Newsday+%28Combined+editions%29&desc=Dog-Lovers+of+the+World%2C+Unite!&pqatl=google Dog-Lovers of the World, Unite!], ''[[Newsday]]'' (""""Following the lead of the boom in pet care and pet products, dog day-care centers have opened all over the country, from Boston to Louisville to San Francisco, expanding the services offered by dog walkers to include play groups, sofas and chairs to snooze on, and classical music. The tab for this comes high, $75 to $100 for a five-day week, or $6,000 to $8,000 {a year} per dog at a Somerville, Mass., day-care center."")</ref> Prior to [[World War II]], dogs more commonly lived outside in the United States, but as urbanization spread dogs started to live indoors more frequently. Other factors, including an increase in the population of adults without children, have gradually led to more attention and money being spent on pets. The first modern dog day care in [[New York City]], [[Yuppie Puppy Pet Care, Inc.]] was reportedly opened in 1987,<ref name=""luxe"">Lewine, Edward. [https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/20/nyregion/a-dog-s-luxe-life.html?pagewanted=all&src=pm A Dog's Luxe Life], ''[[The New York Times]]'' (dating the first dog day care in New York to 1987, and noting huge change in how dogs are treated since the 1940s)</ref> by [[Joseph S. Sporn]].<ref>{{cite news
column4: title=W. Side Dog House Offers Canine Care
column8: date=6 August 2000}}</ref> [[San Francisco]], another wealthy American city, has also been credited for spurring the dog day care trend.<ref name=""start1""/>

column1: There are multiple environments and varieties of dog daycare service. For example, some facilities provide a cage-free environment where dogs play under the supervision of a trained staff member.<ref name=""Cagefree1"">(21 February 2011). [https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=pptHAAAAIBAJ&sjid=YH8MAAAAIBAJ&pg=1042,252919&dq=dog-day-care&hl=en Big benefits of small-dog day care], [[KHGI-TV
column2: Nebraska.tv]]</ref> Other facilities may provide a cage free environment for dogs to play for a portion of the day, placing dogs in cages at other times of the day. A daycare [[kennel]] is a type of facility that offers cages or runs where the dog will be placed alone during the day.

column1: Some facilities allow dogs to play in an outside environment. Others have indoor-only facilities, where dog interact and play in an indoor area and relieve themselves in designated inside areas.<ref name=""aspcaart"">[http://www.aspcabehavior.org/articles/55/Daycare-for-Dogs.asp Daycare for Dogs]{{dead link
column4: fix-attempted=yes }}, [[American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals]] (in depth discussion of dog day cares, including different environments and factors to consider in selecting a facility)</ref><ref name=""alt1"">[https://books.google.com/books?id=F-ECAAAAMBAJ&lpg=PP1&rview=1&pg=PA94#v=onepage&q=daycare&f=false Ultimate Pet Guide], ''[[Atlanta (magazine)]]'' (March 2004) (includes listing of different types of facilities in the [[Atlanta]] metro area)</ref><ref name=""book123"">Kerns, Nancy (ed.) [https://books.google.com/books?id=FNyYZDZQL0gC&pg=PA219&dq=%22dog+daycare%22&hl=en&ei=v967TpmXHMXd0QGBqITfCQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=7&ved=0CGUQ6AEwBg#v=onepage&q=%22dog%20daycare%22&f=false The Whole Dog Journal: Handbook of Dog and Puppy Care and Training], p. 219-21 (2008)</ref>

column3: A dog after being decorated in [[Kukur tihar]]]]

column1: '''[[Dog]]s''' (''Canis lupus familiaris''), which are mankind's first and most common [[Domestication
column2: domestic animal]]s, have played a role in many religious traditions.

column1: Below entries are arranged in alphabetical order.

column2: Dogs in Mesoamerican folklore and myth}}

column1: Dogs had a major religious and symbolic significance to the [[Aztec]] peoples of central [[Mexico]]. Several ancient burial sites for dogs have been discovered in Mexico.<ref>{{cite news
column3: title=Aztec dog burial site found in Mexico City
column6: date=Feb 14, 2014}}</ref> [[Xolotl]], an Aztec god of death, was depicted as a dog-headed monster.

column1: The dog is one of the 12 animals honored in [[Chinese astrology]]. The second day of the [[Chinese New Year]] is considered to be the birthday of all dogs and Chinese people often take care to be kind to dogs on that day.

column5: Statue of [[Saint Roch]] with his dog, in [[Prague]], Czech Republic.]]

column1: A dog is mentioned in the deuterocanonical [[Book of Tobit]], faithfully accompanying Tobias, Tobit's son and the angel [[Raphael (archangel)
[[Jesus]] told the story of the poor man [[Lazarus and Dives
column2: Lazarus]], whose sores were licked by street dogs. This has traditionally been seen as showing Lazarus's wretched situation.

column1: The [[Catholic Church]] recognizes [[Saint Roch]] (also called Saint Rocco), who lived in the early 14th century in France, as the [[patron saint]] of dogs. It is said that he caught the [[Black Death
column2: plague]] while doing charitable work and went into the forest, expecting to die. There he was befriended by a dog which licked his sores and brought him food, and he was able to recover. The [[feast day]] of Saint Roch, August 16, is celebrated in [[Bolivia]] as the ""birthday of all dogs.""<ref name=""culturalcatholic"">{{cite web

column1: [[Saint Guinefort]] was the name given to a dog who received local veneration as a [[saint]] at a French shrine from the 13th to the 20th centuries.<ref>Stephen de Bourbon (died 1262): ''De Supersticione''</ref>
A black and white dog is sometimes used as an informal symbol of the [[Dominican Order
column2: Dominican]] order of [[friar]]s, religious sisters and [[nuns]]. This stems from a Latin pun: though the order's name is actually the Friars Preachers (''Ordus Praedicatorum'' - order of preachers), it is generally called the Dominicans (after St. Dominic, their founder): ''Domini canes'' in Latin means ""the dogs/hounds of the Lord.""

column1: The [[Ancient Egypt]]ians are often more associated with cats in the form of [[Bastet]], yet here too, dogs are found to have a sacred role and figure as an important symbol in religious iconography.<ref name=""google"">{{cite book

Dogs were associated with [[Anubis]], the jackal headed god of the underworld. At times throughout its period of being in use the Anubieion catacombs at [[Saqqara]] saw the burial of dogs.<ref name=""google2"">{{cite book
column2: title=Encyclopedia of the Archaeology of Ancient Egypt

column1: Dogs were closely associated with [[Hecate]] in the Classical world. Dogs were sacred to [[Artemis]] and [[Ares]]. [[Cerberus]] was the three-faced guard dog of the Underworld.
The dogs are worshipped as a part of a five-day [[Tihar (festival)
column2: Tihar]] festival that falls roughly in November every year.

column1: The dog (''[[Shvan]]'') is also the [[vahana]] or mount of the Hindu god [[Bhairava]]. [[Yudhishthira]] had approached heaven with his dog,<ref>Textual Sources for the Study of Hinduism, p. 53, by Wendy Doniger, publisher = Manchester University Press</ref> therefore among many Hindus, the common belief exists that caring for or adopting dogs can also pave way to heaven.
The majority of both Sunni and Shi'a Muslim jurists consider dogs to be [[Ritual purification
column2: ritually unclean]].<ref name=""Fadl"">[http://www.scholarofthehouse.org/dinistrandna.html ''Encyclopedia of Religion and Nature''], s.v. ""Dogs in the Islamic Tradition and Nature."" New York: Continuum International, forthcoming 2004. By: Dr. Khaled Abou El Fadl</ref> It is uncommon for practising Muslims to have dogs as pets.<ref name=""Forw"">Susan J. Armstrong, Richard G. Botzler, ''The Animal Ethics Reader'', p.237, Routledge (UK) Press</ref> They are viewed as [[scavenger]]s.<ref name=""Sherman2008"">{{cite book
column4: title=Storytelling: An Encyclopedia of Mythology and Folklore

column1: In 2015 city councillor Hasan Küçük of [[The Hague]] called for dog ownership to be made illegal in that city.<ref name=""soerenkern"">{{cite web
column3: title=Muslims Declare Jihad on Dogs in Europe
column13: title=Hague: Muslim party wants dog ban; via ''Spitsnieuws'' (Dutch)
column15: date=January 31, 2012}}</ref> Islamic activists in [[Lérida]], Spain, lobbied for dogs to be kept out of Muslim neighborhoods, saying their presence violated Muslims' religious freedom.<ref name=""soerenkern""/><ref name=Dale/><ref>{{cite web
column17: title=Who is Poisoning Dogs in Spain?
column22: title=Are Spanish Muslims Waging an Anti-Dog Jihad by Poisoning Them?
column27: title=Muslims Are Poisoning Dogs in Spain

column1: October 8, 2011}}</ref> In Britain, police [[sniffer dog]]s are carefully used, and are not permitted to contact passengers, only their luggage. They are required to wear leather [[dog booties]] when searching mosques or Muslim homes.<ref name=""soerenkern""/><ref name=Dale/><ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Muslims will be searched by sniffer dogs despite religious objections, say police

column1: There are a number of traditions concerning [[Muhammad]]'s attitude towards dogs. He said that the company of dogs, except as helpers in hunting, herding, and home protection, voided a portion of a Muslim's good deeds.<ref>[[Malik ibn Anas]], [[Muwatta Imam Malik
column2: al-Muwatta]] (Egypt: al-Babi al-Halabi, n.d.), 2:969. Reported in El Fadl</ref>  On the other hand, he advocated kindness to dogs and other animals.  <ref>Abu Huraira Volume 3, Book 40, Number 551.</ref><ref name=""usc.edu"">http://www.usc.edu/dept/MSA/fundamentals/hadithsunnah/bukhari/040.sbt.html Compendium of Muslim Texts - Abu Huraira, Volume 3, Book 40, Number 551</ref> [[Abu Huraira]] narrated that the prophet said:

column1: ""While a man was walking he felt thirsty and went down a well, and drank water from it. On coming out of it, he saw a dog panting and eating mud because of excessive thirst. The man said, 'This (dog) is suffering from the same problem as that of mine.' So, he (went down the well), filled his shoe with water, caught hold of it with his teeth and climbed up and watered the dog. Allah thanked him for his (good) deed and forgave him.'' The people asked ``O Allah's Apostle! Is there a reward for us in serving (the) animals?'' He replied: ``Yes, there is a reward for serving any animate (living being).''
In [[Judaism]], [[Jewish law]] does not prohibit keeping dogs and other pets.<ref name=""jewishvirtuallibrary.org"">{{cite web
column4: work=Jewish Virtual Library}}</ref> Jewish law requires Jews to feed dogs (and other animals that they own) before themselves, and make arrangements for feeding them before obtaining them.<ref name=""jewishvirtuallibrary.org""/> The Book of Exodus (22:31) includes the exhortation ""And ye shall be holy men unto me: neither shall ye eat any flesh that is torn of beasts in the field; ye shall cast it to the dogs"" which implies that dogs have an accepted role in Hebrew society, and that God does not expect them to observe the dietary restrictions imposed on their human masters. The name of the Biblical character [[Caleb]] is written the same way as ''keleb'' ({{lang-he
column5: כָּ֫לֶב}}), meaning ""dog"" - written Hebrew having no [[vowel]]s. The Bible was written down centuries before [[Hebrew diacritics]] were introduced, and there is thus no certain knowledge of how the name was pronounced during the man's own lifetime - leaving open the possibility that at that time it was no dishonor for a major tribal leader to be named ""Dog"".

column1: There is a temple in Isin, Mesopotamia, named é-ur-gi7-ra which translates as “dog house”<ref>Livingstone, A (1988). ""The Isin “Dog House” Revisited"", Journal of Cuneiform Studies, '''40''' (1), p54</ref> Enlilbani, a king from the Old Babylonian First Dynasty of Isin, commemorated the temple to the goddess Ninisina.<ref>Shaffer, Aaron (1974). ""Enlilbaniand the ‘DogHouse’ in Isin"", Journal of Cuneiform Studies, 26(4) p. 251-252)</ref> Although there is a small amount of detail known about it, there is enough information to confirm that a dog cult did exist in this area.<ref>Livingstone ibid, 1988, p. 58</ref> Usually, dogs were only associated with the Gula cult, but there is some information, like Enlilbani’s commemoration, to suggest that dogs were also important to the cult of Ninisina, as Gula was another goddess who was closely associated to Ninisina.<ref>Shaffer, Aaron (1974) Ibid, p. 253</ref> More than 30 dog burials, numerous dog sculptures, and dog drawings were discovered when the area around this Ninisina temple was excavated. In the Gula cult, the dog was used in oaths and was sometimes referred to as a divinity.{{citation needed

column3: a very large dog cemetery]] was discovered in the layer dating from when the city was part of the [[Achaemenid Empire
column4: Persian Empire]]. It is believed the dogs may have had a sacred role - however, evidence for this is not conclusive.

column1: In [[Zoroastrianism]], the dog is regarded as an especially beneficent, clean and righteous creature, which must be fed and taken care of.<ref name=boyce>Boyce, Mary 1989. A History of Zoroastrianism: The Early Period. P.303</ref> The dog is praised for the useful work it performs in the household,<ref name=""avesta"">{{cite web
column7: accessdate=2015-05-12}}</ref> but it is also seen as having special spiritual virtues. A dog's gaze is considered to be purifying and to drive off [[daeva]]s (demons). It is also believed to have a special connection with the [[afterlife]]: the [[Chinvat Bridge
column8: Chinwad Bridge]] to Heaven is said to be guarded by dogs in Zoroastrian scripture,<ref name=""avesta""/> and dogs are traditionally fed in commemoration of the dead.<ref name=iranica/> ''Ihtiram-i sag'', ""respect for the dog"", is a common injunction among Iranian Zoroastrian villagers.<ref name=boyce/>

column1: Detailed prescriptions for the appropriate treatment of dogs are found in the [[Vendidad]] (a subdivision of the Zoroastrian holy scripture [[Avesta]]), especially in chapters 13, 14 and 15, where harsh punishments are imposed for harm inflicted upon a dog and the faithful are required to assist dogs, both domestic and stray, in various ways; often, help or harm to a dog is equated with help and harm to a human.<ref name=""avesta2"">{{cite web
column7: accessdate=2015-05-12}}</ref> The killing of a dog (""a shepherd's dog, or a house-dog, or a Vohunazga [i.e. stray] dog, or a trained dog"") is considered to lead to damnation in the afterlife.<ref name=""avesta2""/> A homeowner is required to take care of a pregnant dog that lies near his home at least until the puppies are born (and in some cases until the puppies are old enough to take care of themselves, namely six months). If the homeowner does not help the dog and the puppies come to harm as a result, ""he shall pay for it the penalty for wilful murder"", because ""[[Atar]] (Fire), the son of [[Ahura Mazda]], watches as well (over a pregnant dog) as he does over a woman"".<ref>[http://www.avesta.org/vendidad/vd15sbe.htm Vendidad, Fargard 15], passim, e.g. 21.</ref> It is also a major sin if a man harms a dog by giving it bones that are too hard and become stuck in its throat, or food that is too hot, so that it burns its throat.<ref>[http://www.avesta.org/vendidad/vd15sbe.htm Vendidad, Fargard 15], 2-4.</ref> Giving bad food to a dog is as bad as serving bad food to a human.<ref>http://www.avesta.org/vendidad/vd15sbe.htm Vendidad, Fargard 13, 20-28</ref> The believers are required to take care of a dog with a damaged sense of smell, to try to heal it ""in the same manner as they would do for one of the faithful"" and, if they fail, to tie it lest it should fall into a hole or a body of water and be harmed.<ref name=""avesta""/>

column1: Both according to the Vendidad and in traditional Zoroastrian practice, dogs are allotted some funerary ceremonies analogous to those of humans.<ref name=iranica>Encyclopaedia Iranica:Dog. In Zoroastrianism. By Mary Boyce.</ref> In the Vendidad, it is stated that the spirits of a thousand deceased dogs are reincarnated in a single [[otter]] (""water dog""), hence the killing of an otter is a terrible crime that brings drought and famine upon the land and must be atoned either by the death of the killer<ref name=""avesta""/> or by the killer performing a very long list of deeds considered pious, including the healing of dogs, raising of puppies, paying of fines to priests, as well as killing of animals considered noxious and unholy (cats, rats, mice and various species of reptiles, amphibians, and insects).<ref name=""avesta3"">{{cite web
''[[Sagdid]]'' is a funeral [[ceremony]] in which a dog is brought into the room where the body is lying so that it can look on it. “Sagdid” means “dog sight” in the [[Middle Persian
column2: Middle Persian language]] of Zoroastrian theological works. There are various spiritual benefits thought to be obtained by the ceremony. It is believed that the original purpose was to make certain that the person was really dead, since the dog’s more acute senses would be able to detect signs of life that a human might miss. A “four-eyed” dog, that is one with two spots on its forehead, is preferred for sagdid.<ref>Jivanji Jamshedji Modi, 1928, [http://www.avesta.org/ritual/funeral.htm The Funeral Ceremonies of the Parsees], Anthropological Society of Bombay</ref><ref>The Zoroastrian Faith: Tradition and Modern Research, by Solomon Alexander Nigosian, Published by McGill-Queen's Press - MQUP, 1993, {{ISBN
column3: 0-7735-1144-X}}, 9780773511446 page 102 (page can be viewed via Google books)</ref>

column1: The traditional rites involving dogs have been under attack by reformist Zoroastrians since the mid-19th century, and they had abandoned them completely by the late 20th century. Even traditionalist Zoroastrians tend to restrict such rites to a significant extent nowadays (late 20th - early 21st century).<ref name=iranica/>
The Ancient Greek philosopher and critic of social mores [[Diogenes of Sinope#Diogenes the dog
column2: Diogenes of Sinope]] was recorded as living with many dogs, seeing their freedom from self-consciousness and sincere enjoyment of simple physical pleasure to be admirable role models.

column1: In an article in the ''[[New York Times Magazine]]'' [[atheist]] [[Natalie Angier]] quoted [[Frans de Waal]], a [[Primatology

:""I've argued that many of what philosophers call moral sentiments can be seen in other species. In [[chimpanzee]]s and other animals, you see examples of sympathy, empathy, reciprocity, a willingness to follow social rules. Dogs are a good example of a species that have and obey social rules; that's why we like them so much, even though they're large [[carnivores]].""<ref name=""nytimes"">{{cite web

column4: Newfoundland]], the breed Byron eulogized, painted by [[Edwin Henry Landseer]], 1802–1873]]

column1: In 1808 the English poet [[Lord Byron]] expressed similar thoughts in his famous poem ''[[Epitaph to a Dog]]'':
:But the poor dog, in life the firmest friend,
:The first to welcome, foremost to defend,
:Whose honest heart is still his master's own,
:Who labors, fights, lives, breathes for him alone,
:Denied in heaven the soul he held on earth –
:While man, vain insect! hopes to be forgiven,
:And claims himself a sole exclusive heaven.<ref name=""poetryloverspage"">{{cite web
column3: title=Poetry Lovers' Page: George Gordon Byron

column2: The dingo in Aboriginal folklore and mythology]]

column1: 34442389,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Ten_Commandments_of_Dog_Ownership,"'''''The Ten Commandments of Dog Ownership''''', also known as '''The Ten Commandments From a Pet's Point of View''', or simply '''Ten Commandments For Dog Owners''' is a set of pet ownership rules. It was created in 1993 by [[Stan Rawlinson]], and is written from the point of view of a dog.<ref name=""thedoglistener"">{{cite web
column3: title=The 10 Commandments From a Pet's Point of View

column1: This set of rules was used as the basis of the 2008 Japanese film ''[[10 Promises to My Dog]]''.<ref name=""nipponcinemareview"">{{cite web
column3: title=Review: 10 Promises to My Dog (Inu to Watashi no 10 no Yakusoku)

column1: The commandments convey the dog's perspective to elicit empathy from humans in their role as owner. They are written from the dog's viewpoint and they allude to principles assumed important to dogs. Commandments convey ideas of trust, tolerance, anger, hurt, pain, and forgiveness amongst others.
The Ten Commandments of Dog Ownership was translated in Japanese and compiled into a [[tankōbon]] by author [[Rie Hasegawa]].<ref name=""amazonjapan"">{{cite web
column3: title=犬の十戒 on Amazon Japan
column7: language=Japanese}}</ref> This book was published by [[Nihon Bungeisha]], and was released in Japan on September 2004.<ref name=""amazonjapan"" />

column1: Additionally, The Ten Commandments of Dog Ownership was used as an inspiration for a novel written by [[Hare Kawaguchi]].<ref name=""nipponcinemareview"" /> Published on 28 July 2007, this book is entitled  {{Nihongo
column4: Inu to Watashi no jyuu no Yakusoku}}.<ref name=""amazonjapan2"">{{cite web
column6: title=犬と私の10の約束 on Amazon Japan
column10: language=Japanese}}</ref> ''10 Promises To My Dog'' was later adapted into a 2008 Japanese film of [[10 Promises to My Dog
column11: the same name]].<ref name=""nipponcinemareview"" /> The film was directed by [[Katsuhide Motoki]], and stars [[Rena Tanaka]], [[Mayuko Fukuda]], [[Etsushi Toyokawa]].<ref name=""nipponcinemareview"" />

column1: '''Roan''' is a coat color found in many animals, including [[horse]]s, [[cattle]] and [[dog]]s.  It is defined generally as an even mixture of white and pigmented hairs that do not [[Gray (horse)
column2: gray out""]] or fade as the animal ages.<ref name=OEDroan>""''roan'', ''a''. and ''n.1''"" [[Oxford English Dictionary]]. 2nd edition 1989. OED Online. [[Oxford University Press]]. 3 June 2008. <http://0-dictionary.oed.com.helin.uri.edu/cgi/entry/50207603>.</ref> There are a variety of genetic conditions which produce the colors described as ""roan"" in various species.

column5: blue roan]]s with white hairs intermingled with a black base coat.]]

column1: A horse with intermixed white and colored hairs of any color is usually called a roan.<ref name=UCDint>{{cite web
column6: publisher=The Regents of the University of California
column7: date=}}</ref> However, such mixtures, which can appear superficially similar, are caused by a number of separate [[Introduction to genetics
column8: genetic]] factors. Identifiable types of roans include true or classic [[roan (horse)
column9: roan]], [[varnish roan]], and [[rabicano]], though other currently unknown factors may be responsible for ambiguous ""roaning.""<ref name=ucdroanzyg>{{cite web
column15: Gray]] horses, which become lighter as they age until their hair coat is nearly completely white, may be confused with roans when they are young.<ref name=UCDint/> [[dun gene
column16: Duns]], which are solid-colored horses affected by the dun [[dilution gene
column17: dilution factor]] on their bodies but with darker points, are also sometimes confused with roans, but they do not have the intermixed white and colored hairs of a roan.

column1: Horses with the classic or true roan pattern may be any base color which is intermingled with unpigmented white hairs on the body. Except for [[Horse markings
column2: white markings]] under the control of other genes, the head, mane, tail, and lower legs are dark.<ref name=UCDint/> Roan is a simple [[Dominance relationship
column3: dominant]] trait symbolized by the ''Rn'' [[allele]].<ref name=ucdroanzyg /> The [[University of California, Davis]] [[University of California, Davis School of Veterinary Medicine
column4: School of Veterinary Medicine]]'s genetics services have developed a [[DNA test]] that uses [[genetic marker]]s to indirectly determine the number of ''Rn'' or ''rn'' alleles a horse has.<ref name=ucdroanzyg /> The [[mutation]] responsible for true roan has not yet been identified exactly, but been assigned to equine [[chromosome]] 21 (ECA21) in the KIT sequence.<ref name=marklund>{{cite journal
column11: title =Close association between sequence polymorphism in the KIT gene and the roan coat color in horses
column17: issue =3 }}</ref> The overall effect is that of a silver or lightened appearance to the affected part of the coat.

column1: * '''Red Roan''' or strawberry roan describes true or classic roan on a [[Chestnut (coat)
column2: chestnut]] base coat. The mane and tail remain red or have only a few white hairs, while the body ranges from nearly chestnut to pinkish. Geneticists prefer the term ""chestnut roan,"" but this term is not in common use.

column1: * '''Bay Roan''' is true roan on a [[Bay (horse)
column2: bay]] coat. The particular shade depends on the underlying shade of bay; but the mane, tail, and lower legs are black, and the reddish body is intermingled with white hairs. The head is usually red. Formerly, bay roans were lumped together with chestnut roans and both called ""red roans.""

column1: * '''Blue Roan''' is true roan on a [[Black (horse)
column2: black]] coat. The mane, tail, head, and legs remain black, while the body takes on a grayish or bluish appearance. Blue roans are sometimes mistaken for [[Gray (horse)
column3: grays]] or [[grullo]]s. However, Grays fade with age, while roans do not; and grullos are blue [[dun gene
column4: duns]] and possess dun markings but not intermingled white hairs.

column1: Any other coat color may also be affected by roaning. Few combinations have the same unique terminology applied to the common roan colors, although palomino roans are sometimes called ''honey roans''.

column5: A varnish roan [[Appaloosa]], showing white sclera, mottled skin, and darker bony regions such as the cheekbones.]]

column1: A [[varnish roan]] is not a true roan; it is actually one of the [[leopard complex]] coat patterns associated with [[Appaloosa]], [[Knabstrupper]], [[Noriker horse]] and related breeds. [[Rabicano]] is a white pattern that falls into the category of ''roaning'' or scattered white hairs, the genetics of which are not yet fully understood.<ref name=UCDint/> Sometimes called ''ticking'', rabicano is common even in breeds that do not have true or classic roan, including [[Arabian (horse)
column2: Arabians]] and [[Thoroughbred]]s. This pattern usually takes the form of scattered white hairs around the junction of the stifle and flank, and peculiar rings of white hairs near the base of the tail. This trait is called a ''coon tail'' or ''skunk tail''.<ref name=overton>{{cite news
column14: pinto]] pattern, have roaning along the edges of other white spots or [[horse markings
column15: markings]]  A roan horse may not fit into any of the traditional categories as there is much still to be learned about the genetics of roan.  The existence of other types of roaning conditions not covered by those mentioned here is possible and likely.<ref name=""UCDint""/>

column1: The genetics behind roan dogs are still unclear, and at present candidate genes have been ruled out.<ref name=dogcolor>{{cite journal
column7: title =Genes affecting coat colour and pattern in domestic dogs: a review
column15: pmid =18052939 }}</ref> There remains a great deal of ambiguity in terminology regarding mottled dogs, which are called ''roan'', ''ticked'', ''mottled'' and ''belton'' depending on the context. The roan or ticked color is described in many breeds of [[gundog]]s such as [[English Cocker Spaniel]]s, [[American Cocker Spaniel]]s, [[English Springer Spaniel]]s, [[Field Spaniel]]s and [[Brittany (dog)
column16: Brittanys]], [[German Longhaired Pointer]]s, [[German Shorthaired Pointer]]s, [[Spinone Italiano
column17: Spinoni Italiani]], [[Lagotto Romagnolo]]s and [[English Setter]]s, as well as [[Border Collie]]s and many other breeds.

column1: In dogs, roan manifests itself only in unpigmented areas, the presence and shape of which are determined by other genes.<ref name=schmutzdog>{{cite web
column8: work=Dog Coat Color Genetics }}</ref> This is in stark contrast to true roan horses and roan cattle, which are roan only in pigmented regions of their coat and may have white markings. Instead, dogs with roaning or ticking are born with clear, open white markings which begin to fill in with flecking in the subsequent weeks and continue to darken with age.<ref name=ukcocker>{{cite web
column13: work=Cocker Spaniel Colours & Markings }}</ref> Most breed standards use the terms ""ticked"" and ""roan"" interchangeably, with the former referring to clearly defined flecks on a white background and the latter to flecks so closely spaced that the mixture appears even.<ref name=byrne/>  The terminology that relates the underlying coat color with the roan modifier is often breed-specific, but most standards call a black dog with roaning ''blue''. In breeds that are characterized by roaning and ticking such as the Large Munsterlander, clear white-marked individuals may be called ''plated''.<ref name=schmutzdog/> The term ''belton'' is reserved for [[English Setter]]s.

column1: In 1957, Little suggested that roan and ticking were controlled separately, and postulated that roan may have been homologous to ""silvered"" coat in mice.<ref name=byrne>{{cite book
column7: title=Der Deutsch Kurzhaar, The German Shorthaired Pointer
column25: chapter=Gene Loci for Coat Colour and Pattern
column26: quote= }}</ref> This condition in mice is actually homologous to [[merle (coat colour in dogs)
column27: merle]], which might be described by some as ""roan.""<ref name=merledog>{{cite conference
column34: title=Retrotransposon insertion in SILV is responsible for merle patterning of the domestic dog.
column35: booktitle=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America 103
column41: id= }}</ref> In 2007, the gene responsible for roan cattle (KITLG) was refuted as a possible cause of roan in dogs.<!--Dalmatian deafness is not linked to roan, but to their wholly white coats.--> Neither roan nor ticking, if they are independently caused, appear to be recessive.<ref name=""dogcolor""/>

column1: Breeds of [[cattle]] known for roans are the [[Belgian Blue]] and [[Shorthorn]]. Among the former, coat color may be solid black, solid white, or blue roan; the latter may be solid red, solid white, or red roan. Belgian Blues also typically exhibit spotting patterns,<ref name=Ibsen>{{cite journal
column13: quote =in Seitz et al. (1999)}}</ref> which are genetically separate from roan. As a result, most roan cows exhibit blotches of clearly colored and clearly white hair, with roan patches.<ref name=cowpattern>{{cite web
column20: work=Genetics of Coat Color Patterns in Cattle.
column27: quote= }}</ref> Some ""cryptic"" roan cattle appear solid, but upon close inspection reveal a small roan patch.<ref name=MGFmissense>{{cite journal
column38: title =A missense mutation in the bovine MGF gene is associated with the roan phenotype in Belgian Blue and Shorthorn cattle.
column47: pmid =10384045 }}</ref> Roan cattle cannot ""breed true"" but breeding white cattle to a solid mate will always yield a roan calf. The white color typical of [[Charolais cattle
column49: White Park]] breeds is not related to roan.<ref>Seitz, Schmutz, Thue & Buchanan: ""Although both Charolais and White Park could be classified as white phenotypically, all typed r/r homozygous colored) at the MGF locus. Alternative loci must be responsible for these forms of white, as has been suggested previously (Olson and William 1982).""</ref>

column1: Roan in Shorthorns and Belgian Blues is controlled by the ''mast cell growth factor'' (MGF) [[gene]], also called the ''steel locus'', on bovine [[chromosome]] 5.<ref name=charlier>{{cite journal
column10: title =Microsatellite mapping of the bovine roan locus: a major determinant of White Heifer disease.
column18: issue =2 }}</ref> Part of the [[Stem cell factor
column19: KIT ligand]], this region is involved in many [[Cellular differentiation
column20: cell differentiation processes]]. Mast cell growth factor promotes [[Melanin
column33: title =Altered Metabolism of Mast-Cell Growth Factor (c-kit Ligand) in Cutaneous Mastocytosis.
column43: pmid =7682288 }}</ref> and without it, skin and hair cells lack pigment. With two functional MGF genes ([[homozygous]] dominant), cattle are fully pigmented; without any functional MGF genes (homozygous [[recessive]]), they are white. MGF-controlled roan occurs when cattle possess one functional and one non-functional MGF gene ([[heterozygous]]), resulting in a roughly even mixture of white regions and colored regions.<ref name=""MGFmissense""/>

column1: The reproductive condition ""White Heifer Disease,"" associated with the MGF gene, is characterized by [[homozygous]] MGF-white heifers with incomplete reproductive tracts.<ref name=cowconditions>{{cite web
column8: work=Genetics of Coat Color Patterns in Cattle.

column2: roan coloration]] of [[guinea pig]]s is linked to [[microphthalmia]]. The allele that controls roaning in guinea pigs is incompletely dominant: an animal with one copy of the allele will have varying amounts of white hair scattered through its coat, particularly on the back and sides. This is not to be confused with the 'Magpie' variety, which is a brindled guinea pig lacking red pigment due to the ""chinchilla"" allele also responsible for self white and silver agouti coloration.

column1: About 25% of guinea pigs born to a mating of two roans are completely white, with a constellation of deformities called lethal white syndrome, although it has no relation to overo lethal white syndrome in horses or double merle syndrome in dogs. These symptoms include:
* Malabsorption in the small intestine, due in some cases to lack of [[intestinal villi]]
It is worth noting that, unlike [[anophthalmia
column2: anophthalmic]] hamsters, lethal white guinea pigs are not sterile. Females may be unable to deliver live young.

column1: Lethal white guinea pigs have a decreased lifespan in general, although individuals have reportedly lived to 6 or 7 years. Many die shortly after birth or at weaning age. With hand-feeding and regular dental care, lethals can live 2–3 years.
<!--A separate section on roan mice may be warranted, but the original intent of that section was to clarify that some ""roaning"" in horses is presently unexplained.-->

column5: The [[Royal Rock Beagles]] started in 1845 and were for some time the oldest pack in the UK.<ref>{{cite web

column3: hare hunting]]) packs of the United Kingdom, registered with either the Association of Masters of Harriers and Beagles, or the Masters of Basset Hounds Association. Prior to the 2004 Hunting Act, these packs either hunted [[European Hare
column4: hare]], or in the case of some harrier packs, [[Red Fox
column5: foxes]]. Hunts are now obliged to either practice [[drag hunting
column6: trail hunting]], hunt rabbits (as has been the case with many beagle packs<ref name=""Association of Masters of Harriers and Beagles"">{{cite web
column8: title=Association of Masters of Harriers and Beagles-An Introduction to Beagling}}</ref>) or follow other exemptions set out in the Act.

This is a list of articles containing the stub designator {{tl
If this is an article about a specific dog breed, see some suggestions in the following ""Dog Breed articles"" section.
If this is any other article about, or related to, dogs, feel free to check [[:Category:Dogs]] and its subcategories to see what other articles currently exist and how they are presented.

'''Do not copy existing material from other sources.''' It is most likely copyrighted and will be deleted. (If you are the author of the original and grant GFDL, please note that on the article's discussion page.) Instead, look for the important details, preferably from more than one source, and rewrite in your own words.
Use these as suggestions to get started:
* Introduction: general information about the breed, brief history, brief description.
**Other distinguishing marks or colors, such as required colors or pattern(s) (the speckle's in [[Australian Cattle Dog]]s, spots in [[Dalmatian (dog)
column2: Dalmatians]] or unusual eye colors or tongue colors (such as the [[Chow Chow]])

column1: **Height and weight ranges (remember that this is an international encyclopedia, so it may vary from country to country; provide general numbers)

* Temperament and/or Characteristics sections, including such items as:
**Very key people involved in the breed (this won't apply for most breeds)
**Other breeds that went into this breed
**How this breed differs from others in similar categories (e.g., ""Unlike other giant breeds, the xxx does not generally suffer from hip dysplasia"")
* Care specific to this breed, such as for the [[Puli]]'s coat
* Training above and beyond, or different from, that required for most breeds
* Activities, including what the breed in general is currently used for or is particularly suited for
**A ''References'' section lists specific reliable sources (print or online) for information in the article
**A ''See also'' section provides links to other relevant Wikipedia articles
**An ''External links'' section provides links to noncommercial non-Wikipedia web sites with relevant information.
These are noted real (as opposed to fictional) dogs.

column2: pǎn hǔ}}/) is an important figure in [[Chinese mythology]]. ""Chinese mythology"" refers to those myths found in the historical geographic area of [[China]], the geographic area of ""China"" being a concept which has evolved historically. The Panhu mythological complex includes myths in [[Chinese language
column3: Chinese]] and also other languages. This myth has a long history of being transmitted by [[Han Chinese]] and several of the other ethnic groups of the fifty-six officially recognized by the current administration of China, both orally and in literature.<ref>[http://202.40.204.216/etext/chi/chi305/2002_3/pdf/chi305_0304.pdf 盤瓠與民族原推圖騰神話]</ref><ref>[http://202.40.204.216/etext/chi/chi305/2002_3/pdf/chi305_0302.pdf 盤瓠 ― 民族推源圖騰]</ref> (Yang 2005:4) The Panhu myth is an important origin myth for various ethnic groups.

column1: The basic Panhu myth is about a dragon-dog who transforms into a man and married a princess. The emperor of China in the course of losing a war which he was waging with a neighbor to the west, offered to marry his daughter to anybody that would present him with the head of his enemy. This was accomplished by the dragon-dog. Accounts vary, but eventually the dog and princess procreated copiously.

There are also various variant versions.<ref>[http://iel.cass.cn/news_show.asp?newsid=2045 盘瓠神话：楚与卢戎的一场战争·中国民族文学网]</ref><ref>[http://www.hmongbq.com/ReadNews.asp?NewsID=230 苗族民间祭祀制度 吴正彪]</ref><ref>[http://www.library.ln.edu.hk/etext/chi/chi305/2002_3/pdf/chi305_0304.pdf 葉曉文 盤瓠與民族原推圖騰神話]</ref><ref>[http://commons.ln.edu.hk/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1000&context=chin_proj_1 盤瓠神話]</ref> In some the dog became transformed into a human, except for his head. (Christie 1968: 121-122)

In the study of historical Chinese culture, many of the stories that have been told regarding characters and events which have been written or told of the distant past have a double tradition: one which tradition which presents a more historicized and one which presents a more mythological version. (Yang 2005:12-13) This is also true in many of the accounts related to the Panhu.

Many of the myths regarding agriculture in China are related to popular religion and ritual. In modern times, Panhu has been worshipped by the [[Yao people]] and [[She people]] as ""King Pan"". (Yang 2005: 52-53).
*Yang, Lihui, ''et al.'' (2005). ''Handbook of Chinese Mythology''. New York: Oxford University Press. {{ISBN

column3: 犬枕}} is an early-[[Edo period]] [[Japanese literature
column4: Japanese]] literary [[parody]] of ''[[The Pillow Book]]'' of [[Sei Shōnagon]]. The title has also been translated as '''''The Mongrel Pillow'''''.<ref name=""Keene""/>

column2: Heian]] court at the end of the tenth-century in {{nihongo
column5: ''Makura no sōshi''}} include passages that resemble a [[poetic diary]], others in an [[Zuihitsu
column6: essay-like style]], as well as a number of poetic catalogues or {{nihongo
column8: ものはつくし}}.<ref name=""Inu""/><ref>{{cite journal
column17: doi=10.2307/2718916}}</ref> For instance, under the heading Elegant Things: 'a white coat worn over a violet [[Japanese clothing
column18: waistcoat]], duck eggs, shaved ice mixed with [[liana]] syrup placed in a new silver bowl, rock-crystal [[Buddhist prayer beads
column20: plum blossoms]] covered with snow, a beautiful child eating strawberries'.<ref name=""Shirane"">{{cite book
column21: title=Early Modern Japanese Literature: An Anthology (1600-1900)

column1: ''Inu makura'' similarly comprises a number of such listings under a series of headings, although without the [[narrative]] accompaniment. Combined with the work's brevity, the effect is sustained through 'the possibilities of terseness, juxtaposition, and surprise', by repeating the same situation under a different heading, or by the subtle alteration of a situation.<ref name=""Inu"">{{cite journal
column9: doi=10.2307/2718596}}</ref> There are in total ninety sections, seventeen of them in the form of kyōka or 'comic [[Waka (poetry)
column11: title=World Within Walls: Japanese Literature of the Pre-Modern Era, 1600-1867
column18: colophon]] or title page, and dated variously between 1596 and 1607, is attributed to Hata Sōha (1550-1607), annotator of [[Tsurezuregusa
column19: Essays in Idleness]], physician to [[Toyotomi Hidetsugu]], [[Taikomochi#History
column20: storyteller (otogishu)]] to [[Toyotomi Hideyoshi]], and later in the employ of [[Tokugawa Ieyasu]].<ref name=""Keene""/><ref name=Inu/><ref>{{cite journal
column21: title=Constructing the Classic: Tsurezuregusa in Tokugawa Readings
column23: journal=[[Journal of the American Oriental Society]]
column29: doi=10.2307/605621}}</ref> An early exemplar of [[kanazōshi]] or 'booklets in the vernacular', it was printed with [[Movable type#Wooden movable type

column1: Illustrative of the work are such sections as Things One Wishes to See: 'the moon, well-performed [[Noh]], the furnishings of a [[Chashitsu
column2: tea house]], the real thoughts of one's lover'; Interesting Things: '[[Tsurezuregusa]], arranging coals for the [[tea ceremony]], a [[Hanami
column3: flower-viewing]] walk with a boy favourite'; and Things that Stand One's Hair on End: 'putting on [[Japanese armour
column4: armour]] in winter without underclothes'.<ref>{{cite journal

column1: Such [[parodies]] were amongst the earliest [[genres]] of [[kanazōshi]], updating and transforming [[Heian period
column2: Heian]] and later court works into 'comic versions of contemporary popular culture'.<ref name=""Shirane""/> In the 1530s, {{nihongo
column4: 犬筑波集}}, attributed to [[Yamazaki Sōkan]] and a response to the first collections of [[Renga
column5: linked verse]], had been infused with the [[haikai]] spirit, 'outlandish [[metaphor]]', and 'irreverent or ribald humour'.<ref>{{cite book
column11: pages=332, 338}}</ref> Following on from ''Inu makura'', other parodies emerged: the {{nihongo
column18: 犬百人一首}} of 1669.<ref name=""Shirane""/><ref>{{cite journal
column28: title=Visual genesis of Japanese national identity: Hokusai's Hyakunin isshu
