column1: The '''domestic dog''' (''Canis lupus familiaris'' or ''Canis familiaris'')<ref name=wang2008/> is a member of genus ''[[Canis]]'' (canines) that forms part of the [[Evolution of the wolf#Wolf-like canids
column2: wolf-like canids]],<ref name=lindblad2005/> and is the most widely abundant [[carnivore]].<ref name=fan2016/><ref name=thalmann2013/><ref name=vila1999/> The dog and the extant [[gray wolf]] are sister [[taxa]],<ref name=vila1997/><ref name=freedman2014/><ref name=larson2014/> with modern wolves not closely related to the wolves that were first domesticated,<ref name=freedman2014/><ref name=larson2014/> which implies that the direct ancestor of the dog is extinct.<ref name=vonholdt2016/> The dog was the first [[domestication
column3: domesticated]] species<ref name=larson2014/><ref name=perri2016/> and has been [[selective breeding
column4: selectively bred]] over millennia for various behaviors, sensory capabilities, and physical attributes.<ref name=""ADW""/>

column2: long association with humans]] has led dogs to be uniquely attuned to human behavior<ref name=berns2012/> and they are able to thrive on a [[starch]]-rich diet that would be inadequate for other canid species.<ref name=axelssonetal2013>{{Cite journal
column23: title = The genomic signature of dog domestication reveals adaptation to a starch-rich diet
column32: bibcode = 2013Natur.495..360A }}</ref> Dogs vary widely in shape, size and colours.<ref>[http://www.scientificamerican.com/article/different-dog-breeds-same-species/ Why are different breeds of dogs all considered the same species? - Scientific American] {{webarchive
column34: date=10 October 2016 }}.  Nikhil Swaminathan. Accessed on 28 August 2016.</ref> Dogs perform many roles for people, such as [[hunting dog
column42: aiding handicapped individuals]]. This influence on human society has given them the [[sobriquet]] ""[[Man's best friend (phrase)

column1: The term ""domestic dog"" is generally used for both [[domesticated]] and [[feral]] varieties. The English word ''dog'' comes from [[Middle English]] ''dogge'', from [[Old English]] ''[[wikt:docga
column4: title=Domestic PetDog Classified By Linnaeus In 1758 As Canis Familiaris And Canis Familiarus Domesticus
column10: df=dmy }}</ref> The term may possibly derive from Proto-Germanic ''*dukkōn'', represented in Old English ''finger-docce'' (""finger-muscle"").<ref>{{Cite book
column13: title = Kluge. Etymologisches Wörterbuch der deutschen Sprache
column18: isbn = 3-11-017473-1}}</ref> The word also shows the familiar petname [[diminutive]] ''-ga'' also seen in ''frogga'' ""frog"", ''picga'' ""pig"", ''stagga'' ""stag"", ''wicga'' ""beetle, worm"", among others.<ref>""Dictionary of Etymology"", ''Dictionary.com'', s.v. ''dog'', [https://web.archive.org/web/20081004042554/http://www.encyclopedia.com/topic/dog.aspx encyclopedia.com] retrieved on 27 May 2009.</ref> Piotr Gąsiorowski has suggested that Old English ''*docga'' is actually derived from  Old English colour adjective ''dox''.<ref>{{cite journal

column2: hund}}) was the general word for all domestic canines, and ''dog'' referred to a subtype of hound, a group including the mastiff. It is believed this ""dog"" type was so common, it eventually became the prototype of the category ""hound"".<ref name=""dog"">{{Cite journal
column5: title = Diachronic Investigations of False Friends
column11: url = http://hrcak.srce.hr/index.php?show=clanak&id_clanak_jezik=48370&lang=en}}</ref> By the 16th century, ''dog'' had become the general word, and ''hound'' had begun to refer only to types used for hunting.<ref>{{Cite book
column14: title=Cognitive exploration of language and linguistics
column19: url=https://books.google.com/?id=uZcs6poXkfEC&pg=PA215}}</ref> The word ""hound"" is ultimately derived from the Proto-Indo-European word ''*kwon-'', ""dog"".<ref>{{cite web
column23: title = The American Heritage Dictionary of the English Language: Fourth Edition
column25: publisher=www.bartleby.com}}</ref> This semantic shift may be compared with in German, where the corresponding words ''Dogge'' and ''Hund'' kept their original meanings. The term ''[[wikt:Reconstruction:Proto-Indo-European/ḱwṓ
column26: *ḱwon-]]'' may ultimately derive from the earliest layer of [[Proto-Indo-European language
column29: title=In search of the Indo-Europeans: language, archaeology and myth

column1: A male canine is referred to as a ""dog"", while a female is called a ""bitch"" (derived from Middle English ''bicche'', from Old English ''bicce'', ultimately from Old Norse ''bikkja''). The father of a [[litter (animal)
column2: litter]] is called the ''sire'', and the mother is called the ''dam''. The process of birth is ""whelping"", from the Old English word ''hwelp''; the modern English word ""whelp"" is an alternative term for puppy.<ref>{{Cite book
column4: title=All about dog breeding for quality and soundness
column9: date=September 2010}}</ref> A litter refers to the multiple offspring at one birth which are called [[Puppy
column10: puppies]] or pups from the French ''poupée'', ""doll"", which has mostly replaced the older term ""whelp"".<ref>{{cite web

column1: *The term ''dog'' typically is applied both to the species (or subspecies) as a whole, and any adult male member of the same.
*An adult female is a ''bitch''. In some countries, especially in North America, ''dog'' is used instead due to the vulgar connotation of ''bitch''.
*An adult male capable of reproduction is a ''stud''.
*An adult female capable of reproduction is a ''brood bitch'', or ''brood mother''.
*Immature males or females (that is, animals that are incapable of reproduction) are ''pups'' or ''puppies''.
*A group of pups from the same [[gestation period]] is a ''litter''.
*The father of a litter is a ''sire''. It is possible for one litter to have multiple sires.
*The mother of a litter is a ''dam''.
*A group of any three or more adults is a ''pack''.

column2: Linnaeus]] published in his ''[[10th edition of Systema Naturae
column3: Systema Naturae]]'' the classification of species. ''[[Canis]]'' is a Latin word meaning dog,<ref>{{OEtymD
column4: canine}}</ref> and under this [[genus]] he listed the dog-like carnivores including domestic dogs, wolves, and jackals. He classified the domestic dog as ''Canis familiaris'' (Linnaeus, 1758) and on the next page as a separate species he classified the [[wolf]] as ''Canis lupus'' (Linnaeus, 1758).<ref name=linnaeus1758/> In 1926, the [[International Commission on Zoological Nomenclature]] (ICZN) ruled in Opinion 91 that the domestic dog ''Canis familiaris'' (Linnaeus, 1758) be placed on its official list.<ref name=iczn1926/> In 1957, the ICZN ruled in Opinion 451 that ''Canis dingo'' (Meyer, 1793) was the name to be used for the [[dingo]] and that this be placed on its official list.<ref name=iczn1957/> These are the [[scientific names]] for the dog and dingo that appear on the ''Official Lists and Indexes of Names in Zoology'' of the ICZN.<ref name=iczn2014/>

column1: In 1978, a review to reduce the number species listed under genus ''Canis'' proposed that ""''Canis dingo'' is now generally regarded as a distinctive feral domestic dog. ''Canis familiaris'' is used for domestic dogs, although taxonomically it should probably be synonymous with ''Canis lupus.''""<ref name=gelder1978/> In 1982, the first edition of [[Mammal Species of the World]] included a note under ''Canis lupus'' with the comment: ""Probably ancestor of and conspecific with the domestic dog, ''familiaris''. ''Canis familiaris'' has page priority over ''Canis lupus'', but both were published simultaneously in Linnaeus (1758), and ''Canis lupus'' has been universally used for this species"".<ref name=honaki1982/> In the same year, an application was made to the ICZN to reclassify the dingo to ''Canis lupus dingo'' because it was proposed that the wolf (''Canis lupus'') was the ancestor of dogs and dingoes, however the application was rejected.<ref name=smith2015/>

In 2003, the ICZN ruled in its [[Opinion 2027]] that the ""name of a wild species...is not invalid by virtue of being predated by the name based on a domestic form."" Additionally, the ICZN placed the taxon ''Canis lupus'' as a [[conserved name]] on the official list under this opinion.<ref name=iczn2003/> In the third edition of ''[[Mammal Species of the World]]'' published in 2005, the mammalogist W. Christopher Wozencraft listed under the wolf ''Canis lupus'' what he proposed to be two subspecies: ""''familiaris'' Linneaus, 1758 [domestic dog]"" and ""''dingo'' Meyer, 1793 [domestic dog]"",{{efn
column2: The addition of [domestic dog] against ''dingo'' and ''familiaris'' is inferred to mean that these two taxons form the ""domestic dog clade"" within ''Canis lupus'', as opposed to its wild ""wolf clade"".}} with the comment ""Includes the domestic dog as a subspecies, with the dingo provisionally separate – artificial variants created by domestication and selective breeding. Although this may stretch the subspecies concept, it retains the correct allocation of synonyms.""<ref name=wozencraft2005/> Although the earliest use of the name ""dingo"" was ''Canis familiaris dingo'' (Blumenbach, 1780),<ref name=blumenbach1780/> Wozencraft attributed it to Meyer from 1793 without comment.<ref name=itis2017/>

column1: This classification by Wozencraft is hotly debated by zoologists.<ref name=smith2015/> Mathew Crowther, Stephen Jackson and [[Colin Groves]] disagree with Wozencraft and argue that based on ICZN Opinion 2027, the implication is that a domestic animal cannot be a subspecies.<ref name=jackson2015/><ref name=crowther2014/> Crowther, [[Juliet Clutton-Brock]] and others argue that because the dingo differs from wolves by behavior, morphology, and that the dingo and dog do not fall genetically within any extant wolf [[clade]], that the dingo should be considered the distinct taxon ''Canis dingo''.<ref name=clutton2015/><ref name=smith2015/><ref name=crowther2014/> Jackson and Groves regard the dog ''Canis familiaris'' as a [[taxonomic synonym]] for the wolf ''Canis lupus'' with them both equally ranked at the species level. They also disagree with Crowther, based on the overlap between dogs and dingoes in their morphology, in their ability to easily hybridize with each other, and that they show the signs of domestication by both having a cranium of smaller capacity than their progenitor, the wolf. Given that ''Canis familiaris'' (Linnaeus, 1758) has date priority over ''Canis dingo'' (Meyer, 1793), they regard the dingo as a  [[Synonym (taxonomy)#zoology
column2: junior taxonomic synonym]] for the dog ''Canis familiaris''.<ref name=jackson2015/> [[Gheorghe Benga]] and others support the dingo as a subspecies of the dog from the earlier ''Canis familiaris dingo'' (Blumenbach, 1780).<ref name=benga2010/><ref name=elledge2006/><ref name=jones1925/> [[Xiaoming Wang]] and [[Richard H. Tedford]] proposed that the dog should be classified as ''Canis lupus familiaris'' under the [[Biological Species Concept]] and ''Canis familiaris'' under the [[Evolutionary developmental biology

column1: <!--Note: What is reflected in this section must be in accord with what is on the ""Origin of the domestic dog"" page and the ""Gray wolf"" page (sub-heading ""Evolution and relationship with the dog""). Unless you have some subject knowledge on the topic, please don't tinker – if you are dog-kind then take your concerns to the ""Origin of the domestic dog"" Talk page, or wolf-kind take it to the ""Gray wolf"" Talk page – all of your queries will be eventually answered.-->
The origin of the domestic dog is not clear. The domestic dog is a member of genus ''[[Canis]]'' (canines) that forms part of the [[Evolution of the wolf#Wolf-like canids
column2: wolf-like canids]],<ref name=lindblad2005/> and is the most widely abundant [[carnivore]].<ref name=fan2016/><ref name=thalmann2013/><ref name=vila1999/> The closest living relative of the dog is the [[gray wolf]] and there is no evidence of any other canine contributing to its genetic lineage.<ref name=fan2016/><ref name=thalmann2013/><ref name=vonholdt2010/><ref name=vila1997/> The dog and the [[wikt:extant
column3: extant]] gray wolf form two sister [[clades]],<ref name=vila1997/><ref name=freedman2014/><ref name=larson2014/> with modern wolves not closely related to the wolves that were first domesticated.<ref name=freedman2014/><ref name=larson2014/> The archaeological record shows the first undisputed dog remains buried beside humans 14,700 years ago,<ref name=giemsch2015/> with disputed remains occurring 36,000 years ago.<ref name=germonpre2009/>  These dates imply that the earliest dogs arose in the time of human [[hunter-gatherers]] and not [[agriculturists]].<ref name=thalmann2013/><ref name=freedman2014/> The dog was the first domesticated species.<ref name=larson2014/><ref name=perri2016/>

column1: Where the [[genetic divergence]] of dog and wolf took place remains controversial, with the most plausible proposals spanning Western Europe,<ref name=machugh2016/><ref name=thalmann2013/> Central Asia,<ref name=machugh2016/><ref name=shannon2015/> and East Asia.<ref name=machugh2016/><ref name=wang2015/> This has been made more complicated by the most recent proposal that fits the available evidence, which is that an initial wolf population split into East and West Eurasian wolves, these were then domesticated independently before going extinct into two distinct dog populations between 14,000-6,400 years ago, and then the Western Eurasian dog population was partially and gradually replaced by East Asian dogs that were brought by humans at least 6,400 years ago.<ref name=machugh2016/><ref name=frantz2016/><ref name=grimm2016/>

Domestic dogs have been selectively bred for millennia for various behaviors, sensory capabilities, and physical attributes.<ref name=""ADW""/> Modern [[dog breed]]s show more variation in size, appearance, and behavior than any other domestic animal.<ref name=""ADW""/> Dogs are [[predation
column2: predators]] and [[scavenger]]s, and like many other predatory mammals, the dog has powerful muscles, fused wrist bones, a cardiovascular system that supports both sprinting and endurance, and teeth for catching and tearing.

column1: Dogs are highly variable in height and weight. The smallest known adult dog was a [[Yorkshire Terrier]], that stood only {{convert
column7: abbr=on}} in length along the head-and-body, and weighed only {{convert
column9: g}}. The largest known dog was an [[English Mastiff]] which weighed {{convert
column15: abbr=on}} from the snout to the tail.<ref name=""zorba"">{{cite web
column18: accessdate=7 January 2008}}</ref> The tallest dog is a [[Great Dane]] that stands {{convert
column25: title=Guinness World Records – Tallest Dog Living

column1: The dog's senses include vision, hearing, sense of smell, sense of taste, touch and sensitivity to the earth's magnetic field. Another study suggested that dogs can see the earth's magnetic field.<ref>{{cite journal
column5: title=Cryptochrome 1 in Retinal Cone Photoreceptors Suggests a Novel Functional Role in Mammals
column23: first7=Leo}}</ref><ref>[http://brain.mpg.de/news-events/news/news/archive/2016/february/article/magnetoreception-molecule-found-in-the-eyes-of-dogs-and-primates.html?tx_ttnews%5Bday%5D=22&cHash=e29a96d380bf79d438733a01ec7bac82 Magnetoreception molecule found in the eyes of dogs and primates] {{webarchive
column25: date=23 December 2016 }} MPI Brain Research, 22 February 2016</ref>

column3: Montage showing the coat variation of the dog.]]

column2: coats]] of domestic dogs are of two varieties: ""double"" being common with dogs (as well as wolves) originating from colder climates, made up of a coarse [[guard hair]] and a soft [[down hair]], or ""single"", with the topcoat only.

column1: Domestic dogs often display the remnants of [[countershading]], a common natural camouflage pattern. A countershaded animal will have dark coloring on its upper surfaces and light coloring below,<ref name=""About.com"">{{cite web
column8: accessdate=22 October 2008}}</ref> which reduces its general visibility. Thus, many breeds will have an occasional ""blaze"", stripe, or ""star"" of white fur on their chest or underside.<ref name=""Encyclopedia of Dog Breeds"">{{Cite book

column1: There are many different shapes for [[dog tail]]s: straight, straight up, sickle, curled, or cork-screw. As with many canids, one of the primary functions of a dog's tail is to communicate their emotional state, which can be important in getting along with others. In some hunting dogs, however, the tail is traditionally [[docking (dog)
column6: accessdate=22 October 2008}}</ref> In some breeds, such as the [[Braque du Bourbonnais]], puppies can be born with a short tail or no tail at all.<ref>{{cite web

column1: There are many household plants that are poisonous to dogs including [[begonia]], [[Poinsettia]] and [[aloe vera]].<ref>{{cite web
Some breeds of dogs are prone to certain genetic ailments such as [[Elbow dysplasia
column6: trick knees]]. Two serious medical conditions particularly affecting dogs are [[pyometra]], affecting [[neutering
column7: unspayed]] females of all types and ages, and [[gastric dilatation volvulus]] (bloat), which affects the larger breeds or deep-chested dogs. Both of these are acute conditions, and can kill rapidly. Dogs are also susceptible to parasites such as [[flea]]s, [[tick]]s, and [[mite]]s, as well as [[hookworms]], [[tapeworms]], [[roundworms]], and [[Dirofilaria immitis

column1: A number of common human foods and household ingestibles are toxic to dogs, including [[chocolate
column2: chocolate solids]] ([[theobromine poisoning]]), onion and [[garlic]] ([[thiosulphate]], [[sulfoxide]] or [[disulfide]] poisoning),<ref>Sources vary on which of these are considered the most significant toxic item.</ref> [[grape]]s and [[raisin]]s, [[macadamia nut]]s, [[xylitol]],<ref>{{Cite journal
column9: journal = Veterinary Clinics of North America: Small Animal Practice
column15: pmc = }}</ref> as well as various plants and other potentially ingested materials.<ref>{{cite web
column16: title=Toxic Foods and Plants for Dogs
column21: title=Foods to Avoid Feeding Your Dog
column24: accessdate=24 June 2010}}</ref> The nicotine in tobacco can also be dangerous. Dogs can be exposed to the substance by scavenging garbage or ashtrays; eating cigars and cigarettes. Signs can be vomiting of large amounts (e.g., from eating cigar butts) or diarrhea. Some other signs are abdominal pain, loss of coordination, collapse, or death.<ref>{{cite book
column29: title=Caring For Your Dog}}</ref> Dogs are highly susceptible to [[theobromine poisoning]], typically from ingestion of [[chocolate]]. Theobromine is toxic to dogs because, although the dog's metabolism is capable of breaking down the chemical, the process is so slow that even small amounts of chocolate can be fatal, especially dark chocolate.

column1: Dogs are also vulnerable to some of the same health conditions as humans, including [[diabetes in dogs
column2: diabetes]], dental and heart disease, epilepsy, cancer, hypothyroidism, and arthritis.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Diseases shared by humans and pets
A mixed-breed terrier. Mixed-breed dogs have been found to run faster and live longer than their pure-bred parents (See [[Heterosis#Heterosis in dogs

column1: In 2013, a study found that mixed breeds live on average 1.2 years longer than pure breeds, and that increasing body-weight was negatively correlated with longevity (i.e. the heavier the dog the shorter its lifespan).<ref>{{Cite journal
column12: title = Longevity and mortality of owned dogs in England

column1: The typical lifespan of dogs varies widely among breeds, but for most the median longevity, the age at which half the dogs in a population have died and half are still alive, ranges from 10 to 13 years.<ref name=""KC Survey"">

column3: title = Kennel Club/British Small Animal Veterinary Association Scientific Committee
column11: title = Mortality of purebred and mixed-breed dogs in Denmark
column20: title=Longevity of British breeds of dog and its relationships with sex, size, cardiovascular variables and disease
column28: title=Dog Longevity Web Site, Breed Data page
column31: accessdate=8 July 2007}}</ref> Individual dogs may live well beyond the median of their breed.

column1: The breed with the shortest lifespan (among breeds for which there is a questionnaire survey with a reasonable sample size) is the [[Dogue de Bordeaux]], with a median longevity of about 5.2 years, but several breeds, including [[Bull Terrier (Miniature)
column2: Miniature Bull Terriers]], [[Bloodhound]]s, and [[Irish Wolfhound]]s are nearly as short-lived, with median longevities of 6 to 7 years.<ref name=""Cassidy Data""/>

column1: The longest-lived breeds, including [[Toy Poodles]], [[Japanese Spitz]], [[Border Terrier]]s, and [[Tibetan Spaniel]]s, have median longevities of 14 to 15 years.<ref name=""Cassidy Data""/> The median longevity of [[mixed-breed dog]]s, taken as an average of all sizes, is one or more years longer than that of purebred dogs when all breeds are averaged.<ref name=""Denmark Survey""/><ref name=""British Owners""/><ref name=""Cassidy Data""/><ref name=""Vet School Data"">{{Cite journal
column2: vauthors=Patronek GJ, Waters DJ, Glickman LT
column3: title=Comparative longevity of pet dogs and humans: implications for gerontology research
column4: journal=The Journals of Gerontology. Series a, Biological Sciences and Medical Sciences
column10: doi=10.1093/gerona/52A.3.B171}}</ref> The dog widely reported to be the longest-lived is ""[[Bluey (dog)
column11: Bluey]]"", who died in 1939 and was claimed to be 29.5 years old at the time of his death. On 5 December 2011, [[Pusuke]], the world's oldest living dog recognized by [[Guinness Book of World Records]], died aged 26 years and 9 months.<ref>{{cite web
column13: title=Pusuke, world's oldest living dog, dies in Japan

column2: sexual maturity]] begins to happen around age six to twelve months for both males and females,<ref name=""ADW""/><ref>{{cite web
column8: accessdate=22 October 2008}}</ref> although this can be delayed until up to two years old for some large breeds. This is the time at which female dogs will have their first [[estrous cycle]]. They will experience subsequent estrous cycles semiannually, during which the body prepares for [[pregnancy]]. At the peak of the cycle, females will come into estrus, being mentally and physically receptive to [[Canine tying
column10: ova]] survive and are capable of being fertilized for a week after ovulation, it is possible for a female to mate with more than one male.<ref name=""ADW""/>

column1: Fertilization typically occurs 2–5 days after ovulation; 14–16 days after ovulation, the embryo attaches to the uterus, and after 7-8 more days the heart beat is detectable.<ref>{{cite journal
column10: title=Embryo development, hormonal requirements and maternal responses during canine pregnancy
column13: journal=Journal of reproduction and fertility. Supplement}}</ref><ref>{{cite web

column1: Dogs bear their litters roughly 58 to 68 days after [[fertilization]],<ref name=""ADW""/><ref>{{cite web
column8: df= }}</ref> with an average of 63 days, although the length of gestation can vary. An average litter consists of about six [[puppy
column12: publisher=The Humane Society of the United States
column13: accessdate=22 October 2008}}</ref> though this number may vary widely based on the breed of dog. In general, [[toy dog]]s produce from one to four puppies in each litter, while much larger breeds may average as many as twelve.

column1: Some dog breeds have acquired traits through selective breeding that interfere with reproduction. Male [[French Bulldog]]s, for instance, are incapable of mounting the female. For many dogs of this breed, the female must be [[artificial insemination
column2: artificially inseminated]] in order to reproduce.<ref name=""French"">{{cite web

column4: A feral dog from [[Sri Lanka]] nursing her four puppies]]

column3: removal of the male's testicle]]s or the female's [[ovary
column4: ovaries]] and [[uterus]], in order to eliminate the ability to procreate and reduce [[sex drive]]. Because of the [[overpopulation in companion animals
column5: overpopulation of dogs]] in some countries, many animal control agencies, such as the [[American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals]] (ASPCA), advise that dogs not intended for further breeding should be neutered, so that they do not have undesired puppies that may have to later be euthanized.<ref>{{cite web
column7: title=Top 10 reasons to spay/neuter your pet
column8: publisher=American Society for Prevention of Cruelty to Animals

column1: According to the [[Humane Society of the United States]], 3–4 million dogs and cats are [[euthanasia
column2: put down]] each year in the United States and many more are confined to cages in shelters because there are many more animals than there are homes. Spaying or castrating dogs helps keep overpopulation down.<ref>{{Cite journal
column3: quote = Although the cause of pet overpopulation is multifaceted, the lack of guardians choosing to spay or neuter their animals is a major contributing factor.
column7: title = Estimation of the proportions of dogs and cats that are surgically sterilized
column8: journal=Journal of the American Veterinary Medical Association
column12: issue = 5}}</ref> Local humane societies, SPCAs, and other [[animal protection organizations]] urge people to neuter their pets and to adopt animals from shelters instead of purchasing them.

column1: Neutering reduces problems caused by [[hypersexuality]], especially in male dogs.<ref>{{Cite journal
column6: title=Changes in the behavior of dogs after castration
column14: issn=0303-6286}}</ref> Spayed female dogs are less likely to develop some forms of cancer, affecting mammary glands, ovaries, and other reproductive organs.<ref>{{Cite book
column16: title=Cancer in Dogs and Cats (1st ed.)
column19: isbn=0-683-06105-4}}</ref> However, neutering increases the risk of [[urinary incontinence]] in female dogs,<ref>{{Cite journal
column21: title=[Urinary incontinence in castrated bitches. Part 1: Significance, clinical aspects and etiopathogenesis]
column28: pmid=9411733}}</ref> and [[prostate cancer]] in males,<ref>{{Cite journal
column44: issn=0378-4320}}</ref> as well as osteosarcoma, hemangiosarcoma, cruciate ligament rupture, obesity, and diabetes mellitus in either sex.<ref>{{Cite journal
column46: title=Determining the optimal age for gonadectomy of dogs and cats

column1: A common breeding practice for pet dogs is mating between close relatives (e.g. between half- and full siblings).<ref name=Leroy>{{cite journal
column3: title=Genetic diversity, inbreeding and breeding practices in dogs: results from pedigree analyses
column11: url=}}</ref> In a study of seven different French breeds of dogs ([[Bernese mountain dog]], [[basset hound]], [[Cairn terrier]], [[Brittany (breed)
column12: Epagneul Breton]], [[German Shepherd]] dog, [[Leonberger]], and [[West Highland white terrier]]) it was found that inbreeding decreases litter size and survival.<ref name=""pmid25475165"">{{cite journal
column13: vauthors=Leroy G, Phocas F, Hedan B, Verrier E, Rognon X
column14: title=Inbreeding impact on litter size and survival in selected canine breeds
column22: url=}}</ref> Another analysis of data on 42,855 [[dachshund]] litters, found that as the [[inbreeding coefficient]] increased, litter size decreased and the percentage of stillborn puppies increased, thus indicating inbreeding depression.<ref name=""pmid15803761"">{{cite journal
column23: vauthors=Gresky C, Hamann H, Distl O
column24: title=[Influence of inbreeding on litter size and the proportion of stillborn puppies in dachshunds]

column1: About 22% of boxer puppies die before reaching 7 weeks of age.<ref name=Beek>{{cite journal
column2: vauthors=van der Beek S, Nielen AL, Schukken YH, Brascamp EW
column3: title=Evaluation of genetic, common-litter, and within-litter effects on preweaning mortality in a birth cohort of puppies
column11: url=}}</ref> Stillbirth is the most frequent cause of death, followed by infection. Mortality due to infection was found to increase significantly with increases in inbreeding.<ref name=Beek /> [[Inbreeding depression]] is considered to be due largely to the expression of homozygous deleterious recessive mutations.<ref name=""pmid19834483"">{{cite journal
column21: url=}}</ref> Outcrossing between unrelated individuals, including dogs of different breeds, results in the beneficial masking of deleterious recessive mutations in progeny.<ref name=""pmid3324702"">{{cite journal
column22: vauthors=Bernstein H, Hopf FA, Michod RE
column23: title=The molecular basis of the evolution of sex

column1: Dog intelligence is the ability of the dog to perceive information and retain it as knowledge for applying to solve problems. Dogs have been shown to learn by inference. A study with [[Rico (Border Collie)
column2: Rico]] showed that he knew the labels of over 200 different items. He inferred the names of novel items by exclusion learning and correctly retrieved those novel items immediately and also 4 weeks after the initial exposure. Dogs have advanced memory skills. A study documented the learning and memory capabilities of a border collie, ""Chaser"", who had learned the names and could associate by verbal command over 1,000 words. Dogs are able to read and react appropriately to human body language such as gesturing and pointing, and to understand human voice commands. Dogs demonstrate a [[theory of mind]] by engaging in deception. An experimental study showed compelling evidence that Australian [[dingo]]s can outperform domestic dogs in non-social problem-solving, indicating that domestic dogs may have lost much of their original problem-solving abilities once they joined humans.<ref>{{cite journal
column8: title = How well do dingoes (Canis dingo) perform on the detour task
column14: doi=10.1016/j.anbehav.2010.04.017}}</ref> Another study indicated that after undergoing training to solve a simple manipulation task, dogs that are faced with an insoluble version of the same problem look at the human, while socialized wolves do not.<ref>{{cite journal
column19: title=A simple reason for a big difference: wolves do not look back at humans, but dogs do
column34: first6=V }}</ref> Modern domestic dogs use humans to solve their problems for them.<ref name=hare2013/><ref>{{cite web
column36: title=Why Dogs are More Like Humans Than Wolves

column1: Dog behavior is the internally coordinated responses (actions or inactions) of the domestic dog (individuals or groups) to internal and/or external stimuli.<ref name=levitis2009/> As the oldest domesticated species, with estimates ranging from 9,000–30,000 years BCE, the minds of dogs inevitably have been shaped by millennia of contact with humans. As a result of this physical and social evolution, dogs, more than any other species, have acquired the ability to understand and communicate with humans, and they are uniquely attuned to human behaviors.<ref name=berns2012/> Behavioral scientists have uncovered a surprising set of social-cognitive abilities in the domestic dog. These abilities are not possessed by the dog's closest canine
relatives nor by other highly intelligent mammals such as great apes but rather parallel some of the social-cognitive skills of human children.<ref name=tomasello2009/>

Dog communication is about how dogs ""speak"" to each other, how they understand messages that humans send to them, and how humans can translate the ideas that dogs are trying to transmit.<ref>Coren, Stanley ""How To Speak Dog: Mastering the Art of Dog-Human Communication"" 2000 Simon & Schuster, New York.</ref>{{rp
column2: xii}} These communication behaviors include eye gaze, facial expression, vocalization, body posture (including movements of bodies and limbs) and gustatory communication (scents, pheromones and taste). Humans communicate with dogs by using vocalization, hand signals and body posture.

column3: The [[Saarloos wolfdog]] carries more [[gray wolf]] DNA than any other dog breed<ref name=skoglund2015/>]]

column1: Despite their close genetic relationship and the ability to inter-breed, there are a number of diagnostic features to distinguish the gray wolves from domestic dogs. Domesticated dogs are clearly distinguishable from wolves by starch gel [[electrophoresis]] of red blood cell acid [[phosphatase]].<ref>Elliot, D. G., and M. Wong. 1972. Acid phosphatase, handy enzyme that separates the dog from the wolf. Acta Biologica et Medica Germanica 28:957–62</ref> The [[Auditory bulla
column2: tympanic bullae]] are large, convex and almost spherical in gray wolves, while the bullae of dogs are smaller, compressed and slightly crumpled.<ref name=""mech1974"">{{cite journal
column14: jstor = 3503924 }}</ref> Compared with equally sized wolves, dogs tend to have 20% smaller skulls and 30% smaller brains.<ref name=""serpell1995"" />{{rp
column15: 35}} The teeth of gray wolves are also proportionately larger than those of dogs.<ref>Clutton-Brock, Juliet (1987). ''A Natural History of Domesticated Mammals.'' British Museum (Natural History), p. 24, {{ISBN
column16: 0-521-34697-5}}</ref> Dogs have a more domed forehead and a distinctive ""stop"" between forehead and nose.<ref>https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4742516/</ref> The [[temporalis muscle]] that closes the jaws is more robust in wolves.<ref name=wang2008/>{{rp
column17: p158}} Wolves do not have [[dewclaws]] on their back legs, unless there has been admixture with dogs that had them.<ref>{{Citation
column20: title = Claws reveal wolf survival threat
column24: accessdate = 12 December 2014}}</ref>  Most dogs lack a functioning [[pre-caudal gland]] and enter [[estrus]] twice yearly, unlike gray wolves which only do so once a year.<ref name=""m257"">{{Harvnb
column28: p=257}}</ref> So-called primitive dogs such as Dingoes and Basenjis retain the yearly estrus cycle.<ref>http://veterinarycalendar.dvm360.com/canine-estrous-cycle-and-ovulation-proceedings</ref> Dogs generally have brown eyes and wolves almost always have amber or light colored eyes.<ref>http://dnr.wi.gov/topic/wildlifehabitat/wolf/identify.html</ref> The skin of domestic dogs tends to be thicker than that of wolves, with some [[Inuit]] tribes favoring the former for use as clothing due to its greater resistance to wear and tear in harsh weather.<ref name=""DOGS"">{{Cite book
column30: title=Dogs: a Startling New Understanding of Canine Origin, Behavior and Evolution
column34: location= New York}}</ref> The paws of a dog are half the size of those of a wolf, and their tails tend to curl upwards, another trait not found in wolves<ref name=""Lopez"">{{cite book
column41: page = 320}}</ref> The dog has developed into hundreds of varied [[Dog breed
column42: breeds]], and shows more behavioral and morphological variation than any other land mammal.<ref name=""spady"">{{Cite journal
column44: title=Canine Behavioral Genetics: Pointing Out the Phenotypes and Herding up the Genes
column52: doi=10.1016/j.ajhg.2007.12.001}}</ref> For example, height measured to the [[withers]] ranges from a {{convert
column57: ft}} in the [[Irish Wolfhound]]; color varies from white through grays (usually called ""blue"") to black, and browns from light (tan) to dark (""red"" or ""chocolate"") in a wide variation of patterns; [[coat (dog)
column58: coats]] can be short or long, coarse-haired to wool-like, straight, curly, or smooth.<ref name=""The Complete Dog"">{{Cite book
column59: title=The Complete dog book: the photograph, history, and official standard of every breed admitted to AKC registration, and the selection, training, breeding, care, and feeding of pure-bred dogs
column64: date=September 2010}}</ref> It is common for most breeds to [[Moult

column2: Dog behavior#Behavior compared with other canids}}

column1: Unlike other domestic species which were primarily selected for production-related traits, dogs were initially selected for their behaviors.<ref>Serpell J, Duffy D. Dog Breeds and Their Behavior. In: Domestic Dog Cognition and Behavior. Berlin, Heidelberg: Springer; 2014</ref><ref name=cagan2016/> In 2016, a study found that there were only 11 fixed genes that showed variation between wolves and dogs. These gene variations were unlikely to have been the result of natural evolution, and indicate selection on both morphology and behavior during dog domestication. These genes have been shown to affect the [[Catecholamine#Synthesis
column2: catecholamine synthesis]] pathway, with the majority of the genes affecting the fight-or-flight response<ref name=cagan2016/><ref>Almada RC, Coimbra NC. Recruitment of striatonigral disinhibitory and nigrotectal inhibitory GABAergic pathways during the organization of defensive behavior by mice in a dangerous environment with the venomous snake Bothrops alternatus [ Reptilia , Viperidae ] Synapse 2015:n/a–n/a</ref> (i.e. selection for tameness), and emotional processing.<ref name=cagan2016/> Dogs generally show reduced fear and aggression compared with wolves.<ref name=cagan2016/><ref>Coppinger R, Schneider R: Evolution of working dogs. The domestic dog: Its evolution, behaviour and interactions with people. Cambridge: Cambridge University press, 1995.</ref> Some of these genes have been associated with aggression in some dog breeds, indicating their importance in both the initial domestication and then later in breed formation.<ref name=cagan2016>{{cite journal
column4: title=Identification of genomic variants putatively targeted by selection during dog domestication

column1: The global dog population is estimated at 900 million and rising.<ref>{{cite book
column5: chapter=The dog–human–wildlife interface: assessing the scope of the problem
column10: pages=9–54}}</ref><ref name=lescureaux2014/> Although it is said that the [[Man's best friend (phrase)
column11: dog is man's best friend""]]<ref name=""J. Derbett London"">{{cite book
column16: title=The life of Frederick the Second, King of Prussia: To which are added observations, Authentic Documents, and a Variety of Anecdotes.
column17: publisher=J. Derbett London}}</ref> regarding 17–24% of dogs in developed countries, in the developing world they are feral, village or community dogs, with pet dogs uncommon.<ref name=""DOGS""/> These live their lives as scavengers and have never been owned by humans, with one study showing their most common response when approached by strangers was to run away (52%) or respond with aggression (11%).<ref>{{Cite journal
column20: title = Ethiopian village dogs: Behavioural responses to a stranger's approach
column26: pages=210–218}}</ref> We know little about these dogs, nor about the dogs that live in developed countries that are feral, stray or are in shelters, yet the great majority of modern research on dog cognition has focused on pet dogs living in human homes.<ref>{{Cite journal
column29: title = What did domestication do to dogs? A new account of dogs' sensitivity to human actions

column1: Being the most abundant carnivore, feral and [[free-ranging dog]]s have the greatest potential to compete with wolves. A review of the studies in the competitive effects of dogs on [[Sympatry
column2: sympatric]] carnivores did not mention any research on competition between dogs and wolves.<ref name=lescureaux2014/><ref name=vanak2014/> Competition would favor the wolf that is known to kill dogs, however wolves tend to live in pairs or in small packs in areas where they are highly persecuted, giving them a disadvantage facing large dog groups.<ref name=lescureaux2014/><ref name=boitani1983/>

column1: Wolves kill dogs wherever the two canids occur.<ref name=""WOLVES""/> One survey claims that in Wisconsin in 1999 more compensation had been paid for dog losses than livestock, however in Wisconsin wolves will often kill hunting dogs, perhaps because they are in the wolf's territory.<ref name=""WOLVES"">{{Cite book
column9: isbn=0-226-51696-2}}</ref> Some wolf pairs have been reported to prey on dogs by having one wolf lure the dog out into heavy brush where the second animal waits in ambush.<ref name=""Graves"">{{Cite book
column12: title = Wolves in Russia: Anxiety throughout the ages
column17: page = 222}}</ref> In some instances, wolves have displayed an uncharacteristic fearlessness of humans and buildings when attacking dogs, to the extent that they have to be beaten off or killed.<ref>{{Cite journal
column18: title=Interactions between wolves Canis lupus and dogs C. familiaris in Finland
column24: author5=Kokko, S. }}</ref> Although the numbers of dogs killed each year are relatively low, it induces a fear of wolves entering villages and farmyards to take dogs. In many cultures, there are strong social and emotional bonds between humans and their dogs that can be seen as family members or working team members. The loss of a dog can lead to strong emotional responses with demands for more liberal wolf hunting regulations.<ref name=lescureaux2014/>

column1: [[Coyote]]s and big cats have also been known to attack dogs. [[Leopard]]s in particular are known to have a predilection for dogs, and have been recorded to kill and consume them regardless of the dog's size or ferocity.<ref name=""Leopard"">{{Cite book
column9: page = 108}}</ref> [[Tiger]]s in [[Manchuria]], [[Indochina]], [[Indonesia]], and [[Malaysia]] are reputed to kill dogs with the same vigor as leopards.<ref name=""Perry"">{{Cite book
column11: title = The World of the Tiger
column14: page = 260}}</ref> [[Striped hyena]]s are major predators of village dogs in [[Turkmenistan]], [[India]], and the [[Caucasus]].<ref name=""Striped"">{{cite web
column17: publisher=IUCN Species Survival Commission Hyaenidae Specialist Group

column1: The spiked collar common on working and pet dogs is no mere ornament: it originated as a protection of the vulnerable neck of a dog from wolves, but also protects dogs from attacks by other dogs.<ref>https://www.quora.com/Why-do-some-dog-collars-have-spikes</ref>
Despite their descent from wolves and classification as [[Carnivora]], dogs are variously described in scholarly and other writings as [[carnivore]]s<ref>{{Cite book
column8: chapter=Ethics and the Study of Carnivores
column17: title=Biology of the pancreas in growing animals
column18: volume=Volume 28 of Developments in animal and veterinary sciences
column26: title=Nutrient requirements of dogs and cats
column27: author=National Research Council (U.S.). Ad Hoc Committee on Dog and Cat Nutrition
column33: title=Grab Life by the Leash: A Guide to Bringing Up and Bonding with Your Four-Legged Friend
column39: url=https://books.google.com/?id=p0y9b9voiI8C&pg=PA77}}</ref> Unlike [[obligate carnivore]]s, dogs can adapt to a wide-ranging diet, and are not dependent on meat-specific protein nor a very high level of protein in order to fulfill their basic dietary requirements. Dogs will healthily digest a variety of foods, including vegetables and grains, and can consume a large proportion of these in their diet, however all-meat diets are not recommended for dogs due to their lack of calcium and iron.<ref name=""ADW""/> Comparing dogs and wolves, dogs have adaptations in genes involved in starch digestion that contribute to an increased ability to thrive on a starch-rich diet.<ref name=""axelssonetal2013""/>

column3: [[Cavalier King Charles Spaniel]]s demonstrate different colored coats within the one breed]]

column2: breeds]] of dog are at most a few hundred years old, having been artificially selected for particular [[morphology (biology)
column4: behaviors]] by people for specific functional roles. Through this [[artificial selection
column5: selective breeding]], the dog has developed into hundreds of varied breeds, and shows more behavioral and morphological variation than any other land mammal.<ref name=""spady""/> For example, height measured to the [[withers]] ranges from {{convert
column11: abbr=on}} in the [[Irish Wolfhound]]; color varies from white through grays (usually called ""blue"") to black, and browns from light (tan) to dark (""red"" or ""chocolate"") in a wide variation of patterns; [[coat (dog)
column12: coats]] can be short or long, coarse-haired to wool-like, straight, curly, or smooth.<ref name=""The Complete Dog""/> It is common for most breeds to [[Moult#In dogs

column1: While all dogs are genetically very similar,<ref name=""autogenerated718"">{{Cite journal
column2: vauthors=Savolainen P, Zhang YP, Luo J, Lundeberg J, Leitner T
column3: title=Genetic evidence for an East Asian origin of domestic dogs
column11: bibcode=2002Sci...298.1610S}}</ref> [[natural selection]] and selective breeding have reinforced certain characteristics in certain populations of dogs, giving rise to dog types and dog breeds. Dog types are broad categories based on function, genetics, or characteristics.<ref>{{Cite book
column13: title= Webster's Third New International Dictionary of the English Language, Unabridged
column18: quote= type (4a) the combination of character that fits an individual to a particular use or function (''a strong horse of the draft type'')}}</ref>

column1: Dog breeds are groups of animals that possess a set of inherited characteristics that distinguishes them from other animals within the same species.{{vague
column2: date=November 2016}}<!--So how is this different from a type?-->{{citation needed
column3: date=November 2016}} Modern dog breeds are non-scientific classifications of dogs kept by modern [[kennel club]]s.

column1: Purebred dogs of one breed are genetically distinguishable from [[purebred (dog)
column2: purebred]] dogs of other breeds,<ref name=""parker"">{{Cite journal
column23: title=Genetic structure of the purebred domestic dog
column31: bibcode = 2004Sci...304.1160P}}</ref> but the means by which kennel clubs classify dogs is unsystematic. DNA [[microsatellite]] analyses of 85 dog breeds showed they fell into four major types of dogs that were statistically distinct.<ref name=""parker""/> These include the ""old world dogs"" (e.g., [[Alaskan Malamute
column32: Malamute]] and [[Shar Pei]]), ""Mastiff""-type (e.g., [[English Mastiff]]), ""herding""-type (e.g., [[Border Collie]]), and ""all others"" (also called ""modern""- or ""hunting""-type).<ref name=""parker""/><ref name=""AmSciarticle"">{{cite web
column34: title= Genetics and the Shape of Dogs; Studying the new sequence of the canine genome shows how tiny genetic changes can create enormous variation within a single species

column4: [[Gunnar Kaasen]] and [[Balto]], the lead dog on the last relay team of the [[1925 serum run to Nome]].]]

column1: Domestic dogs inherited complex behaviors, such as [[bite inhibition]], from their wolf ancestors, which would have been [[pack hunter]]s with complex body language. These sophisticated forms of social cognition and communication may account for their trainability, playfulness, and ability to fit into human households and social situations, and these attributes have given dogs a relationship with humans that has enabled them to become one of the most successful species on the planet today.<ref name=""Miklósi"">{{cite book
The dogs' value to early human hunter-gatherers led to them quickly becoming ubiquitous across world cultures. Dogs perform many roles for people, such as [[hunting dog
column9: aiding handicapped individuals]]. This influence on human society has given them the nickname ""[[Man's best friend (phrase)
column10: man's best friend]]"" in the Western world. In some cultures, however, dogs [[#As a food source
column11: are also a source of meat]].<ref name=""Wingfield-Hayes""/><ref name=""Vietnam's dog meat tradition""/>

column1: Wolves, and their dog descendants, would have derived significant benefits from living in human camps—more safety, more reliable food, lesser caloric needs, and more chance to breed.<ref name=""Groves"">{{Cite journal
column5: title= The Advantages and Disadvantages of Being Domesticated
column9: issn = 1038-5762}}</ref> They would have benefited from humans' upright gait that gives them larger range over which to see potential predators and prey, as well as better color vision that, at least by day, gives humans better visual discrimination.<ref name=Groves/> Camp dogs would also have benefited from human tool use, as in bringing down larger prey and [[control of fire
column10: controlling fire]] for a range of purposes.<ref name=Groves/>

column1: The dogs of [[Thibet]] are twice the size of those seen in India, with large heads and hairy bodies. They are powerful animals, and are said to be able to kill a tiger. During the day they are kept chained up, and are let loose at night to guard their masters' house.''Travels in Central Asia by Meer Izzut-oollah in the Years 1812-13''. Translated by Captain Henderson. Calcutta, 1872, p. 15.
Humans would also have derived enormous benefit from the dogs associated with their camps.<ref name=""Tacon"">{{Cite journal
column11: pages=52–61}}</ref> For instance, dogs would have improved sanitation by cleaning up food scraps.<ref name=""Tacon""/> Dogs may have provided warmth, as referred to in the Australian Aboriginal expression ""three dog night"" (an exceptionally cold night), and they would have alerted the camp to the presence of predators or strangers, using their acute hearing to provide an early warning.<ref name=""Tacon""/>

column1: Anthropologists believe the most significant benefit would have been the use of dogs' robust sense of smell to assist with the hunt.<ref name=""Tacon""/> The relationship between the presence of a dog and success in the hunt is often mentioned as a primary reason for the domestication of the wolf, and a 2004 study of hunter groups with and without a dog gives quantitative support to the hypothesis that the benefits of cooperative hunting was an important factor in wolf domestication.<ref name=""Ruusila"">{{Cite journal
column7: title=Interspecific cooperation in human (''Homo sapiens'') hunting: the benefits of a barking dog (''Canis familiaris'')

column1: The cohabitation of dogs and humans would have greatly improved the chances of survival for early human groups, and the domestication of dogs may have been one of the key forces that led to human success.<ref name=""Newby"">{{Cite book
Emigrants from [[Siberia]] that walked across the [[Beringia
column2: Bering land bridge]] into North America may have had dogs in their company, and one writer<ref name=""Early Americas 1998"">''A History of Dogs in the Early Americas'', Marion Schwartz, 1998, 260 p., {{ISBN
column3: 978-0-300-07519-9}}, Yale University Press</ref> suggests that the use of [[sled dogs]] may have been critical to the success of the waves that entered North America roughly 12,000 years ago,<ref name=""Early Americas 1998""/> although the earliest archaeological evidence of dog-like canids in North America dates from about 9,400 years ago.<ref name=""Miklósi""/>{{rp
column6: title=The University of Maine – UMaine News – UMaine Student Finds Oldest Known Domesticated Dog in Americas
column9: accessdate=4 July 2013}}</ref> Dogs were an important part of life for the [[Athabaskan languages
column10: Athabascan]] population in North America, and were their only domesticated animal. Dogs also carried much of the load in the migration of the [[Apache]] and [[Navajo people
column11: Navajo]] tribes 1,400 years ago. Use of dogs as [[pack animal]]s in these cultures often persisted after the introduction of the [[horse]] to North America.<ref>{{Cite book

column3: alt=Couple sitting on the lawn with a pet British Bulldog
column5: British Bulldog]] shares a day at the park.]]

column3: Green velvet dog collar, dates from 1670 to 1690.]]

column1: It is estimated that three-quarters of the world's dog population lives in the developing world as feral, village, or community dogs, with pet dogs uncommon.<ref name=""DOGS""/>

The most widespread form of interspecies bonding occurs between humans and dogs""<ref name=""Tacon""/> and the keeping of dogs as companions, particularly by elites, has a long history.<ref name=""Derr"">{{Cite book
column8: isbn= 0-226-14280-9}}</ref> (As a possible example, at the [[Natufian culture]] site of [[Ain Mallaha]] in [[Israel]], dated to 12,000 BC, the remains of an elderly human and a four-to-five-month-old puppy were found buried together).<ref name=""Clutton-Brock1995"">{{Citation
column9: title=The domestic dog: its evolution, behaviour and interactions with people
column18: chapter=Origins of the dog: domestication and early history}}</ref> However, pet dog populations grew significantly after World War II as suburbanization increased.<ref name=""Derr""/> In the 1950s and 1960s, dogs were kept outside more often than they tend to be today<ref name=""Franklin"">{{Cite journal
column23: title = Be[a]ware of the Dog: a post-humanist approach to housing
column28: issn = 1403-6096}}</ref> (using the expression ""in the doghouse"" to describe exclusion from the group signifies the distance between the doghouse and the home) and were still primarily functional, acting as a guard, children's playmate, or walking companion. From the 1980s, there have been changes in the role of the pet dog, such as the increased role of dogs in the emotional support of their human guardians.<ref name=""Katz"">{{Cite book
column31: title= The New Work of Dogs
column35: isbn= 0-375-76055-5}}</ref> People and dogs have become increasingly integrated and implicated in each other's lives,<ref name=""Haraway"">{{Cite book
column38: title= The Companion Species manifesto: Dogs, People and Significant Otherness
column42: isbn= 0-9717575-8-5}}</ref> to the point where pet dogs actively shape the way a family and home are experienced.<ref name=""Power"">{{Cite journal
column46: title= Furry Families: Making a Human-Dog Family through Home

column1: There have been two major trends in the changing status of pet dogs. The first has been the 'commodification' of the dog, shaping it to conform to human expectations of personality and behaviour.<ref name=""Power""/> The second has been the broadening of the concept of the family and the home to include dogs-as-dogs within everyday routines and practices.<ref name=""Power""/>
There are a vast range of commodity forms available to transform a pet dog into an ideal companion.<ref name=""Nast"">{{Cite journal
column5: title= Loving ... Whatever: Alienation, Neoliberalism and Pet-Love in the Twenty-First Century
column6: journal=ACME: an International E-Journal for Critical Geographies
column10: issn= 1492-9732}}</ref> The list of goods, services and places available is enormous: from dog perfumes, couture, furniture and housing, to dog groomers, therapists, trainers and caretakers, dog cafes, spas, parks and beaches, and dog hotels, airlines and cemeteries.<ref name=""Nast""/> While [[dog training]] as an organized activity can be traced back to the 18th century, in the last decades of the 20th century it became a high-profile issue as many normal [[dog behavior]]s such as barking, jumping up, digging, rolling in dung, fighting, and [[Spraying (animal behavior)
column11: urine marking]] (which dogs do to establish territory through scent), became increasingly incompatible with the new role of a pet dog.<ref name=""dogzone"">{{cite web
column13: title= A Brief History of Dog Training
column16: accessdate=19 February 2010}}</ref> Dog training books, classes and television programs proliferated as the process of commodifying the pet dog continued.<ref name=""Myths"">{{Cite journal
column19: title = Mythologies and Commodifications of Dominion in The Dog Whisperer with Cesar Millan

column1: The majority of contemporary people with dogs describe their pet as part of the family,<ref name=""Power"" /> although some ambivalence about the relationship is evident in the popular reconceptualization of the dog–human family as a pack.<ref name=""Power""/> A [[dominance (ethology)
column2: dominance]] model of dog–human relationships has been promoted by some dog trainers, such as on the television program ''[[Dog Whisperer]]''. However it has been disputed that ""trying to achieve status"" is characteristic of dog–human interactions.<ref name=""Bradshaw"">{{Cite journal
column9: title=Dominance in domestic dogs: useful construct or bad habit?
column21: df=dmy }}</ref> Pet dogs play an active role in family life; for example, a study of conversations in dog–human families showed how family members use the dog as a resource, talking to the dog, or talking through the dog, to mediate their interactions with each other.<ref name=""Tannen"">{{Cite journal
column26: title= Talking the Dog: Framing Pets as Interactional Resources in Family Discourse
column27: journal=Research on Language and Social Interaction

column1: Increasingly, human family members are engaging in activities centered on the perceived needs and interests of the dog, or in which the dog is an integral partner, such as [[Musical canine freestyle

According to statistics published by the [[American Pet Products Manufacturers Association]] in the National Pet Owner Survey in 2009–2010, it is estimated there are 77.5 million people with pet dogs in the United States.<ref>{{cite web
column4: accessdate=24 June 2010}}</ref> The same survey shows nearly 40% of American households own at least one dog, of which 67% own just one dog, 25% two dogs and nearly 9% more than two dogs. There does not seem to be any gender preference among dogs as pets, as the statistical data reveal an equal number of female and male dog pets. Yet, although several programs are ongoing to promote [[pet adoption]], less than a fifth of the owned dogs come from a shelter.

column1: The latest study using [[magnetic resonance imaging]] (MRI) comparing humans and dogs showed that dogs have same response to voices and use the same parts of the brain as humans do. This gives dogs the ability to recognize emotional human sounds, making them friendly social pets to humans.<ref>{{cite news
column3: title=Dogs and humans respond to voices in same way

column1: Dogs have lived and worked with humans in so many roles that they have earned the unique nickname, ""man's best friend"",<ref>{{cite web
column5: publisher=Cedarcroft Farm Bed & Breakfast — Warrensburg, MO
column9: df= }}</ref> a phrase used in other languages as well. They have been bred for herding livestock,<ref>{{Cite book
column16: location=Collingwood, Vic.}}</ref> hunting (e.g. pointers and hounds),<ref name=""serpell1995"">{{Cite book
column20: chapter=Origins of the dog: domestication and early history
column24: location=Cambridge}}</ref> rodent control,<ref name=""ADW"">Dewey, T. and S. Bhagat. 2002. ""[http://animaldiversity.ummz.umich.edu/site/accounts/information/Canis_lupus_familiaris.html Canis lupus familiaris] {{webarchive
column26: date=23 October 2014 }}"", Animal Diversity Web. Retrieved 6 January 2009.</ref> guarding, helping fishermen with nets, [[detection dog]]s, and pulling loads, in addition to their roles as companions.<ref name=""ADW""/> In 1957, a husky-terrier mix named [[Laika]] became the first animal to orbit the [[Earth]].<ref name=""sputnik"">{{cite web
column35: title=Russia fetes dog Laika, first earthling in space

column1: [[Service dog]]s such as [[guide dog]]s, utility dogs, assistance dogs, hearing dogs, and psychological therapy dogs provide assistance to individuals with physical or mental disabilities.<ref>{{cite web
column12: title=About Guide Dogs – Assistance Dogs International
column17: archivedate=12 December 2010 }}</ref> Some dogs owned by epileptics have been shown to alert their handler when the handler shows signs of an impending seizure, sometimes well in advance of onset, allowing the guardian to seek safety, medication, or medical care.<ref name=""seizure"">{{Cite journal
column18: vauthors=Dalziel DJ, Uthman BM, Mcgorray SP, Reep RL
column19: title=Seizure-alert dogs: a review and preliminary study

column1: Dogs included in human activities in terms of helping out humans are usually called [[Working Group (dogs)

column3: Dogs come in a range of sizes.]]

column1: People often enter their dogs in competitions<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=A Beginner's Guide to Dog Shows
column5: accessdate=30 October 2008}}</ref> such as breed-conformation shows or [[list of dog sports
column6: sports]], including racing, sledding and agility competitions.

column1: In conformation shows, also referred to as breed shows, a judge familiar with the specific dog breed evaluates individual purebred dogs for conformity with their established breed type as described in the breed standard. As the breed standard only deals with the externally observable qualities of the dog (such as appearance, movement, and temperament), separately tested qualities (such as ability or health) are not part of the judging in conformation shows.

column3: ''Gaegogi'' (dog meat) stew being served in a Korean restaurant]]

column1: Dog meat is consumed in some [[East Asian]] countries, including [[Korea]], [[China]]<ref name=""Wingfield-Hayes"">{{cite news
column7: date=29 June 2002}}</ref> and [[Vietnam]],<ref name=""Vietnam's dog meat tradition"">{{cite news
column11: date=31 December 2001}}</ref> a practice that dates back to antiquity.<ref>{{Cite book
column12: title=Eat not this flesh: food avoidances from prehistory to the present
column19: url=https://books.google.com/?id=JwGZTQunH00C&pg=PA208}}</ref> It is estimated that 13–16 million dogs are killed and consumed in Asia every year.<ref>{{cite web
column21: title=How many dogs and cats are eaten in Asia?
column27: df= }}</ref> Other cultures, such as [[Polynesia]] and [[pre-Columbian Mexico]], also consumed dog meat in their history. However, Western, South Asian, African, and Middle Eastern cultures, in general, regard consumption of dog meat as [[taboo food and drink
column28: taboo]]. In some places, however, such as in rural areas of Poland, dog fat is believed to have medicinal properties—being good for the lungs for instance.<ref>{{cite news
column32: title=Polish couple accused of making dog meat delicacy
column36: location=London}}</ref> Dog meat is also consumed in some parts of Switzerland.<ref>{{cite book
column44: isbn=0-8139-1162-1}}</ref>  Proponents of eating dog meat have argued that placing a distinction between livestock and dogs is western hypocrisy, and that there is no difference with eating the meat of different animals.<ref>{{cite web
column46: title=Wok The Dog – What's wrong with eating man's best friend?
column59: title='Do Koreans eat dogs?' and Western hypocrisy}}</ref><ref>{{cite web
column61: title=The Politics of Dog – When globalization and culinary practice clash

column1: In Korea, the primary dog breed raised for meat, the ''[[nureongi]]'' (누렁이), differs from those breeds raised for pets that Koreans may keep in their homes.<ref name=""pettid"">Pettid, Michael J., Korean Cuisine: An Illustrated History, London: Reaktion Books Ltd., 2008, 25. {{ISBN
The most popular Korean dog dish is ''[[bosintang
column2: gaejang-guk]]'' (also called ''bosintang''), a spicy stew meant to balance the body's heat during the summer months; followers of the custom claim this is done to ensure good health by balancing one's ''[[Qi
column3: gi]]'', or vital energy of the body. A 19th century version of ''gaejang-guk'' explains that the dish is prepared by boiling dog meat with [[scallion]]s and chili powder. Variations of the dish contain chicken and bamboo shoots. While the dishes are still popular in Korea with a segment of the population, dog is not as widely consumed as beef, chicken, and pork.<ref name=""pettid""/>

column1: In 2005, the [[WHO]] reported that 55,000 people died in Asia and Africa from rabies, a disease for which dogs are the most important vector.<ref>{{citation
column2: title=WHO expert consultation on rabies: First report

column1: Citing a 2008 study, the U.S. [[Center for Disease Control]] estimated in 2015 that 4.5 million people in the USA are bitten by dogs each year.<ref>{{cite web
column4: publisher=[[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]]
column14: author4=Kresnow, M.J.}}</ref> A 2015 study estimated that 1.8% of the U.S. population is bitten each year.<ref>{{cite journal
column16: title=Dog bites: how big a problem?

column5: page=53}}</ref> In the 1980s and 1990s the US averaged 17 fatalities per year, while in the 2000s this has increased to 26.<ref name= autogenerated1>{{cite web
column7: title=Statistics about dog bites in the USA and elsewhere
column9: accessdate=18 December 2012}}</ref> 77% of dog bites are from the pet of family or friends, and 50% of attacks occur on the property of the dog's legal owner.<ref name=autogenerated1/>

column1: A [[Colorado]] study found bites in children were less severe than bites in adults.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title= Study: Chihuahuas bite vets most; Lhaso Apsos inflict worst injuries
column8: accessdate= 15 February 2013}}</ref> The incidence of dog bites in the US is 12.9 per 10,000 inhabitants, but for boys aged 5 to 9, the incidence rate is 60.7 per 10,000. Moreover, children have a much higher chance to be bitten in the face or neck.<ref>{{Cite journal
column15: title=Incidence of dog bite injuries treated in emergency departments
column22: doi= 10.1001/jama.279.1.51}}</ref> Sharp claws with powerful muscles behind them can lacerate flesh in a scratch that can lead to serious infections.<ref>{{Cite journal
column29: title=Capnocytophaga canimorsus Mycotic Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm: Why the Mailman Is Afraid of Dogs

column1: In the UK between 2003 and 2004, there were 5,868 [[dog attack]]s on humans, resulting in 5,770 working days lost in sick leave.<ref>{{cite news
column3: title= Mail campaign over dog attacks

column1: In the [[Dogs in the United States
column2: United States]], [[cat]]s and dogs are a factor in more than 86,000 falls each year.<ref>{{Cite news
column5: publisher=Northwest Territories Health and Social Services
column11: df= }}</ref> It has been estimated around 2% of dog-related injuries treated in UK hospitals are domestic accidents. The same study found that while dog involvement in road traffic accidents was difficult to quantify, dog-associated road accidents involving injury more commonly involved two-wheeled vehicles.<ref>{{Cite journal

column1: ''[[Toxocara canis]]'' (dog [[roundworm]]) eggs in dog feces can cause [[toxocariasis]]. In the United States, about 10,000 cases of ''Toxocara'' infection are reported in humans each year, and almost 14% of the U.S. population is infected.<ref>{{cite web
column10: accessdate= 15 February 2013}}</ref> In Great Britain, 24% of soil samples taken from public parks contained ''T. canis'' eggs.<ref name= kidshealth>{{cite web
column18: reason=No percentages given}} Untreated toxocariasis can cause retinal damage and decreased vision.<ref name=kidshealth /> Dog feces can also contain [[hookworm]]s that cause [[cutaneous larva migrans]] in humans.<ref>{{Cite news
column19: title=Parasites in pet feces cause puzzling infections
column30: title=Related factors to human toxocariasis in a rural community of Argentina
column57: title= Human toxocariasis: A report of 3 cases
column58: work= Pakistan Journal of Medical Sciences Quarterly

column3: alt=Small dog laying between the hands

column1: The scientific evidence is mixed as to whether companionship of a dog can enhance human physical health and psychological wellbeing.<ref name=""Pet ownership and human health: a brief review of evidence and issues"">{{cite journal
column3: title=Pet ownership and human health: A brief review of evidence and issues
column22: pmc=1289326}}</ref> Studies suggesting that there are benefits to physical health and psychological wellbeing<ref>{{Cite journal
column26: title=Positive and Negative Aspects of Our Relationship with Companion Animals
column31: doi=10.1007/s11259-006-0005-0}}</ref> have been criticised for being poorly controlled,<ref name=""Health effects of ownership of and attachment to companion animals in an older population"">{{cite journal
column33: title=Health effects of ownership of and attachment to companion animals in an older population
column45: pmid=19005930}}</ref> and finding that ""[t]he health of elderly people is related to their health habits and social supports but not to their ownership of, or attachment to, a companion animal."" Earlier studies have shown that people who keep pet dogs or cats exhibit better mental and physical health than those who do not, making fewer visits to the doctor and being less likely to be on medication than non-guardians.<ref>{{Cite journal
column48: title = Health benefits and health cost savings due to pets: preliminary estimates from an Australian national survey

column1: A 2005 paper states ""recent research has failed to support earlier findings that pet ownership is associated with a reduced risk of cardiovascular disease, a reduced use of general practitioner services, or any psychological or physical benefits on health for community dwelling older people. Research has, however, pointed to significantly less absenteeism from school through sickness among children who live with pets.""<ref name=""Pet ownership and human health: a brief review of evidence and issues""/> In one study, new guardians reported a highly significant reduction in minor health problems during the first month following pet acquisition, and this effect was sustained in those with dogs through to the end of the study.<ref name=""autogenerated717"">{{cite journal
column3: title=Beneficial effects of pet ownership on some aspects of human health and behaviour
column4: journal=Journal of the Royal Society of Medicine

column1: In addition, people with pet dogs took considerably more physical exercise than those with cats and those without pets. The results provide evidence that keeping pets may have positive effects on human health and behaviour, and that for guardians of dogs these effects are relatively long-term.<ref name=""autogenerated717""/> Pet guardianship has also been associated with increased coronary artery disease survival, with human guardians being significantly less likely to die within one year of an acute myocardial infarction than those who did not own dogs.<ref>{{Cite journal
column3: title=Pet ownership, social support, and one-year survival after acute myocardial infarction in the Cardiac Arrhythmia Suppression Trial (CAST)

column1: The health benefits of dogs can result from contact with dogs in general, and not solely from having dogs as pets. For example, when in the presence of a pet dog, people show reductions in cardiovascular, behavioral, and psychological indicators of anxiety.<ref>{{Cite journal
column4: title=The pet as an anxiolytic intervention
column5: journal=The Journal of Nervous and Mental Disease
column10: pmid=1856711}}</ref> Other health benefits are gained from exposure to immune-stimulating microorganisms, which, according to the [[hygiene hypothesis]], can protect against allergies and autoimmune diseases. The benefits of contact with a dog also include social support, as dogs are able to not only provide companionship and social support themselves, but also to act as facilitators of social interactions between humans.<ref>{{Cite book
column15: chapter=Animals as social supports: Insights for understanding animal assisted therapy
column17: title=Handbook on animal-assisted therapy: theoretical foundations and guidelines for practice
column22: isbn=0-12-369484-1}}</ref> One study indicated that wheelchair users experience more positive social interactions with strangers when they are accompanied by a dog than when they are not.<ref>{{Cite journal
column23: vauthors=Eddy J, Hart LA, Boltz RP
column24: title=The effects of service dogs on social acknowledgments of people in wheelchairs
column31: doi=10.1080/00223980.1988.10542941}}</ref> In 2015, a study found that pet owners were significantly more likely to get to know people in their neighborhood than non-pet owners.<ref>{{cite journal
column36: title=The Pet Factor – Companion Animals as a Conduit for Getting to Know People, Friendship Formation and Social Support

column1: The practice of using dogs and other animals as a part of therapy dates back to the late 18th century, when animals were introduced into mental institutions to help socialize patients with mental disorders.<ref>Kruger, K.A. & Serpell, J.A. (2006). Animal-assisted interventions in mental health: Definitions and theoretical foundations, In Fine, A.H. (Ed.), Handbook on animal-assisted therapy: Theoretical foundations and guidelines for practice. San Diego, CA, Academic Press: 21–38. {{ISBN
column2: 0-12-369484-1}}</ref> Animal-assisted intervention research has shown that animal-assisted therapy with a dog can increase social behaviors, such as smiling and laughing, among people with Alzheimer's disease.<ref>{{Cite book
column7: chapter=The effect of a therapy dog on socialization and psychological indicators of stress in persons diagnosed with Alzheimer's disease
column15: isbn=978-0-7619-1061-9}}</ref> One study demonstrated that children with ADHD and conduct disorders who participated in an education program with dogs and other animals showed increased attendance, increased knowledge and skill objectives, and decreased antisocial and violent behavior compared with those who were not in an animal-assisted program.<ref>{{Cite book
column18: chapter=The Centaur's Lessons: Therapeutic education through care of animals and nature study
column20: title=Handbook on animal-assisted therapy: theoretical foundations and guidelines for practice

column1: Medical detection dogs are capable of detecting diseases by sniffing a person directly or samples of urine or other specimens. Dogs can detect odour in one part per trillion, as their brain's olfactory cortex is (relative to total brain size) 40 times larger than humans. Dogs may have as many as 300 million odour receptors in their nose, while humans may have only 5 million. Each dog is trained specifically for the detection of single disease from the blood glucose level indicative to diabetes to cancer. The process of training a cancer dog requires six months. A [[Labrador Retriever]] called Daisy has detected 551 cancer patients with an accuracy of 93 percent and received the [[Blue Cross (animal charity)
column2: Blue Cross]] (for pets) Medal for her life-saving skills.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=How my dog sniffed out breast cancer and saved my lifeYYY
column8: title=Medal for the heroic dog who sniffed out her owner's cancer: Daisy the Labrador has helped find disease in 551 patients

column1: Every year, between 6 and 8 million dogs and cats enter US [[animal shelter]]s.<ref>[http://www.thestar.com/News/World/article/557223 Animals abandoned as recession hits home] {{webarchive
column3: date=7 June 2011 }}. TheStar.com. 22 December 2008.</ref> The [[Humane Society of the United States]] (HSUS) estimates that approximately 3 to 4 million of those dogs and cats are [[Animal euthanasia
column4: euthanized]] yearly in the United States.<ref>[http://www.humanesociety.org/issues/pet_overpopulation/facts/overpopulation_estimates.html HSUS Pet Overpopulation Estimates] {{webarchive
column6: date=25 April 2013 }} The Humane Society of the United States</ref> However, the percentage of dogs in US animal shelters that are eventually adopted and removed from the shelters by their new legal owners has increased since the mid-1990s from around 25% to a 2012 average of 40% among reporting shelters<ref>{{cite web
column9: accessdate=8 August 2012}}</ref> (with many shelters reporting 60–75%).<ref>{{Cite book
column12: title=Purebred Rescue Dog Adoption: Rewards and Realities

column1: Dogs have been viewed and represented in different manners by different cultures and religions, over the course of history.
In mythology, dogs often serve as pets or as watchdogs.<ref name=""Sherman2008"">{{cite book
column3: title=Storytelling: An Encyclopedia of Mythology and Folklore

column1: In [[Greek mythology]], [[Cerberus]] is a three-headed watchdog who guards the gates of [[Hades]].<ref name=""Sherman2008""/> In [[Norse mythology]], a bloody, four-eyed dog called [[Garmr]] guards [[Helheim]].<ref name=""Sherman2008""/> In [[Persian mythology]], two four-eyed dogs guard the [[Chinvat Bridge]].<ref name=""Sherman2008""/> In [[Philippine mythology]], Kimat who is the pet of [[Tadaklan]], god of thunder, is responsible for lightning. In [[Welsh mythology]], [[Annwn]] is guarded by [[Cŵn Annwn]].<ref name=""Sherman2008""/>
In [[Hindu mythology]], [[Yama]], the god of death owns two watch dogs who have four eyes. They are said to watch over the gates of [[Naraka]].<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Indian Myth and Legend: Chapter III. Yama, the First Man, and King of the Dead
column5: accessdate=4 July 2013}}</ref> Hunter god [[Muthappan]] from [[North Malabar]] region of [[Kerala]] has a hunting dog as his mount. Dogs are found in and out of the [[Muthappan Temple]] and offerings at the shrine take the form of bronze dog figurines.<ref>{{cite book
column7: title=Fodor's Essential India: with Delhi, Rajasthan, Mumbai, and Kerala

column1: The role of the [[dog in Chinese mythology]] includes a position as one of the twelve animals which cyclically represent years (the [[Dog (zodiac)

column2: epic poem]] the ''[[Odyssey]]'', when the disguised [[Odysseus]] returns home after 20 years he is recognized only by his faithful dog, [[Argos (dog)
column3: Argos]], who has been waiting for his return.

column1: In Islam, dogs are viewed as unclean because they are viewed as [[scavenger]]s.<ref name=""Sherman2008"" />
[[Jewish law]] does not prohibit keeping dogs and other pets.<ref name=""jewishvirtuallibrary.org"">{{cite web
column4: work=Jewish Virtual Library}}</ref> Jewish law requires Jews to feed dogs (and other animals that they own) before themselves, and make arrangements for feeding them before obtaining them.<ref name=""jewishvirtuallibrary.org""/> In Christianity, dogs represent faithfulness.<ref name=""Sherman2008""/>

column1: In China, Korea, and Japan, dogs are viewed as kind protectors.<ref name=""Sherman2008""/>

column2: Cultural depictions of dogs in Western art}}

column1: Cultural depictions of dogs in art extend back thousands of years to when dogs were portrayed on the walls of caves. Representations of dogs became more elaborate as individual breeds evolved and the relationships between human and canine developed. [[Hunting]] scenes were popular in the [[Middle Ages]] and the [[Renaissance]]. Dogs were depicted to symbolize guidance, protection, loyalty, fidelity, faithfulness, watchfulness, and love.<ref>{{cite web
