'''Canine Efficiency'''<ref>[http://www.canineefficiency.com Canine Efficiency]</ref> is a [[non-profit organisation]] initiated in 2013 and developed out of various similar project activities since 2009. Canine Efficiency focusses on effective, non lethal conflict prevention between pedators and humans through the correct use of good livestock guard dogs (LGDs) instead interference by humans. Canine Efficiency aims for the most efficient use of dogs within their utility purpose. Nature and dogs are closely connected.
[[Nature conservation]] has many facets and various specialities, including correct implementation of LGDs. Canine Efficiency works especially with [[Carpathian Shepherd Dog
column2: Ciobanesc Romanesc Carpatin]] dogs in Romania.

column1: Canine Efficiency (internationally) works to help shepherds and livestock farmers to start or improve a responsible LGD situation, resulting in livestock being safe from various threats in a sustainable, non lethal and effictive way.
In addition Canine Efficiency writes articles, aiming to educate stakeholders regarding LGDs, coexistence and responsible predator conflict prevention.

'''Dog Parker''' is a membership based pay-by-the-minute [[doghouse]] service launched in a private pilot program in [[Brooklyn, NY]] in October 2015. The company <ref name=""The New York Post"">{{cite web
column3: title=You can now pay to ‘park’ your pup
column5: accessdate=3 June 2016}}</ref> plans to install dog houses across [[New York City]], as well as other locations across the US.<ref name=""FOX5NY"">{{cite web

column1: In November of 2016, Dog Parker announced the release of their new model that would be installed in various Brooklyn neighborhoods. <ref name=""Dog Parker Press Release"">{{cite web
Dog Parker to Release New Model
column3: accessdate=22 November 2016}}</ref> The new model contains an internet-connected webcam that users can view their dog with. Members use either the app or a membership card to lock and unlock the Dog Parker. Dog Parkers are also fitted with a UVC sanitation light, which handles surface level cleaning of the Dog Parker between daily maintenance visits. <ref name=""Tech Crunch"">{{cite web

column1: Dog Parker, because even your dogs deserve a smart home
column3: accessdate=22 November 2016}}</ref> The membership works similar to services such as [[Car2Go]].<ref name=""The Washington Post"">{{cite web

column1: Would you park your dog in a locker while you eat brunch?
Dog Parker was founded by Chelsea Brownridge and Todd Schechter in 2015 and completed the Entrepreneurs Roundtable Accelerator in NYC in 2016. <ref name=""Dog Parker Press Release"">{{cite web
Dog Parker to Release New Model
[[Category:Buildings and structures used to confine animals]]

column4: A Full Grown Greater Swiss Mountain Dog]]

column1: A '''drafting dog''' or '''draft dog''' is a dog bred and used for cart pulling. Dogs bred for this work have strong builds. All drafting dogs have the qualities that are needed, strength and determination. Draft Dogs are in the [[Molosser
column2: Molosser breed group]] which are dogs that are solidly-built, strong dogs some Molossers are medium and others are large. Larger mountain dogs pulled larger carts. While smaller ones pulled smaller carts<ref>{{Cite web
column4: title=Breeds Who Enjoy Drafting Just for the Haul of it

column1: These dogs are some of the working dogs known for drafting work. Like the four [[Swiss mountain dog]]s, they were used for pulling carts. The size of the cart matched the size of the dog.
Examples of dogs used to pull larger carts include:
Examples of dogs used to pull smaller carts:

Large draft dogs like the [[Bernese Mountain Dog]] and [[Greater Swiss Mountain Dog]] are known for their large size. But all four Swiss Mountain Dogs are known for their coat color tricolor the combination of black white and brown. The smallest  of the four Swiss Mountain Dogs is the Entlebucher Mountain Dog usually weighing between 20 and 30 kg (44–66 lb). Next up in size is the Appenzeller Mountain Dog weighing between 22 and 32 kg (48–70 lb). The second largest is the Bernese Mountain Dog the female weight is usually 36–48 kg 80–105 lbs. while the male weight is usually 39–50 kg (85–110 lb). The Largest is the Greater Swiss Mountain Dog. Female Greater Swiss Mountain Dogs are usually between 50 and 60 kg (110 and 132 lb). Males are usually between 60 and 70 kg (132–154 lb). The St Bernard's appearance is similar to the [[Moscow Watchdog]]s appearance. The two breeds come in the White & Red Color. While the original St Bernard was short haired today there are no long haired varieties. The long coat was important in improving the warmth of the St Bernard coat by breeding them with the [[Newfoundland (dog)

The Greater Swiss Mountain Dog,  Bernese Mountain Dog, and Rottweiler have personalities that are closely matched. They were watchdogs so the Greater Swiss Mountain Dog and Rottweiler are cautious with strangers yet if socialized with them the dog will like them better. All dog breeds need early socialization and [[Dog training
column2: training]]. All breeds can be gentle and stable if trained and socialized properly. Bernese Mountain Dogs were likely watchdogs. They are not aggressive. The Bernese Mountain Dog tends to be gentle and friendly. The St Bernard is gentle and loves people. However, like all dog breeds, Bernard's need early socialization and training to avoid issues. These dogs are not the best for the novice dog owner.

column1: '''The Indian National Kennel Club''' (INKC) is a registry of Purebred Dogs in India. Beyond maintaining its pedigree registry, this kennel club also promotes and sanctions events for purebred dogs, including Dog Shows and  Specialty Shows.
The Indian National Kennel Club was established on 21 March 1957 to promote proper breeding, rearing and training of dogs.

The Indian National Kennel Club is the leading authority on registration on purebreds and maintains the recognized registry. It issues Pedigrees for purebreds and litters. It hosts annual shows across the country and awards championships to various breeds of dogs.
The President of the INKC is H. H. [[Maharana Mahipendra Singh]] of [[Danta, Banaskantha
column3: Mrs. Ratty P. Javeri]] is the Secretary and Founder Member of the Organization.<ref name=""INKC Team"">{{cite web

column1: The Indian National Kennel Club registers litters of puppies whose Sire and Dam have both been registered with the The Indian National Kennel Club and The Kennel Club of India. The INKC also registers puppies/dogs which have been imported from other countries. Finally the INKC also registers puppies/dogs which are purebred but whose parents do not carry any papers. These dogs are registered as purebreds with '''Unknown Pedigree'''.

Pedigree Papers (Certificates) are issued by the INKC and is continuously appended as the dog keeps winning championships or keeps changing owners. Pedigree papers are very important as it provides the lineage and keeps peddling<ref name=""Peddling Pedigree"">{{cite web
column4: accessdate=5 February 2017}}</ref> of pedigreed dogs at bay.

column1: The most common registered breeds with the INKC include: [[Labrador Retriever]]s, [[Golden Retriever]]s, [[German Shepherd Dog]]s, [[Dachshund]]s, [[Doberman Pinscher]]s and [[Pug]]s. Along with the common breeds, Indian National Kennel Club also registers the [[Mudhol hound]].<ref name=""Mudhol Hound"">{{cite web

Speciality and General Dog Shows are conducted by the Indian National Kennel Club all over the country. These shows are generally held from October to May every year. The show follows procedures and guidelines set by the Indian National Kennel Club.

Dogs are issued [[Challenge Certificates]] and [[Championship Certificates]]. Dogs are awarded points (depending on their breed and temperament) in every dog show and at the end of the year - the dog receiving the most show points receives the Dog of the Year award.
[[Best in Class]], [[Best of Breed]], [[Best in Group]], [[Conformation show
INKC organizes an event<ref name=""Prakruti"">{{cite web
column4: accessdate=23 January 2015}}</ref> in the Prakruti festival in Bhavan's College, Andheri, Mumbai every year on animal petting and dog shows.

column1: In addition to General Dog Shows, the INKC also organizes Specialty Dog Shows. This include Fancy Dress for Dogs. They also arrange Doggie Dates<ref name=""Doggie Dates"">{{cite web
column4: accessdate=13 December 2016}}</ref> for dogs which helps the owner to find a suitable mate for their dog.

column24: source=Yong-Geun Ann (1999)<ref>Ann Yong-Geun [http://wolf.ok.ac.kr/~annyg/report/r2.htm ""Dog Meat Foods in Korea""], Table 4. Composition of dog meat and Bosintang (in 100g, raw meat), ''Korean Journal of Food and Nutrition'' 12(4) 397 – 408 (1999).</ref>}}

column1: '''Dog meat''' is the flesh and other edible parts derived from [[dog]]s. Historically, human consumption of dog meat has been recorded in many parts of the world, including [[East Asia
column2: East]] and [[Southeast Asia]], [[West Africa]], [[Europe]], [[Oceania]] and the [[Americas]].<ref name=schwabe1979p168>{{cite book
column11: ref=harv}}</ref> In the 21st century, dog meat is consumed in many parts of [[China]],<ref name=""Wingfield-Hayes"">{{cite news
column20: title=Good to Pet and Eat: The Keeping and Consuming of Dogs and in South Korea
column27: quote='Dog meat is eaten nationwide and all year round, although it is most commonly eaten during summer, especially on the (supposedly) three hottest days.

column1: Today, some cultures view the consumption of dog meat as part of their traditional and day-to-day [[cuisine]], while other cultures consider consumption of dog meat a [[food taboo
column2: taboo]], although they have been consumed in times of war or other hardships.<ref name=Times1940/><ref name=Mawson/> It was estimated in 2014 that worldwide, 25 million dogs are eaten each year by humans.<ref name=""Cz"" />

column1: In 2017, Taiwan became the first Asian country to ban the consumption of dog and cat meat - previously, the legislation had covered only the slaughter and sale of these meats.  Those convicted of eating dog or cat meat can be fined between $1,640 and $8,200.<ref name=CNN2017>{{cite web
column6: title=Taiwan bans eating dog and cat meat

column2: 누렁이}}) is a yellowish [[landrace]] from [[Korea]].  Similar to other native Korean dog breeds, such as the [[Jindo (dog)
column3: Jindo]], nureongi are medium-sized [[spitz]]-type dogs, but are larger with greater musculature and a distinctive coat pattern. They are quite uniform in appearance, yellow hair and [[melanistic mask]]s.  Nureongi are most often used as a [[livestock]] dog, raised for its meat, and not commonly kept as pets.<ref name=""Morris Dogs pp. 585-586"">{{cite book
column5: title= Dogs: The Ultimate Dictionary of Over 1,000 Dog Breeds

column1: The '''Hawaiian Poi Dog''' or ''ʻīlio'' (''ʻīlio mākuʻe'' for brown-furred Poi dogs) is an [[:Category:Extinct dog breeds
column3: Hawai{{okina}}i]] which was used by [[Native Hawaiian]]s as a spiritual protector of children and as a source of food.<ref name=""Titcomb 1969"">{{cite book
column7: title=Dog and Man in the Ancient Pacific
column9: publisher=Bernice P. Bishop Museum Special Publication 59

column1: The '''Tahitian Dog''' or ''ʻūrī Mā’ohi'' were a food source, and served by high ranking chiefs to the early European explorers who visited the islands. Captain [[James Cook]] and his crew developed a taste for the dog, with Cook noting, ""For tame Animals they have Hogs, Fowls, and Dogs, the latter of which we learned to Eat from them, and few were there of us but what allow'd that a South Sea dog was next to an English Lamb.""<ref name=""Salmond2003"">{{cite book
column4: title=The Trial of the Cannibal Dog: The Remarkable Story of Captain Cook's Encounters in the South Seas
column12: title=Sciences of Antiquity: Romantic Antiquarianism, Natural History, and Knowledge Work
column23: title=Feasting and Fasting with Lewis & Clark: A Food and Social History of the Early 1800's

column1: The '''Xoloitzcuintle''', or '''Xolo''' for short, is a hairless [[breed]] of [[dog]], found in toy, miniature and standard sizes.The Xolo also comes in a coated variety and all three sizes can be born to a single litter.   It is also known as '''Mexican hairless dog''' in English speaking countries, is one of several breeds of [[hairless dog]] and has been used as a historical source of food for the [[Aztec Empire]].<ref name=""About THE XOLOITZCUINTLE"">[https://web.archive.org/web/20120719044113/http://www.xolorescueusa.org/about.html About THE XOLOITZCUINTLE] (archived from [http://www.xolorescueusa.org/about.html the original] on 2012-07-19), [https://web.archive.org/web/20120714064639/http://www.xolorescueusa.org/ Xolo Rescue USA] (archived from [http://www.xolorescueusa.org/ the original] on 2012-07-14).</ref>

In 2015, '''The Korea Observer'' reported that many different pet breeds of dog are eaten in South Korea, including labradors, retrievers and cocker spaniels, and that the dogs slaughtered for their meat may include former pets.<ref name=""Hyams"">{{cite news
column4: title=Former pets slaughtered for dog meat across Korea

column2: Vame]] people, domestic dogs are only eaten for specific rituals.<ref>Eric Thys & Olivier Nyssens ''Préparation et commercialisation de la viande canine chez les Vamé Mbrémé population animiste des monts Mandara.'' in ""Tropical Animal Production for the Benefit of Man. Antwerp, 1982, pp. 511–517.</ref>

column1: Despite tests showing 156 dogs were infected with [[Ebola]], the consumption of dog meat is no longer taboo.<ref>{{cite web

The [[Tallensi]], the Akyims, the Kokis, and the Yaakuma, one of many cultures of Ghana, consider dog meat a delicacy. While the [[Mamprusi]] generally avoid dog meat, it is eaten in a ""courtship stew"" provided by a king to his royal lineage. Two Tribes in Ghana, [[Frafra people
column2: Frafra]] and [[Dagaaba]] are particularly known to be ""tribal playmates"" and consumption of dog meat is the common bond between the two tribes. Every year around September, games are organised between these two tribes and the Dog Head is the trophy at stake for the winning tribe.<ref name=simoons1994p229>{{Cite book
column3: title=Eat not this flesh: food avoidances from prehistory to the present

column1: Islamic law bans the eating of dog meat as does the government of Morocco. However, the consumption of dog meat still occurs particularly in poorer regions, often being passed off as other meats as was the situation in 2013 and 2009 cases.<ref name=""Morocco"">{{cite web
column7: title=Dog meat sausage scandal grips Morocco as owners fight law banning aggressive breeds}}</ref>

column1: Dogs are eaten by various groups in some states of Nigeria, including Ondo State, Akwa Ibom, Cross River, Plateau, Kalaba, Taraba and Gombe of Nigeria.<ref name=simoons1994p229/> They are believed to have medicinal powers.<ref>{{cite news
column4: title=Dog's dinners prove popular in Nigeria
column10: title=""Man bites dog"": Dining on dog meat in Nigeria

column1: In late 2014, the fear of contracting the [[Ebola virus disease]] from [[bushmeat]] led at least one major Nigerian newspaper to imply that eating dog meat was a healthy alternative.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=EBOLA: Jos residents shun bush meat, stick to dog meat
column10: df= }}</ref>  That paper documented a thriving trade in dog meat and slow sales of even well smoked bushmeat.

column1: It is legal to sell and serve dog meat provided that it is killed and gutted in front of [[Canadian Food Inspection Agency
column4: title=Canine carcasses at Edmonton restaurant were coyotes
column7: accessdate=2007-04-19}}</ref> If a dog is killed out of the view of federal inspectors, the killing might involve cruelty, which would violate the [[Criminal Code (Canada)
column8: Criminal Code]], and those convicted may be sentenced to up to 5 years in prison.<ref>{{cite web
column10: title=LEGAL GUIDE: ANIMALS AND THE CRIMINAL LAW (CANADA) – Ch. 6 Penalties

column1: In the time of the [[Aztec Empire]] in what is now central Mexico, [[Mexican Hairless Dog]]s were bred, among other purposes,<ref name=""About THE XOLOITZCUINTLE""/> for their meat. [[Hernán Cortés]] reported when he arrived in [[Tenochtitlan]] in 1519, ""small gelded dogs which they breed for eating"" were among the goods sold in the city markets.<ref>{{cite book
column10: location=New Haven}}</ref> These dogs, ''[[Xoloitzcuintle]]s'', were often depicted in [[pre-Columbian]] Mexican pottery. The breed was almost extinct in the 1940s, but the British Military Attaché in Mexico City, Norman Wright, developed a thriving breed from some of the dogs he found in remote villages.<ref>{{Cite journal

column1: Reports of families eating dog meat out of choice, rather than necessity, were rare and newsworthy. Stories of families in Ohio and Newark, New Jersey who did so made it into editions of ''The New York Times'' in 1876 and 1885.<ref name=nytimes1885>{{cite web
column6: title=A family living on dog meat

column1: In the early 20th century, dog meat was consumed during times of meat shortage.<ref name=nytimes1904>{{cite web

The traditional culture surrounding the consumption of dog meat varied from [[tribe]] to tribe among the original inhabitants of North America, with some tribes relishing it as a [[delicacy]], and others (such as the [[Comanche]]) treating it as a forbidden food.<ref>{{cite web
column9: archivedate=March 18, 2012 }} (archived from [http://www.nativeradio.com/jworley/column4.cfm the original] on 2012-03-18)</ref> Native peoples of the [[Great Plains]], such as the [[Sioux]] and [[Cheyenne]], consumed it, but there was a concurrent religious [[taboo]] against the meat of wild canines.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20060925225102/http://www.westonaprice.org/traditional_diets/native_americans.html Guts and Grease: The Diet of Native Americans] (archived from [http://www.westonaprice.org/traditional_diets/native_americans.html the original] on 2006-09-25)</ref>

column1: During their 1803–1806 expedition, [[Meriwether Lewis]] and the other members of the [[Corps of Discovery]] consumed dog meat, either from their own animals or supplied by [[Native Americans in the United States
column2: Native American]] tribes, including the [[Paiute]]s and Wah-clel-lah Indians, a branch of the [[Watlata]]s,<ref>{{cite web
column24: accessdate=2012-10-24}}</ref><!--still not sure which tribe introduced them to dog meat, maybe someone can find out--> Lewis and the members of the expedition ate dog meat, except [[William Clark (explorer)
column25: William Clark]], who reportedly could not bring himself to eat dogs.<ref>{{cite web
column27: title=Sex, Dog Meat, and the Lash: Odd Facts About Lewis and Clark
column33: title=Food History Almanac: Over 1,300 Years of World Culinary History, Culture, and Social Influence

column1: The [[Kickapoo people]] include puppy meat in many of their traditional festivals.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=QxlElGfSlvQC&pg=PA339#v=onepage&f=false The Mexican Kickapoo Indians] Felipe A. Latorre and Dolores L. Latorre (1976).</ref> This practice has been well documented in the [[Works Progress Administration]] ""Indian Pioneer History Project for Oklahoma"".<ref>[https://digital.libraries.ou.edu/cdm/ref/collection/indianpp/id/7256 WPA Indian Pioneer History Project for Oklahoma] Ed Cooley (July 29, 1937)</ref><ref>[https://digital.libraries.ou.edu/cdm/ref/collection/indianpp/id/7330 WPA Indian Pioneer History Project for Oklahoma] Albert Couch (October 12, 1937)</ref>

In most states and territories it is not an offence to eat cats and dogs. South Australia is the only state which definitively prohibits the consumption of meat derived from a cat or dog, including the killing of a cat or dog for such purpose. However, it is illegal to sell dog meat in any Australian State or Territory.<ref>{{cite web
column2: title=Is eating cats or dogs legal?
column4: website=Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals

column1: British explorer [[Ernest Shackleton]] and his [[Imperial Trans-Antarctic Expedition]] became trapped, and ultimately killed their sled dogs for food. Norwegian explorer [[Roald Amundsen]] was known to have eaten sled dogs during his expedition to the South Pole. By eating some of the sled dogs, he required less human or dog food, thus lightening his load.<ref name=southpole /> When comparing sled dogs to ponies as draught animals he also notes:

<blockquote>there is the obvious advantage that dog can be fed on dog. One can reduce one's pack little by little, slaughtering the feebler ones and feeding the chosen with them. In this way they get fresh meat. Our dogs lived on dog's flesh and [[pemmican]] the whole way, and this enabled them to do splendid work. And if we ourselves wanted a piece of fresh meat we could cut off a delicate little fillet; it tasted to us as good as the best beef. The dogs do not object at all; as long as they get their share they do not mind what part of their comrade's carcass it comes from. All that was left after one of these canine meals was the teeth of the victim – and if it had been a really hard day, these also disappeared.<ref name=southpole >{{cite web
[[Douglas Mawson]] and [[Xavier Mertz]] were part of the [[Far Eastern Party]], a three-man sledging team with [[Belgrave Edward Sutton Ninnis
column2: Lieutenant B.E.S. Ninnis]], to survey King George V Land, Antarctica. On 14 December 1912 Ninnis fell through a snow-covered crevasse along with most of the party's rations, and was never seen again. Mawson and Mertz turned back immediately. They had one and a half weeks' food for themselves and nothing at all for the dogs. Their meagre provisions forced them to eat their remaining sled dogs on their {{convert
column6: adj=on}} return journey. Their meat was tough, stringy and without a vestige of fat. Each animal yielded very little, and the major part was fed to the surviving dogs, which ate the meat, skin and bones until nothing remained. The men also ate the dog's brains and livers. Unfortunately eating the liver of sled dogs produces the condition [[hypervitaminosis A]] because canines have a much higher tolerance for vitamin A than humans do. Mertz suffered a quick deterioration. He developed stomach pains and became incapacitated and incoherent. On 7 January 1913, Mertz died. Mawson continued alone, eventually making it back to camp alive.<ref name=""Mawson"">{{cite web

column4: Dogs being butchered in Guangdong, China]]
A platter of cooked dog meat in [[Guilin]], China]]

column1: Although consuming dog meat is not illegal in [[mainland China]], Chinese Ministry of Agriculture has never issued quarantine procedures for slaughtering dogs.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=农业部关于印发《生猪屠宰检疫规程》等4个动物检疫规程的通知
column6: title=畜禽屠宰卫生检疫规范(NY 467-2001)
column11: pages=3–4}}</ref> Besides, selling dog meat as food is against Food Safety Law of the People's Republic of China. According to the Animal Epidemic Prevention Law of the People’s Republic of China (2013 Amendment), dogs need to be vaccinated. But dogs for eating are not vaccinated, so those are illegal to be transported or sold. Still, approximately 10 million dogs each year were slaughtered for consumption.<ref name=""Independent2015b"">{{cite journal
column13: title=Yulin Dog Meat Festival: Netizens rally in defence of event that will see 10,000 cats and dogs slaughtered
column19: title=Yulin dog meat festival: Chinese city retains its appetite despite months of protests
column23: url=http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/asia/yulin-dog-meat-festival-china-retains-appetite-despite-protests-10337679.html}}</ref> The eating of dog meat in China dates back thousands of years.  Dog meat ({{zh
column25: p=gǒu ròu}}) has been a source of food in some areas from around 500 BC and possibly even earlier. It has been suggested that wolves in southern China may have been domesticated as a source of meat.<ref name=NYT2009>{{cite news
column28: title=In Taming Dogs, Humans May Have Sought a Meal
column32: date=7 September 2009}}</ref> [[Mencius]], the philosopher, talked about dog meat as being an edible, dietary meat.<ref>{{Cite book
column34: title=Ya she xiao pin xuan ji
column39: url=https://books.google.com/?id=UMZdQT_FyHAC&pg=PA144}} Translated by Ta-tsun Chen.</ref> It is thought to have medicinal properties, and is especially popular in winter months in northern China, as it is believed to raise body temperature after consumption and promote warmth.<ref>{{Cite book
column42: title=Food in China: a cultural and historical inquiry
column56: title = Dog meat row hits HK chain
column59: date=4 August 2002}}</ref> Historical records have moreover shown how in times of food scarcities (as in war-time situations), dogs could also be eaten as an emergency food source.<ref>{{Cite book
column62: title=The Nanking atrocity, 1937–38: complicating the picture

column1: Dog meat is sometimes called ""fragrant meat"" (香肉 ''xiāng ròu'') or ""mutton of the earth"" (地羊 ''dì yáng'') in [[Standard Mandarin
column4: cy=''sàam luhk hèung yuhk''}}) in [[Standard Cantonese
column5: Cantonese]] (3 plus 6 is 9 and the words ""nine"" and ""dog"" have close pronunciation. In Mandarin, ""nine"" and ""dog"" are pronounced differently).

column1: In modern times, the extent of dog consumption in China varies by region, most prevalent in Guangdong, Yunnan and Guangxi, as well as the northern provinces of Heilongjiang, Jilin and Liaoning.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=How many cats & dogs are eaten in Asia? AP 9.03
column4: work=animalpeoplenews.org}}</ref> It is still common to find dog meat served in restaurants in Southern China, where dogs are specially raised on farms. However, there are instances of finding stolen pet meat on menus.<ref>{{cite web
column6: title=Inside the cat and dog meat market in China
column9: title=Pets snatched and butchered for food – Global Times
column10: work=globaltimes.cn}}</ref>  Chinese [[netizen]]s and the Chinese police intercepted trucks transporting caged dogs to be slaughtered in localities such as [[Chongqing]] and [[Kunming]].<ref>{{cite web
column11: title='Tech-savvy citizen rescues 69 dogs from becoming dinner'
column16: archivedate=November 24, 2012 }}</ref>  In 2014, 11 people in the [[Hunan]] province were sentenced to prison for allegedly poisoning over 1,000 dogs and selling the poisonous meat to restaurants.<ref name=""Gabriel2014"">{{cite web
column18: title=Enlightened Chinese public condemns dog meat consumption

column4: Prepared and cooked dog ready for purchase]]

column1: Since 2009,<ref name=""O'Neil"" /> [[Yulin, Guangxi]] has held an annual [[Dog Meat Festival
column2: festival of eating dog meat]].  This purportedly celebrates the [[summer solstice]], however, in 2014, the municipal government published a statement that the festival is not a cultural tradition, rather, a commercial event held by restaurants and the public.<ref name=""SMC"" />  Various dog meat dishes (and more recently, [[cat]]s) are eaten, washed down by [[lychees]] wine.  The festival in 2011 spanned 10 days, during which 15,000 dogs were consumed.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=陝西榆林10天美食節 1萬5千隻狗慘遭下肚 | 大陸新聞 | NOWnews 今日新聞網
column6: accessdate=2011-06-30}}</ref> Estimates of the number of dogs eaten during the festival range between 10<ref name=""Independent2015"" /><ref name=""BBC2015"">{{cite web
column9: title=China Yulin dog meat festival under way despite outrage
column13: title=Gemoederen lopen hoog op bij discussie over hondenvlees-festival
column19: accessdate=22 June 2015}}</ref>  Festival organisers say that only dogs bred specifically for consumption are used, however, there are claims that some of the dogs purchased for slaughter and consumption are strays or stolen pets, as evidenced by their wearing collars.<ref name=""Independent2015b"" /> Some of the dogs eaten at the festival are burnt or boiled alive<ref name=""Asiaone"">{{cite news
column20: title=Celebrities join campaign to stop dog meat festival in China
column26: quote=Thousands of dogs are traded, killed and then eaten in the home or on the street. Some of them are burnt or boiled alive.}}</ref> and there are reports that the dogs are sometimes clubbed<ref name=""Independent2015"" /> or beaten to death in the belief that the increased [[adrenalin]] circulating in the dog's body adds to the flavour of the meat.<ref name=""Independent2015b"" />  At the 2015 festival, there were long queues outside large (300-seat) eateries which sold the dog meat for around £4 (€5.60) per kilogram.<ref name=""Keating"">{{cite web
column27: title=China dog meat estival: Business is 'booming' say dog and cat meat traders
column32: url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/china-dog-meat-festival-business-booming-say-dog-cat-meat-traders-1507236}}</ref> Prior to the 2014 festival, eight dogs (and their two cages) sold for 1,150 yuan ($185) and six puppies for 1,200 yuan.<ref name=""china.org"">{{cite web
column37: accessdate=May 21, 2015}}</ref>  Prior to the 2015 festival, a protester bought 100 dogs for 7,000 yuan ($1,100; £710).<ref name=""BBC2015"" /> The animal rights [[NGO]] Best Volunteer Centre claims the city has more than 100 slaughterhouses, processing between 30 and 100 dogs a day.  However, the Yulin Centre for Animal Disease Control and Prevention claims the city has only eight dog slaughterhouses selling approximately 200 dogs, although this increases to about 2,000 dogs during the Yulin festival.<ref name=""Huifeng"">{{cite web
column38: title=Dog-eating festival loses its bite as animal rights activists step in
column43: accessdate=May 21, 2015}}</ref>  There are several campaigns to stop the festival; more than 3,000,000 people have signed petitions against it on [[Sina Weibo
column44: Weibo]] (China’s equivalent of [[Twitter]])<ref name=""Independent2015"" /> and a petition to stop the festival (addressed to the Chinese Minister of Agriculture, Chen Wu) reads ""Do the humane thing by saying no to this festival and save the lives of countless dogs that will fall victim to this event – an event that will butcher, skin alive, beat to death etc. thousands of innocent dogs.""<ref name=""O'Neil"">{{cite web
column46: title=Dog meat festival in China takes place despite massive online protest
column50: url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/trending/dog-meat-festival-in-china-takes-place-despite-massive-online-protest-1.3123266}}</ref>  Prior to the 2014 festival, doctors and nurses staff were ordered not to eat dog meat there, and local restaurants serving dog meat were ordered to cover the word ""dog"" on their signs and notices.<ref name=""SMC"">{{cite web
column52: title=Southwest China hospital staff ordered to stay away from ‘dog meat festival’

column1: The movement against the consumption of cat and dog meat was given added impetus by the formation of the Chinese Companion Animal Protection Network (CCAPN).  Expanded to more than 40 member societies, CCAPN in 2006 began organizing protests against eating dogs and cat, starting in Guangzhou and following up in more than ten other cities with a positive response from the public.<ref name=""Guangzhou bans eating snakes--ban helps cats(Animal People)"">{{cite web
column4: title=Guangzhou bans eating snakes—ban helps cats
column8: df= }}</ref> Before the [[2008 Beijing Olympics]], officials ordered dog meat to be taken off the menu at its 112 official Olympic restaurants to avoid offending visitors from various nations who might have been concerned by the offering of dog meat.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/7501768.stm China bans dog from Olympic menu], BBC News, 11 July 2008.</ref>

column1: In 2010, draft legislation was proposed to prohibit the consumption of dog meat.<ref name=""xinhua"">Li Xianzhi, 2010-01-27, [http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/china/2010-01/27/c_13153405.htm Eating cats, dogs could be outlawed], [[Xinhua News Agency]]</ref> The legislation, however, was not expected to be enforced, making the consumption of dog meat illegal if it passed.<ref name=xinhua/> In 2010, the first draft proposal of the legislation was introduced, with the rationale to protect animals from maltreatment.  The legislation includes a measure to jail people for up to 15 days for eating dog meat.<ref>[http://www.nguoi-viet.com/absolutenm/anmviewer.asp?a=107622&z=5 Trung Quốc sắp sửa cấm ăn thịt chó, mèo] {{vi}}</ref><ref name=""China to jail people for up to 15 days who eat dog (China Daily)"">{{cite web
column4: title=China to jail people for up to 15 days who eat dog
column5: publisher=China Daily}}</ref>  However, certain cultural food festivals continue to promote the meat. For example, in 2014, 10,000 dogs were killed for the Yulin dog eating festival.<ref name=""Guardian"">{{cite web

column1: As of the early 21st century, dog meat consumption is declining or disappearing.<ref name=""China2"">{{cite web
column2: title=To eat dog, or not to eat dog
column7: accessdate=May 20, 2015}}</ref>  In 2014, dog meat sales decreased by a third compared to 2013.<ref name=""Guardian"" /> It was reported that in 2015, one of the most popular restaurants in Guangzhou serving dog meat was closed after the local government tightened regulations; the restaurant had served dog meat dishes since 1963. Other restaurants that served dog and cat meat dishes in the Yuancun and Panyu districts also stopped serving these in 2015.<ref name=""China"">{{cite web
column8: title=Dog meat restaurant in Guangzhou closes amid ‘falling demand’

column1: In [[Hong Kong]], the ''Dogs and Cats Ordinance'' was introduced by the British Hong Kong Government on 6 January 1950.<ref>{{cite web
column6: publisher = [[Department of Justice (Hong Kong)]]}}</ref> It prohibits the slaughter of any dog or cat for use as food by fine and imprisonment.<ref>{{cite web
column8: title=Slaughter of dog or cat for food prohibited
column13: title= Slaughter of dog or cat for food – Penalty
column16: publisher=[[Department of Justice (Hong Kong)]]}}</ref> In February 1998, a [[Hong Konger]] was sentenced to one month imprisonment and a fine of two thousand HK dollars for hunting street dogs for food.<ref>{{cite web
column18: title=First Case Imprisonment in HK for Dog Meal
column23: fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Four local men were sentenced to 30 days imprisonment in December 2006 for having slaughtered two dogs.<ref>{{cite web

column1: Dog meat is believed by some in Taiwan to have health benefits, including improving circulation and raising body temperature.<ref name=chinapost /> In 2001, the Taiwanese government imposed a ban on the sale of dog meat, due to both pressure from domestic animal welfare groups and a desire to improve international perceptions, although there were some protests.<ref>{{cite news
column6: accessdate=2007-05-15}}</ref> In 2007, another law was passed, significantly increasing the fines to sellers of dog meat.<ref name=chinapost>{{cite news
column7: title=Taiwan law takes bite out of dog meat sales
column10: date=17 December 2007}}</ref> However, animal rights campaigners have accused the Taiwanese government of not prosecuting those who continue to slaughter and serve dog meat at restaurants. A law was passed in April 2017 that totally prohibits the sale and consumption of dog and cat meat. Those found guilty of breaking the law risk being named and shamed and facing fines of up to 250,000 Taiwan new dollars <ref>{{cite news

column1: Dog meat is a delicacy in some states of [[Northeast India]], particularly [[Mizoram]],<ref>{{cite news
column2: title=Dog meat, a delicacy in Mizoram
column14: title=Manipur – a slice of Switzerland in India

column1: Indonesia is predominantly [[Muslim]], a faith which considers dog meat, along with [[pork]], to be ""[[haraam]]"" (ritually unclean). Therefore, Muslims do not eat it. However, dog meat is eaten by several of Indonesia's non-Muslim minorities.<ref name=""buzzfeed"">{{Citation
column4: title = All About Indonesian Dog Meat

column1: However, several Indonesian ethnicities are known to consumes [[bushmeat]], which also includes dog meat. The consumption of dog meat is associated with the [[Minahasa]] culture of northern [[Sulawesi]],<ref>{{cite news
column2: title=Mercato shock in Indonesia, dai cani ai pitoni arrosto in vendita
column6: date=2014-03-31}}</ref> [[Maluku culture]], [[Toraja]] culture, various ethnic from [[East Nusa Tenggara]], and the [[Batak (Indonesia)
column14: archivedate=October 10, 2007 }}</ref> The code for restaurants or vendors selling dog meat is ""RW"" ([[Minahasan languages

column1: Popular Indonesian dog-meat dishes are Minahasan spicy meat dish called ''[[rica-rica]]''. Dog meat ''rica-rica'' spicifically called ''rica-rica'' ""RW"" which stands for ''Rintek Wuuk'' in Minahasan dialect, which means ""fine hair"" as a euphemism referring for fine hair found in roasted dog meat.<ref name=""buzzfeed"" /> It is cooked as ''Patong'' dish by Toraja people, and as ''[[Saksang]]'' ""B1"" (stands for ''Biang'' which means ""dog"" or ""bitch"" in Batak dialect) by Batak people of North Sumatra. On [[Java]], there are several dishes made from dog meat, such as ''sengsu'' (''[[tongseng]] asu''), [[Satay
column2: ''sate'']] ''jamu'' (lit. ""medicinal satay""), and ''kambing balap'' (lit. ""racing goat""). ''Asu'' is [[Javanese language

column1: Dog consumption in Indonesia gained attention during the [[2012 United States Presidential election
column2: 2012 U.S. Presidential election]] when incumbent [[Barack Obama]] was pointed out by his opponent to have eaten dog meat served by his Indonesian stepfather [[Lolo Soetoro]] when Obama was living in the country.<ref name=""buzzfeed"" /> Obama wrote about his experience of eating dog in his book ''[[Dreams of My Father]]'',<ref name=""YouTube1"">{{cite web
column4: title=Barack Obama reading from Dreams From My Father in Springfield, IL. (3/7/01)}}</ref> and at the 2012 [[White House Correspondents' Association#White House Correspondents.27 Dinner
column5: White House Correspondents' Dinner]] joked about eating dog.<ref name=""YouTube2"">{{cite web
column7: title=Obama Jokes About Eating Dog: ""A Pitbull is Delicious""}}</ref><ref name=""CNN"">{{cite web
column9: title=President Obama's humor goes to the 'dogs' during annual dinner

column1: In June 2017, there is an investigative report discovered that tourists in [[Bali]] are unknowingly eating dog meat sold by street vendors.<ref>{{cite web
column2: title = Bali tourists are unknowingly eating dog meat, undercover investigation reveals

column1: The consumption of dog meat is not a feature of modern Japanese culture.  There is a belief in Japan that certain dogs have special powers in their religion of [[Shintoism]] and [[Buddhism]]. Dog meat was consumed in Japan until 675 AD, when [[Emperor Tenmu]] decreed a prohibition on its consumption during the 4th through 9th months of the year. Normally a dog accompanied the emperor for [[battle]], so it was believed that eating a dog gave [[emperor]]s bad [[luck]].{{citation needed
column2: date=August 2015}} In Japanese [[shrines]] certain animals are [[worshipped]], such as [[dogs]] as it is believed they will give people a [[good luck charm]].{{citation needed
column3: date=August 2015}} Animals are described as good luck in scrolls and [[Kakemono]] during the [[Kofun period]], [[Asuka period]] and [[Nara period]].<ref>[[Nihon Shoki]] Chapter 29 – [[Kanbun]]: 亦四月朔以後。九月三十日以前。莫置比満沙伎理梁。且莫食牛・馬・犬・猿・鶏之完。以外不在禁例。[http://www.j-texts.com/jodai/shoki29.html] English: Also, from the first day of the first[''sic. it should read fourth''] month until the 30th day of the ninth month, it is prohibited to use hinasakiri or fish traps. Also, cow, horse, dog, monkey, and chicken meat are not to be eaten.However, other meats outside of these are not prohibited.[http://nihonshoki.wikidot.com/scroll-29-emperor-temmu-2]</ref> According to ''Meisan Shojiki Ōrai'' (名産諸色往来) published in 1760, the meat of wild dog was sold along with boar, [[venison
column7: cat]] in some regions of [[Edo]].<ref>{{cite book
column10: title=Everyday things in premodern Japan: the hidden legacy of material culture
column15: isbn=0-520-21812-4}}</ref> [[Ōta Nanpo]] recorded witnessing puppies being eaten in [[Satsuma Province]] in a dish called ''Enokoro Meshi'' ([[:ja:えのころ飯

column1: '''''Gaegogi''''' (개고기) literally means ""dog meat"" in Korean. The term itself, however, is often mistaken as the term for [[Korean cuisine
column2: Korean]] [[soup]] made from dog meat, which is actually called ''[[bosintang]]'' (보신탕; 補身湯, ''Body nourishing soup'') (sometimes spelled ""bo-shintang"").

column1: The consumption of dog meat in Korean culture can be traced through history. Dog bones{{Elucidate
column3: date=August 2010}} were excavated in a [[neolithic]] settlement in Changnyeong, [[Gyeongsangnam-do
column4: South Gyeongsang]] Province. A wall painting in the [[Complex of Goguryeo Tombs
column5: Goguryeo Tombs complex]] in South Hwangghae Province, a [[World Heritage site]] which dates from the 4th century AD, depicts a slaughtered dog in a storehouse. The [[Balhae]] people also enjoyed dog meat, and the modern-day tradition of canine cuisine seems to have come from that era.<ref>[http://www.dbpia.co.kr/view/ar_view.asp?arid=720538 A Study of the favorite Foods of the Balhae People] Yang Ouk-da</ref>

column2: Mohe]] ancestors did not respect dogs, the [[Jurchen people]] began to respect dogs around the time of the [[Ming dynasty]] and passed this tradition on to the [[Manchu people
column3: Manchu]]. It was prohibited in Jurchen culture to use dog skin, and forbidden for Jurchens to harm, kill, and eat dogs, as the Jurchens believed the ""utmost evil"" was the usage of dog skin by Koreans.<ref>[http://www.ritsumei.ac.jp/acd/cg/lt/rb/601/601PDF/aisin.pdf Aisin Gioro & Jin], p. 18.</ref>

column5: A dish made with dog meat in South Korea, [[Seoul]], Korea]]
Dog meat sold in [[Gyeongdong Market]], Seoul, South Korea]]

column2: Dog meat consumption in South Korea}}

column1: Dog meat is often consumed during the summer months and is either roasted or prepared in soups or stews. The most popular of these soups is ''[[bosintang
column2: bosintang and gaejang-guk]]'', a spicy stew meant to balance the body's heat during the summer months. This is thought to ensure good health by balancing one's ""[[qi]]"", the believed vital energy of the body. Dog meat is also believed to increase the body temperature, so people sweat more to keep one cool during the summer (the way of dealing the heat) is so called 이열치열,{{transliteration needed

column1: whereas in China dog meat is consumed in the winter months under the belief that it increases warmth. There has been no scientific evidence to support any purported health benefits from consuming dog meat.
A 19th-century version of ''gaejang-guk'' explains the preparation of the dish by boiling dog meat with vegetables such as [[scallion
column3: chili pepper powder]]. Variations of the dish contain [[chicken (food)
column4: chicken]] and [[bamboo shoot]]s.<ref>Pettid, Michael J., ''Korean Cuisine: An Illustrated History'', London: Reaktion Books Ltd., 2008, 84–85.</ref>

column3: title=The South Korean Dog Meat Trade
column4: publisher=Animal Welfare Institute}}</ref> of dog meat, or 2.5 million dogs,<ref name=""Cz"">{{cite journal
column7: title=Dog meat trade in South Korea: A report on the current state of the trade and efforts to eliminate it
column11: url=https://litigation-essentials.lexisnexis.com/webcd/app?action=DocumentDisplay&crawlid=1&doctype=cite&docid=21+Animal+L.+29&srctype=smi&srcid=3B15&key=d9029f1ccf66735779b5e3defa01b270}}</ref> are consumed annually in South Korea. Although a fair number of South Koreans (approximately 42% to 60%)<ref name=KARA>{{cite web

column1: Statistics on the Dog Meat Industry
column3: at=Percentage of Population Eating Dog Meat}}</ref> have eaten dog meat at least once in their lifetime, only a small percentage of the population is believed to eat it on a regular basis.<ref name=AWI/>

column1: The [[Ministry of Food and Drug Safety]] recognizes any edible product other than drugs as food.<ref>{{Harvnb
column4: p=209}}</ref> South Korean Food Sanitary Law (식품위생법) does not include dog meat as a legal food ingredient. In the capital city of [[Seoul]], the sale of dog meat was outlawed by regulation on February 21, 1984 by classifying dog meat as ""repugnant food"" (혐오식품{{transliteration needed
column5: date=October 2016}}), but the regulation was not rigorously enforced except during the [[1988 Seoul Olympics]]. In 2001, the Mayor of Seoul announced there would be no extra enforcement efforts to control the sale of dog meat during the [[2002 FIFA World Cup]], which was partially hosted in Seoul. In March 2008, the [[Seoul Metropolitan Government]] announced its plan to put forward a policy suggestion to the central government to legally classify [[Nureongi
column6: slaughter dog]]s as livestock, reigniting debate on the issue.<ref name=""Kim 2008, p.231"">{{cite journal
column7: title=Dog Meat in Korea: A Socio-Legal Challenge
column21: title=Dog Meat to Be Subject to Livestock Rules
column26: trans_title=Half of citizens [say] 'Dog Meat Should be Controlled as Livestock Product'

column1: The primary dog breed raised for meat is a non-specific landrace, whose dogs are commonly named as ''[[Nureongi]]'' (누렁이) or ''Hwangu'' (황구).<ref name=Podberscek>{{cite journal
column4: title=Good to Pet and Eat: The Keeping and Consuming of Dogs and Cats in South Korea
column15: df= }}</ref><ref name=edible>[http://kmbase.medric.or.kr/Main.aspx?d=KMBASE&m=VIEW&i=0665219990120040397 Dog Meat Foods in Korea], Ann, Yong-Geun, Korean Medical Database</ref> Nureongi are not the only type of dog currently slaughtered for their meat in South Korea. In 2015, ''The Korea Observer'' reported that many different pet breeds of dog are eaten in South Korea, including labradors, retrievers and cocker spaniels, and that the dogs slaughtered for their meat often include former pets.<ref name=""Hyams"" />

column1: There is a large and vocal group of Koreans (consisting of a number of animal welfare groups) who are against the practice of eating dogs.<ref name=aboutk>[http://koreanfood.about.com/od/koreanfoodbasics/f/DogMeat.htm Do Koreans Really Eat Dog?] about.com</ref> Popular television shows like 'I Love Pet' have documented, in 2011 for instance, the continued illegal sale of dog meat and slaughtering of dogs in suburban areas. The program also televised illegal dog farms and slaughterhouses, showing the unsanitary and horrific conditions of caged dogs, several of which were visibly sick with severe eye infections and malnutrition. However, despite this growing awareness, there remain some in Korea that do not eat or enjoy the meat, but do feel that it is the right of others to do so, along with a smaller but still vocal group of pro-dog cuisine people who want to popularize the consumption of dog in Korea and the rest of the world.<ref name=""aboutk""/> A group of pro-dog meat individuals attempted to promote and publicize the consumption of dog meat worldwide during the run-up to the [[2002 FIFA World Cup]], co-hosted by Japan and South Korea, which prompted retaliation from animal rights campaigners and prominent figures such as [[Brigitte Bardot]] to denounce the practice.<ref>{{cite news
column5: date=2002-01-13}}</ref> Opponents of dog meat consumption in South Korea are critical of the eating of dog meat, as some dogs are beaten, burnt or hanged to make their meat more tender.<ref>{{cite news

column1: The restaurants that sell dog meat, often exclusively, do so at the risk of losing their restaurant licenses. A case of a dog meat wholesaler, charged with selling dog meat, arose in 1997 where an appeals court acquitted the dog meat wholesaler, ruling that dogs were socially accepted as food.<ref>{{cite book
column4: title=Extreme Cuisine: The Weird & Wonderful Foods That People Eat
column13: isbn= 0-7946-0255-X}}</ref> According to the [[National Assembly of South Korea]], more than 20,000 restaurants, including the 6,484 registered restaurants, served soups made from dog meat in Korea in 1998.<ref>{{cite web
column17: trans_title=Bosintang Controversy: What is the Solution?
column23: title=Dog Meat in Korea: A Socio-Legal Challenge
column35: df= }}</ref><ref name=bbc422338>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/422338.stm South Korea's dog day], BBC News, 17 August 1999.</ref> In 1999 the BBC reported that 8,500 tons of dog meat were consumed annually, with another 93,600 tons used to produce a medicinal tonic called ''gaesoju'' (개소주).<ref name=bbc422338 />

column1: [[Daily NK]] reported that the [[North Korea]]n government included dog meat in its new list of one hundred fixed prices, setting a fixed price of 500 [[North Korean won
column2: won]] per kilogram in early 2010.<ref>{{cite web

column1: New Zealand has no specific law banning the consumption of dog meat, but it is generally considered to be taboo.
A Tongan man living in New Zealand caused public outrage when he was caught cooking his pet dog in his backyard; this event led to calls for change in the law.<ref>{{cite web
column5: title=In defence of dog eating – national

column1: ====Philippines====<!-- This section is linked from [[Cuisine of the Philippines]] -->

column2: Malays]], a sea-faring population that is now scattered throughout South-East Asia, introduced the practice of domesticating dogs for meat consumption to the indigenous population of the Philippines.<ref>{{cite journal
column4: title=Do Filipino Americans eat dogs? Filipinos, Filipino Americans, and the dog eating stereotype.

column1: In the capital city of [[Manila]], Metro Manila Commission Ordinance 82-05 specifically prohibits the killing and selling of dogs for food.<ref>{{cite web
column5: archivedate=2005-12-16 }}</ref> Generally however, the Philippine Animal Welfare Act 1998<ref>{{cite web
column8: accessdate=2006-08-30}}</ref> prohibits the killing of any animal other than cattle, pigs, goats, sheep, poultry, rabbits, [[carabao]]s, horses, deer and crocodiles, with exemptions for religious, cultural, research, public safety and/or animal health reasons. Nevertheless, the consumption of dog meat is not uncommon in the Philippines, reflected in the occasional coverage in Philippine newspapers.<ref name=""PDI2006-01-07"">{{cite web
column12: title=Dog meat eating doesn’t hound Cordillera natives

column1: The province of [[Benguet]] specifically allows cultural use of dog meat by indigenous people and acknowledges this might lead to limited commercial use.<ref>{{cite web
column9: archivedate=September 30, 2007 }} (archived from [http://elgu2.ncc.gov.ph/benguet/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=288&Itemid=1 the original] on 2007-09-30){{dead link

column1: [[Asocena]] is a dish primarily consisting of dog meat originating from the Philippines.

In the early 1980s, there was an international outcry about dog meat consumption in the Philippines after newspapers published photos of [[Margaret Thatcher]], then British Prime Minister, with a dog carcass hanging beside her on a market stall. The British Government discussed withdrawing foreign aid and other countries, such as Australia, considered similar action. To avoid such action, the Filipino government banned the sale of dog meat, despite dog meat being the third most consumed meat, behind [[pork]] and [[goat]] and ahead of [[beef]]. The ban eventually became totally disregarded, although it was reinstated by [[President Ramos]] in 1998 in the Animal Welfare Act (Republic Act 8485).<ref>{{cite journal
[[File:Hawaiian natives wearing kihei, with animals, sketch by Louis Choris.jpg

Dogs were historically eaten in [[Tahiti]] and other islands of [[Polynesia]], including Hawaii<ref name=""Titcomb 1969""/><ref name=""Ellis 1839""/> at the time of first European contact. [[James Cook]], when first visiting Tahiti in 1769, recorded in his journal, ""few were there of us but what allow'd that a South Sea Dog was next to an English Lamb, one thing in their favour is that they live entirely upon Vegetables"".<ref>{{cite book
column5: title=The Explorations of Captain James Cook in the Pacific
column9: location=New York }}</ref> Calwin Schwabe reported in 1979 that dog was widely eaten in Hawaii and considered to be of higher quality than pork or chicken. When Hawaiians first encountered early British and American explorers, they were at a loss to explain the visitors' attitudes about dog meat. The Hawaiians raised both dogs and pigs as pets and for food. They could not understand why their British and American visitors only found the pig suitable for consumption.<ref name=schwabe1979p168/> This practice seems to have died out, along with the native Hawaiian breed of dog, the unique [[Hawaiian Poi Dog]], which was primarily used for this purpose.<ref>{{cite journal
column15: title=The Cranial Characters of the Hawaiian Dog
column16: author=Frederic Wood-Jones }}</ref> The consumption of domestic dog meat is still commonplace in the [[Kingdom of Tonga]], and has also been noted in expatriate [[Tonga]]n communities in New Zealand, Australia, and the United States.<ref>{{cite web
column18: title=Auckland man Paea Taufa cooked his pet dog in a backyard barbecue | thetelegraph.com.au

column1: Unlike other countries where dog meat consumption has been shown to have historical precedents, Thailand does not have a mainstream culture of dog eating. However, in recent years, the consumption of dog meat in certain areas of the country, especially in certain northeastern provinces like Sakon Nakhon and Nakhon Phanom, notably Sakon Nakhon province's Tha Rae sub-district, which has been identified as the main center for the country's illegal, albeit lucrative, dog meat trade, has attracted widespread attention from the Thai population and local news media. This has led large groups of Thai citizens to become increasingly vocal against the consumption of dog meat and the selling of dogs that are transported through Laos to neighbouring Mekong countries, including Vietnam and China. According to news reports, a considerable number of these dogs continue to be stolen from people's homes by illegal carriers. This was also the case following the 2011 Thailand Floods. Dubbed the country's ""Trade of Shame"",{{whose quote}} Thai citizens have now formed several informal animal welfare and rescue groups, particularly online, in an attempt to stop this illegal trade, with the collective attitude being that ""Dogs are not food"".{{whose quote}} Established not-for-profit animal charity organizations like the [[Soi Dog Foundation]] have also been active in raising awareness and working in conjunction with local Thai authorities to rehabilitate and relocate dogs rescued from trucks attempting to transport live dogs across the border to nearby countries. Significantly, this issue has strengthened the nation's animal rights movement, which continues to call on the Thai government to adopt a stricter and more comprehensive animal rights law to prevent the maltreatment of pets and cruelty against all animals.<ref>{{cite web
column2: title='Vietnam Demand for Dog Meat Keeps Thai Dog Trade Alive'
column6: title='Thai authorities seize 800 dogs destined for Indochina meat trade'
column14: title='Business booming for the dog smugglers of the Mekong'
column23: title='The rise of the dog snatchers'
column27: title='You Can Help Stop the Slaughter...'

column1: Dog meat is a delicacy popular in East Timor.<ref>{{cite web
Although not commonly eaten, dog meat is sometimes used in Uzbekistan in the belief that it has medicinal properties.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Uzbekistan news report on dog restaurants
column18: title=Dog meat is believed to be a TB medicine in Andizhan

column1: ====Vietnam====<!-- This section is linked from [[Cuisine of Vietnam]] -->

column4: A dog meat platter found in a street market a few miles east of [[Hanoi]], Vietnam]]

column1: [[File:Dog meat for sale in a market in Hanoi, Vietnam (6827793370).jpg

Dog meat is particularly popular in the urban areas of the north, and can be found in special restaurants which specifically serve dog meat. Dog meat is believed to bring good fortune in Vietnamese culture.<ref name=""news.bbc.co.uk"">{{cite news
column5: date=2001-12-31}}</ref> It is seen as being comparable in consumption to chicken or pork.<ref name=""news.bbc.co.uk""/> In urban areas, there are sections that house a lot of dog meat restaurants. For example, on Nhat Tan Street, [[Tay Ho
column6: Tây Hồ]] District, [[Hanoi]], many restaurants serve dog meat. Groups of customers, usually male, seated on mats, will spend their evenings sharing plates of dog meat and drinking alcohol. The consumption of dog meat can be part of a ritual usually occurring toward the end of the [[lunar month]] for reasons of [[astrology]] and luck. Restaurants which mainly exist to serve dog meat may only open for the last half of the lunar month.<ref name=""news.bbc.co.uk"" />  Dog meat is also believed to raise the [[libido]] in men.<ref name=""news.bbc.co.uk"" /> The [[Associated Press]] reported in October 2009 that a soaring economy has led to the booming of dog restaurants in Hanoi, and that this has led to a proliferation of dognappers. Reportedly, a {{convert
column10: adj=on}} dog can sell for more than $100 — roughly the monthly salary of an average Vietnamese worker.{{citation needed
column11: date=October 2013}} There is a large smuggling trade from Thailand to export dogs to Vietnam for human consumption.<ref>{{cite web
column13: title=How eating dog became big business in Vietnam

column1: In 2009, dog meat was found to be a main carrier of the ''[[Vibrio cholerae]]'' bacterium, which caused the summer epidemic of [[cholera]] in northern Vietnam.<ref>{{cite web
column5: title=Hanoi dog meat restaurants come under scrutiny after cholera outbreak
column9: title=Cholera, bird flu present, but VN still A/H1N1-free
column14: archivedate=May 20, 2009 }} Retrieved from Internet Archive 12 January 2014.</ref>

column1: Prior to 2014, more than 5 million dogs were killed for meat every year in Vietnam according to the Asia Canine Protection Alliance. However, there are indications that the desire to eat dog meat in Vietnam is waning.<ref name=""China2"" />  Part of the decline is thought to be due to an increased number of Vietnamese people keeping dogs as pets, as their incomes have risen in the past few decades. ""[People] used to raise dogs to guard the house, and when they needed the meat, they ate it. Now they keep dog as pets, imported from China, Japan, and other countries. One pet dog might cost hundreds of millions of dong [100 million dong is $4,677].""<ref name=""China2"" />
Generally speaking, the consumption of dog flesh is taboo in Europe. This has been the case for many centuries, although exceptions have occurred in times of scarcity such as sieges or famines.

There are occasional accounts of Europeans travelling in remote areas (outside of Europe) who get lost and have to eat their companion dog to survive. The explorer [[Benedict Allen]] claims to have done this,<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/money/2011/oct/07/benedict-allen-my-greatest-mistake ""Benedict Allen: my greatest mistake""], as told to Graham Snowdon, 7 October 2011, The Guardian. ""Explorer Benedict Allen has been haunted for decades about having to eat his faithful dog to save his life when lost in the Brazilian rainforest""</ref> and a case in Canada was reported in 2013.<ref>{{cite news
column3: title=Marco Lavoie, Stranded Hiker, 'Eats His Dog To Survive'
column6: accessdate=19 April 2016}}</ref> This is distinct from Arctic and Antarctic expeditions, where the sled dogs are factored into the rations.<ref>{{cite book
column9: title=The Last Viking: The Life of Roald Amundsen

column1: Section 6, Paragraph 2 of the law for the protection of animals (''Tierschutzgesetz'' (''TSchG'')) prohibits the killing of dogs and cats for purposes of consumption as food or for other products.<ref>{{cite web
Eating dog meat is considered entirely taboo. However, [[Taliesin
column2: Brittonic]] and Irish texts which date from the early Christian period suggest that dog meat was sometimes consumed but possibly in ritual contexts such as [[Druidic]] ritual trance.{{citation needed
column3: date=August 2015}} Sacrificial dog bones are often recovered from archaeological sites;<ref>{{cite web
column5: title=The curious case of the dog in the...
column6: work=Museum of London Blog}}</ref> however, they were typically treated differently, as were [[horse meat
column7: horses]], from other food animals.<ref>http://eprints.bournemouth.ac.uk/18298/1/Madgwick.pdf</ref> One of Ireland's mythological heroes, [[Cuchulainn]], had two [[geis
column8: geasa]], or vows, one of which was to avoid the meat of dogs. The breaking of his geasa led to his death in the Irish mythology.

column1: A few meat shops sold dog meat during the German occupation of Belgium in [[World War I]], when food was extremely scarce.<ref>{{cite web
column2: title= Meat Shops Closed As Belgians Go Hungry
column6: quote=We found the meat shops all closed, ... with three exceptions, namely; shops that have recently and openly sold dog meat.... The average price were 12 francs a kilo, bones and all, (about $1.30 a pound) and some meat that had been obtained by special exertions for the soup kitchens.}}</ref> According to The New York Times, in the 19th century the Council of the Veterinary School of Belgium occasionally recommended dog meat for human consumption after being properly inspected.<ref>{{cite news
column7: title=The Council of the Veterinary School of Belgium even recommended dog meat for human food after being properly inspected

column1: Although consumption of dog meat is uncommon in France, and is now considered taboo, dog meat has been consumed in the past by the [[Gauls]]. The earliest evidence of dog consumption in France was found at Gaulish archaeological sites, where butchered dog bones were discovered.<ref>{{cite book
column8: pages=81–84}}</ref> French news sources from the late 19th century carried stories reporting lines of people buying dog meat, which was described as being ""beautiful and light"".<ref>{{cite book
column12: title=Histoire des festins insolites et de la goinfrerie, Artulen, Paris
column14: pages= }}</ref> During the [[Siege of Paris (1870–1871)]], there were lines at butchers' shops of people waiting to purchase dog meat. Dog meat was also reported as being sold by some butchers in Paris in 1910.<ref>{{cite book
column16: title=Histoire des festins insolites et de la goinfrerie

column1: Dog meat has been eaten in every major German crisis since, at least, the time of [[Frederick the Great]], and is commonly referred to as ""blockade mutton"".<ref name=Times1940>{{Cite journal
column7: postscript=<!--None-->}}</ref> In the early 20th century, high meat prices led to widespread consumption of horse and dog meat in Germany.<ref name=Times1907>{{Cite journal
column9: title= Germany's dog meat market; Consumption of Canines and Horses Is on the Increase.
column16: title=Monthly consular and trade reports, Volume 64, Issues 240–243.
column18: publisher=United States. Bureau of Manufactures, Bureau of Foreign Commerce, Dept. of Commerce
column21: author2=Bureau Of Foreign Commerce (1854–1903), United States
column22: author3=Bureau Of Statistics, United States. Dept. of Commerce and Labor
column24: title=Use Horse and Dog Meat – Germans forced to that diet by high price of other meat
column32: quote=...the German breeders... heightened the price to such an extent that horse, and even dog's meat, has become staple with the poorer classes in certain districts, and notably in the large cities}}</ref>

column1: The consumption of dog meat continued in the 1920s.<ref name=nytimes1923>{{cite news
column2: title=DOGS AS MEAT IN MUNICH; Butcher's Shop Hangs Sign Offering Either to Buy or Sell
column6: title=GERMANS STILL EAT DOGS; Berlin Police Chief Issues Rules for Inspection of the Meat
column9: url= http://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F30616FD3E551B7A93C0A8178DD85F418285F9&scp=3&sq=germans+dog+meat&st=p}}</ref>  In 1937, a meat inspection law targeted against [[trichinella]] was introduced for pigs, dogs, [[boar]]s, foxes, [[badger]]s, and other carnivores.<ref>{{cite web
column15: page= 458}} then becoming § 1 para. 3, [http://alex.onb.ac.at/cgi-content/anno-plus?apm=0&aid=dra&datum=19400007&zoom=2&seite=00001463&ues=0&x=8&y=8 RGBl. 1940 I p. 1463] (in German)</ref> Dog meat has been prohibited in Germany since 1986.<ref>Fleischhygienegesetz (Law on Meat Hygiene), § 1 para. 1 sent. 4, [http://www.landtag.nrw.de/portal/WWW/dokumentenarchiv/Dokument/XBCBGI8614.pdf BGBl. (Federal Law Gazette) 1986 I p. 398] (in German).</ref>

column1: In the latter part of [[World War I]], dog meat was being eaten in [[Kingdom of Saxony
column2: Saxony]] by the poorer classes because of famine conditions.<ref name=nytimes1918>[https://query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9807E3DC163EE433A25751C2A9639C946996D6CF ""FEAR OF FAMINE APPALS AUSTRIA; Charges of Cannibalism by Vienna Workmen Are Officially Hushed Up. PEOPLE JEER AT THE WAR. German Promises of Victory Flouted—Soldiers Beg for Bread and Long for Peace. Quaratine Against Bolshevism. Real Famine in the Country. Saxons Eat Camels and Dogs""], New York Times, May 22, 1918</ref>

column1: During severe meat shortages coinciding with the German occupation from 1940 to 1945, sausages found to have been made of dog meat were confiscated by authorities in the Netherlands.<ref name=nytimes1940>{{cite news
column2: title = NETHERLANDERS SEEK SUNDAY MEAT IN VAIN; Food Situation Becomes Acute as Nazis Seize Dog Sausage

column1: While dog meat is not eaten, in some rural areas of Poland, especially [[Lesser Poland]], dog [[fat]] can be made into [[lard]], which by tradition is believed to have medicinal properties – being good for the lungs, for instance.{{citation needed
column2: date=August 2015}} Since the 16th century, fat from various animals, including dogs, was used as part of [[folk medicine]], and since the 18th century dog fat has had a reputation as being beneficial for the lungs. It is worth noting that the consumption of such meat is considered taboo in Polish culture, and making lard out of dogs' fat is illegal.<ref name=""telegraph.co.uk"">{{cite news
column6: title=Polish couple accused of making dog meat delicacy
column11: location=London}}</ref> In 2009, a scandal erupted when a farm near [[Częstochowa]] was discovered rearing dogs to be rendered down into lard.<ref name=""telegraph.co.uk""/> According to Grazyna Zawada, from ''[[Gazeta Wyborcza]]'', there were farms in Czestochowa, Klobuck, and in the Radom area, and in the decade from 2000 to 2010 six people producing dog lard were found guilty of breaching animal welfare laws (killing dogs and animal cruelty) and sentenced to jail.<ref>{{Cite news
column19: via = }}</ref> As of 2014 there have been new cases prosecuted.<ref>{{Cite news
column21: title = Psi smalec. Przeraźliwy skowyt zarzynanych psów

column1: In 2012, the Swiss newspaper ''[[Tages-Anzeiger]]'' reported that dogs, as well as cats, are eaten regularly by a few farmers in rural areas.<ref name=""thelocal.ch"">{{cite web
column3: title=Dogs and cats 'still eaten in Switzerland'
column6: title=Forget chocolate or cheese: Cat and dog meat is Swiss delicacy
column9: title=Schweizer sollen keine Hunde und Katzen mehr essen
column10: publisher=[[Tages Anzeiger]]}}</ref> While commercial slaughter and sale of dog meat is illegal, farmers are allowed to slaughter dogs for personal consumption. The favorite type of meat comes from a dog related to the Rottweiler and consumed as ''Mostbröckli'', a form of marinated meat. Animals are slaughtered by butchers and either shot or bludgeoned.

column1: In his 1979 book ''Unmentionable Cuisine'', Calvin Schwabe described a Swiss dog meat recipe ''gedörrtes Hundefleisch'' served as paper-thin slices, as well as smoked dog ham, ''Hundeschinken'', which is prepared by salting and drying raw dog meat.<ref name=""books.google.com"">{{Harvnb
It is illegal in Switzerland to commercially produce food made from dog meat, or to produce such food for commercial purposes.<ref>[[Federal Department of Home Affairs (Switzerland)
column2: FDHA]] Ordinance of 23 November 2005 on food of animal origin, [http://www.admin.ch/ch/f/rs/817_022_108/a2.html Art.2].</ref>

column1: == Torture for health or culinary benefits ==

There are some groups who believe that torturing the animal before slaughter makes the meat taste better and/or imparts health benefits into the dish, however there is no evidence to support this claim.<ref>{{cite web

column5: title=Dog Meat in Korea: A Socio-Legal Challenge

column2: title = The Pet Cookbook: Have your best Friend for dinner

column7: author = Yong-Geun Ann, Ph.D }} (contains some recipes)

column3: title=Manchuria from the Fall of the Yuan to the rise of the Manchu State (1368-1636)

column1: * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110811070002/http://articles.cnn.com/2010-03-09/world/china.animals_1_dog-meat-cats-and-dogs-number-of-pet-owners?_s=PM:WORLD CNN: Inside the cat and dog meat market in China]
* [http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/7501768.stm BBC News: China bans dog meat from Olympic menu]
* [http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-pacific-13268235 BBC News: Chinese dogs rescued from dinner table]
* [http://savedogs.soidog.org Soi Dog's Save the Dogs Petition]
* [http://notodogmeat.com Leading welfare group and British charity]

column5: internal use of a company's own products

column4: Three ways to feed dogs: Raw food, wet food and dry food in a bowl.]]

column1: <!--In various countries, the semantics of the words ""food"" and ""meat"" are not entirely clear-cut, and a person from a non-English speaking country may be looking for ""dog meat"" rather than ""dog food"". This is especially the case in some South East Asian countries; hence there is always the possibility for confusion between the two topics.-->

'''Dog food''' refers to food specifically intended for consumption by [[dog]]s. Like all [[carnivore]]s, dogs have sharp, pointed teeth, and have short gastrointestinal tracts better suited for the consumption of meat. In spite of this natural carnivorous design, dogs have still managed to adapt over thousands of years to survive on the meat and non-meat scraps and [[leftovers]] of human existence and thrive on a variety of foods.
In the United States alone, dog owners spent over $8.6 billion on commercially manufactured dog food in 2007.<ref>{{cite book
column2: title=Chow hounds: Why our dogs are getting fatter
column11: accessdate=7 January 2011--></ref> Some people make their own dog food, feed their dogs meals made from ingredients purchased in grocery or health food stores or give their dogs a raw food diet.

column1: In 37 BCE [[Virgil]] talks about the feeding of dogs in his ''Bucolics'':

column2: text=''Nec tibi cura canum fuerit postrema; sed una Veloces Spartae catulos, acremque Molossum, Pasce sero pingui:''<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?lr=&cd=3&as_drrb_is=b&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=1600&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=1850&dq=whey+%22dog+food%22&q=Sero+pingui&pg=PA62&id=1KAWAAAAYAAJ&num=100&as_brr=1#v=onepage&q&f=false Virgil, Bucolica, Georgica, et Aeneis: accedunt clavis metrica, notulae Anglicae, et ... 1829  book III, 404–406], with [https://books.google.com/books?pg=PA389&dq=whey%20%22dog%20food%22&lr&as_drrb_is=b&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=1600&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=1850&cd=3&id=1KAWAAAAYAAJ&num=100&as_brr=1&output=text the note]</ref>

column1: Do not let the care of dogs be last; but the swift Spartan hounds, and fierce Mastiff, Feed the whey""}}
Around 70 CE, [[Columella]] wrote his book ''On Agriculture'' in which he addresses the feeding of dogs:

column2: text=''Cibaria fere eadem sunt utrique generi praebenda. Nam si tam laxa rura sunt, ut sustineant pecorum greges, omnis sine discrimine hordeacea farina cum sero commode pascit. Sin autem surculo consitus ager sine pascuo est, farreo vel triticeo pane satiandi sunt, admixto tamen liquore coctae fabae, sed tepido, nam fervens rabiem creat.'' <ref>[http://www.thelatinlibrary.com/columella/columella.rr7.shtml Columella, On Agriculture, Book 7.]</ref>

column1: Provisions of victuals are almost the same for both [types of dog]. If the fields are so large as to sustain herds of animals, barley meal mixed with whey is a convenient food. But if it is an orchard without grain, spelt or wheat bread is fed mixed with the liquid from cooked beans, but warm, for boiling creates rabies.""}}
In the ''[[Avesta]]'', written from 224 to 651 CE, Azura Mazda advises:

column2: text=Bring ye unto him milk and fat with meat; this is the right food for the dog.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=4PE1AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA162&lpg=PA162&dq=columella+sero&source=bl&ots=Hb73VzqsX7&sig=NhsIFYiAtx2id2DJ8N6lZlqzOso&hl=en&sa=X&ei=BA0HVbaFHJHkoAT0lYHIDQ&ved=0CDIQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=columella%20sero&f=false The Zend-Avesta: The Vendîdâd, translated by James Darmesteter. 1880.]</ref>}}

column1: In France, the word ''pâtée'' began to appear in the 18th century and referred to a paste originally given to poultry. In 1756, a dictionary indicates it was made of a mixture of bread crumbs and little pieces of meat given to pets.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?pg=PA192&dq=p%C3%A2t%C3%A9e+chien&lr=&as_drrb_is=b&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=1600&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=1800&cd=57&id=lQGqLxH9eAYC&num=100&as_brr=0#v=onepage&q=p%C3%A2t%C3%A9e%20chien&f=false ''Nouveau dictionnaire universel des arts et des sciencies: françois, latin et'', edited by Fr Girard ((Viuda de))]</ref>

In 1781, an encyclopedia mentioned an earlier practice of removing the liver, heart, and blood of a downed stag and mixing it with milk, cheese, and bread; and then giving it to dogs.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?pg=PA145&dq=p%C3%A2t%C3%A9e+chien&lr=&as_drrb_is=b&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=1600&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=1800&cd=4&id=QP06AAAAcAAJ&num=100&as_brr=0#v=onepage&q&f=false Denis Diderot, Jean Le Rond d' Alembert, ''Encyclopédie ou dictionnaire raisonné des sciences'' ..., Volume 35, Part 1]</ref>

In 1844, the French writer, Nicolas Boyard, warned against even giving tallow graves (the dregs of the [[tallow]] pot) to dogs, though the English favored them (see below), and suggested a meat-flavored soup:

column2: text=By a misguided economy dogs are given meat scraps and tallow graves; one must avoid this, because these foods make them heavy and sick; give them twice a day a soup of coarse bread made with water, fat and the bottom of the stew pot; put a half-kilogram of bread at least in each soup.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=ODpFAAAAYAAJ&pg=RA2-PA552&dq=intitle:%22animaux+domestiques%22+chat&lr=&as_drrb_is=b&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=1800&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=1880&num=100&as_brr=1&cd=49#v=onepage&q=intitle%3A%22animaux%20domestiques%22%20chat&f=false Nicolas Jean Baptiste Boyard,'' Manuel du bouvier et zoophile: ou l'art d'élever de soigner les animaux'' 1844, 327]</ref>}}

column1: In England, care to give dogs particular food dates at least from the late eighteenth century, when ''The Sportsman's dictionary'' (1785) described the best diet for a dog's health in its article ""Dog"":

column2: text=A dog is of a very hot nature: he should therefore never be without clean water by him, that he may drink when he is thirsty. In regard to their food, carrion is by no means proper for them. It must hurt their sense of smelling, on which the excellence of these dogs greatly depends.

column1: Barley meal, the dross of wheatflour, or both mixed together, with broth or skim'd milk, is very proper food. For change, a small quantity of greaves from which the tallow is pressed by the chandlers, mixed with their flour ; or sheep's feet well baked or boiled, are a very good diet, and when you indulge them with flesh it should always be boiled. In the season of hunting your dogs, it is proper to feed them in the evening before, and give them nothing in the morning you take them out, except a little milk. If you stop for your own refreshment in the day, you should also refresh your dogs with a little milk and bread.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?pg=PT158&dq=intitle:dogs&lr=&as_drrb_is=b&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=1600&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=1790&cd=1&id=x-oDAAAAYAAJ&num=100&as_brr=1#v=onepage&q&f=false The Sportsman's Dictionary]</ref>}}
(Greaves, which was often recommended for dogs, is ""the sediment of melted tallow. It is made into cakes for
dogs' food. In Scotland and parts of the US it is called '[[pork rind
column3: for=If tallow is beef fat then it is unlikely to be called pork rind

column1: In 1833, ''The Complete Farrier'' gave similar but far more extensive advice on feeding dogs:<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?pg=PA429&dq=intitle:dogs&lr=&as_drrb_is=b&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=1600&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=1890&cd=43&id=xj8AAAAAQAAJ&num=100&as_brr=1#v=onepage&q&f=false The complete farrier, and British sportsman, by Richard Lawrence, p. 429]</ref>

column2: text=The dog is neither wholly carnivorous nor wholly herbivorous, but of a mixed kind, and can receive nourishment from either flesh or vegetables. A mixture of both is therefore his proper food,<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=The Best Dog Food for Small Dogs
column9: date=December 21, 2013}}</ref> but of the former he requires a greater portion, and this portion should be always determined by his bodily exertions.}}

column1: It was not until the mid-1800s that the world saw its first food made specifically for dogs. An American electrician, [[Spratt's
column2: James Spratt]], concocted the first dog treat. Living in London at the time, he witnessed dogs around a shipyard eating scraps of discarded biscuits. Shortly thereafter he introduced his dog food, made up of wheat meals, vegetables and meat. By 1890 production had begun in the United States and became known as ""Spratt’s Patent Limited"".

column1: In later years, [[dog biscuit]] was sometimes treated as synonymous with dog food:

column2: text=The first three prize winners at the late coursing meeting at Great Bend were trained on Spratt's Patent Dog Biscuit. This same dog food won no less than three awards, including a gold medal, at the Exposition in Paris which has just closed. It would seem that the decision of the judges is more than backed up by the result in the kennel. Another good dog food is that manufactured by Austin & Graves, of Boston. They, too, seem to be meeting with great success in their line.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?pg=PA523&dq=%22dog+food%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=b&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=1600&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=1890&cd=77&id=qAygAAAAMAAJ&num=100&as_brr=1#v=onepage&q=%22dog%20food%22&f=false Outing: sport, adventure, travel, fiction, Volume 15, January 1890, p. 42]</ref>}}

column1: Canned horse meat was introduced in the United States under the [[Ken-L Ration]] brand after World War I as a means to dispose of deceased horses. The 1930s saw the introduction of canned cat food and dry meat-meal dog food by the Gaines Food Co. By the time World War II ended, pet food sales had reached $200 million. In the 1950s Spratt's became part of General Mills.
