column1: A '''cat lady''' is a cultural archetype or a [[stock character]], often depicted as a single woman, a middle-aged or elderly [[spinster]], who owns many pet [[cat]]s. The term can be considered [[pejorative]],<ref name=""Forbes"">{{citation
column6: work=Forbes}}</ref> though it is sometimes embraced.<ref name=""timesunion.com"">{{citation
column8: title= Do you believe in the Crazy Cat Lady?

column1: Women who have cats have long been associated with the concept of [[spinster]]hood. In more recent decades, the concept of a cat lady has been associated with ""romance-challenged (often career-oriented) women"".<ref name=Forbes/>
A cat lady may also be an [[Animal hoarding
column2: animal hoarder]] who keeps large numbers of cats without having the ability to properly house or care for them.<ref>{{Citation
column9: title = Prosecuting Animal Hoarders is like Herding Cats
column17: accessdate = June 26, 2011 }}</ref> They may be ignorant about their situation, or generally unaware of their situation. People who are aware of it are not normally considered cat ladies.

column1: Some writers, celebrities, and artists have challenged the  gender-based ""Crazy Cat Lady"" stereotype, and embraced the term to mean an animal lover or rescuer who cares for one or multiple cats, and who is psychologically healthy.<ref>[http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/gossip/beth-ostrosky-stern-crazy-cat-lady-article-1.2361539 Beth Ostronsky Stern: I Am A Crazy Cat Lady, New York Daily News, September 15, 2015]</ref><ref>[http://www.mnn.com/family/pets/stories/its-time-to-smash-the-crazy-cat-lady-stereotype Moss, Laura, It's Time to Smash the Crazy Cat Lady Stereotype, Mother Nature Network, November 12, 2015]</ref><ref>[http://abcnews.go.com/Lifestyle/photos/meet-men-proud-crazy-cat-ladies-29245631/image-29246901 Williams, David, Meet The Men Proud to Be Crazy Cat Ladies, ABC News, Retrieved November 12, 2015]</ref>

The documentary ''Cat Ladies'' (2009) tells the stories of four women whose lives became dedicated to their cats. The film was directed by Christie Callan-Jones and produced by Chocolate Box Entertainment, originally for [[TVOntario]]. It was an official selection at the 2009 Hot Docs Festival, Silverdocs Festival, and San Francisco's DocFest.<ref>{{cite web
Naftali Berrill, Ph.D., Director of the New York Center for Neuropsychology and Forensic Behavioral Science told [[AOL
column2: AOL Health]], ""These may be people who have a very hard time expressing themselves to other people. They may find the human need for affection is met most easily through a relationship with a pet."" This devotion can sometimes signal mental or emotional issues such as depression.<ref name=""huso"">{{cite web
column6: title=Some Live Among Hundreds of Cats

column1: Recent research indicates a link between the parasite ''[[Toxoplasma gondii]]'', which sexually reproduces exclusively in cats, and numerous psychiatric conditions, including [[obsessive compulsive disorder]] (OCD).<ref name=""The Atlantic"">{{cite web
column3: title=How Your Cat Is Making You Crazy - Kathleen McAuliffe
column6: accessdate=2013-06-03}}</ref> The [[compulsive hoarding]] of cats, a symptom of obsessive compulsive disorder (OCD), has long been associated with ""crazy cat ladies"".<ref>{{cite web
column9: author= D.J. Moran and Jennifer L. Patterson
column11: date=2011-06-16}}</ref> Mass media has drawn on this stereotype to coin the term ''Crazy Cat Lady Syndrome'' to refer to the association between ''T. gondii'' and psychiatric conditions.<ref name=""The Atlantic""/>

column1: * [[Florence Nightingale]] had many cats named after famous public figures such as [[William Ewart Gladstone

column2: Edith ""Big Edie"" Ewing Bouvier Beale]] and her daughter [[Edith Beale
column3: Edith ""Little Edie"" Bouvier Beale]] had many cats living with them in their decrepit home [[Grey Gardens (estate)
column4: Grey Gardens]]. Reportedly, some 30 cats lived in the house by the time [[Little Edie]] sold it in 1979.<ref>[http://www.wmagazine.com/w/blogs/editorsblog/2009/04/08/sally-quinn.html Sally Quinn on life in Grey Gardens], ''[[W magazine]]'', April 8, 2009</ref>

column1: * Bertha Rand was Winnipeg's notorious Cat Lady, who for years battled her neighbours and city hall to save her dozens of cats. Even years after her death, she still holds a place in Canadian popular culture. [[Maureen Hunter]]'s play ''The Queen of Queen Street'' is based on Rand's life.<ref>{{cite web
Cat ladies in popular culture include:
* In ''[[Codename: Kids Next Door]]'', the Crazy Old Cat Lady is a half-human half-feline villainess who lives with thousands of black and white cats and possesses the power to control them.
* In the ''[[CSI: Crime Scene Investigation]]'' episode ""[[Cats in the Cradle (CSI episode)
column2: Cats in the Cradle]]"", a cat lady is revealed to have been murdered by a young girl, after the girl and her sister wanted a cat which the lady was unwilling to part with as she considered it one of her children.

column1: * ""Grandma Puggy"" (played by [[Dana Carvey]]) is a widowed grandmother who had cats everywhere and whose hair got on the guests. She was also mentioned in a ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'' ""[[Wayne's World]]"" sketch by Garth (also played by Carvey) who trick-or-treated at the house of ""some weird old lady who had about a gazillion cats and their hair got on my candy apple"".
* [[Angela Martin]] is a character on ''[[The Office (U.S. TV series)
column2: The Office]]'' who is a cat lady.

column1: * In ''[[The Simpsons]]'', the [[Crazy Cat Lady]] is a recurring character whose real name is Eleanor Abernathy.
* Emma Tutweiller in ''[[The Suite Life on Deck]]'' has 30 cats in her cabin.
* Jefferson, as played by [[Tyler, The Creator]] in [[Adult Swim]] television series ''[[Loiter Squad]]'', is a cat person.

* Hattie McDoogal (voiced by [[Tress MacNeille]]), a recurring character in the animated series [[Futurama]] is an old woman who lives alone with her cats and often uses nonsense words and phrases, such as ""kerjigger"". She briefly serves as the landlady of Fry and Bender, and holds a single share of Planet Express, allowing her the decisive vote for its CEO. She has been married twice, surviving both of them, and often dates. She once hired Kif Kroker as a male escort. MacNeille also voices the Crazy Cat Lady on [[The Simpsons]].
* In a key scene in ''[[A Clockwork Orange (film)
column2: A Clockwork Orange]]'' (1971), the violent sociopath Alex DeLarge murders a [[paranoia
column3: paranoid]] cat lady, for which he is convicted and sentenced to a prison term during which he undergoes behavioral training to become a vastly different person.

column2: The End]]'' (1978), [[Sally Field]] plays [[Burt Reynolds]]' distracted cat lady girlfriend Mary Ellen, who is too absorbed in her feline pets to react to Burt's news that he is dying.

column1: * In an iconic scene from [[Tim Burton]]'s ''[[Batman Returns]]'', after being pushed to her breaking point, Selina Kyle ([[Michelle Pfeiffer]]) transforms from a cat lady into [[Catwoman]].

column2: Catwoman]]'', Patience Phillips ([[Halle Berry]]) visits a cat lady who tells her about how to embrace her new identity as [[Catwoman]], claiming an [[Egyptian Mau]] called Midnight chose to give her cat-like superpowers.

column1: * In ''[[The Lego Movie]]'' (2014), Mrs. Scratchen-Post is a cat lady minifigure who is one of Emmet Brickowski's neighbors.

* On [[Venetian Snares]]'s album Songs about my Cats he features a song called ""For Bertha Rand."" The album features many samples of cats which are worked into Aaron's distinct breakcore style of [[Oldschool jungle]].
* ''[[The Cat Lady]]'' (2012) is a psychological horror graphic adventure game developed by Remigiusz Michalski.

column5: accessdate = 2015-11-21}}</ref> an event described as ""like ComicCon, for cat people"" debunked the cat lady myth with panels featuring actress Mayim Bialik<ref>{{Cite web
column6: title = CatConLA Shows the ""Crazy Cat Lady"" Stereotype Is Completely Wrong
column9: accessdate = 2015-11-21}}</ref> and ''Cat Lady Chic'' author Diane Lovejoy.<ref>{{Cite web
column10: title = Here's the Official Schedule For Next Month's Cat Lady Heaven, CatCon LA

column4: Nineteenth century oil painting, ''The Cat's Lunch'' by [[Marguerite Gérard]]]]

column1: The '''cultural depiction of cats''' and their relationship to humans is as old as civilization and stretches back over 9,500 years. [[Cat]]s have figured in the history of many nations, are the subject of legend and are a favorite subject of artists and writers.
Cats were originally domesticated because they hunted [[Mouse
column2: mice]] that would eat stored grains, protecting the food stores. It was a beneficial situation for both species: cats got a reliable source of prey, and humans got effortless pest control. This mutually beneficial arrangement began the relationship between cats and humans which continues to this day.

column1: While the exact history of human interaction with cats is still somewhat vague, a shallow grave site discovered in 1983 in [[Cyprus]], dating to 7500 BCE, during the [[Neolithic]] period, contains the skeleton of a human, buried ceremonially with stone tools, a lump of iron oxide, and a handful of seashells. In its own tiny grave 40 centimeters (18 inches) from the human grave was an eight-month-old cat, its body oriented in the same westward direction as the human skeleton. Cats are not native to Cyprus. This is evidence that cats were being tamed just as humankind was establishing the first settlements in the part of the Middle East known as the [[Fertile Crescent]].<ref>{{cite journal
column6: title=The Evolution of House Cats; Genetic and archaeological findings hint that wildcats became house cats earlier--and in a different place--than previously thought

column1: Cats, known in [[ancient Egypt]] as the ''mau'', played a large role in ancient Egyptian society. They were associated with the goddesses [[Isis]] and [[Bastet
column9: page=38}}</ref> Cats were very commonly depicted in art and routinely mummified.

column5: ''Cats in the Garden'', by Mao Yi, 12th century]]

column1: Cats that were favored pets during the Chinese [[Song Dynasty]] were long-haired cats for catching rats, and cats with yellow-and-white fur called 'lion-cats', who were valued simply as cute pets.<ref name=""gernet 48"">Gernet, 48.</ref><ref name=""gernet 122 123"">Gernet, 122–123.</ref> Cats could be pampered with items bought from the market such as ""cat-nests"", and were often fed fish that were advertised in the market specifically for cats.<ref name=""gernet 48""/><ref name=""gernet 122 123""/>

In [[Norse mythology]], the goddess [[Freyja]] was associated with cats. Farmers sought protection for their crops by leaving pans of milk in their fields for Freya's special feline companions, the two grey cats who fought with her and pulled her chariot.<ref>{{Cite book
column2: title=The Cat in Magic and Myth

column1: [[Folklore]] dating back to as early as 1607 tells that a cat will suffocate a newborn infant by  putting its nose to the child's mouth, sucking the breath out of the infant.<ref name=""deVries76""/>

[[Black cat]]s are generally held to be unlucky in the United States and Europe, and to portend good luck in the United Kingdom.<ref name=""deVries76""/> In the latter country, a black cat entering a house or ship is a good omen, and a sailor's wife should have a black cat for her husband's safety on the sea.<ref name=""deVries76""/><ref>Eyers, Jonathan (2011). ''Don't Shoot the Albatross!: Nautical Myths and Superstitions''. A&C Black, London, UK. {{ISBN
column2: 978-1-4081-3131-2}}.</ref> Elsewhere, it is unlucky if a black cat crosses one's path; black cats have been associated with death and darkness.<ref name=Cirlot62/> White cats, bearing the colour of ghosts, are conversely held to be unlucky in the United Kingdom, while tortoiseshell cats are lucky.<ref name=""deVries76""/> It is common lore that cats have nine lives.<ref name=""deVries76""/> It is a tribute to their perceived durability, their occasional apparent lack of instinct for self-preservation, and their seeming ability to survive falls that would be fatal to other animals.

column1: Cats were seen as good luck charms by actors, and the cats often helped cure the actors' stage fright.<ref name=100cats/>

The Greek essayist [[Plutarch]] linked cats with cleanliness, noting that unnatural odours could make them mad.<ref>Plutarch: Adv. on Marr. 44</ref> Pliny linked them with lust,<ref>Pliny 10, 83</ref> and [[Aesop]] with deviousness and cunning.<ref name=""deVries76"">{{cite book

Cats were associated with witches, and were killed ''en masse'' in the middle of the 14th century during the time of the [[Black Death]]. Had this bias toward cats not existed, local rodent populations could have been kept down, lessening the spread of plague-infected fleas from host to host.<ref>[http://www.usatoday.com/tech/science/genetics/2008-06-09-science-of-cats_N.htm Feline geneticist traces origin of the cat]</ref>
Vikings used cats as rat catchers and companions.

A medieval King of Wales, [[Hywel Dda]] (the Good) passed legislation making it illegal to kill or harm a cat.<ref>[http://www.bl.uk/onlinegallery/takingliberties/staritems/31lawsofhyweldda.html Taking Liberties - Star Items - Laws of Hywel Dda]</ref>
In Medieval [[Ypres]], cats were used in the winter months to control the vermin infesting the wool stored in the upper floors of the [[Cloth Hall, Ypres
column2: Cloth Hall]] (Lakenhall). At the start of the spring warm-up, after the wool had been sold, the cats were thrown out of the [[bell tower
column3: belfry]] tower to the town square below, which supposedly symbolised ""the killing of evil academics"". In today's [[Kattenstoet]] (Cat Parade), this was commuted to the throwing of woolen cats from the top of out houses and also the people from the Middle Ages used to often suck on the wool as a sign of good luck.

column1: In the [[Renaissance]], cats were often thought to be [[witch]]es' [[familiar spirit
column2: familiar]]s (for example, Greymalkin, the first witch's familiar in ''[[Macbeth]]'''s famous opening scene), and during festivities were sometimes [[cat-burning
column3: burnt alive]] or thrown off tall buildings. Cats became popular and sympathetic characters in such [[folklore
column4: folk tale]] as ''[[Puss in Boots]]''.<ref name=purr>Roberts, Patrick. [http://www.purr-n-fur.org.uk/fabled/whittington.html ""Dick Whittington and his Cat: The myth and the reality""], Fabled Felines, purr-n-fur.org (2008)</ref>

column1: One English folk tale in which a cat is given a heroic role is ''[[Dick Whittington and His Cat]]'', which has been adapted for many stage works, including plays, [[musical theatre
column2: musical comedies]] and [[pantomime]]s. It tells of a poor boy in the 14th century, based on the real-life [[Richard Whittington]], who becomes a wealthy merchant and eventually the [[Lord Mayor of London]] because of the ratting abilities of his cat. There is no historical evidence that Whittington had a cat,<ref name=purr/> In the tale, Dick Whittington, a poor orphan finds work at the great house of Mr. Fitzwarren, a rich merchant. His little room infested with rats, Dick acquires a cat, who drives off the rats. One day, Mr. Fitzwarren asked his servants if they wished to send something in his ship, leaving on a journey to a far off port, to trade for gold. Reluctantly, Dick sent his cat. In the far-off court, Dick's cat had become a hero by driving very troublesome vermin from the royal court. When Fitzwarren's ship returned, it was loaded with riches. Dick was a rich man. He joined Mr. Fitzwarren in his business and married his daughter Alice, and in time became the Lord Mayor of London.<ref>Cruikshank, George.  [https://archive.org/details/historyofdickwhi00cruiiala ''The history of Dick Whittington, Lord Mayor of London: with the adventures of his cat''], Banbury, c.1820</ref>

column1: In [[Japan]], there is also the saying called the [[Maneki-neko
column2: Maneki Neko]], also referred to in English as the ""good fortune"" or ""good luck"" cat. It is usually a sitting cat with paw raised and bent. Legend in Japan has it that a cat waved a paw at a Japanese landlord, who was intrigued by this gesture and went towards it. A few seconds later a lightning bolt struck where the landlord had been previously standing. The landlord attributed his good fortune to the cat's fortuitous action. A symbol of good luck hence, it is most often seen in businesses to draw in money. In Japan, the flapping of the hand is a ""come here"" gesture, so the cat is beckoning customers.

column1: There is also a small cat shrine ({{nihongo
column3: 猫神社}}) built in the middle of the [[Tashirojima
column4: Tashirojima island]]. In the past, the islanders raised silkworms for silk, and cats were kept in order to keep the mouse population down (because mice are a natural predator of silkworms). Fixed-net fishing was popular on the island after the Edo Period and fishermen from other areas would come and stay on the island overnight. The cats would go to the inns where the fishermen were staying and beg for scraps. Over time, the fishermen developed a fondness for the cats and would observe the cats closely, interpreting their actions as predictions of the weather and fish patterns. One day, when the fishermen were collecting rocks to use with the fixed-nets, a stray rock fell and killed one of the cats. The fishermen, feeling sorry for the loss of the cat, buried it and enshrined it at this location on the island.

column1: Another Japanese legend of cats is the [[nekomata]]: when a cat lives to a certain age, it grows another tail and can stand up and speak in a human language.

column3: Eighteenth century folk art, ''Cat of Kazan'']]

column1: Cats have been considered good luck in Russia for centuries. Owning a cat, and especially letting one into a new house before the humans move in, is said to bring good fortune.<ref>[http://www.moscowcatmuseum.com/eng/06.html Moscow Cat Museum]</ref>

column2: Many cats have guarded]] the [[Hermitage Museum]]/[[Winter Palace]] continually, since [[Elizabeth of Russia
column3: Empress Elizabeth]]'s reign, when she was presented by the city of [[Kazan]] in [[Tatarstan]] five of their best mousers to control the palace's rodent problem.<ref>[http://www.russianlife.com/article.cfm?Number=1733 Russian Life]</ref> They lived pampered lives and even had special servants until the [[October Revolution]], after which they were cared for by volunteers. Now, they are again looked after by employees.

column1: Cats are considered a delicacy by the West African [[Ewe people]], who believe that eating cat meat, particularly the head, brings good luck to the eater and would prevent them from dying in a foreign land. In [[Ghana]], cats are often associated with witchcraft and evil. Thus, seeing a black cat in one's dream is considered a bad omen.

column3: Pictures of [[Grumpy Cat]] are frequently found in the form of memes, due to Grumpy Cat's deformed features giving a permanently unhappy appearance.]]

column1: Cats have also featured prominently in modern culture. For example, a cat named Mimsey was used by [[MTM Enterprises]] as their mascot and features in their logo as a spoof of the [[Leo the Lion (MGM)
column5: title=100 Cats Who Changed Civilization: History's Most Influential Felines
column9: 1990}} cats were the most popular subject depicted on gift items, such as coasters, napkins, jewelry, and bookends. An estimated 1,000 stores in the United States sold nothing but cat-related items.<ref name=""dickinson19900722"">{{cite news
column11: title=All About/Cat Supplies; Billions for Food, And Knicknacks to Boot

column1: On the Internet, [[The Internet and cats
column2: cats frequently appear]] often as [[meme]]s and other humor; and on social media people frequently post pictures of their own cats.

column1: *[[Muezza]] (Arabic: معزة) was the Prophet [[Muhammad]]'s favorite cat. The most famous story about Muezza recounts how the call to prayer was given, and as Muhammad went to put on one of his robes, he found his cat sleeping on one of the sleeves. Instead of disturbing the cat he cut off the sleeve and let him sleep.
* A similar legend states that when [[Jesus
column2: Jesus Christ]] was born, he would not stop crying no matter what anyone did, and what finally calmed him was when a tabby cat jumped into the manger, and its purring lulled him to sleep. The [[Mary (mother of Jesus)
column3: Virgin Mary]] petted the cat in gratitude, and the ""M"" on the forehead of the [[tabby cat]] is for her name.

column1: *In [[Celtic Mythology]], a [[Cat Sith]] is a fairy cat, sith or sidhe (both pronounced shee) meaning fairy.
*In [[Catholicism]], the patron saint of cats is Saint [[Gertrude of Nivelles]].

* The [[Cat Duet]] ([[Duetto buffo di due gatti]]), attributed to [[Rossini]], is a popular performance piece for two [[soprano]]s, whose ""lyrics"" consist entirely of the repeated word ""miau"" (""[[Cat communication
*Gernet, Jacques (1962). ''Daily Life in China on the Eve of the Mongol Invasion, 1250–1276''. Translated by H.M. Wright. Stanford: Stanford University Press. {{ISBN

*Dodge, Alleine (1949). ''Nine lives: an exhibition of the cat in history and art'', New York: Cooper Union Museum for the Arts of Decoration, [https://archive.org/details/ninelivesanexhib00coop archive.org]

* ''[http://www.worldcat.org/title/cat-and-the-human-imagination-feline-images-from-bast-to-garfield/oclc/37902327/viewport The Cat and the Human Imagination]'' by Katharine M. Rogers; Ann Arbor: University of Michigan Press, 1998. {{ISBN
*[http://www.thegreatcat.org/category/cat-in-history/ The Complete History of the Domestic Cat]
A '''kitten''', also known as a '''kitty''' or '''kitty cat''', is a [[Juvenile (organism)
column2: juvenile]] [[cat]]. After being born, kittens are totally dependent on their mother for survival and they do not normally open their eyes until after seven to ten days. After about two weeks, kittens quickly develop and begin to explore the world outside the nest. After a further three to four weeks, they begin to eat solid food and grow adult teeth. Domestic kittens are highly social animals and enjoy human companionship.

column1: The word ""kitten"" derives from the [[Middle English]] word ''kitoun'', which in turn came from the [[Old French]] ''chitoun'' or ''cheton''.{{sfn
column2: Oxford Dictionary 2005}} Juvenile [[big cat]]s are called ""cubs"" rather than kittens; either term may be used for the young of smaller wild [[felidae
column3: felids]], such as [[ocelot]]s, [[caracal]]s and [[lynx]], but ""kitten"" is usually more common for these species.{{sfn

column4: A litter of kittens being suckled by their mother]]
A kitten opens its eyes for the first time]]
A mother cat protecting her kittens at [[Chinawal]], India]]

column2: litter]] usually consists of two to five kittens{{sfn
column6: p=1699}} born after a [[gestation]] lasting between 64 and 67 days, with an average length of 66 days.{{sfn
column10: p=1699}} Kittens emerge in a sac called the [[amnion]], which is bitten off and eaten by the mother cat.{{sfn

column1: For the first several weeks, kittens are unable to [[urinate]] or [[defecate]] without being stimulated by their mother.{{sfn
column2: Pet Education 2011}} They are also unable to regulate their body temperature for the first three weeks, so kittens born in temperatures less than {{convert
column5: F}} can die from [[hypothermia]] if their mother does not keep them warm.{{sfn
column6: International Cat Care 2015}} The mother's milk is very important for the kittens' nutrition and proper growth. This milk transfers [[antibody
column7: antibodies]] to the kittens, which helps protect them against [[infectious disease]].{{sfn
column12: p=1653}} Newborn kittens are unable to produce concentrated [[urine]], and so have a very high requirement for fluids.{{sfn
column16: p=243}} Kittens open their eyes about seven to ten days after birth. At first, the [[retina]] is poorly developed and vision is poor. Kittens are not able to see as well as adult cats until about ten weeks after birth.{{sfn

column1: Kittens develop very quickly from about two weeks of age until their seventh week. Their coordination and strength improve. They [[play (activity)
column2: play]]-fight with their litter-mates and begin to explore the world outside the nest or den. They learn to wash themselves and others as well as play hunting and stalking games, showing their inborn ability as predators. These innate skills are developed by the kittens' mother or other adult cats, who bring live prey to the nest. Later, the adult cats demonstrate hunting techniques for the kittens to emulate.{{sfn
column6: pp=133–148}} As they reach three to four weeks old, the kittens are gradually [[weaning
column7: weaned]] and begin to eat solid food, with weaning usually complete by six to eight weeks.{{sfn
column11: p=244}} Kittens generally begin to lose their [[deciduous teeth
column12: baby teeth]] around three months of age, and have a complete set of adult teeth by nine months.{{sfn
column13: Veterinary Medicine 2013}} Kittens live primarily on solid food after weaning, but usually continue to suckle from time to time until separated from their mothers. Some mother cats will scatter their kittens as early as three months of age, while others continue to look after them until they approach [[sexual maturity]].{{sfn

column1: The sex of kittens is usually easy to determine at birth. By six to eight weeks they are harder to sex because of the growth of fur in the genital region. The male's [[urinary meatus
column2: urethral opening]] is round, whereas the female's urethral opening is a slit. Another marked difference is the distance between [[anus]] and urethral opening, which is greater in males than in females.{{sfn

column1: Kittens are highly social animals and spend most of their waking hours interacting with available animals and playing on their own. Play with other kittens peaks in the third or fourth month after birth, with more solitary hunting and stalking play peaking later, at about five months.{{sfn

Kittens are vulnerable because they like to find dark places to hide, sometimes with fatal results if they are not watched carefully.<ref>Cats have a habit of seeking refuge under or inside cars or on top of car tires during stormy or cold weather. This often leads to broken bones, burns, heat stroke, damaged internal organs or death. Daphne Sashin, [http://pets.webmd.com/cats/features/risky-hiding-places-for-cats Five Risky Hiding Places For Cats]. WebMD, September 14, 2010.</ref>

Although domestic kittens are commonly sent to new homes at six to eight weeks of age, it has been suggested that being with their mother and litter-mates from six to twelve weeks is important for a kitten's social and behavioural development.{{sfn
column4: p=18}} Usually, breeders and foster/rescue homes will not sell or adopt out a kitten that is younger than twelve weeks. In many jurisdictions, it is illegal to give away kittens younger than eight weeks of age.{{sfn
column8: p=111}} Kittens generally reach sexual maturity at around seven months old. A cat reaches full ""adulthood"" around one year of age.{{sfn

column1: Domestic kittens in developed societies are usually vaccinated against common illnesses from two to three months of age. The usual combination vaccination protects against [[feline viral rhinotracheitis]] (FVR), [[feline calicivirus]] (C), and [[feline panleukopenia]] (P). This FVRCP inoculation is usually given at eight, twelve, and sixteen weeks, and an inoculation against [[rabies]] may be given at sixteen weeks. Kittens are usually [[spaying and neutering
column2: spayed or neutered]] at seven months of age, but kittens may be neutered as young as seven weeks (if large enough), especially in [[animal shelter]]s.{{sfn
column7: pp=223–232}} Such early neutering does not appear to have any [[Spaying and neutering#Disadvantages
column8: long-term health risks to cats]], and may even be beneficial in male cats.{{sfn
column13: pp=372–379}} Kittens are commonly wormed against [[roundworm]]s from about four weeks.{{sfn

column6: black kitten]] in [[Los Angeles]], showing signs of [[malnourishment]]]]

column1: Kittens require a high-calorie diet that contains more protein than the diet of adult cats.{{sfn
column5: pp=718–723}} Young orphaned kittens require cat milk every two to four hours, and they need physical stimulation to defecate and urinate.{{sfn
column6: Pet Education 2011}} Cat milk replacement is manufactured to feed to young kittens, because [[Dairy cattle
column7: cow]]'s milk does not provide all the necessary nutrients.{{sfn
column10: pp=2663–2669}} Human-reared kittens tend to be very affectionate with humans as adults and sometimes more dependent on them than kittens reared by their mothers, but they can also show volatile mood swings and aggression.{{sfn
column13: p=102}} Depending on the age at which they were orphaned and how long they were without their mothers, these kittens may be severely underweight and can have health problems later in life, such as heart conditions. The compromised immune system of orphaned kittens (from lack of antibodies found naturally in the mother's milk) can make them especially susceptible to infections, making antibiotics a necessity.{{sfn

study]] of [[cat]]s.<ref>As noted in the [[University of Belgrade]]'s Faculty of Veterinary Medicine [http://www.vfs.unsa.ba/ba_docs/desavanja/workshop_bologna_2007/7a_Beograd.ppt Curriculum]</ref> The term is of [[Latin]]-[[Greek language
column3: Greek]] origin and comes from the Latin word ''{{lang
column5: felinus}}'' (of cats, feline) and the Greek ''{{lang
column7: -logos}}'' (science). Felinology is concerned with studying the [[anatomy]], [[genetics]], [[physiology]], and [[animal husbandry
column8: breeding]] of domestic and wild cats.

column1: '''Fel d 1''' is a [[protein]] that in cats is encoded by the ''CH1'' (chain 1/Fel d 1-A) and ''CH2'' (chain 2/Fel d 1-B) [[genes]].<ref name=""pmid1946388"">{{cite journal
column2: vauthors=Morgenstern JP, Griffith IJ, Brauer AW, Rogers BL, Bond JF, Chapman MD, Kuo MC
column3: title = Amino acid sequence of Fel dI, the major allergen of the domestic cat: protein sequence analysis and cDNA cloning
column4: journal = Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A.
column13: vauthors=Griffith IJ, Craig S, Pollock J, Yu XB, Morgenstern JP, Rogers BL
column14: title = Expression and genomic structure of the genes encoding FdI, the major allergen from the domestic cat

column1: Fel d 1, produced largely in [[cat]] [[saliva]] and [[sebaceous gland]]s, is the primary [[allergen]] present on cats and kittens.<ref name=""pmid12851385"" /> Fel d 1 is also produced by cat skin itself.<ref>{{cite journal
column16: title=Cat skin as an important source of Fel d I allergen
column17: journal=Journal of Allergy and Clinical Immunology
column21: doi=10.1016/S0091-6749(05)80200-3}}</ref> The protein is of an unknown function to the animal but causes an [[IgG]] or [[IgE]] reaction in sensitive humans (either as an allergic or asthmatic response). Removal of soft surfaces in the home (carpet, furniture), frequent washings of bed linens, [[HEPA]] filters and even washing cats has been proven to reduce the amounts of Fel d 1 present in the home.

column1: Female cats produce a lower level of Fel d 1 than males, and neutered males produce a lower level of Fel d 1 than unneutered males.<ref>Sex difference in Fel d 1 allergen production. http://www.jacionline.org/article/S0091-6749(96)70238-5/fulltext . Accessed 31 Oct 2016.</ref>

Neutered males produce Fel d 1 in levels similar to females (both intact and spayed females produce Fel d 1 in similar levels). Even though females and neutered males produce Fel d 1 in lower levels, they still produce enough to cause [[Allergy#Signs and symptoms
The complete [[quaternary structure]] of Fel d 1 has been determined.<ref name=""pmid12851385"" /> The allergen is a [[tetrameric protein
column2: tetrameric]] [[glycoprotein]] consisting of two [[disulfide]]-linked [[heterodimer]]s of chains 1 and 2. Fel d 1 chains 1 and 2 share [[secondary structure
column4: superfamily]] member; chain 2 is a glycoprotein with N-linked [[oligosaccharide]]s. Both chains share an all alpha-helical structure.<ref name=""pmid12851385"" />

column2: zoosadistic]] entertainment in [[France]] prior to the 1800s. In this form of entertainment, people would gather dozens of [[cat]]s in a net and hoist them high into the air from a special bundle onto a [[bonfire]]. In the [[medieval]] and [[early modern]] periods, cats, which were associated with [[vanity]] and [[witchcraft]], were sometimes burned as symbols of the [[Devil]].<ref>{{Cite book
column7: title= Holy Terrors: Gargoyles on Medieval Buildings

column1: According to [[Norman Davies]], the assembled people ""shrieked with laughter as the animals, howling with pain, were singed, roasted, and finally [[Carbonization

[[James Frazer]] wrote: ""It was the custom to burn a basket, barrel, or sack full of live cats, which was hung from a tall mast in the midst of the bonfire; sometimes a [[fox]] was burned. The people collected the embers and ashes of the fire and took them home, believing that they brought good luck. The French kings often witnessed these spectacles and even lit the bonfire with their own hands. In 1648 [[Louis XIV]], crowned with a wreath of roses and carrying a bunch of roses in his hand, kindled the fire, danced at it and partook of the banquet afterwards in the town hall. But this was the last occasion when a monarch presided at the midsummer bonfire in Paris. At [[Metz]] midsummer fires were lighted with great pomp on the esplanade, and a dozen cats, enclosed in [[wicker]] cages, were burned alive in them, to the amusement of the people. Similarly at [[Gap, Hautes-Alpes
column3: department]] of the [[Hautes-Alpes]], cats used to be roasted over the midsummer bonfire.""<ref>[[James Frazer
column4: Frazer, Sir James George]]. ''The Golden Bough'', (1922). [http://www.bartleby.com/196/164.html Online version.]</ref>

column1: Cat-burning was also described in [[The Great Cat Massacre]], a scholarly work by American historian [[Robert Darnton]]:

<blockquote>Cats also figured in the cycle of Saint John the Baptist, which took place on June 24, at the time of summer solstice. Crowds made bonfires, jumped over them, danced around them, and threw into them objects with magical power, hoping to avoid disaster and obtain good fortune during the rest of the year. A favorite object was cats — cats tied up in bags, cats suspended from ropes, or cats burned at stake. Parisians liked to incinerate cats by the sackful, while the Courimauds (or ""cour à miaud"" or cat chasers) of Saint Chamond preferred to chase a flaming cat through the streets. In parts of Burgundy and Lorraine they danced around a kind of burning May pole with a cat tied to it. In the Metz region they burned a dozen cats at a time in a basket on top of a bonfire. The ceremony took place with great pomp in Metz itself, until it was abolished in 1765. ... Although the practice varied from place to place, the ingredients were everywhere the same: a ""feu de joie"" (bonfire), cats, and an aura of hilarious witch-hunting. Wherever the scent of burning felines could be found, a smile was sure to follow.<ref name=""Cat Massacre"">{{cite book
column4: title=The Great Cat Massacre: And Other Episodes in French Cultural History

column1: Cat-burning was the subject of a 1758 text from the Benedictine Dom Jean François, ''Dissertation sur l’ancien usage des feux de la Saint-Jean, et d’y brûler les chats à Metz'', recently published.<ref name=""Dissertation"">{{cite book
column4: title=Dissertation sur l’ancien usage des feux de la Saint-Jean, et d’y brûler les chats à Metz, un inédit de dom Jean François

column1: [[Jean Meslier]], a French Catholic priest who privately held atheist views, briefly mentioned the practice of cat burning in his ''Testament'' as follows:

<blockquote>Among other things, these mischievous, brutal madmen make [the cats] cruelly suffer harsh and violent tortures in their entertainments and even in public celebrations; they tie up nipping cats to the end of some pole they set up and at the bottom of which they light the fires of joy where they burn them alive to have the pleasure of seeing the violent movements and hearing the frightening cries that these poor unfortunate beasts are forced to make because of the harshness and violence of the tortures.<ref name=""Meslier"">{{cite book
column4: title=Testament: Memoir of the thoughts and sentiments of Jean Meslier

column1: Meslier largely attributed these customs to [[Cartesianism
column2: Cartesian philosophy]], wherein non-human animals were viewed as possessing no soul, and thus, no sentience.<ref>{{cite web
column8: accessdate=16 September 2012}}</ref> He posited that this ""tends to stifle in the heart of man all feelings of gentleness, kindness, and compassion that they may have for beasts ...""<ref name=""Meslier"" />

column1: * [https://books.google.com/books?id=5lclnUXYB4sC&pg=PA107&lpg=PA107&dq=%22cat+burning%22&source=web&ots=Nv37ccz_ru&sig=8WkQl0dPws4LzE1Lsh_-iNytUzY Link to Google book excerpt describing cat-burning in France]
* Jouffroy, Christian [http://hdl.handle.net/2042/34009 La société d'étude des sciences et des arts, Metz, avril 1757]

* Dunwich, Gerina [https://books.google.com/books?id=Wxl29ZAvx54C&pg=PA61&dq=%22cat+burning%22&ei=4_QMR7KzB4Xy6gLDwcWuBg&sig=oHkM6jcJKHkAQnVZVZ5-fjPiA5c#PPA60,M1 Your Magickal Cat: Feline Magick, Lore, and Worship] Google Books
This category is for non-fictional domestic felines.  For fictional cats, use [[:Category:Fictional cats]].
Hundreds of millions of [[cat]]s are kept as [[pet]]s around the world. Cats have either a [[Mutualism (biology)
column3: commensal]] relationship with humans. Cats are also used in the fur trade, as food, and to control pests.

column1: Cats and humans evolutionarily diverged from a common ancestor ([[boreoeutherian ancestor]]) approximately 80 million years ago, accumulating only 10–12 [[chromosomal translocation]]s.<ref>{{cite book
column8: isbn =0851990754}}</ref> The order of several [[gene]]s in chromosomes [[X chromosome
column10: Y]] in cats closely resembles that in humans.<!-- already referenced below -->

column3: Cat and human resting in bed together.]]

column1: [[Cat]]s are common [[pet]]s in all continents of the world, and their global population is difficult to ascertain, with estimates ranging from anywhere between 200 million to 600 million.<ref>{{cite web
column6: title=Tentative estimation of the total number of domestic cats in the world
column15: title=Cats: most interesting facts about common domestic pets
column19: title=Study Traces Cat’s Ancestry to Middle East
column27: title=Urban Carnivores: Ecology, Conflict, and Conservation

column1: In 1998 there were around 76 million cats in Europe, 7 million in Japan and 3 million in Australia.<ref name=""Turner 2000"" >{{Cite book
column6: title=The Domestic Cat: The Biology of its Behaviour
column12: 4}} A 2007 report stated that about 37 million US households owned cats, with an average of 2.2 cats per household giving a total population of around 82 million; in contrast, there are about 72 million pet dogs in that country.<ref name=AMAstats>{{cite web
column14: title=Market Research Statistics – U.S. Pet Ownership
column20: df=dmy-all }}</ref> Cats exceeded dogs in number as pets in the United States in 1985 for the first time, in part because the development of [[Litter box
column21: kitty litter]] in the mid-20th century eliminated the unpleasantly powerful smell of cat urine.<ref name=""mcgthomas19951006"">{{cite news
column23: title=Edward Lowe Dies at 75; a Hunch Led Him to Create Kitty Litter

column1: Although cat ownership has commonly been associated with women,<ref name=""Ellin"">{{Cite news
column3: title=More Men Are Unabashedly Embracing Their Love of Cats
column7: date=5 October 2008}}</ref> a 2007 [[Gallup (company)#Polling in the United States
column8: Gallup poll]] reported that men and women in the United States of America were equally likely to own a cat.<ref name=""Gallup"">{{cite web
column10: title=Companionship and Love of Animals Drive Pet Ownership
column15: accessdate=30 August 2009}}</ref> The ratio of pedigree/purebred cats to random-bred cats varies from country to country. However, generally speaking, purebreds are less than 10% of the total population.<ref>{{cite book

column1: According to the [[Humane Society of the United States]], as well as being kept as pets, cats are also used in the international [[fur trade]].<ref>{{cite web
column6: publisher=Humane Society of the United States
column7: accessdate=22 October 2009}}</ref> Cat fur is used in coats, gloves, hats, shoes, blankets and stuffed toys. About 24 cats are needed to make a cat fur coat.<ref>{{Cite news
column9: title=EU proposes cat and dog fur ban
column12: date=20 November 2006}}</ref> This use has now been outlawed in several countries, including the United States, Australia and the European Union.<ref>{{cite web
column16: title=EU Announces Strict Ban on Dog and Cat Fur Imports and Exports
column22: accessdate=14 December 2011}}</ref> However, some cat furs are still made into blankets in [[Switzerland]] as [[traditional medicine
column23: folk remedies]] that are believed to help [[rheumatism]].<ref>{{Cite news
column25: title=Switzerland Finds a Way to Skin a Cat for the Fur Trade and High Fashion

column1: It has long been common for cats to be eaten in some parts of China and in some other Asian countries and it is estimated that in southern China's [[Guangdong]] province people eat 10,000 cats per day.<ref>{{cite news
column3: title=China Protesters: Stop 'Cooking Cats Alive' – Fury After Newspaper Says 10,000 Felines Are Eaten Daily in Single Province
column7: accessdate=14 December 2011}}</ref> [[Animal People]] estimates that 4 million cats are killed and consumed in Asia every year.<ref>{{cite web
column12: title=How Many Dogs and Cats Are Eaten in Asia?
column20: df=dmy-all }}</ref> An animal-rights group collected 16,000 signatures in 2014 to outlaw the consumption of cat meat in Switzerland.<ref>{{cite web
column21: title= Cat and dog meat off the menu in Switzerland?

column1: Cats are also used as a form of pest control, particularly in the case of rat or mouse infestation.<ref>''Clones, Cats, And Chemicals: Thinking Scientifically About Controversial Issues''. p. 9. Irwin L. Slesnick (2004).</ref><ref>''Pests of Crops in Warmer Climates and Their Control''. p. 120. Dennis S. Hill (2008).</ref>

The current [[list of cat breeds]] is quite large: with the [[Cat Fanciers' Association]] recognizing 41 breeds, of which 16 are ""natural breeds"" that probably emerged before humans began breeding pedigree cats, while the others were developed over the latter half of the 20th century.<ref name=Lipinski>{{Cite journal
column6: title=The ascent of cat breeds: Genetic evaluations of breeds and worldwide random-bred populations

column1: }}</ref> Because of common crossbreeding, many cats are simply identified as belonging to the homogeneous breeds of [[domestic long-haired cat
column3: domestic shorthair]], depending on their type of fur.

column1: These are discussed at [[Cat coat genetics#Cat coat patterns and colors
Cats can also come in several body types, ranging between two extremes:
; Oriental: Not a specific breed, but any cat with an elongated slender build, almond-shaped eyes, long nose, large ears (the Siamese and [[Oriental Shorthair]] breeds are examples of this).
; Foreign: Less slender than the oriental type, but nevertheless a cat with a slight build and generally athletic look. Typical example breeds would be the [[Abyssinian (cat)
; Semi-Foreign: More or less the middle range of body conformation types, this type of cat is less slender without being stocky. Example breeds would be the [[Devon Rex]] and the [[Egyptian Mau]].
; Semi-Cobby: These cats look more rounded without looking too stocky. Example breeds would be the [[American Shorthair]] and [[British Shorthair]].
; Cobby: Any cat with a short, muscular, compact build, roundish eyes, short nose, and small ears. [[Persian cat]]s and [[Exotic Shorthair
column2: Exotic cat]]s are two prime examples of such a body type.

column1: Because of their small size, domesticated house cats pose little physical danger to adult humans. However, in the USA cats inflict about 400,000 bites per year. This number represents about one in ten of all animal bites.<ref name=Kravetz/> Many cat bites will become infected,<ref>{{Cite journal
column2: vauthors=Talan DA, Citron DM, Abrahamian FM, Moran GJ, Goldstein EJ
column3: title=Bacteriologic analysis of infected dog and cat bites. Emergency Medicine Animal Bite Infection Study Group
column10: doi=10.1056/NEJM199901143400202}}</ref> sometimes with serious consequences such as [[cat-scratch disease]], or, more rarely, [[rabies]].<ref name=Kravetz>{{Cite journal
column19: doi=10.1001/archinte.162.17.1945}}</ref> Cats may also pose a danger to pregnant women and [[immunosuppression
column20: immunosuppressed]] individuals, since their feces can transmit [[toxoplasmosis]].<ref name=Torda>{{Cite journal
column22: title=Toxoplasmosis. Are cats really the source?
column28: pmid=11681144}}</ref> A large percentage of cats are infected with this parasite, with infection rates ranging from around 40 to 60% in both domestic and stray cats worldwide.<ref name=""pmid9870370"">{{Cite journal
column29: vauthors=Svobodová V, Knotek Z, Svoboda M
column30: title=Prevalence of IgG and IgM antibodies specific to Toxoplasma gondii in cats
column38: vauthors=Meireles LR, Galisteo AJ, Pompeu E, Andrade HF
column39: title=Toxoplasma gondii spreading in an urban area evaluated by seroprevalence in free-living cats and dogs
column47: vauthors=De Craeye S, Francart A, Chabauty J
column48: title=Prevalence of Toxoplasma gondii infection in Belgian house cats
column55: doi=10.1016/j.vetpar.2008.07.001}}</ref> Research indicates a link between the parasite ''[[Toxoplasma gondii]]'', which sexually reproduces exclusively in cats, and numerous human psychiatric conditions, including OCD.<ref name=""The Atlantic"">{{cite web
column57: title=How Your Cat Is Making You Crazy - Kathleen McAuliffe
column60: accessdate=2013-06-03}}</ref> The [[compulsive hoarding]] of cats, a symptom of obsessive compulsive disorder (OCD), has long been associated with ""crazy [[Cat lady

column2: Allergic]] reactions to cat [[dander]] and/or cat saliva are common.<ref>{{Cite journal
column3: vauthors=Erwin EA, Woodfolk JA, Custis N, Platts-Mills TA
column11: doi=10.1016/S0889-8561(03)00004-3}}</ref> Some humans who are [[Allergy to cats
column12: allergic to cats]]—typically manifested by [[Allergic rhinitis
column13: hay fever]], [[asthma]], or a skin [[rash]]—quickly acclimate themselves to a particular animal and live comfortably in the same house with it, while retaining an allergy to cats in general.<ref>{{cite web
column20: date=October 2016}}</ref> Whether the risk of developing allergic diseases such as asthma is increased or decreased by cat ownership is uncertain.<ref>{{Cite journal
column23: title=Early pet exposure: friend or foe?
column31: title=Pets and the development of allergic sensitization
column38: doi=10.1007/s11882-005-0040-x}}</ref> Some owners cope with this problem by taking allergy medicine, along with bathing their cats frequently, since weekly bathing will reduce the amount of dander shed by a cat.<ref>{{Cite journal

column2: title=Evaluation of different techniques for washing cats: quantitation of allergen removed from the cat and the effect on airborne Fel d 1
journal=Journal of Allergy and Clinical Immunology

column1: }}</ref> There have also been attempts to breed [[Allergy to cats#Hypoallergenic cats
column2: hypoallergenic cats]], which would be less likely to provoke an allergic reaction.<ref>{{Cite journal
title=Cat and Mouse in Regulating Genetic 'Enhancement'

column1: As well as posing health risks, interactions with cats may improve health and reduce physical responses to stress: for example the presence of cats may moderate increased [[blood pressure]].<ref>{{Cite journal
column8: title=Cardiovascular reactivity and the presence of pets, friends, and spouses: the truth about cats and dogs
column15: doi=10.1097/01.PSY.0000024236.11538.41}}</ref> Cat ownership may also improve psychological health by providing emotional support and dispelling feelings of depression, anxiety and loneliness.<ref name=""Fogle"" >{{Cite book
column22: 23–56}} Their ability to provide companionship and friendship are common reasons given for owning a cat.<ref name=Gallup/>

column1: From another point of view, cats are thought to be able to improve the general [[Mood (psychology)
column2: mood]] of their owners by alleviating negative attitudes. According to a Swiss study carried out in 2003, cats may change the overall psychological state of their owner as their company's effect appears to be comparable to that of a human partner.<ref name=""Turner 2003"">{{Cite journal
column10: title=Abstract: 'Spouses and Cats and Their Effects on Human Mood'
column15: accessdate=25 June 2010}}</ref> The researchers concluded that, while cats were not shown to promote positive moods, they do alleviate negative ones.

column1: One study found that cat ownership is associated with a reduced risk of heart attacks and strokes at the 95% confidence interval.<ref>{{Cite journal
column10: title=Cat Ownership and the Risk of Fatal Cardiovascular Diseases
column11: journal=Journal of Vascular and Interventional Neurology

column1: Several studies have shown that cats develop affection towards their owners. However, the effect of these pets on human health is closely related to the time and effort the cat owner is able to invest in it, in terms of bonding and playing.<ref>{{cite journal
column2: title=Beneficial Effects of Pet Ownership on Some Aspects of Human Health and Behaviour
column11: journal=Journal of the Royal Society of Medicine}}</ref>

column1: A natural behavior in cats is to hook their front claws periodically into suitable surfaces and pull backwards. Cats, like humans, keep their muscles trim and their body flexible by stretching.  Additionally, such periodic scratching serves to clean and sharpen their claws.<ref>{{Cite journal
column3: title=Feline scratching and destruction and the effects of declawing
column4: journal=Vet. Clin. North Am. Small Anim. Pract.
column9: pmid=2053250}}</ref>  Indoor cats may benefit from being provided with a [[scratching post]] so that they are less likely to use carpet or furniture, which they can easily ruin.<ref>{{cite web
column10: title=FAB Information Sheet: Scratching or Clawing in the House
column16: accessdate=14 August 2005}}</ref> However, some cats may simply ignore such a device. Commercial scratching posts typically are covered in carpeting or upholstery. Using a plain wooden surface, or reversing the carpeting on the posts so that the rougher texture of the carpet backing, may be a more attractive alternative to the cat than the floor covering. Scratching posts made of [[sisal]] rope or [[corrugated fiberboard

column1: Although scratching can serve cats to keep their claws from growing excessively long, their nails can be trimmed if necessary. Another response to indoor scratching is [[onychectomy]], commonly known as declawing. This is a surgical procedure to remove the claw and first bone of each digit of a cat's paws. Declawing is most commonly only performed on the front feet. A related procedure is [[tendonectomy]], which involves cutting a tendon needed for cats to extend their claws.<ref name=Swiderski>{{Cite journal
column3: title=Onychectomy and its alternatives in the feline patient
column10: doi=10.1053/svms.2002.36604}}</ref> Declawing is a major surgical procedure and can produce pain, and  infections.<ref name=""Swiderski""/>

column1: Since this surgery is almost always performed for the benefit of owners, it is controversial and remains uncommon outside of North America.<ref name=AMAwelfare>[https://www.avma.org/KB/Resources/Backgrounders/Pages/Welfare-Implications-of-Declawing-of-Domestic-Cats-Backgrounder.aspx Welfare Implications of Declawing of Domestic Cats] ''American Veterinary Medical Association'' 9 April 2009</ref> In many countries, declawing is prohibited by [[animal welfare]] laws and it is ethically controversial within the veterinary community.<ref name=""autogenerated1"">{{Cite journal
column4: title=Assessment of claims of short- and long-term complications associated with onychectomy in cats
column12: url=http://symptomresearch.nih.gov/chapter_1/index.htm}}</ref> While both the [[Humane Society of the United States]] and the [[American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals]] strongly discourage or condemn the procedure,<ref>{{cite web
column17: accessdate=30 October 2011}}</ref> the [[American Veterinary Medical Association]] supports the procedure under certain guidelines and finds ""no scientific evidence that declawing leads to behavioral abnormalities when the behavior of declawed cats is compared with that of cats in control groups.""<ref name=AVMA>{{cite web
column19: title=Issues: AVMA Policy: Declawing of Domestic Cats
column27: df=dmy-all }}</ref> They further argue that many cats would be given up and euthanized were declawing not performed.<ref name=""AMAwelfare"" />

column1: Being fastidious self-cleaners, cats detest their own waste and instinctually bury their urine and feces. Indoor cats are usually provided with a box containing [[Litter box
column2: litter]], generally consisting of [[bentonite]], but sometimes other absorbent material such as shredded paper or wood chips, or sometimes [[sand]] or similar material can be used. It should be cleaned daily and changed often, depending on the number of cats in a household and the type of litter; if it is not kept clean, a cat may be fastidious enough to find other locations in the house for urination or defecation. This may also happen for other reasons; for instance, if a cat becomes [[constipation
column3: constipated]] and defecation is uncomfortable, it may associate the discomfort with the litter box and avoid it in favor of another location.

column1: Daily attention to the litter box also serves as a monitor of the cat's health. Bentonite or clumping litter is a variation which absorbs urine into clumps which can be sifted out along with feces, and thus stays cleaner longer with regular sifting, but has sometimes been reported to cause health problems in some cats.<ref>{{Cite journal
column7: title=Suspected bentonite toxicosis in a cat from ingestion of clay cat litter

column1: Some cats can be trained to use the human toilet, eliminating the litter box and its attendant expense, [[Odor
column2: unpleasant odor]], and the need to use landfill space for disposal.

column1: An exhibit at the [[San Diego Natural History Museum]] states that cat feces from [[urban runoff]] carry [[Toxoplasma gondii]] parasites to the ocean and kill [[sea otter]]s.<ref>http://www-csgc.ucsd.edu/RESEARCH/PROJPROF_PDF/Conrad_CZ169.pdf</ref>
The order of eight [[gene]]s on the cats' [[Y chromosome]] closely resembles that in humans.<ref name=""GNN"">{{cite web
column3: title=Cats and humans share similar X and Y chromosomes
column7: accessdate =14 Feb 2015}}</ref> Genes on [[X chromosome]]s of cats and humans are arranged in similar way.<ref name=""GNN""/>

column1: Domestic cats are affected by over 250 naturally occurring [[Genetic disorder
column2: hereditary disorders]], many of which are similar to those in humans, such as [[diabetes]], [[haemophilia
column3: hemophilia]] and [[Tay–Sachs disease]].<ref name=""GNN""/><ref name=""GR"">{{cite web
column7: accessdate =14 Feb 2015}}</ref> For example, [[Abyssinian cat]]'s pedigree contains a [[Mutation
column8: genetic mutation]] that causes [[retinitis pigmentosa]], which also affects humans.<ref name=""GR""/> The domestic cat is also an excellent model for human infectious diseases, including [[HIV/AIDS]].<ref name=""GR""/> [[Feline immunodeficiency virus]] (FIV) is a genetic relative of [[HIV]].<ref name=""GR""/>

column1: '''Operation Cat Drop''' is the name commonly given to an account, of uncertain veracity, about the delivery, by the [[United Kingdom]]'s [[Royal Air Force]], of cats to a remote village in [[Sarawak]], [[Borneo]]. The cats were delivered in crates, dropped by parachute, as part of a broader program of supplying cats to combat a plague of rats. The cat population had previously been reduced as an unintended consequence of spraying [[DDT]] for [[malaria]] control. The story, often with various elaborations is often told as an illustration of the problems that may arise from well-intended interventions in the environment, or of [[unintended consequences]] more generally.

It is not clear whether the events of the Operation Cat Drop story actually transpired as the story is commonly told or if the cats were ever delivered by parachute. While cats are indeed unusually susceptible to the toxic effects of DDT, and cat die-offs were a not unheard of side effect of malaria control operations, many aspects of the story have been called into question. For example, it was probably [[dieldrin]] rather than DDT which was used for malaria control in the region and caused numerous cat deaths.<ref name=""pmid18799776"">{{cite journal
column3: title=Parachuting cats and crushed eggs the controversy over the use of DDT to control malaria

column1: Video footage purporting to show an aerial drop of beavers, intended to improve water quality, appeared in October 2015<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Beavers are good for streams. Now watch found footage of beavers parachuting
