* [http://www.strange-loops.com/scicatdrop.html Systems Thinking: Operation Cat Drop and Chaotic Kindness]

column4: Feral cat with a tipped ear indicating it was neutered in a [[trap-neuter-return]] program]]

column2: feral]] cat''' is a [[cat]] that has been born to other ferals or from stray cats as opposed to domesticated cats.  These ferals are unaccustomed to human interaction.<ref name="":10"">{{Cite web
column9: publisher=[[The Humane Society of the United States]]

column1: This article discusses the definition, history, behavior, health, distribution and habitat, control and management, and effects on wildlife.  Further subtopics incehaviors and characteristics of both farm cats and ship's cats and how they relate to feral cats.

Feral is an adjective defined as existing in a wild state, not domesticated. It can also be used to describe a quality of wild animals as ferocious or brutal. The meaning of the term ''feral cat'' varies between professions and countries, and is sometimes used interchangeably with other terms such as ''free-roaming'', ''street'', ''alley,'' or ''community cat''. Feral can also mean reverting to the wild state from domestication therefore, some of these terms are also used to refer to stray cats, although stray and feral cats are generally considered to be different by [[Animal rescue group
column3: veterinarians]], and researchers.<ref name=""definition"" /> Stray cats are socialized cats who no longer live in homes, but could potentially be successfully reintroduced to a home environment.<ref>{{cite web
column5: title=Feral and Stray Cats—An Important Difference

column1: A 2013 article in the ''[[Journal of Feline Medicine and Surgery]]'' found that rescuers and veterinarians in the [[United Kingdom]] tended to distinguish feral cats from domesticated cats based on traits such as their levels of socialization, ownership, and confinement, and on the amount of fear of, interaction with, and dependence upon humans. They found that rescuers and veterinarians tended to agree that feral cats were cats that had not had much human contact (particularly before eight weeks of age), would try to avoid humans, and would prefer to escape rather than attack a human. However, veterinarians and rescuers disagreed on whether a feral cat would tend to hiss and spit at or attack a human during an encounter, and disagreed on whether adult ferals could potentially be [[Tame animal
column2: tamed]]. The article provided a composite definition of a feral cat as a cat that would choose not to interact with humans, could survive with or without human assistance, and would hide or defend itself when trapped rather than allowing itself to be handled.<ref name=""definition"">{{cite journal
column10: title = What is a feral cat?: Variation in definitions may be associated with different management strategies.
column11: journal = Journal of Feline Medicine and Surgery
column12: quote = PROPOSED DEFINITION: A feral cat is proposed by this study to be a cat that is unapproachable in its free-roaming environment and is capable of surviving with or without direct human intervention, and may additionally show fearful or defensive behaviour on human contact.

column1: A survey of rescuers and veterinarians in the [[United States]] found that there was no widely accepted definition of a feral cat. Many facilities used waiting periods to evaluate whether a cat was feral by observing whether the cat became less afraid and evasive over time. Other indicators included the cat's response to touch with an inanimate object, and observation of social behavior from the cat in varying environments (in response to human contact, with a human nearby, or when moved to a quieter environment).<ref name="":5"">{{Cite journal
column13: title=A survey of the methods used in shelter and rescue programs to identify feral and frightened pet cats
column14: journal=Journal of Feline Medicine and Surgery
column20: pmid=20460192}}</ref> The [[American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals]] defines community cats as either cats who were born and raised in the wild, or domestic cats who have been abandoned or lost and turned to wild ways in order to survive.<ref name="":3"">{{cite web
column22: title=A Closer Look at Community Cats

column1: The Australian government categorizes cats who have no interaction with or assistance from humans as feral, and unowned cats who rely on humans as [[semi-feral]] or stray.<ref name=""dsewpc"" /><ref name=""daf"">{{Cite report
column3: author = Department of Agriculture and Fisheries

column1: [[Farm cat]]s (also called barn cats) are cats that live on agricultural properties in [[feral]] or [[semi-feral]] condition. They primarily live outdoors, usually sheltering in outbuildings. They hunt [[vermin]] such as rodents and other small animals that live in or around outbuildings and farm fields.

The need to keep rodents from consuming or contaminating grain crops stored for later human consumption may be the original reason cats were domesticated.<ref name=""Pedersen 1991"" /> They are still commonly kept for the purpose of catching undesired vermin found on [[farm]]s and [[ranch]]es, which would otherwise eat or contaminate [[crops]], especially [[cereal
column5: title=Geller: The care, keeping and importance of barn cats

column1: [[Ship's cat]]s are typically feral or semi-feral, and were once common features on many trading, exploration, and naval ships. Cats were primarily brought aboard to catch mice and rats, which can cause damage to ropes, woodwork, and eventually as technology progressed, electrical wiring. Rodents also presented a threat to the stores the ship carried, both as cargo and as food for sailors. Rats and mice were also sources of [[disease]], which was dangerous for ships at sea for long periods of time.<ref>{{cite web
column5: access-date=9 March 2016}}</ref> Cats have been officially banned from some commercial and military fleets, though they are sometimes still kept privately by sailors.<ref>{{Cite encyclopedia

column1: Although scientists do not agree on whether cats were originally domesticated in [[Egypt]] or if they were introduced there after domestication, the spread of cats throughout much of the world is thought to have originated in Egypt, where they were popular and effective at controlling [[mouse]] populations. Traders from [[Phoenicia]] brought them to Europe to control [[rat]] populations, and monks brought them further into Asia. Roman armies also helped with the spread, eventually bringing them to [[England]].<ref name=""Pedersen 1991"">{{Cite encyclopedia
column2: title = History of domestic cats and cat breeds
column4: encyclopedia = Feline Husbandry: Diseases and Management in the Multiple Cat Environment
column11: isbn = 978-0939674299}}</ref> Since then, cats continued to be introduced to new areas, often by sailors or settlers. Cats are thought to have been introduced to Australia in either the 1600s by Dutch shipwrecks, or the late 1700s by English settlers.<ref name=""dsewpc"" /><ref name="":0"" /> These domesticated cats began to form feral populations after their offspring began living away from human contact.<ref name="":0"">{{Cite report
column12: title = Overview of the Impacts of Feral Cats on Australian Native Fauna
column17: publisher = Australian Nature Conversation Agency and University of Sydney}}</ref>

column1: Some behaviors are commonly observed among feral cats, although there is disagreement among veterinarians, rescuers, and researchers on the prevalence of some. In a free-roaming environment, feral cats avoid humans. They do not allow themselves to be handled or touched by humans, and back away or run when they are able to do so. If trapped, they may hiss, growl, bare their teeth, or strike out.<ref name="":4"">{{Cite book
column2: title=Cat Culture: The Social World of A Cat Shelter
column11: pages=}}</ref> They remain fairly hidden from humans and will not approach, although some feral cats gradually become more comfortable around humans who feed them regularly.<ref>{{cite web
column15: website=The Humane Society of the United States

column1: Feral cats often live in ''colonies'', groups of feral cats that live together in one territory, often near food sources and shelter.<ref name="":3"" /> Researchers disagree on the existence, extent, and structure of [[Dominance hierarchy
column2: dominance hierarchies]] within feral colonies.<ref name="":4"" /><ref>{{Cite journal
column10: title=Social organization in the cat: A modern understanding
column11: journal=Journal of Feline Medicine and Surgery
column17: pmid=15123163}}</ref> Different types of hierarchies have been observed in feral colonies, including [[Despotism
column18: despotic]] and linear hierarchies. Some colonies are organized in more complex structures, such as relative hierarchies, where social status of individual cats can vary on their location, the time of day, or the activity the cats are engaged in (particularly feeding and mating).<ref>{{Cite journal
column20: title = Social Behavior of Domestic Cats
column24: journal = Compendium on Continuing Education for the Practising Veterinarian
column44: title=Feeding-order in an urban feral domestic cat colony: relationship to dominance rank, sex and age

column1: When a human decides to care for a feral colony, it is often called a ''managed colony.'' The care given can include regularly supplying food and water to the cats, providing shelters, helping with [[trap-neuter-return]] programs, providing continued veterinary care, finding foster homes for cats that can be socialized for eventual adoption, and working to educate people who live in the neighborhood.<ref name="":3"" /><ref>{{cite web
[[File:Transformation of a stray kitten in 3 weeks after adoption.jpg
column5: Socialization]] of a stray kitten over three weeks]]Feral kittens can be trapped and socialized, then adopted into a home. The age at which a kitten becomes difficult to socialize is not agreed upon, but suggestions generally range from seven weeks to four months of age.<ref name="":5"" /><ref>{{cite web
column13: accessdate = 30 October 2015}}</ref> Although older cats can sometimes be socialized, it is a very long and difficult process, and the cat rarely becomes friendly and may remain fearful.<ref name=""definition"" /><ref name="":1"" />

column1: In a 2013 study of participants from the United Kingdom, rescuers tended to be more willing than veterinarians to attempt to tame adult feral cats. Veterinarians tended to be more opposed to this practice, with some expressing concerns for the welfare of such a cat in a home environment.<ref name=""definition"" /> In a 2010 study of veterinarians and rescuers in the United States, 66% of respondents had socialization programs for kittens, and 8% for adult cats.<ref name="":5"" />

column3: Feral cats can be effective hunters of small animals.]]

column1: Feral cats primarily subsist on food scavenged from [[Municipal solid waste
column2: garbage]] when it is available to them.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Biology and Behavior of the Cat
column6: accessdate=27 December 2015}}</ref> They also eat animals they kill, and carcasses of animals already dead.<ref name="":9"" /> Feral cats living in managed colonies are fed [[cat food]] by volunteers.<ref>{{cite web

column1: Domesticated and feral cats have been observed to prey on a wide variety of both [[vertebrate]]s and [[invertebrate]]s. Cats typically prefer smaller animals with body weights under {{Convert
column3: g}}, particularly [[mammal]]s, birds, and lizards.<ref name=""Dickman"">{{cite book
column6: title = Overview of the Impacts of Feral Cats on Australian Native Fauna
column7: publisher = The Director of National Parks and Wildlife – Australian Nature Conservation Agency – Institute of Wildlife Research
column12: title = Estimation of the dietary nutrient profile of free-roaming feral cats: possible implications for nutrition of domestic cats
column26: last3 = Hendriks}}</ref> A [[meta-analysis]] of studies of cat diet found that cats preyed on over 1,000 species. The analysis found [[House mouse
column27: house mice]], [[European rabbit]]s, [[black rat]]s, [[house sparrow]]s, and [[common blackbird]]s were some of the most commonly observed prey species.<ref name="":9"" />

column1: Feral cats in Australia prey on a variety of wildlife. In [[arid]] and [[Semi-arid climate
column2: semi-arid]] environments, they eat mostly [[introduced species
column3: introduced]] European rabbits and house mice. In arid environments where rabbits do not occur, native rodents are taken. In forests and urbanized areas, they eat mostly native [[marsupial]]s (particularly the [[common ringtail possum]]) and rodents.<ref name=""Dickman""/>

column1: Feral cats may be [[mesopredator]]s or [[apex predator]]s in some local ecosystems.<ref>{{Cite journal
column22: year=2009}}</ref> In others, they may be preyed upon by animals such as [[Dog
column26: author = Department of Sustainability, Environment, Water, Population and Communities
column30: title = The Dingoes Ate My Kitten

column1: Feral cats in managed colonies can live long lives. A number of cats in managed colonies in the [[United Kingdom
column2: U.K.]] died of old age.<ref name=""Remfry 1996"">{{cite journal
column8: title=Feral cats in the United Kingdom
column9: journal=Journal of the American Veterinary Medical Association
column13: 522}} In the U.S., the last cat in a managed colony in [[Washington, D.C.]] died at age 17, and Zorro, the last cat of a colony at the [[Merrimack River]] in [[Newburyport, Massachusetts]], died in 2009 at age 16.<ref>{{cite web
column15: title=Trap-Neuter-Return Effectively Stabilizes and Reduces Feral Cat Populations
column19: title=Advocates report success with trap, neuter, return approach to stray cats

column1: A long-term study of a [[trap-neuter-return]] (TNR) program on a university campus in Central Florida found that, despite widespread concern about the welfare of free-roaming cats, 83% of the cats studied had been present for more than six years, with almost half first observed as adults of unknown age. The authors compare this result to a 1984 study that found the [[mean]] lifespan for domesticated cats was 7.1 years.<ref name=""Nassar 1984"">{{Cite journal
column9: title=Study of the feline and canine populations in the greater Las Vegas area
column22: title=Evaluation of the effect of a long-term trap-neuter-return and adoption program on a free-roaming cat population
column23: journal=Journal of the American Veterinary Medical Association

column1: Without human assistance, feral kittens are expected to have a high death rate, with approximately 50% dying within the first year.<ref name=""Levy 2003"">

column2: author=Levy JK, Gale DW, Gale LA
column3: title=Evaluation of the effect of a long-term trap-neuter-return and adoption program on a free-roaming cat population

column1: Adult feral cats without human assistance have been found in surprisingly good condition. In Florida, a study of feral cats admitted to a trap-neuter-return program concluded that ""euthanasia for debilitated cats for humane reasons is rarely necessary"".<ref name=""Scott 2002"">{{cite journal
column2: title=Characteristics of free-roaming cats evaluated in a trap-neuter-return program
column3: journal=Journal of the American Veterinary Medical Association
column15: doi=10.2460/javma.2002.221.1136}}</ref> A further study of over 100,000 community cats (feral and stray) admitted to TNR programs in diverse locations of the U.S. resulted in the same 0.4% rate of euthanasia for debilitating conditions.<ref name=""Wallace 2006"">{{cite journal
column17: title=Population Characteristics of Feral Cats Admitted to Seven Trap-Neuter-Return Programs in the United States
column28: doi=10.1016/j.jfms.2006.02.004}}</ref> The body condition of feral cats entering a TNR program in Florida was described as ""generally lean but not emaciated"".<ref name=""Scott 2002b"">{{cite journal
column29: title=Body Condition of Feral Cats and the Effect of Neutering
column30: journal=Journal of Applied Animal Welfare Science
column44: doi=10.1207/S15327604JAWS0503_04}}</ref> However, many community cats had suffered from parasites such as [[flea]]s and [[ear mite]]s before entering TNR programs.<ref name=""Levy 2004"">{{cite journal
column45: title=Humane strategies for controlling feral cat populations
column46: journal=Journal of the American Veterinary Medical Association

column1: Feral cats, as with all cats, are susceptible to diseases and infections including [[rabies]], [[bartonellosis]], [[toxoplasmosis]], [[Plague (disease)
column4: rickettsial diseases]], and [[feline respiratory disease complex]] (FRDC, a group of respiratory illnesses including [[Feline viral rhinotracheitis
column5: feline herpesvirus type 1]], [[feline calicivirus]], ''[[Chlamydia felis]]'', and ''[[Mycoplasma felis]]'').<ref name="":7"">{{Cite journal
column21: title=Rabies Prevention and Management of Cats in the Context of Trap–Neuter–Vaccinate–Release Programmes

column1: Feline leukemia virus and feline immunodeficiency virus belong to the [[Retrovirus
column2: ''Retroviridae'']] family, and both cause [[immunosuppression]] in cats, which can increase their susceptibility to other infections. Research has shown that the prevalence of these viruses among feral cat populations is low and is similar to prevalence rates for owned cats in the United States.<ref name=""lee"">{{cite journal
column7: title=Prevalence of feline leukemia virus infection and serum antibodies against feline immunodeficiency virus in unowned free-roaming cats
column8: journal=Journal of the American Veterinary Medical Association
column39: title=Prevalence of infectious diseases in feral cats in Northern Florida
column40: journal=Journal of Feline Medicine and Surgery

column1: Researchers studying 553 feral cats in Northern [[Florida]] in the United States tested them for a number of infections that could be detrimental to feline or human health. The study found the most prevalent infection to be ''[[Bartonella henselae]]'', the cause of [[cat-scratch disease]] in humans, with 33.6% of the cats testing positive. [[Feline coronavirus]] was the next most common infection, found in 18.3% of the cats, although they noted that the antibody levels were low in most of the cats who tested positive, and concluded that the cats they tested did not appear to be a greater risk for [[Viral shedding
column2: shedding]] the virus than pet cats.<ref name="":6"" /> Researchers studying 96 feral cats on [[Prince Edward Island]] in Canada found that [[Toxocara cati
column3: feline roundworm]] was the most common infection in cats in that colony, afflicting 34% of cats. This was followed by ''[[Toxoplasma gondii]]'', which was detected in 29.8% of cats, although only one cat of the 78 for whom fecal samples were available was shedding ''T. gondii'' [[Apicomplexan life cycle
column4: oocysts]]. They did note that most fecal samples collected indicated the presence of one [[intestinal parasite]], with some samples indicating the presence of multiple parasites.<ref name="":2"">{{Cite journal
column10: title=Infectious disease prevalence in a feral cat population on Prince Edward Island, Canada

column1: The [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
column2: Center for Disease Control and Prevention]] has warned about the rabies risk associated with feral cats. With 16% of people infected with rabies from exposure to rabid cats, cats have been the primary animals responsible for transmission of the virus to humans in the United States since the efforts to control rabies in dogs in the 1970s.<ref name="":8"">{{cite web
column4: title=Feral cat colonies could pose rabies risk, CDC says
column9: access-date=10 March 2016}}</ref> In 2010, there were 303 rabid cats reported within the United States.<ref name="":7"" /> Although some colony management programs involve administering [[rabies vaccine]]s, the need to revaccinate every few years makes this challenging to maintain.<ref name="":8""/> Furthermore, lack of documentation can mean that contact with vaccinated feral cats may still require [[Post-exposure prophylaxis

column1: The study of feral cats on Prince Edward Island warned of ""considerable [[Zoonosis
column2: zoonotic]] risk"" for transmission of intestinal parasites. Although the authors noted that their study did not provide evidence for great risk associated with ''T. gondii'' in cats, they advised that the risk should still be considered, as the infection in humans can cause significant health problems, and cats who are not otherwise transmitting the infection can begin shedding the virus in times of stress.<ref name="":2"" />

column1: Feral cats live on all continents except for Antarctica.<ref>{{cite web
column5: access-date=2016-03-30}}</ref> The worldwide feral cat population is estimated to be at least 100 million. The United States' feral cat population is estimated at 60 million, Australia's at 12 million, and Britain's at one million.<ref>{{cite web
column7: title=The Global Impact of Feral Cats

column2: Aoshima]] is populated with feral cats.<ref>{{Cite news
column4: title=It's raining cats and tourists on a Japanese island
column9: title=Cat Empire: Moggies outnumber humans on Aoshima Island in Japan, in pics

column1: Cats are found on many remote islands, such as the [[Hawaiian Islands]], where they are an invasive species. Based on [[microsatellite]] genetic tests it was determined that these cats have a mainly European ancestry. These cats’ globetrotting ways can be attributed to Humans’ ship trading routes in the 19th century.<ref>{{Cite journal
column9: title=Feral Cat Globetrotters: genetic traces of historical human-mediated dispersal
column21: Feral cat father (right) with his kitten (left). Kitten is age 6 months and not feral.

column1: Most feral cats have small [[home range]]s, although some are more transient and travel long distances. The home ranges of male feral cats, which are generally two or three times larger than those of female cats, are on average under {{Convert
column4: lk=on}}, but can vary from almost {{Convert
column8: ha}}. This variance is often due to breeding season, access to females, whether the cat is neutered, age, time of day, and availability of prey.<ref name="":9"">{{Cite journal
column15: title=A review of cat behavior in relation to disease risk and management options

column3: spaying or neutering]] them, and then returning them to the place where there were originally trapped, where ongoing care is provided by caregivers.<ref name=""ACA TNR guide"">{{cite book
column4: title=How to Help Community Cats: A step-by-step guide to Trap-Neuter-Return
column9: url=http://www.alleycat.org/document.doc?id=461}}</ref> When neutered, the cats receive [[feline vaccination
column10: vaccination]]s against [[rabies]], and attention to other medical needs, such as dental care and [[Flea#For pets
column19: url=http://www.neighborhoodcats.org/uploads/File/Resources/NC%20TNR%20Handbook_PRINT_v5-4.pdf}}</ref> TNR programs are prevalent in several countries, including England,<ref name=""Remfry 1996""/> Italy,<ref name=""Natoli 2006"">{{cite journal
column22: title=Management of feral domestic cats in the urban environment of Rome (Italy)
column41: first7=Claudio}}</ref> Canada, and the United States,<ref>{{cite web
column45: publisher=The Humane Society of the United States
column49: access-date=3 March 2016}}</ref> supported by many [[list of governments supporting trap-neuter-return
column50: local and state governments]]. Various long-term studies have shown that TNR is effective in stopping reproduction and [[Population control
column51: reducing the population]] over time.<ref name=""Remfry 1996""/><ref name=""Levy 2003""/><ref name=""Hughes 2002"">{{cite journal
column54: title=Implementation of a feral cat management program on a university campus
column57: journal=Journal of Applied Animal Welfare Science
column63: author=Hughes KL, Slater MR}}</ref> TNR results in fewer complaints, as nuisance behaviors diminish following neutering,<ref name=""Hughes 2002""/>{{rp
column64: 16}} and the quality of life of the cats is improved.<ref name=""Scott 2002b""/><ref name=""Levy 2004""/>{{rp
column65: 1359}} The practice is reported to save money<ref name=""Hughes 2002""/>{{rp
column66: 294}} and garner more public support and better morale than efforts that involve killing cats.<ref name=""Hughes 2002""/>{{rp

column1: The International Companion Animal Management Coalition advocates for TNR as a humane method of controlling feral cat populations.<ref>{{Cite journal
column10: access-date=}}</ref> In the U.S., the practice is endorsed by the [[Humane Society of the United States]]<ref>{{Citation
column14: publisher=The Humane Society of the United States}}</ref> and the National Animal Control Association.<ref>{{Cite journal
column18: title=Taking a Broader View of Cats in the Community
column26: access-date=}}</ref> While the [[United States Department of Defense]] does not formally advocate TNR, it provides information to military installations on how to implement TNR programs,<ref name=""DOD"">{{cite web
column28: title='Trap, Neuter, Return,' Cat Lovers Urge
column34: archivedate=14 July 2015}}</ref> with the main message that population control programs must be humane.<ref>{{cite web
column36: title=Cat Herding on the Military Range-DoD Advocates Humane Cat Control

column1: The multiple, managed, feral colonies at the [[Colosseum]] in Rome exceed 250 cats. Other notable colonies include the [[Canadian Parliamentary Cats]] and the cats of Jerusalem.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Blair and the stray cats of Jerusalem

column1: In 2011, an Australian study emphasised the need to monitor the effects of culling programs after [[infrared camera]]s found that the culling of feral cats led to an increase in feral cat populations in the culled areas. It was thought that only dominant cats were being baited and trapped during such operations. After the removal of dominant cats, there was an influx of subordinate animals to the area which unlike the dominant cats, did not venture into the traps. Within a year cat numbers in culled areas stabilised to original numbers.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Culling cats 'may do more harm than good'

column1: Cats hunt small prey, such as rodents and birds. Free-ranging cats kill one to four billion birds and six to 22 billion mammals annually in the forty eight contiguous states of the United States.  Feral cats kill the majority of birds.  They are the largest source of human caused killing of birds.<ref name=""NATURE.COMMUNICATIONS.1396"">{{cite report
column9: title=The impact of free-ranging domestic cats on wildlife of the United States
column15: quote=Here we conduct a systematic review and quantitatively estimate mortality caused by cats in the United States. We estimate that free-ranging domestic cats kill 1.3–4.0 billion birds and 6.3–22.3 billion mammals annually. Un-owned cats, as opposed to owned pets, cause the majority of this mortality. Our findings suggest that free-ranging cats cause substantially greater wildlife mortality than previously thought and are likely the single greatest source of anthropogenic mortality for US birds and mammals.}}</ref>

column1: Sometimes feral cats kill non-native pests. Feral cats have been intentionally introduced to some areas as a [[Pest (organism)
column2: pest]] control strategy. In the 1800s, thousands of cats were introduced near settlements in Australia that had developed near [[Gold mining
column3: gold dig]] sites and farms as an attempt to manage populations of mice, rabbits, and rats.<ref name="":0"" />

column5: A [[Kellas cat]], a feline [[landrace]] resulting from crossbreeding between a domestic cat and a [[Scottish wildcat]] (''F. s. grampia'').]]

column1: Feral cats have interbred with [[wildcat]]s to various extents throughout the world, the first reported case occurring more than 200 years ago. The significance of hybridisation is disputed.  Older documentation suggests that the wildcat was a separate species from the domestic cat, but modern genetic analysis<ref>{{Cite journal

column2: title = The Near Eastern Origin of Cat Domestication

column1: }}</ref> has shown that the domestic cat is a domesticated version of the near-eastern wildcat (''[[Felis silvestris lybica]]'').  In some locations, high levels of hybridisation have led to difficulties in distinguishing a ""true"" wildcat from feral domestic and domestic hybrid cats, which can complicate conservation efforts.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20090309161424/http://www.arkive.org/european-wildcat/felis-silvestris-grampia/info.html European wildcat (''Felis silvestris grampia'')] Arkive.org</ref> Some researchers argue that ""pure"" wildcats do not exist anymore, but others dispute this.<ref name=""ICUN"">{{cite web
column5: publisher=[[IUCN Species Survival Commission#Cat Specialist Group

column1: One study in Scotland suggests that while ""true"" Scottish wildcats are unlikely to exist, the current wildcat population is distinct enough from domestic cats to be worth protecting,<ref>[http://pritch.bsd.uchicago.edu/publications/wildcats.pdf Genetic diversity and introgression in the Scottish wildcat]. ''Molecular Ecology'' (2001) '''10''': 319–336.  {{webarchive
column3: date=17 May 2008 }}</ref> genetics research is still underway as part of the Wildcat Haven project in Scotland, which has reported success protecting wildcats from hybridisation with widespread [[trap-neuter-return]] work.<ref>[http://www.heraldscotland.com/news/13169976.Haven_to_save_the_wildcat_from_total_extinction/ (Herald Scotland 'Haven to Save the Wildcat from Total Extinction')]</ref> Wildcat populations' notable gene [[introgression]] exists also in Italy, Hungary, Spain and Portugal.<ref>[http://petsaspests.blogspot.com.es/search/label/feline%20hybridization Domestic gene introgression into wildcat populations in Europe]. Petsaspests.blogspot.com.es. Retrieved on 2015-11-01.</ref>

column1: For a discussion of this issue see The Encyclopedia of Mammals, OUP, pages 656–657.<ref>The Encyclopedia of Mammals, OUP, {{ISBN
*[http://www.straycatalliance.org/cats-101/tnr/ A feral cat advocacy organization's explanation of feral cats] Stray Cat Alliance
*[http://www.messybeast.com/ukferal.htm Feral cat control in the UK]
*[http://www.feralcats.org.uk/ Study of the feral cats in Portsmouth Naval Dockyard, UK] with photos and scientific papers
*[http://www.saveacat.org/index.php/acr-get-involved/acr-findlocalgroups List of Humane Societies and Rescue Groups With TNR Programs] Alley Cat Rescue

column4: The word ''pussy'' refers to cats, weakness or cowardice, or female genitalia, in addition to other meanings.]]

column1: The word '''pussy''' is a [[noun]], an [[adjective]], and in rare uses a [[verb]] in the [[English language]]. It has several meanings, including use as [[slang]], as [[euphemism]], and as [[vulgarity]]. Common [[Meaning (linguistics)
column2: meanings]] of the noun include ""[[cat]]"", as well as ""[[cowardice
column4: weakling]]"", and ""the human [[vulva]] or [[vagina]]"", or as a [[synecdoche]], ""[[sexual intercourse]] with a woman"".<ref name=""OED 1"" /> Because of its multiple senses including both innocent and vulgar [[connotation]]s, ""pussy"" is often the subject of [[double entendre]].

column1: The [[etymology]] of the word is not entirely clear. Several different senses of the word have different histories or origins.<ref name=""OED 1"">{{cite encyclopedia
The noun ''pussy'' meaning ""cat"" comes from the [[Modern English]] word ''puss'', a conventional name or term of address for a pet cat.<ref name=""OED puss"">{{cite encyclopedia
column7: location=Oxford}}</ref> The ''[[Oxford English Dictionary]]'' (OED) says that [[cognate]]s are common to several [[Germanic language]]s, including [[Dutch language
column8: Dutch]] ''poes'' and [[Middle Low German]] ''pūse'', which are also used to call a cat. The word ''puss'' is attested in English as early as 1533. Earlier etymology is uncertain, but similar words exist in other European languages, including [[Lithuanian language
column10: Irish]] ''puisín'', both traditional calls to attract a cat.<ref name=""OED puss""/>

column1: The words ''puss'' and derived forms ''pussy'' and ''pusscat'' were extended to refer to girls or women by the seventeenth century.<ref name=""OED 1"" /><ref name=""OED puss""/> This sense of ''pussy'' was used to refer specifically to genitalia by the eighteenth century, and from there further extended to refer to sexual intercourse involving a woman by the twentieth century.<ref name=""OED 1"" />

column2: American Dictionary of the English Language]]'', defined ''pussy'' as: ""inflated, swelled; hence, fat, short and thick; and as persons of this make labor in respiration, the word is used for short breathed"". He gave ''pursy'' as a ""corrupt orthography"" or misspelling of ''pussy''.<ref>{{cite book
column5: title=An American Dictionary of the English Language
column9: oclc=468942038}}</ref> In 1913, however, ''Webster's Revised Unabridged Dictionary'' reversed the original, suggesting that ''pussy'' was a ""colloquial or low"" variant of ''pursy''. That word, in turn, was defined as ""fat and short-breathed"", with etymology from [[Old French]] ''pousser'' ""to push"".<ref>{{cite book
column14: title=Webster's Revised Unabridged Dictionary of the English Language

column1: The ''Webster's Third International Dictionary'' points out similarities between ''pussy'' in the sense of ""vulva"" and Low German or Scandinavian words meaning ""pocket"" or ""purse"", including [[Old Norse]] ''pūss'' and [[Old English]] ''pusa''.<ref>{{cite book
column4: title=Webster's Third New International Dictionary of the English Language, Unabridged

column2: French]] word ''pucelle'', meaning ""maiden"" or ""virgin"", is not related to the English word. It is attested in Old French from the ninth century, and likely derives from [[Latin]]. The precise Latin source is disputed, with either ''puella'' ""girl"" or ''pulla'' ""[[pullet]], young female chicken"" suggested as earlier sources.<ref>{{cite encyclopedia

column1: As a [[homograph]], ''pussy'' also has the meaning ""containing [[pus]]"";<ref name=""OED 3"" /> with this meaning, the word is pronounced {{IPAc-en
column6: ɪ}}, while the other forms are all pronounced {{IPAc-en
column11: ɪ}}. Another adjective is the rare or obsolete [[Northern England English
column12: Northern English]] dialect form ''pursy'' meaning ""fat"" or ""short-winded"".<ref name=""OED 2"" />

column1: Meanings of the verb relate to the common noun senses, including ""to act like a cat"", ""to act like a coward"", or ""to have sex with a woman"".<ref name=""OED verb"">{{cite encyclopedia
column7: location=Oxford}}</ref> <!-- Add modern slang senses: man (especially prisoner) used unwillingly for another man's sexual gratification; submissive subordinate or underling. --> Adjective meanings are related to the noun.

column1: Both in English and in [[German language
column2: German]] ''puss'' was used as a ""call-name"" for cats, but in English ''pussy'' was used as a synonym for the word ''cat'' in other uses as well. In addition to cats, the word was also used for [[rabbit]]s and [[hare]]s as well as a humorous name for [[tiger]]s. In the 19th century,  the meaning was extended to anything soft and furry. ''[[Pussy willow]]'', for example, is a name applied to various species in the genus ''[[Salix]]'' with furry [[catkin]]s. In [[thieves' cant]] the word ''pussy'' means a ""fur coat"".<ref name=""OED 1"" />

column1: The ''[[Oxford English Dictionary]]'' gives as the first meaning of the noun: ""Chiefly colloq[uial]. A girl or woman exhibiting characteristics associated with a cat, esp[ecially] sweetness or amiability. Freq[uently] used as a pet name or as a term of endearment."" The examples it cites from the mid-19th to mid-20th centuries are not sexual. Another example, not cited by the OED, is one of the main characters of [[E. Nesbit]]'s ''[[Five Children and It]]'' - Jane, nicknamed Pussy by her siblings.

The verb ''pussyfoot'', meaning to walk softly or to speak in an evasive or cautious manner, may come from the adjective ''pussy-footed'' ""having a cat-like foot"", or directly from the noun ''pussyfoot''. This word, first attested in the late nineteenth century, is related to both the ""cat"" and the ""woman"" meanings of ''pussy''.<ref>{{cite encyclopedia

column5: An example of [[double entendre]] in [[street art]]: a graffiti mural of a woman caressing a pussycat between her legs.]]

column1: In contemporary English, use of the word ''pussy'' to refer to women is considered derogatory or demeaning, treating people as sexual objects.<ref>{{Cite journal
column4: title=Gender-linked derogatory terms and their use by women and men
column10: doi=10.2307/455584}}</ref> As a reference to genitals or to sexual intercourse, the word is considered vulgar slang. Studies find the word used more commonly in conversations among men than in groups of women or mixed-gender groups, though subjects report using ''pussy'' more often than other slang terms for female genitals.<ref>{{cite journal
column15: title=Male and female sexual vocabulary in different interpersonal contexts

column1: [[Donald Trump]]'s use of the word to describe his interactions with women (""grab them by the pussy"", known as the [[Donald Trump and Billy Bush recording
column2: Billy Bush recording]]) provoked strong reactions by media figures and politicians across the political spectrum; an image of a snarling cat with the slogan ""pussy grabs back"" became a ""rallying cry for female rage against Trump"".<ref>Nicole Puglise, [https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/oct/10/donald-trump-pussy-grabs-back-meme-women-twitter 'Pussy grabs back' becomes rallying cry for female rage against Trump], ''The Guardian'' (October 10, 2016).</ref> Pink ""pussyhats"" (knitted caps with cat-like ears) were a notable feature of [[2017 Women's March
column3: the worldwide protests]] held the day after Trump's inauguration as President of the United States. <ref>{{cite news
column6: title=With 'Pussyhats,' Liberals Get Their Own Version Of The Red Trucker Hat

column1: Words referring to cats are used as vulgar slang for female genitals in some other European languages as well. Examples include German ''Muschi'' (literally ""house cat""),<ref>{{cite book
column9: isbn=978-0-19-860248-4}}</ref> French ''chatte'' (""female cat"", also used to refer to sexual intercourse),<ref name=""Robert"">{{cite book
column12: title=Le Nouveau Petit Robert Dictionnaire De La Langue Francais
column15: language=French}}</ref> and Dutch ''poes'' (""puss"").<ref name=""OED puss"" /> The Portuguese term ''rata'' (literally ""female rat"")<ref>{{cite book
column28: isbn=978-8200182931}}</ref> are also animal terms used as vulgar slang for women's genitals.

column1: The word ''pussy'' is also used in a derogatory sense to mean cowardly, weak, or easily fatigued. The ''Collins Dictionary'' says: {{nowrap
column2: (}}taboo, slang, mainly US) an ineffectual or timid person.""<ref>[http://www.collinsdictionary.com/dictionary/english/pussies online]</ref> It may refer to a male who is not considered sufficiently masculine, as in: ""The coach calls us pussies.""<ref>{{cite book

column1: Men who are dominated by women (particularly by their partners or spouses and at one time referred to as 'hen-pecked', see [[pecking order]]) can be referred to as ''pussy-whipped'' (or simply ''whipped'' in slightly more polite society or media).{{citation needed
column2: date=May 2014}} This may be used simply to denigrate a man who is contented in a relationship. The hyphenated phrase is parsed as ""whipped by pussy"" – a manipulative relationship dynamic wherein a female deliberately or subconsciously [[sex strike
column3: withholds sexual intercourse]] to coerce the male into surrendering power in other aspects of the relationship. The male's weakness is his desire for access to female genitalia, and his willingness to weaken his position in the relationship to obtain that access, combining two uses of the word pussy.{{citation needed

column5: The [[Barrison Sisters]] lift their dresses to show a live kitten, a double entendre of ""pussy"".]]

column1: '''Pussy''' is one of a large number of English words that has both erotic and non-erotic meanings. Such [[double entendre]] has long been used in the creation of sexual humor.<ref>{{cite journal
column8: title=Locus of control and the expression of humor
column14: doi=10.1111/1467-6494.ep8969660}}</ref> The double entendre has been used for over a hundred years by performers, including the late-19th-century [[vaudeville]] act the [[Barrison Sisters]], who performed the notorious routine ""Do You Want To See My Pussy?"" in which they raised their skirts to reveal live kittens.<ref>{{cite book
column17: title=Filthy English: The How, Why, When And What Of Everyday Swearing

column1: In the British comedy ''[[Are You Being Served?]]'' the character [[Mrs. Slocombe]] often expressed concern for the welfare of her pussy. The double entendre made every reference to her cat seem to be a salacious and therefore humorous reference to her vagina.<ref>{{cite book
column4: title=American Taboo: The Forbidden Words, Unspoken Rules, and Secret Morality of Popular Culture

column2: 8 Mile]]'' a rapper insults his rivals by including the line, ""How can six dicks be pussies?"" The line relies on double meanings of both [[Dick (slang)
column3: ''dick'']] (either ""contemptible person"" or ""male genitalia"") and ''pussy'' (""weak"" or ""female genitalia""). Such [[word play]] presents a challenge for translators of the film.<ref>{{cite journal
column6: title=Subtitling ''8 Mile'' in three languages: Translation problems and translator licence
column7: journal=Target: International Journal of Translation Studies

column1: [[Pussy Riot]] is a Russian radical [[feminist]] punk-rock collective that stages illegal events in [[Moscow]] protesting the President [[Vladimir Putin]] and the status of women in Russian society. Band member ""Kot"" says that she knows how the word is used in English, and that it is also used in Russian as term of endearment for little girls. These various meanings create a tension with the word ""riot"", which the group likes.<ref name=""Pussy Riot"">{{cite web
column4: title=In Russia, Punk-Rock Riot Girls Rage Against Putin

column2: Fanny]], also a term for female genitalia and an old-fashioned nickname (for Frances)

column1: * [[Cunt]], an ancient vulgarism for the vulva
* [https://www.theguardian.com/weekend/story/0,3605,975787,00.html Don't be so beastly!] by Justine Hankins. ''The Guardian'', June 14, 2003.
* [http://www.smc.edu/voices/forerunner/Spring2002/philosophy/pussythispussythat.htm Pussy This, Pussy That] by [[Aura Bogado]], 2002.
977022,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Cat_health,"This is a collection of articles about the [[cat health
column2: health and care of cats]], primarily domestic cats. This includes medical conditions, health issues, parasites, surgical procedures, and similar topics.

column1: The '''[[anatomy]] of the [[domestic cat]]''' is similar to that of other members of the genus ''[[Felis]]''.

column2: caption = A yawning cat, exposing its mouth
teeth]] for the killing of prey and the tearing of meat. The ''[[premolar]]'' and ''[[Molar (tooth)
column3: first molar]]'', together the ''[[carnassial]] pair'' are located on each side of the mouth. These teeth efficiently function to shear meat like a pair of scissors. While this is present in [[Canidae
column4: canids]], it is highly developed in felines.

column1: The cat's [[tongue]] has sharp spines, or ''[[Filiform papilla
column2: papillae]]'', useful for retaining and ripping flesh from a carcass. These papillae are small backward-facing hooks that contain [[keratin]] which also assist in their [[Personal grooming

column1: The cat's oral structures provide for a variety of vocalizations used for [[cat communication
column2: communication]], including meowing, purring, hissing, growling, squeaking, chirping, clicking, and grunting.
caption = A cat's ear which has special fur for sensing and protection

column1: Thirty-two individual muscles in each ear allow for a manner of [[directional hearing]];<ref>{{cite web
column2: title = At Home: Care / Health: Understanding Cats
column6: accessdate = 15 August 2005}}</ref> a cat can move each ear independently of the other. Because of this mobility, a cat can move its body in one direction and point its ears in another direction. Most cats have straight ears pointing upward. Unlike [[dog]]s, flap-eared breeds are extremely rare (''[[Scottish Fold]]s'' are one such exceptional [[mutation]]). When angry or frightened, a cat will lay back its ears to accompany the growling or hissing sounds it makes. Cats also turn their ears back when they are playing or to listen to a sound coming from behind them. The fold of skin forming a pouch on the lower posterior part of the ear, known as [[Henry's pocket]], is usually prominent in a cat's ear.<ref name=""consultations"">{{cite book
column10: title = Consultations in Feline Internal Medicine, Volume 6
column18: isbn = }}</ref> It is of unknown function, though it may assist in filtering sounds.

column4: A cat's nose is highly adapted]]

column1: Cats are highly territorial and secreting odors plays a major role in cat communication. The nose helps cats to identify territories, other cats and mates, to locate food, and for various other causes.<ref name=About.com>{{cite web
column3: title=The Nose Knows Cats' Amazing Sense of Scent
column5: work=About.com}}</ref> A cat's sense of smell is believed to be about fourteen times stronger than that of humans. The [[rhinarium]] (the leathery bit of nose we see) is quite tough to allow it to absorb rather rough treatment sometimes. The color varies according to the [[genotype]] (genetic makeup) of the cat. Cat's skin has the same color as the fur but the color of the nose leather is probably dictated by a dedicated gene. Cats with white fur have skin susceptible to damage by [[ultraviolet light]] that may cause cancer. Extra care is required when outside in hot sun.<ref>{{cite web

column1: Cats, like dogs, are [[digitigrade]]s. They walk directly on their [[toe]]s, with the bones of their feet making up the lower part of the visible leg.<ref name=""Lacquaniti 1999"">{{Cite journal
}}</ref> Domestic cats are capable of walking very precisely, as is true for all cats.  Like all [[felinae
column2: felines]], they directly register; that is, they place each hind paw (almost) directly in the print of the corresponding forepaw, minimizing noise and visible tracks.{{citation needed
column3: date=November 2014}} This also provides sure footing for their hind paws when they navigate rough terrain. The two back legs allow falling and leaping far distances without injury.

column1: Unlike most mammals, when cats walk, they use a ""pacing"" [[gait]]; that is, they move the two legs on one side of the body before the legs on the other side. This trait is shared with [[camel]]s and giraffes. As a walk speeds up into a trot, a cat's gait will change to be a ""diagonal"" gait, similar to that of most other mammals: the diagonally opposite hind and forelegs will move simultaneously. Cat height can vary depending on breed and/or gender, but is usually around 12 inches or 30.5 centimeters<ref name=""Christensen 2004"">{{Cite book
Like nearly all members of the [[family (biology)
column2: family]] [[Felidae]], cats have retractable [[claw]]s. In their normal, relaxed position, the claws are sheathed with the [[skin]] and [[fur]] around the [[paw
column3: toe pads]]. This keeps the claws sharp by preventing wear from contact with the ground and allows the silent stalking of prey. The claws on the forefeet are typically sharper than those on the hind feet.<ref>{{cite journal
column15: accessdate=12 November 2007 }}</ref> Cats can voluntarily extend their claws on one or more paws. They may extend their claws in hunting or self-defense, climbing, ""[[Kneading (cats)
column16: kneading]]"", or for extra traction on soft surfaces (bedspreads, thick rugs, skin, etc.). It is also possible to make a cooperative cat extend its claws by carefully pressing both the top and bottom of the paw. The curved claws can become entangled in carpet or thick fabric, which can cause injury if the cat is unable to free itself.

column1: Most cats have a total of 18 digits and claws. 5 on each forefoot, the 5th digit being the [[dewclaw]]; and 4 on each hind foot. The dewclaw is located high on the foreleg, is not in contact with the ground and is non-weight bearing.<ref>{{cite web
Some cats can have more than 18 digits, example: five on their rear paws ([[Polydactyl cat

column2: title=Heredity of Polydactyly in the Cat

column1: Because of an ancient [[mutation]], however, some domestic and feral cats are born with polydactylyism (particularly in the east coast of [[Canada]] and northeast coast of the [[United States]]), with six or seven toes.

column2: body temperature]] of a cat is between {{Convert
column8: title = Normal Values For Dog and Cat Temperature, Blood Tests, Urine and other information in ThePetCenter.com
column12: accessdate = 1 August 2005}}</ref> A cat is considered ''[[fever
column14: hyperthermic]]) if it has a temperature of {{Convert
column19: °C}}. For comparison, humans have an average [[Human body temperature
column23: disp=flip}}.<ref>http://www.health.harvard.edu/press_releases/normal_body_temperature</ref> A domestic cat's normal heart rate ranges from 140 to 220 beats per minute (bpm), and is largely dependent on how excited the cat is. For a cat at rest, the average heart rate usually is between 150 and 180 bpm, more than twice that of a human, which averages 70 bpm.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20090413173009/http://highlanderpetcenter.com/content/view/24/2 Cat Health And Cat Metabolism Information For The Best Cat Care]. Highlander Pet Center</ref>

column1: Cats possess rather loose skin; this allows them to turn and confront a predator or another cat in a fight, even when it has a grip on them. This is also an advantage for [[Veterinary medicine
column4: title = Vaccinate Your Cat at Home
column6: accessdate = 18 October 2006}}</ref> In fact, the lives of cats with [[renal failure
column7: kidney failure]] can sometimes be extended for years by the regular injection of large volumes of fluid subcutaneously, which serves as an alternative to [[dialysis]].<ref>{{cite web
column13: title = How to Give Subcutaneous Fluids to a Cat

column1: The particularly loose skin at the back of the neck is known as the ''[[nape
column2: scruff]]'', and is the area by which a mother cat grips her [[kitten]]s to carry them. As a result, cats tend to become quiet and passive when gripped there. This behavior also extends into adulthood, when a male will grab the female by the scruff to immobilize her while he mounts, and to prevent her from running away as the mating process takes place.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title = Scruffing your dog or cat

column1: This technique can be useful when attempting to treat or move an uncooperative cat. However, since an adult cat is heavier than a kitten, a pet cat should never be carried by the scruff, but should instead have its weight supported at the rump and hind legs, and at the chest and front paws.{{Or

Some cats share common traits due to heredity. One of those is the primordial pouch, sometimes referred to as ""spay sway"" by owners who notice it once the cat has been spayed or neutered. It is located on a cat's belly. Its appearance is similar to a loose flap of skin that might occur if the cat had been overweight and had then lost weight. It provides a little extra protection against kicks, which are common during cat fights as a cat will try to rake with its rear claws. In wild cats, the ancestors of domesticated felines, this pouch appears to be present to provide extra room in case the animal has the opportunity to eat a large meal and the stomach needs to expand. This stomach pouch also allows the cat to bend and expand, allowing for faster running and higher jumping.<ref>[http://pets.thenest.com/primordial-pouch-cats-11178.html What Is the Primordial Pouch in Cats? by Nicholas DeMarino at pets.thenest.com]</ref>

column4: Diagram of the skeleton of a cat

column1: '''A''' – Cervical or Neck Bones (7 in number). '''B''' – Dorsal or Thoracic Bones (13 in number, each bearing a rib).
'''C''' – Lumbar Bones (7 in number).'''D''' – Sacral Bones (3 in number).'''E''' – Caudal or Tail Bones (19 to 21 in number).

1 – Cranium, or Skull.
2 – Mandible, or Lower jaw.
3 – Scapula, or Shoulder-blade.
4 – Sternum, or Breast-bone.

5 – Humerus.
6 – Radius.
7 – Phalanges of the Toes.
8 – Metacarpal Bones.

9 – Carpal or Wrist-bones.
10 – Ulna.
11 – Ribs.
12 – Patella, or Knee-cap.
13 – Tibia.

17 – Femur, or Thigh-bone.
18 – Pelvis, or Hip-bone.]]
Cats have seven [[cervical vertebrae]] like almost all [[mammals]], thirteen [[thoracic vertebrae]] (humans have twelve), seven [[lumbar vertebrae]] (humans have five), three [[sacrum
column2: sacral vertebrae]] (humans have five because of their bipedal posture), and, except for [[Manx (cat)
column3: Manx cat]]s and other shorter tailed cats, twenty-two or twenty-three [[caudal vertebrae]] (humans have three to five, fused into an internal [[coccyx]]). The extra lumbar and thoracic vertebrae account for the cat's enhanced spinal mobility and flexibility, compared to humans. The caudal vertebrae form the ''[[tail]]'', used by the cat as a counterbalance to the body during quick movements.  Between their vertebrae, they have elastic discs, useful for cushioning the jump landings.

column1: Unlike human arms, cat forelimbs are attached to the shoulder by free-floating [[clavicle]] bones, which allows them to pass their body through any space into which they can fit their heads.<ref name=""Gillis 2002"">{{cite web

column2: work=Zoolab: A Website for Animal Biology

column1: The cat skull is unusual among mammals in having very large [[eye socket]]s and a powerful and specialized jaw.<ref name=""Case"">{{Cite book

column2: title=The Cat: Its Behavior, Nutrition, and Health
35}} Compared to other felines, domestic cats have narrowly spaced canine teeth, adapted to their preferred prey of small rodents.<ref name=Smith1992>{{Cite book
title=Structure, Function and Evolution of teeth

column4: alt=Labelled diagram of the muscular system of a cat
column5: Diagram of the muscular system of a cat]]

column1: This muscle's origin is the lumbodorsal fascia and ribs. Its [[insertion (anatomy)
column2: insertion]] is at the pubis and [[Linea alba (abdomen)
column3: linea alba]] (via aponeurosis), and its action is the compression of abdominal contents. It also laterally flexes and rotates the vertebral column.

column1: This muscle is the innermost abdominal muscle. Its origin is the second sheet of the lumbodorsal fascia and the pelvic girdle and its insertion is the linea alba. Its action is the compression of the abdomen.

To see this muscle, first remove the extensive aponeurosis situated on the [[ventral]] surface of the cat. Its fibers are extremely longitudinal, on each side of the linea alba. It is also traversed by the inscriptiones tendinae, or what others called ''[[myosepta]]''.

The '''deltoid muscles''' lie just lateral to the [[trapezius muscles]], originating from several fibers spanning the clavicle and scapula, converging to insert at the humerus. Anatomically, there are only two deltoids in the cat, the ''acromiodeltoid'' and the ''spinodeltoid''. However, to conform to [[human anatomy]] standards, the clavobrachialis is now also considered a deltoid and is commonly referred to as the ''clavodeltoid''.

The acromiodeltoid is the shortest of the deltoid muscles. It lies lateral to (to the side of) the clavodeltoid, and in a more husky cat it can only be seen by lifting or reflecting the clavodeltoid. It originates at the acromion process and inserts at the deltoid ridge. When contracted, it raises and rotates the humerus outward.

A stout and short muscle lying posterior to the acromiodeltoid. It lies along the lower border of the scapula, and it passes through the upper arm, across the upper end of muscles of the upper arm. It originates at the spine of the scapula and inserts at the deltoid ridge. Its action is to raise and rotate the humerus outward.
The '''Masseter''' is a great, powerful, and very thick muscle covered by a tough, shining [[fascia]] lying [[Anatomical terms of location
column2: ventral]] to the [[zygomatic arch]], which is its origin. It inserts into the [[Anatomical terms of location
column3: posterior]] half of the [[Anatomical terms of location
column4: lateral]] surface of the [[mandible]]. Its action is the elevation of the mandible (closing of the jaw).

column1: The '''temporalis''' is a great mass of mandibular muscle, and is also covered by a tough and shiny fascia. It lies [[Anatomical terms of location
column2: dorsal]] to the zygomatic arch and fills the [[temporal fossa]] of the [[skull]]. It arises from the side of the skull and inserts into the coronoid process of the mandible. It too, elevates the jaw.

column1: The two main integumentary muscles of a cat are the ''[[platysma]]'' and the ''cutaneous maximus''. The ''cutaneous maximus'' covers the dorsal region of the cat and allows it to shake its skin. The ''platysma'' covers the neck and allows the cat to stretch the skin over the pectoralis major and deltoid muscles.

The Rhomboideus is a thick, large muscle below the [[Trapezius muscles]]. It extends from the vertebral border of the scapula to the mid-dorsal line. Its origin is from the neural spines of the first four thoracic vertebrae, and its insertion is at the vertebral border of the scapula. Its action is to draw the scapula to the dorsal.
The Rhomboideus capitis is the most cranial of the deeper muscles. It is underneath the [[Trapezius muscles
column2: Clavotrapezius]]. Its origin is the superior nuchal line, and its insertion is at the scapula. Action draws scapula cranially.

column1: The Splenius is the most superficial of all the deep muscles. It is a thin, broad sheet of muscle underneath the [[Trapezius muscles
column2: Clavotrapezius]] and deflecting it. It is crossed also by the Rhomboideus capitis. Its origin is the mid-dorsal line of the neck and fascia. The insertion is the superior nuchal line and atlas. It raises or turns the head.

column1: The Serratus Ventralis is exposed by cutting the wing-like [[Latissimus Dorsi]]. The said muscle is covered entirely by [[adipose tissue]]. The origin is from the first nine or ten ribs and from part of the cervical vertebrae.

The Serratus Dorsalis is medial to both the scapula and the Serratus Ventralis. Its origin is via apoeurosis following the length of the mid-dorsal line, and its insertion is the dorsal portion of the last ribs. Its action is to depress and retracts the ribs during breathing.

The Intercostals are a set of muscles sandwiched among the ribs. They interconnect ribs, and are therefore the primary respiratory skeletal muscles. They are divided into the ''external'' and the ''internal subscapularis''. The origin and insertion are in the ribs. The intercostals pull the ribs backwards or forwards.
The [[Caudofemoralis]] is a muscle found in the pelvic limb. <ref>Rosenzweig, L. J. (1990). ''Anatomy of the Cat: Text and Dissection Guide''. Wm. C. Brown Publishers Dubuque, IA. p. 110, {{ISBN
column2: 0697055795}}.</ref> The Caudofemoralis acts to flex the tail laterally to its respective side when the pelvic limb is bearing weight. When the pelvic limb is lifted off the ground, contraction of the Caudofemoralis causes the limb to abduct and the shank to extend by extending the hip joint.

column1: Pectoantebrachialis muscle is just one-half inch wide and is the most superficial in the pectoral muscles. Its origin is the [[manubrium]] of the [[sternum]], and its insertion is in a flat [[tendon]] on the [[fascia]] of the proximal end of the [[ulna]]. Its action is to draw the arm towards the [[chest]]. There is no human equivalent.

The pectoralis major, also called ''pectoralis superficialis'', is a broad triangular portion of the pectoralis muscle which is immediately below the pectoantebrachialis. It is smaller than the pectoralis minor muscle. Its origin is the [[sternum]] and median ventral raphe, and its insertion is at the [[humerus]]. Its action is to draw the [[arm]] towards the [[chest]].

The pectoralis minor muscle is larger than the Pectoralis major. However, most of its anterior border is covered by the pectoralis major. Its origins are ribs three–five, and its insertion is the coracoid process of the scapula. Its actions are the tipping of the scapula and the elevation of ribs three–five.

The most posterior, flat, thin, and long strip of pectoral muscle is the Xiphihumeralis. It is a band of parallel fibers that is found in felines but not in humans. Its origin is the Xiphoid Process of the sternum. The insertion is the humerus.
In the [[cat]] there are three thin flat muscles that cover the back, and to a lesser extent, the neck. They pull the scapula toward the mid-dorsal line, anteriorly, and posteriorly.

The most anterior of the trapezius muscles, it is also the largest. Its fibers run obliquely to the ventral surface. Its origin is the superior nuchal line and median dorsal line and its insertion is the [[clavicle]]. Its action is to draw the clavicle dorsally and towards the head.

Acromiotrapezius is the middle trapezius muscle. It covers the dorsal and lateral surfaces of the scapula. Its origin is the neural spines of the cervical vertebrae and its insertion is in the metacromion process and fascia of the clavotrapezius. Its action is to draw the scapula to the dorsal, and hold the two scapula together.

Spinotrapezius, also called ''thoracic trapezius'', is the most posterior of the three. It is triangular shaped. Posterior to the acromiotrapezius and overlaps latissimus dorsi on the front. Its origin is the neural spines of the thoracic vertebrae and its insertion is the scapular fascia. Its action is to draw the scapula to the dorsal and caudal region.

The beginning of the digestion system of cats begins with their sharp teeth. Their sharp teeth help them tear meat which is most if not all of their diet. Cats naturally do not have a diet high in carbohydrates, and therefore, their saliva doesn’t contain the enzyme amylase.<ref>https://www.cathealth.com/digestive-system/cat-digestive-system</ref>Food moves from the mouth through the esophagus and into the stomach. The gastrointestinal tract of domestic cats contains a small cecum and unsacculated colon.<ref>https://books.google.com/books?hl=en&lr=&id=DZuAsci2apAC&oi=fnd&pg=PR15&dq=cat+digestive+system&ots=rMq-0Omu5Q&sig=lpIgnRMTUiy4RO2QFoWI9WMiGVo#v=onepage&q=cat%20&f=false</ref> The cecum while similar to dogs, doesn’t have a coiled cecum. The stomach of the cat can be divided into distinct regions of motor activity. The proximal end of the stomach relaxes when food is digested.<ref>https://books.google.com/books?hl=en&lr=&id=DZuAsci2apAC&oi=fnd&pg=PR15&dq=cat+digestive+system&ots=rMq-0Omu5Q&sig=lpIgnRMTUiy4RO2QFoWI9WMiGVo#v=onepage&q=cat%20&f=false</ref>While food is being digested this portion of the stomach either has rapid stationary contractions or a sustained tonic contraction of muscle.<ref>https://books.google.com/books?hl=en&lr=&id=DZuAsci2apAC&oi=fnd&pg=PR15&dq=cat+digestive+system&ots=rMq-0Omu5Q&sig=lpIgnRMTUiy4RO2QFoWI9WMiGVo#v=onepage&q=cat%20&f=false</ref> These different actions result in either the food being moved around or the food moving towards the distal portion of the stomach.<ref>https://books.google.com/books?hl=en&lr=&id=DZuAsci2apAC&oi=fnd&pg=PR15&dq=cat+digestive+system&ots=rMq-0Omu5Q&sig=lpIgnRMTUiy4RO2QFoWI9WMiGVo#v=onepage&q=cat%20&f=false</ref>The distal portion of the stomach undergoes rhythmic cycles of partial depolarization.<ref>https://www.cathealth.com/digestive-system/cat-digestive-system</ref>This depolarization sensitizes muscle cells so they are more likely to contract. The stomach is not only a muscular structure, it also serves a chemical function by releasing hydrochloric acid and other digestive enzymes to break down food. Food moves from the stomach into the small intestine. The first part of the small intestine is the duodenum. As food moves through the duodenum it mixes with bile, a fluid that neutralizes stomach acid and emulsifies fat. Bile is created in the liver and stored in the gall bladder. The pancreas releases enzymes that aid in digestion so that nutrients can be broken down and pass through the intestinal mucosa into the blood and travel to the rest of the body.<ref>https://books.google.com/books?hl=en&lr=&id=DZuAsci2apAC&oi=fnd&pg=PR15&dq=cat+digestive+system&ots=rMq-0Omu5Q&sig=lpIgnRMTUiy4RO2QFoWI9WMiGVo#v=onepage&q=cat%20&f=false</ref>The pancreas doesn’t produce starch processing enzymes because cats don’t eat a diet high in carbohydrates.<ref>https://www.cathealth.com/digestive-system/cat-digestive-system</ref>   Since the cat digests low amounts of glucose, the pancreas uses amino acids to trigger insulin release instead of glucose. Food then moves on to the jejunum. This is the most nutrient absorptive section of the small intestine. The liver regulates the level of nutrients absorbed into the blood system from the small intestine. From the jejunum, whatever food that has not been absorbed is sent to the ileum which connects to the large intestine.<ref>http://www.cat-health-detective.com/cat-digestive-system.html</ref>The first part of the large intestine is the cecum and the second portion is the colon. The large intestine reabsorbs water and forms fecal matter. There are some things that the cats are not able to digest. For example, cats clean themselves by licking their fur with their tongue, which causes them to swallow a lot of fur. This causes a build-up of fur in a cat’s stomach and creates a mass of fur. This is often thrown up and is better known as a hair ball.<ref>https://www.vetinfo.com/cat-digestive-diseases.html</ref> The short length of the digestive tract of the cat causes cats’ digestive system to weigh less than other species of animals, which allows cats to be active predators.<ref>https://www.cathealth.com/digestive-system/cat-digestive-system</ref> While cats are well adapted to be predators they have a limited ability to regulate catabolic enzymes of amino acids meaning amino acids are constantly being destroyed and not absorbed.<ref>https://www.cathealth.com/digestive-system/cat-digestive-system</ref>Therefore, cats have a higher protein requirement in their diet than many other species. Cats are not adapted to synthesize niacin from tryptophan and because they are carnivores can’t convert carotene to vitamin A so eating plants while not harmful does not provide them nutrients. Understanding the digestive system of a domestic cat is very important for pet owners. If a pet owner understands how the different parts work together then if a problem occurs they could potentially help the cat’s situation even before taking it to a vet.

In the female cat, the genitalia include two gonads, the uterus, the vagina, the genital passages and teats. Together with the vulva, the [[vagina]] of the cat is involved in mating and provides a channel for newborns during ''parturition'', or birth. The vagina is long and wide.<ref name=aniwa>[https://web.archive.org/web/20070929122935/http://www.aniwa.com/en/general/Grand_Public/document/100358/28398/index.htm  The cat's genital system and reproduction]. aniwa.com</ref> Genital passages are the [[oviducts]] of the cat. They are short, narrow, and not very sinuous.<ref name=aniwa/>
In the male cat, the genitalia includes the penis, which is covered with small spines.<ref name=""SchattenConstantinescu2008"">{{cite book
*[https://archive.org/details/catintroductiont00miva The cat; an introduction to the study of backboned animals, especially mammals (1881)]
*[https://archive.org/details/laboratoryguidef00gorhrich A laboratory guide for the dissection of the cat: An introduction to the study of anatomy (1895)]
