column1: <div class=""portal-column-left""> <!-- Switch to one column on narrow screens -->

column5: Cat cafe ""Cats Republic"" Saint Petersburg, Russia]]

column1: A '''cat café''' is a theme [[café]] whose attraction is [[cat]]s that can be watched and played with. Patrons pay a [[Cover charge
column2: cover fee]], generally hourly, and thus cat cafés can be seen as a form of supervised indoor [[pet rental]].

column1: ''Cat café'' has been officially recognized in the online edition of the [[Oxford Dictionary of English]] since August 2015.<ref>{{cite web
column6: title = Manspreading, hangry, Grexit join Oxford online dictionary

column1: The world's first cat café, ""Cat Garden"" (貓花園<ref name=""NBP"">[[Nihon Keizai Shimbun
column2: Nikkei BP]] : [http://trendy.nikkeibp.co.jp/article/column/20080422/1009762/ Article on 2 May 2008] {{jp icon}}</ref>), opened its doors in [[Taipei]], Taiwan, in 1998.<ref name=""bbc_20120402"">{{cite web
column4: title=BBC - Travel - Feline fun in Japan's cat cafes
column8: accessdate=7 January 2016}}</ref> The Taiwanese cat café eventually became a tourist destination, attracting tourists from Japan as well as all over the globe.<ref>{{cite web
column10: title=A Brief History of the Cat Café
column12: accessdate=7 January 2016}}</ref> Though the origin of cat café is in Taiwan, the concept blossomed in Japan,<ref name=""bbc_20120402""/> where the first one named ""Neko no Jikan"" (lit. ""Cat's Time"") was opened in [[Osaka]] in 2004.<ref name=""NBP""/> Due to the Japan's land size and population, many residents live in small apartments or condominiums which do not allow pets, making a cat café a very popular destination for young workers looking for the companionship and comfort offered. Tokyo's first cat café, named ""Neko no mise"" (Shop of Cats), opened in 2005. After this, the popularity of cat cafés boomed in Japan. From 2005 to 2010, seventy-nine cat cafés opened across the country.<ref>{{cite web

column1: In the United Kingdom animal charities disagree on whether cat cafés are a suitable environment for cats with the [[Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals
column2: RSPCA]], [[Cats Protection]] and the [[Celia Hammond#Celia Hammond Animal Trust
column3: Celia Hammond Animal Trust]] criticizing them for keeping large numbers of cats in a confined space with a revolving population of people. International Cat Care takes a more positive view saying ""It is a difficult environment to get right but it's not impossible by any means"". However, all the charities agree that cat cafés need to be properly regulated.<ref>{{cite news
column4: title=Are cat cafes good for cats?

column1: India's first cat café, Cat Café Studio, opened in 2010 in [[Mumbai]].<ref name=""CCS"">{{cite web
column4: title=This Versova cafe is home to adorable cats

column1: [[File:Nekokaigi, a cat cafe in Kyoto - March 16, 2010.jpg
[[File:Roo Female Somali in Cat Café Tokyo.jpg
column6: Somali]] in Cat Café in Tokyo]]

column1: Cat cafés are quite popular in Japan, with [[Tokyo]] being home to 58 cat cafés as of 2015.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Tokyo cat cafe shut down for animal neglect
column8: Neko no Mise}}, by Norimasa Hanada, which opened in 2005. The popularity of cat cafés in Japan is attributed to many apartments forbidding pets, and to cats providing relaxing companionship in what may otherwise be a stressful and lonesome urban life. Other forms of [[pet rental]], such as rabbit cafés, are also common in Japan.<ref>""[http://www.japantimes.co.jp/text/nn20120216f2.html?fb_ref=article_japantimes Tokyo's rabbit cafes hopping with customers]."" ''[[The Japan Times]]''. 16 February 2012. Retrieved on 13 July 2013.</ref>

column1: There are various types of cat cafés in Japan. Some feature specific categories of cat such as [[black cat]]s, fat cats, rare [[cat breed
column3: stray cat]]s. Every cat café in Japan is required to obtain a license and comply with the strict requirements and regulations of the nation's Animal Treatment and Protection Law.<ref>Iwata, Mamiko, [[About.com
column4: All About]] : [http://allabout.co.jp/pet/cat/closeup/CU20100051A/ Article on 7 March 2010] {{jp icon}}</ref>

column1: Japanese cat cafés feature strict rules to ensure cleanliness and animal welfare, in particular seeking to ensure that the cats are not disturbed by excessive and unwanted attention, such as by young children or when sleeping. Many cat cafés also seek to raise awareness of cat welfare issues, such as abandoned and stray cats and many often have cats from local animal shelters to help them lose any fear of humans and advertise them for possible adoption. From 2012 the cats could be displayed until 8 pm, but in 2016 the guidelines of the [[Ministry of the Environment (Japan)
column2: environment ministry]] state that they may visit  and play with customers until 10 pm.<ref>[http://www.news.com.au/lifestyle/real-life/wtf/cats-at-japans-cat-cafes-now-allowed-to-stay-up-till-10pm/news-story/ab6955ba24d2af012438cd4c6b999c4a Cats at Japan's ‘cat cafes’ now allowed to stay up till 10pm 28 April 2016] ''News.com.au'' Retrieved 3 May 2016</ref>

column1: One café in Tokyo added goats as a way of having a unique element.<ref>""[https://www.theguardian.com/world/video/2013/jul/11/tokyo-cafe-goats-video Tokyo cafe employs goats to add 'wow factor' - video]."" ''[[Reuters]]'' at ''[[The Guardian]]''. 11 July 2013. Retrieved on 13 July 2013.</ref>
The first cat café in Singapore is Cat Café Neko no Niwa (Japanese for ‘Cat Garden’). As of today, there are more than five cat and dog cafés in the city.<ref>{{cite web
column2: title=Cat cafés in Singapore: boon or bane for cats?
column5: title=Which of the 3 cat cafes in S’pore is the best?
column7: accessdate=23 September 2015}}</ref> The cat cafés are namely Neko no Niwa, The Cat Cafés, The Company of Cats, Meomi Cat Café and Cuddles Cat Café. Neko no Niwa, The Company of Cats and The Cat Café feature cats who were rescued.<ref>{{Cite web
column8: title = Five Cat Cafés That Have Taken Over Singapore And Why You Need To Visit Them - MustShareNews.com

column1: The Singaporean Cat Cafes are regulated and licensed by [[Agri-Food and Veterinary Authority of Singapore
column2: AVA]] and they are all bound to a 'code of conduct'.  Individuals having questions with their cat needs, can join the Cat Welfare Society, which helps with medical fees, sterilization costs or adopting of the cats. Cat Cafes usually have their own/specific houserules.<ref>{{cite web

column1: Cuddles Cat Cafe was investigated by [[Agri-Food and Veterinary Authority of Singapore]] (AVA) in December 2014.<ref>{{cite web
column2: title=AVA investigates allegations of animal deaths at cat cafe

column1: Cats are popular pets in Taiwan, with the cat population increasing rapidly in recent years.<ref name=""taiwantoday1"">{{cite web
column3: title=Taiwan's love affair with cats purrs ahead
column4: publisher=}}</ref> The world's first cat café, named ""Cat Garden"", opened in [[Taipei]] in 1998,<ref>{{cite web
column8: title=Travel - Feline fun in Japan's cat cafes
column11: accessdate=2016-06-19}}</ref> where there is also a luxurious ""Cathy Hotel"" especially for cats.<ref name=""taiwantoday1""/> The Taiwanese cat café concept next spread to Japan, and later to most other countries around the world.<ref>{{cite web
column15: title=Cat-ching! Cat cafes take over world - CNN.com

column1: Thailand has several cat cafés, most in Bangkok. Cat Cafe by Dome, Cat Up Cafe, Caturday, Cataholic Cafe, The Coffee Cat, Mohu Mohu Cafe and Purr Cat Cafe Club are all located in Bangkok.<ref>{{Cite web
column2: title = Dogs, Cats, Lattes: Bangkok's Best Pet Cafes
column5: accessdate = 2015-11-24}}</ref> Each serves baked goods with a small menu of main dishes and coffee and tea. Many have special pricing for petting time with a specific cat. Prices are usually higher than at most cafés but not unreasonably so. They all have rules regarding the behavior of guests towards the cats and often have purebred cats. Catmosphere Cat Cafe and Maewmoth cafés are located in Chiang Mai.<ref>{{Cite web

column1: According to local legend, the world's first cat café opened in Vienna in the summer of 1912 and ceased operation approximately two years later. It is said that Vladimir Lenin was a regular for a period in 1913, finding the feline companionship a comfort during his time of exile. The cat café is known to have ceased operation shortly after the beginning of the First World War, although the much repeated story that the closure was due to its patriotic owner's donating all the cats to a factory making fur-lined boots for the war effort may be apocryphal.<ref>https://www.pressreader.com/uk/the-oldie/20151209/282218009716840</ref> In 2012 cat café Neko was opened in Vienna.
Le chat touille opened up in [[Brussels]] in 2014.{{Citation needed
Kočkafé Freya opened in Prague in 2014. It was followed by three other cafes in [[Prague]], along with cat cafes in [[Olomouc]], [[Pardubice]], and other Czech cities.
Cafe Miao opened up in Copenhagen in 2014.
The first cat café in Estonia, Kassikohvik Nurri, opened in October  2014 in [[Tallinn]].
The first cat café in Finland, Kissakahvila Purnauskis, opened in November 2014 in [[Tampere]]. It is a permanent home for seven cats.
The second cat café, Kissakahvila Helsinki, opened in July 2015 in [[Helsinki]]. It is a permanent home for six cats.<ref>{{cite web
Le Café des Chats is a cat café located on 16 Rue Michel le Comte in Paris in 2013. This café is a diner that includes desserts, tea, and, of course, cats.<ref>{{cite news
column3: title=Vidéo: A Paris, le Café des chats invite les clients à un moment de ronron

column1: Kafelin is a cat cafe in Montpellier.
Stubentiger Cafe in [[Hannover]] opened in August 2015 with a varied menu, including vegetarian, gluten-free and vegan.<ref>{{cite web
column5: accessdate=18 April 2016}}</ref> In Munich, there is Café Katzentempel. Cologne has Cafe Schnurrke.<ref>{{cite web
column7: title=Cafe Schnurrke - erstes und einziges Katzencafe in Köln
column9: accessdate=18 April 2016}}</ref>  In Berlin there is Pee Pees Katzencafe,<ref name=""NPR Berlin"">{{cite web
column10: title=In Neukölln, Drink Your Latte With The House Cat

column1: Cat Café & Gallery is located in downtown Budapest near St. Stephen's Basilica at Révay utca 3.<ref>{{cite web
column5: accessdate=18 April 2016}}</ref> Cat Café is located on Damjanich utca 38.<ref>{{cite web

column1: The first Italian cat café opened in [[Turin]] in March 2014; at first it hosted six cats. Its name is MiaGola Café,<ref>{{cite news
column2: title = Sei gatti ""seduti"" al MiaGola Café a intrattenere i clienti
column8: language = it }}</ref> which in Italian can be interpreted as a [[language game]]: literally ''mia gola'' can be translated ''my throat'', while ''miagola'' ([[Stressed syllable
column9: stressed]] on the first syllable: miàgola) means ''(he or she) [[Cat communication#meow

column1: The Neko Cat Cafe was opened in [[Turin]] on 5 April 2014.<ref name=""eat"">{{cite web
column2: title=Get the Purrr-fect Snack in These Cat Cafés Around the World
column8: title=Cat cafe, from Japan to Italy was born the trend
column11: accessdate=18 April 2016}}</ref> The resident cats are all adopted from animal welfare organizations.

column1: The cat café in Latvia, MINKA cat cafe, opened in Riga in February 2015. MINKA Cat Cafe is located near the center at Meža street 4a.<ref>{{cite news
column2: title=Durvis vērusi Latvijā pirmā kaķu kafejnīca

column1: The cat café in Lithuania ""Cat Cafe Kačių kavinė"" opened in Vilnius in October 2014. Cat Cafe is located in center at Jasinskio str 1. It is one of the biggest cafes with cats in the world. 15 cats live there.<ref>{{cite news
The cat café ''Kopjes'' opened in [[Amsterdam]] in April 2015.<ref>{{cite news
column7: date=22 April 2015 }}</ref> In [[Groningen]] ''Kattencafé Op z'n Kop'' opened in February 2016.<ref>{{cite web
column11: accessdate=18 April 2016}}</ref> The cat café ''Miespoes'' opened in [[Den Bosch]] in 2016, as did cat café ''Katdeau'' in [[Hengelo]]. In August 2016 ''kattencafé Ditjes & Katjes'' opened in [[The Hague]].<ref>{{cite news
column12: title=Kroelen bij opening nieuw kattencafé in Den Haag
column16: date=9 August 2016}}</ref> Shortly afterwards Pebbles opened its doors as the first cat café in [[Rotterdam]].<ref>{{cite news
column19: title=Knuffels en cupcakes in Rotterdams eerste kattencafé

column1: Kociarnia"", the first cat café in Poland was opened in [[Kraków]] in June 2015.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Timeline Photos - Kocia Kawiarnia Kociarnia - Facebook
column5: accessdate=7 January 2016}}</ref> The name is a combination of Polish words ''kocia'' (of a cat) and ''kawiarnia'' (a café).

column1: A second cat café, ""Miau Café"", opened in [[Warsaw]] in January 2016.<ref>{{cite web
column6: date=3 February 2016}}</ref> This is a coffee and cake cafe that is also a shelter for homeless cats. It has vegan items on the human menu.<ref name=""moo"">{{cite web
column10: accessdate=17 June 2016}}</ref> The Miau Café came to life thanks to the crowdfunding campaign on the Polish platform, wspieram.to where the 1 700 residents of Warsaw pulled in the financial resources to make the idea of the first cat café in Warsaw come true.<ref>{{cite web
column12: title=WHEN ARE YOU GOING FOR A COFFEE WITH CATS ? - CAT CAFE WARSAW

column1: Miau Cafe was opened in Spring 2015 in [[Bucharest]].<ref>{{cite news
column3: title=Aici vii să bei cafeaua şi pleci cu mâţa la pachet
column4: trans_title=You come to have a coffee, you leave with a cat to go
column9: accessdate=26 March 2016}}</ref> A coffee house named Lady Cat also opened in [[Cluj-Napoca]] in March 2016.<ref>{{cite news
column11: title=Nou în Cluj: Lady Cat, o cafenea închinată Măriei Sale, pisica
column12: trans_title=New in Cluj: Lady Cat, a coffe house dedicated to Her Royal Highness, the cat

column1: The first cat cafe in Europe and in Russia ""Cats Republic"" was opened in the center of [[Saint Petersburg]] in 2011. There are live 25 cats.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Feline like a coffee? St Petersburg cafe offers customers the chance to enjoy a hot drink... while patting the in-house cats

column1: The first British cat café opened in [[Totnes]], Devon in June 2013.<ref>{{cite news
column2: title=Purrfect! Britain's first cat cafe opens in England's 'Narnia'
column6: date=21 July 2013}}</ref> However it closed in May 2014 due to staff illness and the need to safeguard the owner's health.<ref>{{cite web
column7: title=Closure of Totnes Cats Café (see most recent entry)
column9: website=Facebook, Totnes Cats Café group timeline

column1: In 2014 Lady Dinah's Cat Emporium opened to significant media attention<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=What's Right Meow: This London Café Has Us Feline Groovy - InStyle.com
column7: title=Funding secured for cat café to open in east London
column11: title=Lady Dinah's Cat Emporium, Shoreditch - London's cat café  (Condé Nast Traveller)
column13: accessdate=7 January 2016}}</ref> and a two-month waiting list.<ref>{{cite news
column16: title=London cat cafe opens to two-month waiting list

column2: date=February 2017}} home to Mog on The Tyne Cat Café<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Meet the moggy family at Newcastle city centre's new cat cafe Mog on the Tyne
column9: accessdate=7 January 2016}}</ref> and Willow Cat Cafe.<ref>{{cite news
column13: title=Moggie-lover opens cat cafe to raise funds for feline shelter

column1: Nottingham has a cat café called Kitty Café.<ref>{{cite web
In 2015, several other UK cafes were in planning.<ref>{{cite news
column7: title=The rise of cat cafes: the perfect solution for animal lovers who can't have pets

column1: The Bag of Nails in Bristol is a cat [[pub]], and has had as many as 24 cats.<ref>{{cite news
column5: title=Move Over Cat Cafes, This Cat Pub Is Taking Over
column11: title=The pub full of cats bringing feline fans to Bristol

column1: A cat cafe opened in the Northern Quarter of Manchester on 30 July 2016.<ref name=""MEN_17Jun16"">{{cite news
column3: title=Cat Cafe Manchester announces opening date - and you can book your visit NOW

column1: PAUSE cat cafe will open its doors in [[Bournemouth]] later on in the year and will become the first on the South coast. After a crowdfunding campaign, the cafe, at Old Christchurch Road, will have 12 resident rescue cats roaming the two floors. Rescuing felines will be promoted.<ref name=""daily echo"">{{cite web
column2: title=World getting you down? Bournemouth's getting its first-ever cat cafe to help you relax

column1: Maison de Moggy is the first cat café in Scotland and opened in January 2015.<ref>{{cite news
column5: title=In pictures: Scotland's first cat cafe Maison de Moggy opens its doors in Edinburgh
column12: title=Cat cafe Maison de Moggy finds purr-fect home in West Port
column16: archivedate=11 April 2015 }}</ref> Purrple Cat Cafe is planning to be Glasgow's first cat cafe, and is due to open in the summer of 2017 <ref>{{Cite news
column18: title=There is a cat cafe opening in Glasgow - here’s everything we know so far

column1: Cat cafés have been spreading across North America since 2014. The goal in North America generally is to help get cats adopted by partnering with local cat rescues.{{Citation needed
The first cat café to open in North America was Le Café des Chats/Cat Café Montreal<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Crazy cat ladies rejoice: The first two kitty cafes in North America now open in Montreal - The Boston Globe
column5: accessdate=7 January 2016}}</ref> in Montreal, Quebec, Canada, which opened its doors to the public in August 2014.

column1: Le Café des Chats in August 2014; Café Chat L'Heureux (also in [[Montreal]]) opened in September 2014 with 8 cats adopted from local shelters.
Saturday, 17 October 2015 saw the opening of Ontario's first cat café located in [[Guelph]], [[Ontario]].<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Guelph's first Kitty Café is open for business

column1: Catfe opened in [[Vancouver]], [[British Columbia]] on 14 December 2015 <ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Vancouver's first cat cafe opens in International Village
column6: accessdate=2 March 2016}}</ref> and Kitty Cat Café and Pet Me Meow are both planning cafés for [[Toronto]] to open in 2015.<ref>{{cite web
column8: title=Whatever Happened to Those Rival Cat Cafés?

column1: The Siberian Cat Café opened in 2015 [[Chelsea, Quebec
column2: Chelsea]]. This cat café has only [[Siberian cat]]s, making it the first [[Hypoallergenic cats
column3: hypoallergenic]] cat café in the world.<ref>{{cite news
column4: title=World's first hypoallergenic cat cafe opening in Chelsea, Quebec

column2: alt=The Charming Cat Cafe in Vista Ridge mall, Lewisville, TX
column5: The Charming Cat Cafe in [[Vista Ridge Mall]], [[Lewisville, Texas]]]]

column1: [[File:Cat petting store in lower east side nyc.jpg
column5: A cat café in the [[Lower East Side]], [[New York City]]]]

column1: In the United States, compliance with governmental food service regulations is required.  The area where the cats are playing or being considered for adoption must be entirely separated from the area where food and drink are served. For example, a newly adopted cat must leave through a separate door without passing a food serving area.<ref name=""webcat"">{{cite web

Cat cafés in the United States differ from those in many other countries by their focus on adoptions. Hundreds of animals have been adopted through their efforts. In some cases, adoptions are completed for customers visiting on vacation. For example, ''The Cat Cafe'' in [[San Diego]] has completed adoptions for customers visiting from [[Nebraska]],<ref name=""NBC7 San Diego"">{{cite web
column3: title=Tourist Adopts Cat From Cat Cafe on Trip to San Diego
column6: date=29 July 2015}}</ref> the [[San Francisco Bay Area]], [[Los Angeles]], and [[Pennsylvania]].

column1: KitTea was the first cat café to announce its plans to open in the United States. The news was first leaked via an article posted via The Laughing Squid<ref>{{Cite web
column2: title = KitTea, An Upcoming Cat Cafe in San Francisco
column7: title = BREAKING: Cat Cafe Coming To San Francisco
column12: last = Keeling}}</ref> on 22 January 2014. Although KitTea was unable to open as the first cat café due to raised rents and construction delays,<ref>{{Cite web
column13: title = Hayes Valley Cat Cafe Is Back On Track, Signs Lease
column18: last = Phaneuf}}</ref> they are proudly known as the first and only cat café in [[San Francisco, California]].<ref>{{Cite web
column19: title = KIT TEA'S CAT-OPOLY {{!}} SAN FRANCISCO'S FIRST AND ONLY CAT CAFE
column22: access-date = 2016-02-01}}</ref> On 24 June 2015, KitTea finally opened its doors to the anticipating public<ref>{{Cite web
column23: title = A trip to S.F.'s KitTea cat cafe
column26: access-date = 2016-02-01}}</ref> and continues to support cats from Wonder Cat Rescue and the ACC in San Francisco.

column1: The Cat Town Café opened in October 2014 and is a ""cross between a coffee shop and an adoption center"" in [[Oakland, California]].<ref>{{cite news
column4: title=America's First Cat Cafe Is Open. Here's What It's Like Inside
column5: date=3 November 2014}}</ref> They were soon followed in December 2014 by Planet Tails Cat Café in [[Naples, Florida]]; and in quick succession by Denver Cat Company in [[Denver, Colorado]]; Meow Parlour in [[New York City]]; The Cat Café<ref name=""The Cat Cafe"">{{cite web
column8: publisher=The Cat Cafe}}</ref><ref name=""Fox 5 San Diego"">{{cite web
column9: title=Cat Cafe Opens in San Diego
column11: publisher=Fox 5 San Diego}}</ref> in [[San Diego, California]]; [[Purringtons Cat Lounge]] in [[Portland, Oregon]]; and Calico Nook in [[Franklin, Massachusetts]].

column1: In June 2015, [[Crumbs and Whiskers]] opened its first cat café in [[Washington, D.C.]], where it partnered with the local chapter of the [[The Humane Society of the United States
column2: Humane Society]]; this café provides a boarding space for around 15–25 cats at a time, all of which are provided by the Humane Society and made available for adoption.<ref name=""ABC7"">{{cite web
column4: title=Cat cafe pounces forward in D.C.
column10: title=D.C.'s Cat Cafe, Crumbs and Whiskers, Makes Strides Toward Opening This Year
column16: title=Founder shares plans for D.C.'s first cat café, Crumbs and Whiskers
column23: title=Meet the woman who left her consulting job to open D.C.'s first cat cafe
column29: title=Not-yet-open D.C. cat cafe raises serious money in 1 day
column35: title=So, how would a cafe crawling with adorable kittens pass a D.C. health inspection?
column39: date=20 November 2014}}</ref> Crumbs and Whiskers subsequently opened its second café in Los Angeles, California in September 2016.<ref name=""NBC LA"">{{cite web

column4: This cat's coat allows it to blend in well with its environment]]

column1: The '''[[genetics]] of [[cat]] coat''' coloration, pattern, length (short, medium or long), and texture is a complex subject, and many different [[gene]]s are involved.

Cat coat genetics can produce a variety of colors and coat patterns. These are physical properties and should not be confused with a breed of cat. Furthermore, cats may show the color and/or pattern particular to a certain breed without actually being of that breed. For example, cats may have point coloration, but not be [[Siamese cat

column2: Bicolor, Tuxedo, and Van]] :This pattern varies between the [[Bicolor cat#Tuxedo cats
column3: tuxedo cat]] which is mostly black with a white chest, and possibly markings on the face and paws/legs, all the way to the ''Van'' pattern (so named after the [[Lake Van]] area in Turkey, which gave rise to the [[Turkish Van]] breed), where the only colored parts of the cat are the tail (usually including the base of the tail proper), and the top of the head (often including the ears). There are several other terms for amounts of white between these two extremes, such as ''Harlequin''. Bicolor cats can have as their primary (non-white) color black, red, any dilution thereof, and tortoiseshell (see below for definition).
Mackerel tabby, showing the characteristic ""M"" on its forehead.]]

column1: ; [[Tabby]] :Striped, with a variety of patterns. The classic blotched tabby (or marbled) pattern is the most common and consists of butterflies and bullseyes. The mackerel or striped tabby is a series of vertical stripes down the cat's side (resembling the fish). This pattern broken into spots is referred to as a spotted tabby. In addition, the individual hairs in a tabby-patterned coat may be banded with different colors, hence a ""ticked"" tabby. The worldwide evolution of the cat means that certain types of tabby are associated with certain countries; for instance, blotched tabbies are quite rare outside NW Europe, where they are the most common type.

: This cat is also known as a calimanco cat or clouded tiger cat, and by the abbreviation 'tortie'. In the cat fancy, a tortoiseshell cat is patched over with red (or its dilute form, cream) and black (or its dilute blue) mottled throughout the coat. Additionally, the cat may have white spots in its fur, which make it a 'tortoiseshell and white' cat; if there is a significant amount of white in the fur and the red and black colors form a patchwork rather than a mottled aspect, in North America the cat will be called a calico. All calicos are tortoiseshell (as they carry both black and red), but not all tortoiseshells are calicos (which requires a significant amount of white in the fur and patching rather than mottling of the colors). The calico is also sometimes called a tricolor cat. The Japanese refer to this pattern as ''mi-ke'' (meaning ""triple fur""), while the Dutch call these cats ''lapjeskat'' (meaning ""patches cat""). A true tricolor must consist of three colors: a reddish color, dark or light; white; and one other color, typically a brown, black, or blue.<ref>{{cite web
column8: date=November 2011}}</ref> Both tortoiseshell and calico cats are typically female because the coat pattern is the result of differential [[X chromosome]] [[x-inactivation
column9: inactivation]] in females (which, as with all normal female mammals, have two X chromosomes). Conversely, cats where the overall color is ginger (orange) are commonly male (roughly in a 3:1 ratio). In a litter sired by a ginger tom, the females will be tortoiseshell or ginger. Male tortoiseshells can occur as a result of chromosomal abnormalities (often linked to sterility) or by a phenomenon known as [[chimera (genetics)
column10: chimerism]], where two early stage embryos are merged into a single kitten.  The manifestation of coloured patches on both males and females is termed mosaicism.

column1: : The colorpoint pattern is most commonly associated with Siamese cats, but may also appear in any domesticated cat. A colorpointed cat has dark colors on the face, ears, feet, and tail, with a lighter version of the same color on the rest of the body, and possibly some white. The exact name of the colorpoint pattern depends on the actual color, so there are seal points (dark brown), chocolate points (warm lighter brown), blue points (dark gray), lilac or frost points (silvery gray-pink), red or flame points (orange), and tortie (tortoiseshell mottling) points, among others. This pattern is the result of a [[Mutation#Special classes
column2: temperature sensitive mutation]] in one of the [[enzyme]]s in the [[metabolic pathway]] from [[tyrosine]] to pigment, such as [[melanin]]; thus, little or no pigment is produced except in the extremities or points where the skin is slightly cooler. For this reason, colorpointed cats tend to darken with age as bodily temperature drops; also, the fur over a significant injury may sometimes darken or lighten as a result of temperature change.

column1: : The tyrosine pathway also produces [[neurotransmitter]]s, thus mutations in the early parts of that pathway may affect not only pigment, but also neurological development. This results in a higher frequency of [[strabismus
column2: cross-eyes]] among colorpointed cats, as well as the [[White tiger#Genetics and albinism
column3: high frequency of cross-eyes in white tigers]].

column1: : True albinism (a mutation of the tyrosinase gene) is quite rare in cats. Much more common is the appearance of white coat color that is caused by a lack of [[melanocyte]]s in the skin. A [[Melanin#Genetic disorders and disease states
column2: higher frequency of deafness in white cats]] is due to a reduction in the population and survival of melanoblast stem cells, which in addition to creating pigment-producing cells, develop into a variety of neurological cell types. White cats with one or two blue eyes have a particularly high likelihood of being deaf.

column1: : The bottom eighth of each hair is white or creamy-white, with the rest of the hair being a solid color. Genetically this color is a non-[[agouti signalling peptide
column2: agouti]] cat with the dominant inhibitor gene; a non-agouti version of the silver [[tabby cat
column3: tabby]]. Smoke cats will look solid colored until they move, when the white undercoat becomes apparent. It is mostly found in [[cat breed
column4: pedigreed cat]]s (especially longhair breeds) but also present in some [[domestic long-haired cat]]s.

column1: == Genes involved in albinism, dominant white, and white spotting ==

column4: The temperature sensitive albino genotype c<sup>s</sup>c<sup>s</sup> produces [[point coloration]] at body extremities where lower temperature allows the mutated tyrosinase enzyme to become active.]]

column1: * The ""C"" gene codes for the enzyme [[tyrosinase]], the first step in pigment production. Its [[Recessive gene
column2: recessive alleles]] determine whether a cat is a complete [[albinism
column3: albino]] (pink-eyed) or a temperature sensitive albino. The temperature sensitive albino genotypes are c<sup>b</sup>c<sup>b</sup> [[Burmese (cat)
column6: Tonkinese]] (mink). The c<sup>s</sup>c<sup>s</sup> gene can turn a cat's eyes blue due to a reduced number of [[melanocytes]], affecting pigmentation of the eyes. If a cat has the dominant C allele, then the cat is non-albino and full pigment production occurs.

column1: * The ''white masking'' gene, ''W/w''. The ""W"" gene prevents the normal replication and migration of pigment-producing cells during embryologic development. As a result, ''WW'' and ''Ww'' cats have a greatly reduced number of [[melanocytes]] and appear white, no matter what other color genes it may carry.  Only a cat that is [[homozygous]] [[recessive]] (''ww'') will express normal pigmentation. Thus, ''W'' is [[epistasis
column2: epistatic]] to the other coat pigmentation genes. Some cats with the ''W'' allele of this gene are deaf and/or have depigmentation of the iris of one or both eyes, resulting in blue eye color. White cats are also more likely to get skin cancer.

column1: * The ''white spotting'' or ''piebald spotting'' gene, ''S/s'', has variable expression, so that an ''SS'' cat often has more extensive white patching than an ''Ss'' cat. It is this gene that creates the familiar white blaze across the face, a white bib, ''tuxedo'' pattern, or dappled paws.  A hypothetical Sb allele (""gloving gene"") may cause the mittens in [[Birman]] and [[Snowshoe (cat)
column2: Snowshoe]] breeds.  Some researchers believe that there are separate white spotting genes for distinct forms of white pattern, such as the white locket that some cats have on their neck or bellies.

column1: == Genes involved in red, black, brown, and diluted colors ==

column4: This probably male cat shows the ""red"" O- genotype, with ll for long hair (though not show-quality), ss for absence of white spotting, and at least one Mc gene for the mackerel tabby pattern]]

column1: * The sex-linked ''red'' gene, ''O'', determines whether there will be red variations to fur color.<ref name=""fanciers"">{{cite web
column3: title=Cat Colors FAQ: Cat Color Genetics
column6: accessdate=2014-08-11}}</ref>  This gene is located on the X chromosome.  In cats with red variants of fur tone, [[phaeomelanin]] (red pigment) completely replaces eumelanin (black or brown pigment).<ref name=""fanciers""/>

column1: * Males have only one X chromosome, so only have one allele of this gene. O results in red variations, and o results in non-orange fur.

* Since females have two X chromosomes, they have two alleles of this gene. OO results in red toned fur, oo results in non-orange fur, and Oo results in a [[tortoiseshell cat]], in which some parts of the fur are red variants and others areas non-red.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Feline Breeds, Domestic Cats and Color Patterns

column1: A cat with Oo and white spotting genes is commonly called a [[calico cat
column2: calico]].  The reason for the patchwork effect in female cats heterozygous for the O gene (Oo) is [[X-inactivation]] – one or the other X chromosome in every cell in the embryo is randomly inactivated (see [[Barr body]]), and the gene in the other X chromosome is expressed.

column1: * [[Rufous polygenes]], as yet unidentified, can affect the richness of the orange/red gene's expression.

For a cat to be tortoiseshell, calico, or one of the variants such as blue-cream or chocolate tortoiseshell, the cat must simultaneously express two [[allele]]s, ''O'' and ''o'', which are located on the [[XY sex-determination system
column2: X chromosome]]. Males normally cannot do this, as they have only one X chromosome, and therefore only one allele, and so calico cats are normally only female. Male tortoiseshell or calico cats occur only if they have chromosomal abnormalities such as the genotype XXY (in which case they are [[Sterility (physiology)
column4: chromosomal mosaicism]] (only portions of their cells have the genotype XXY, so these cats may be fertile), or [[Chimera (genetics)
column5: chimerism]] (a single individual formed from two fused embryos, at least one of which was male). Approximately 1 in 3,000 calico/tortoiseshell cats are male.<ref>{{cite web
column12: accessdate=2008-07-03}}</ref> Chimericism (which may result in fertile male cats) appears to be the most common mechanism.

column1: * The browning gene ''B/b/b<sup>l</sup>'' codes for tyrosinase related protein-1, an enzyme involved in the metabolic pathway for eumelanin pigment production. Its dominant form, ''B'', will produce black color.  Recessive variants are ''b'', producing brown (or ''chocolate''), and ''b<sup>l</sup>'' producing light brown or ''cinnamon''.

* ''Barrington Brown'' is a recessive browning gene that dilutes black to mahogany, brown to light brown and chocolate to pale coffee.  It is different from the browning gene and has only been observed in laboratory cats.

* The ''Dense pigment'' gene, ''D/d'', codes for [[melanophilin]], a protein involved in the transportation and deposition of pigment into a growing hair. When a cat has two of the recessive ''d'' alleles (Maltese dilution), black fur becomes ""blue"" (appearing gray), chocolate fur becomes ""lilac"" (appearing light brown), cinnamon fur becomes fawn, and orange fur becomes cream.
* Dilution modifier gene, Dm, ""caramelizes"" the dilute colors as a dominant trait. The existence of this phenomenon as a discrete gene is a controversial subject among feline enthusiasts.
*  A mutation at the extension locus ''E/e'' (the [[melanocortin]] receptor) changes black pigment to amber or light amber. This phenomenon was first identified in [[Norwegian forest cat
* A modifying factor has also been hypothesized in shaded silver and chinchilla [[Persian cat
column2: Persians]] whose fur turns pale golden in adulthood, due to low levels of phaeomelanin production. These cats resemble shaded or tipped goldens, but are genetically shaded or tipped silvers. This is probably related to the phenomenon known as ""tarnishing"" in silvers.

column1: One can deduce that a grey male cat with a white bib and paws, but showing no tabby pattern:
*has the ''o'' variant of the orange gene on its only X chromosome (because the grey color corresponds to black, not orange)
*has at least one ''S'' variant of the white Spotting gene (because it has the white bib and paws)
*has two ''w'' alleles (because it expresses a fur color)
*has the dominant ''B'' allele (because its fur color is a shade of black rather than brown)
*has two ''d'' (dilute) alleles (because its fur is grey, rather than black).
== Genes involved in fur pattern and shading ==

column4: A mackerel tabby with the classic ""M"" on forehead.]]
An orange tabby with facial markings and nose spot.]]
The recessive mutant gene ''mc'' produces the blotched or classic tabby pattern.]]
A Brown Mackerel [[tabby cat]] with pencil lines on the face.]]
A tabby point on a Mekong bobtail.]]

column1: * The [[agouti gene]], ''A/a'' which codes for [[agouti signaling protein]].  The dominant, wild-type ''A'' causes the agouti shift phenomenon which causes hairs to be black pigmented at the tips and orange pigmented at the roots (revealing the underlying tabby pattern), while the recessive ''non-agouti'' or ""hypermelanistic"" allele, ''a'', prevents this shift in the pigmentation pathway.  In its homozygous form, aa, this results in black pigment production throughout the growth cycle of the hair.  Thus, the non-agouti genotype (aa) masks or hides the tabby pattern, although sometimes a suggestion of the underlying pattern can be seen (called ""ghost striping""), especially in kittens.  The O allele is also [[epistatic]] over the aa genotype.  That is, the ''A'' to ''a'' mutation does not have a discernible effect on red or cream colored cats, resulting in these cats displaying tabby striping independent of their genotype at this locus.  This explains why you can usually see the tabby pattern in the orange patches of non-agouti tortoiseshell cats, but not in the black or brown patches.

* The primary [[tabby]] pattern gene, ''Mc/mc'', sets the basic pattern of stripes that underlies the coat: the basic wild-type tabby gene, ''Mc'', produces what is called a ''mackerel striped'' tabby (stripes look like thin fishbones and may break up into bars or spots); while a recessive mutant, ''mc'', produces a blotched or ''classic'' tabby pattern (broad bands, whorls, and spirals of dark color on pale background usually with bulls-eye or oyster pattern on flank), common in Iran, Great Britain and in lands that were once part of the British Empire and Persian Empire. The gene responsible for this differential patterning has been identified as ''transmembrane aminopeptidase Q'' (''Taqpep''), which also produces the [[king cheetah]] coat variant.<ref>{{cite journal
column2: title=Specifying and Sustaining Pigmentation Patterns in Domestic and Wild Cats

column1: * Secondary [[tabby]] pattern genes such as ''T<sup>a</sup> / t<sup>a</sup>'', at which locus a dominant mutation produces an ''Abyssinian ticked'' or non-patterned agouti tabby, having virtually no stripes or bars.  (This is one type of unpatterned tabby; the other type of unpatterned tabby is the shaded/chinchilla. See inhibited pigment gene, below.)  The dominant ticked tabby allele masks all other tabby patterns.

* Other genes (''pattern modifier'' genes) are theorized to be responsible for creating various type of spotting patterns, many of which are variations on a basic mackerel or classic pattern.  There are also hypothetical factors which affect the timing and frequency of the agouti shift, affecting agouti band width and the number and quality of alternating bands of eumelanin and phaeomelanin on individual hairs.
Tabby cats (AA or Aa), normally have:
* M on forehead. (Visible in ticked tabby cats, but hard to discern in shaded silver/golden, and tipped cats)
* Thin pencil lines on face. (Visible in ticked tabby cats, but hard to discern in shaded silver/golden, and tipped cats)
* Black ""eyeliner"" appearance and white or pale fur around eyeliner.
* A pink nose outlined in darker pigment
* Torso, leg, and tail banding. (Torso banding disappears in the ticked tabby.)
Most or all striping disappears in the chinchilla or shaded cat, but it is still possible to identify the cat as a tabby from these other features.
* There is a gene, not yet identified but believed to be related to the agouti gene, in the [[Chausie]] breed, that produces silver-tipped black fur similar to [[Abyssinian cat
column2: Abyssinian]] ticked fur. The ""grizzled"" phenomenon is purported to have been inherited from the hybridization of the domestic cat to the jungle cat (''Felis chaus'').

column1: * The ''inhibited pigment'' gene, ''I/i''. The dominant allele (I) produces ''tipped'' hairs that are fully colored only at the tip and have a white base. This allele appears to interact with other genes to produce various degrees of tipping, ranging from deeply tipped silver tabby to lightly tipped shaded silver and chinchilla silver.  The inhibitor gene interacts with the non-agouti genotype (I-aa) to produce the color known as smoke. The homozygous recessive genotype when combined with the agouti gene (iiA-), produces tabby coloration, which can vary along a spectrum ranging from a deeply patterned brown tabby, to a lighter ""golden tabby"", to the very lightly colored shaded or chinchilla golden colors. Orange cats with the inhibitor gene (I-O-) are commonly called ""cameo"".

The genetics involved in producing the ideal tabby, tipped, shaded, or smoke cat is complex.  Not only are there many interacting genes, but genes sometimes do not express themselves fully, or conflict with one another.  For example, the melanin inhibitor gene sometimes does a poor job blocking pigment, resulting in an excessively gray undercoat, or in tarnishing (yellowish or rusty fur).

Likewise, poorly-expressed non-agouti or over-expression of melanin inhibitor will cause a pale, washed out black smoke. Various polygenes (sets of related genes), epigenetic factors, or modifier genes, as yet unidentified, are believed to result in different phenotypes of coloration, some deemed more desirable than others by fanciers.
Here are the genetic influences on tipped or shaded cats:
* Tabby pattern genes (such as T<sup>a</sup> masking the tabby pattern).
* Factors affecting the number and width of bands of color on each hair (such as the hypothetical wide band gene).
* Factors affecting the amount and quality of eumelanin and/or phaeomelanin pigment expression (such as theorized rufousing factors)
* Genes causing sparkling appearance (such as ''glitter'' in the Bengal, ''satin'' in the Tennessee Rex, ''grizzle'' in the Chausie).
* Factors to clear up residual striping (hypothetical Chaos, Confusion, Unconfused, Erase, and Roan factors).
== Genes involved in fur length and texture ==
Cat fur length is governed by the ''Long hair'' gene in which the dominant form, ''[[domestic shorthaired cat
column2: L]]'', codes for '''short''' hair, and the recessive ''[[domestic long-haired cat
column3: l]]'' codes for '''long''' hair. In the longhaired cat, the transition from anagen (hair growth) to catagen (cessation of hair growth) is delayed due to this mutation. A rare recessive shorthair gene has been observed in some lines of Persian cat (silvers) where two longhaired parents have produced shorthaired offspring.

column1: There have been many genes identified that result in unusual cat fur.  These genes were discovered in random-bred cats and selected for. Some of the genes are in danger of going extinct because the cats are not sold beyond the region where the mutation originated or there is simply not enough demand for cats expressing the mutation.

In many breeds, coat gene mutations are unwelcome. An example is the rex allele which appeared in Maine Coons in the early 1990s. Rexes appeared in America, Germany and the UK, where one breeder caused consternation by calling them ""Maine Waves"". Two UK breeders did test mating which indicated that this was probably a new rex mutation and that it was recessive. The density of the hair was similar to normally coated Maine Coons, but consisted only of down type hairs with a normal down type helical curl, which varied as in normal down hairs. Whiskers were more curved, but not curly. Maine Coons do not have awn hairs, and after moulting, the rexes had a very thin coat.

There are various genes producing curly coated or ""rex"" cats.  New types of rex pop up spontaneously in random-bred cats now and then.  Here are some of the rex genes that breeders have selected for:

column3: locus]] as Cornish, but proposed as a different [[allele]]. However, most breeders consider the German Rex to have r/r genotype.

column2: dominant]] although sometimes described as an [[Dominance (genetics)#Incomplete dominance
column3: incomplete dominant]] because the three possible allele pairings relate to three different phenotypes: heterozygous cats (Sese) may have a fuller coat that is preferred in the show ring, while homozygous cats (SeSe) may have a tighter curl and less coat volume. (sese type cats have a normal coat.) This phenomenon may also colloquially be referred to as additive dominance.

column2: dominant]]: Lp/lp and Lp/Lp individuals have the same phenotype.

column1: There are also genes for hairlessness:
* h = French hairless cat, [[Recessive gene#Recessive allele
* hd = British hairless cat, [[Recessive gene#Recessive allele
Some rex cats are prone to temporary hairlessness, known as baldness, during moulting.
Here are a few other genes resulting in unusual fur:
* The Wh gene (dominant, possibly incomplete) results in [[American Wirehair
column2: Wirehair]] cats.  They have bent or crooked hair producing springy, crinkled fur.

column1: * A hypothetical Yuc gene, or [[York Chocolate cat
column2: York Chocolate]] undercoat gene, results in cats with no undercoat. However, the proportional relationship between [[Guard hair
column4: awn]], and [[down hair]] production varies greatly between all breeds.

column1: * A recessive autosomal gene for ''Onion hair'' which causes roughness and swelling on the hairs.  The swelling is due to enlargement of the inner core of medulla cells.

* A recessive autosomal gene spf for ''sparse fur''.  As well as sparse coat, the hairs are thin, straggly and contorted and there is brown exudate around the eyes and nose and on the chest and stomach. A similar condition is linked to [[Ornithine Transcarbamylase Deficiency]] in mice.
*[http://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/0750640693 Genetics for Cat Breeders and Veterinarians]  Carolyn M. Vella, Lorraine M. Shelton, John J. McGonagle, Terry W. Stanglein.  Butterworth-Heinemann Ltd {{ISBN
*[http://cc.ysu.edu/~helorime/BasicCol.html Coat Color Genetics] Heather E. Lorimer.
*[http://www.messybeast.com/catarchive.htm#genetics Cat Genetics articles in plain English]
*[http://home.earthlink.net/~featherland/off/white.html The Pigment Parade: White and White Spotting in the Cat]

'''Pinch-induced behavioral inhibition''' ('''PIBI''') or '''clipnosis''' is a partially inert state which results from a gentle squeeze of the skin behind the [[neck]].  It is mostly observed among [[Felidae]] and allows the mother cat to easily carry her kitten with her jaws. It can be used to effectively restrain most cats in a domestic or veterinary context.<ref>{{Cite journal

column2: title = Pinch-induced behavioral inhibition ('clipnosis') in domestic cats
journal = Journal of Feline Medicine & Surgery

column3: A pink cat with folded ears]]

column1: While '''[[cat]]s''' have a variety of breeds and coats, [[pink]] is not a natural colour among them. Nevertheless, several instances of '''pink cats''' have been reported by the media, sometimes as a result of interference with chemicals or [[dye]]s rather than any [[Cat coat genetics
column2: natural genetics]]. Additionally, several fictional pink cats have been used in popular culture.

column3: A bicolor pink-white cat and a bicolor orange-white cat]]

column1: In September 2005, a cat, Brumas, briefly left his owners in [[Launceston, Cornwall]], and returned with his fur coloured pink. The cause of the colour change was not identified, but Brumas was examined by the [[RSPCA]] and found to have no toxins.<ref>{{cite news
column3: title=Cat in the pink over new colour

column1: In September 2010, a cat with dyed pink fur was discovered in [[Swindon]]. The RSPCA called the dyeing a ""sick prank"" and were unable to wash the colour out of the cat's fur, though no side-effects were observed.<ref>{{cite news
column3: title='Sick prank' leaves cat dyed pink in Swindon
column6: accessdate=14 January 2015}}</ref> The event made worldwide news,<ref>{{cite news
column8: title='Pink cat' puts Swindon on the global media map
column11: accessdate=14 January 2015}}</ref> before the owner came forward and said the cat had been dyed pink using [[food colouring]] because she was a fan of the colour.<ref>{{cite news
column13: title=Swindon pink cat owner will get pet back
column16: accessdate=14 January 2015}}</ref> She said the act ""seemed like a good idea. I always wanted a pink animal – a bit like my hair"" and insisted she read the instructions carefully, knowing that the colouring could not be toxic as it was intended for human consumption.<ref>{{cite news
column18: title=Pink cat mystery solved: owner dyed it to match her hair
column23: accessdate=14 January 2015}}</ref> The RSPCA later confirmed they would not press charges.<ref>{{cite news
column25: title=Owner who dyed cat pink reunited with pet after RSPCA says she didn't commit a crime

column1: In May 2011, four kittens were found abandoned in a concrete factory in [[Redruth]], Cornwall, one of which had pink fur. The charity [[Cats Protection]] attempted to wash out the colour with shampoo, but were unsuccessful.<ref>{{cite news
In 2010, a report showed pollution from the [[Port Talbot Steelworks]] in [[Wales]] had turned cats both grey and pink.<ref>{{cite web
column5: title=Glitter rain and pink cat town demands clean air

column1: Cats having pinkish patches can be found in [[Bulgaria]]. The color is probably the result of a [[genetic mutation]] and is very close to orange. They are usually pink-white [[bicolor cat
column2: bicolor]]; or pink-[[Russian Blue]]-white or pink-black-white [[calico cat]]s.
Pink Panther]] is a cartoon character created by [[Friz Freleng]]. As well as featuring in the opening titles of the [[The Pink Panther
column3: films]] starring [[Peter Sellers]], he has appeared in spin-off cartoon series. Animation historian [[Jerry Beck]] has said the character is ""anti-authority – he's cool yet he's pink"".<ref>{{cite news

column1: The title character of the children's television series ''[[Bagpuss]]'' was a pink cat. The puppet used for [[animation]] was originally supposed to be marmalade, but was dyed pink accidentally during the manufacturing process.<ref>{{cite news
column3: title=How firm's error made Bagpuss a kitty in pink
column6: accessdate=14 January 2014}}</ref> Another children's television series, ''[[Roobarb and Custard]]'' featured a pink cat, Custard. Creator [[Grange Calveley]] based Custard's mannerisms on [[Sid James]].<ref>{{cite news

column5: adj=on}} tall pink cat as part of an exhibition in [[Century Park (Shanghai)
column8: title=Colossal pink cat makes its debut

column5: Cats for sale as food in an East Asian market area. They will either be sold live for use in restaurants or slaughtered on site, dressed, and sold as meat.]]

column1: '''Cat meat''' is meat prepared from [[domestic cat]]s for human consumption. Some countries eat cat meat regularly, whereas others have only consumed cat meat in desperation during wartime or poverty.
Prehistoric human feces have contained bones from the wild cat of Africa.<ref name=""TaylorNegus1989"">{{cite book
In some cultures of [[Cameroon]], there is a special ceremony featuring cat-eating that is thought to bring good luck.<ref>{{Cite news
column3: title= The cat eaters of Cameroon

column1: In [[Guangdong]] and [[Guangxi]] provinces in south-eastern [[China]], some—especially older—people consider cat flesh a good warming food during winter months. However, in northern China eating cat is considered unacceptable. <ref name=Xinhuanet/>
In Guangdong, cat meat is a main ingredient in the traditional dish ""[[Dragon tiger phoenix
column2: dragon, tiger, phoenix]]"" (snake, cat, chicken), which is said to fortify the body.<ref name=Xinhuanet>[http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/indepth/2012-01/13/c_131358233.htm Some call it an indelicate trade, others, a delicacy], Xinhuanet.com, 13 Jan 2012 (from China Daily)</ref>

column1: Organized cat-collectors supply the southern restaurants with animals that often originate in [[Anhui]] and [[Jiangsu]] provinces.<ref name=Xinhuanet/><ref>{{Cite news
column3: title= Nanjing sends meat that meows to Guangzhou
column10: title= Cat-nappers feed Cantonese taste for pet delicacy
column15: date=2009-01-01}}</ref> On 26 January 2010 China launched its first draft proposal to protect the country's animals from maltreatment including a measure to jail people, for periods up to 15 days, for eating cat or dog meat.<ref name=""China to jail people for up to 15 days who eat dog (China Daily)"">{{cite web
column19: title = China to jail people for up to 15 days who eat dog}}</ref><ref>{{cite web
column21: title = Trung Quốc sắp sửa cấm ăn thịt chó, mèo}} {{vi}}</ref>

column1: With the increase of cats as pets in [[China]], opposition towards the traditional use of cats for food has grown. In June 2006, approximately 40 activists stormed the Fangji Cat Meatball Restaurant in [[Shenzhen]], forcing it to shut down.<ref name=""Fangji Cat Meatball Restaurant (Reuters)"">{{Cite news
column9: df= }}</ref> Expanded to more than 40 member societies, the [[Chinese Animal Protection Network]] in January 2006 began organizing well-publicized protests against dog and cat consumption, starting in [[Guangzhou]], following up in more than ten other cities ""with very optimal response from public.""<ref name=""Guangzhou bans eating snakes--ban helps cats(Animal People)"">{{cite web
column13: title=Guangzhou bans eating snakes--ban helps cats

column1: In Japan, cat meat was consumed until the end of [[Tokugawa period]] in the 19th century.<ref name=""hanleycat66"">{{Cite book
column4: title = Everyday Things in Premodern Japan
column7: Okinawans]] once ate a cat soup called ''Mayaa no Ushiru'' ([[:ja:マヤーのウシル

column1: In [[Korea]], cat meat was historically brewed into a tonic as a folk remedy for [[neuralgia]] and [[arthritis]]. Modern consumption is more likely to be as cat soup.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Boiled Alive Cat Meat Soup, South Korea
column11: title=Dog and Cat Meat Consumption – In Defense of Animals – In Defense of Animals
column15: title=Ban South Korean dog and cat meat trade
column22: title=Important Update On South Korean Dog And Cat Meat Trade

column1: Cat meat is eaten in Vietnam, even though it is technically illegal.<ref name=""meovb"">Việt Báo [http://vietbao.vn/The-gioi-giai-tri/Thanh-pho-thit-meo/50760981/407/ Thịt mèo]</ref><ref name=""tptm"">[http://tuoitre.vn/Chinh-tri-Xa-hoi/Phong-su-Ky-su/99714/Thanh-pho-thit-meo.html Thành phố thịt mèo]</ref><ref>{{cite web
column3: title=9 Countries That Eat Cats and Dogs (Slideshow)
column7: title=9 Countries That Eat Cats and Dogs
column15: title=The Truth About Cats & Dogs In Vietnam - The Dropout Diaries
column19: title=Where cat sits happily on the menu
column23: title=Why do Vietnamese keep cats on a leash? (Hint: What's for dinner?)
column26: accessdate=22 November 2015}}</ref> It is generally seen on menus with the euphemism ""[[wiktionary:tiểu hổ
column27: tiểu hổ]]"", literally ""baby tiger"" rather than the literal ""[[wiktionary:thịt
column29: mèo]]"". Cat galls have [[aphrodisiac]]al properties according to people in North Vietnam.<ref name=""Hopkins2004"">{{cite book
column31: title=Extreme Cuisine: The Weird and Wonderful Foods That People Eat

column1: Cat meat is eaten in some parts of India, even though it is technically illegal.{{citation needed
column2: date=November 2016}} It is generally cooked with flavoured rice and is part of the main course during wedding feasts in the Narikurvar community; cat soup is also served on the occasion of the birth of a male child.<ref name=""huffindia"">{{cite news
column5: title=For biryani in Chennai, cats are being boiled alive, sold for Rs 100 per kg

column1: In Switzerland the private consumption and slaughter of dog and cat meat is permitted though its commercial trade is prohibited by law. A 1993 petition to ban consumption failed with the government declaring the matter a ""personal ethical choice.""

In June 2008, three students at the Danish School of Media and Journalism published pictures of a cat being slaughtered in ''Citat'', a magazine for journalism students. Their goal was to create a debate about [[animal welfare]]. The cat was shot by its owner, a [[farmer]], and it would have been [[animal euthanasia
column2: put down]] in any case. The farmer [[animal slaughter
column3: slaughtered]] the cat all within the limits of [[Law of Denmark
column4: Danish law]]. This led to criticism from Danish animal welfare group Dyrenes Beskyttelse,<ref name=""Journalistelever spiser kat"">{{cite news
column15: accessdate=2013-10-28}}</ref><ref name=""Journaliststuderende spiser kat på nettet"">{{cite news

column2: title = Journaliststuderende spiser kat på nettet
column3: trans_title = Journalism students eat cat online

column4: accessdate = 2013-10-28}}</ref> and [[death threat]]s received by the students.<ref name=""Århus-studerende spiste kat - nu trues de på livet"">{{cite news
column8: title=Århus-studerende spiste kat - nu trues de på livet
column9: trans_title=Students from Århus ate cat - are now threatened on their life

column1: In 18th-century Britain, there are a few records of cats eaten as a form of entertainment.<ref name=""The Cat Eaters"">{{cite web
In February 2010, on a television cooking show, the [[Italy
column2: Italian]] food writer Beppe Bigazzi mentioned that during the famine in [[World War II]] cat stew was a ""succulent"" and well known dish in his home area of [[Valdarno]], [[Tuscany]]. Later he claimed he had been joking, but added that cats used to be eaten in the area during famine periods, historically; he was widely criticised in the media for his comments and ultimately dropped from the television network.<ref>{{Cite news
column4: title = Celebrity chef Beppe Bigazzi upsets viewers with his cat casserole

column1: Cats were sometimes eaten as a [[famine food]] during harsh winters, poor harvests, and wartime. Cat gained notoriety as ""roof rabbit"" in [[Central Europe]]'s hard times during and between [[World War I]] and [[World War II]].<ref>{{cite web
Cat consumption was a stereotype attributed to Vincenzans in [[Vicenza]], Italy.<ref name=""Albala2003"">{{cite book

According to the ""Butchers' Advocate, Dressed Poultry and the Food Merchant"" in 1904, ''""Just before Christmas it is common for a group of young men in northern Italy to kill some cats, skin them and soak them in water for two or three days. They are cooked with great care on Christmas day and served up hot about 1.30 P. M., after mass. ""Many people in Italy, 'on the quiet,' keep cats like the English do rabbits—to kill. A catskin there is worth ten pence, as the material for muffs for girls. ""Extraordinary care has to be taken in procuring the animals, for the Italian Society for the Protection of Cats is vigilant, and offenses against the law are followed by imprisonment only. We have no fines in Italy.''<ref>{{cite book
column2: title=Butchers' Advocate, Dressed Poultry and the Food Merchant

column1: According to ""The Dietetic & Hygienic Gazette"" in 1905, ''Italy cultivates the cat for home consumption as English people raise rabbits. It is to be done on the quiet, however, for in spite of the profit in the business and the demand for the delicacy, the law has to be looked out for, and the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Cats is vigilant. Offenses against the law are visited with imprisonment. Cats are raised for the market none the less. Fattened on the finest of milk, a choice specimen will attain the weight of fifteen pounds.''<ref>{{cite book
There are recounts of cat being consumed in France's Gallia Norbon region and Spain in the 17th century.<ref name=""Albala2003""/>
[[Indigenous Australians]] in the area of [[Alice Springs, Northern Territory#Wild Cat Stew Challenge
column2: Alice Springs]] roast feral cats on an open fire. They have also developed recipes for cat stew. Some other inhabitants of the area have also taken up this custom, justified on the grounds that felines are ""a serious threat to Australia's native [[fauna]]"". Scientists warned that eating wild cats could expose humans to harmful [[bacteria]] and [[toxins]].<ref>{{Cite news
column5: title= Australians cook up wild cat stew

column1: Cat is not a regular menu item in [[Peru]], but is used in such dishes as [[fricassee]] and stews most abundant in two specific sites in the country: the southern town of [[Chincha Alta]] ([[Ica Region]], [[Afro-Peruvian]] mostly) and the north-central [[Andean]] town of [[Huari, Peru
column2: Huari]] ([[Ancash Region]]). Primarily used by [[Afro-Peruvian]]s. Cat cooking techniques are demonstrated every September during the festival of [[Ephigenia
column3: Saint Efigenia]] in a town of La Quebrada.<ref name=""FEATURE - 'Cat-eaters' take note - feline feast at Peru festival"">{{cite web
column6: title='Cat-eaters' take note - feline feast at Peru festival

column1: In October 2013, a judge banned the annual El Festival Gastronomico del Gato (the Gastronomic Festival of the Cat), which was held every September in La Quebrada to commemorate the arrival of settlers who were forced to eat cats to survive, citing it as cruel to the 100+ cats specifically bred for the event, which involves being kept in cages for a year prior the Festival. The judge also cited concerns over the safety of the meat, which drew criticism from residents who contend that cat meat is far richer than rabbit or duck, and that it has been long consumed globally without any deleterious effects.<ref>Golgowksi, Nina (October 15, 2013). [http://www.nydailynews.com/news/world/judge-bans-peruvian-town-annual-cat-eating-festival-article-1.1486233 ""Judge bans Peruvian town's annual cat-eating festival""]. ''[[Daily News (New York)

That same month, magistrate Maria Luyo banned the festival of Curruñao in the small town of San Luis. Locals say that the festival, which sees cats being drowned, skinned and tied to fireworks and blown up, dates back to the practice of eating cat on the part of African slaves who worked on sugar-cane plantations in colonial times, and is part of the religious celebrations of [[Santa Efigenia]], an African-Peruvian folk saint. Luyo stated in her ruling that the festival ""fomented violence based on cruel acts against animals which caused grave social damage and damaged public health"", and that minors could be ""psychologically damaged"" by watching the events.<ref>Collyns, Dan (October 18, 2013). [https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/oct/18/peru-judge-suspends-cat-race-feast ""Claws out as Peruvian judge suspends annual cat race and feast""]. ''[[The Guardian]]''.</ref>

In a 1996, report some citizens in a [[shanty town]] in [[Rosario, Santa Fe]], [[Argentina]], stated that, during an economic crisis, they had to feed the neighborhood children with cat's meat, and commenting, ""It's not denigrating to eat cat, it keeps a child's stomach full"". The validity of this report has been questioned, however.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Nunca se comieron gatos en Rosario

column2: Jewish]] laws of [[kashrut]] and [[Islam]]ic [[Islamic dietary laws
column3: dietary laws]] both [[taboo food and drink
column4: forbid]] the consumption of cat meat.<ref>{{hadith-usc
column8: 4752}}</ref> Kashrut disallows the consumption of any terrestrial predators. To be considered kosher in the case of mammals, it must not be a predator and it must both chew cud and have [[cloven hooves]].{{cite needed

column1: In the American science fiction sitcom ''[[ALF (TV series)
column2: ALF]]'', cat is considered a delicacy on the protagonist's home planet, Melmac, and was sometimes garnished with [[plum sauce]].<ref name=""Interesting Questions, Facts, and Information"">{{cite web

column1: In the opening scene of the 2010 American post-apocalyptic action film
''[[The Book of Eli]]'', the main character is seen hunting a hairless cat in the woods.<ref name=""The Book of Eli Reviews"">{{cite web

column1: '''Crumbs and Whiskers''' is a [[small business]] which operates [[cat café]]s, or [[coffeehouse]]s that feature [[cats]] as an attraction, in {{nowrap
column2: [[Washington, D.C.]]}} and [[Los Angeles]], California. Crumbs and Whiskers opened its first cat café in Washington on June 20, 2015; this was the first cat café to open in the [[Washington metropolitan area]].{{refn
column5: title=Meet the woman who left her consulting job to open D.C.’s first cat cafe
column11: title=Not-yet-open D.C. cat cafe raises serious money in 1 day
column17: title=So, how would a cafe crawling with adorable kittens pass a D.C. health inspection?
column23: title=D.C.’s Cat Cafe, Crumbs and Whiskers, Makes Strides Toward Opening This Year
column29: title=Founder shares plans for D.C.’s first cat café, Crumbs and Whiskers
column36: name=""Notability""}} The Washington D.C. café is partnered with the local chapter of the [[The Humane Society of the United States
column37: Humane Society]] in order to provide a boarding space for around 15–25 cats at a time.<ref name=""ABC7"">{{cite web
column39: title=Cat cafe pounces forward in D.C.
column45: title=D.C.’s first cat cafe (yes, a cafe with cats) opens this month
column49: date=June 9, 2015}}</ref> Through the partnership arrangement, the Humane Society provides vaccinated and vetted cats to Crumbs and Whiskers, which functions as a foster home for the cats until they are adopted.<ref name=""ABC7"" /><ref name=""Crumbs location"">{{cite web
column56: quote=On Tuesday morning, a zoning hearing approved to operate Crumbs & Whiskers – a café that specializes in cats.  Kanchan Singh said this means a blue building on the corner of Wisconsin and O St NW will officially become the location of her café.}}</ref>

column1: The Los Angeles café opened on September 30, 2016, and was the first cat café to open in the [[Los Angeles metropolitan area]].<ref name=""Epoch Times"" /><ref name=""NBC LA"">{{cite web
column3: title=Cats Looking for Furever Homes at LA's First Cat Cafe
column9: title=Everything you need to know about LA’s first cat cafe Crumbs & Whiskers
column13: date=September 23, 2016}}</ref> The Los Angeles café is partnered with Karma Rescue, a Los Angeles-based [[animal shelter]] which provides cats for the café.<ref name=""Epoch Times"" /><ref name=""NBC LA"" /><ref name=""LA Daily News"" /> Similar to the Washington D.C. café, the Los Angeles café offers boarding space for the cats until they are adopted.<ref name=""Epoch Times"" /><ref name=""NBC LA"" /><ref name=""LA Daily News"" />

column1: Crumbs and Whiskers uses an online reservation system for scheduling visits and charges a fixed hourly fee.<ref name=""WashPost June 9th"">{{cite web
column3: title=DC’s first cat cafe to open in Georgetown June 20
column7: date=June 9, 2015}}</ref><ref name=""WashPost 1"" /><ref name=""Eagle"" /> For safety reasons, children under 13 are not allowed, and young adults between the ages of 13 and 17 must have a form signed by an adult. Crumbs and Whiskers allows customers to begin the application process for adopting one of the cats on site at their cafés.<ref name=""Eagle"">{{cite web
column9: title=Crumbs and Whiskers: D.C.’s first cat cafe.
column14: quote=Customers who decided to purchase any of the cats will start the application process at the cafe.}}</ref>

column1: The business founder, Kanchan Singh, opted to finance the venture by [[crowdfunding]] through a [[Kickstarter]] project with a {{currency
column2: 15,000}} target, an amount which she was initially uncertain that she could raise.<ref name=""WashPost 1"" />  The Crumbs and Whiskers Kickstarter project reached its funding target less than a day after it launched, and doubled this amount prior to the project deadline.<ref name=""ABC7"" /><ref name=""Crumbs location"" /> The campaign ended with 705 backers and raised a total of $35,881 for the café.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Crumbs & Whiskers: Washington DC's Cat Cafe

column2: Эрмитажные коты}}) are a group of [[cats]] residing in the [[Hermitage Museum]] in [[Saint Petersburg]], Russia. The museum has a press secretary dedicated to the cats,<ref name=BBCRodgers>Rodgers, James. ""[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/7029370.stm Hermitage palace is cat's whiskers]"" ([http://www.webcitation.org/6ZiAtzyTB Archive]). [[BBC]]. Friday 5 October 2007. Retrieved on 2 July 2015.</ref> and three people act as caretakers.<ref name=Cole>Cole, Teresa Levonian. ""[http://www.telegraph.co.uk/travel/destinations/europe/russia/10075304/St-Petersburg-the-cats-of-the-Hermitage.html St Petersburg: the cats of the Hermitage]"" ([http://www.webcitation.org/6ZiITTFVE Archive]). ''[[The Daily Telegraph
column3: The Telegraph]]''. 23 May 2013. Retrieved on 2 July 2015.</ref> The cats live in the museum's basement, and they also appear on the embankment and on the square during the summer. In previous eras they roamed throughout the museum galleries.<ref name=Natgeo>""[http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2009/06/090612-cats-video-ap.html Cat ""Army"" Guards Treasures]"" ([http://www.webcitation.org/6ZiDyoCnW Archive]). ''[[National Geographic Channel
column4: National Geographic]]''. June 12, 2009. Retrieved on July 2, 2015.</ref>

column1: In 2010 Maria Khaltunen (also ""Khaltunin"" or ""Haltunen"")<!--The ""Khaltunin"" spelling is from ABC News, ""Haltunen"" is from ''The New Yorker''-->, who directs the museum's cat programme, stated that there were 60 cats on the museum grounds, even though the staff has a joke that officially the museum is only supposed to have 50 cats.<ref name=Marquardt>Marquardt, Alexander. ""[http://abcnews.go.com/Travel/International/russias-hermitage-museum-home-artistic-masters-cats/story?id=11218561 St. Petersburg's Hermitage Museum Home to Masters...and Cats]"" ([http://www.webcitation.org/6ZiE5oEZQ Archive]). ''[[ABC News]]''. July 30, 2010. Retrieved on July 2, 2015.</ref>

Irina Popovets, who became the head of the cat department, stated that the cats were ""as well-known as our collections.""<ref>""[http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/the-nine-lives-of-russias-hermitage-museum-cats.aspx?pageID=238&nID=91288&NewsCatID=378 The nine lives of Russia’s Hermitage Museum cats]."" ''[[Agence France-Presse]]'' at ''[[Hurriyet Daily News]]''. November 18, 2015. Retrieved on July 18, 2016.</ref>

In May 2013, the count had grown to 74 cats, of both sexes (but neutered), according to Haltunen.<ref name=Cole/>  There are kitchens for preparing their food (""they all have different preferences""), and even a small hospital.<ref name=Cole/>
As of 2013 donations, a €400-per-month payment from the charity Pro Animale, and the sponsorship of [[Royal Canin]] fund the presence of the cats.<ref name=Cole/>

The cats were present in the museum, originally a palace, since the 18th century;<ref name=BBCRodgers/> in 1745, [[Elizabeth of Russia]] ordered cats to be placed in the palace in order to control the mice.<ref name=McGrane>McGrane, Sally. ""[http://www.newyorker.com/culture/culture-desk/russias-museum-cats Russia’s Museum Cats]"" ([http://www.webcitation.org/6ZiGPBiwT Archive]). ''[[The New Yorker]]''. September 25, 2012. Retrieved on July 2, 2015.</ref> James Rodgers of the [[BBC]] stated that the belief is that the cats originated from [[Kazan]], a city known for having cats good at catching mice. The cats remained in St. Petersburg except during [[World War II]],<ref name=BBCRodgers/> when the existing cat population was killed. A new group of cats replaced the previous cats since the rat population had increased.<ref name=Marquardt/>
In the late 1990s,<!--About 15 years before 2012 is 1997--> Khaltunen began a programme to care for the cats, which previously lived in poor conditions.<ref name=McGrane/>
As of 2007 the museum began adopting cats needing homes.<ref name=BBCRodgers/>
In 2011, the museum began a ""Catfest"", a celebration of its cat population. ""Catfest"" has included cat painting contests and scavenger hunts for children.<ref name=McGrane/>

Beginning in 2015, because of the number of visiting tourists, a website has been set up by the museum for people who may be interested in adopting a cat. “It is an honor to adopt a Hermitage cat,” one potential cat owner was told.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Russia’s Hermitage Museum Is Filled With Cats

column1: Other cats kept to deter mice in public buildings include:

column2: Chief Mouser to the Cabinet Office, United Kingdom]]

column1: * [[Tibs the Great]] kept by the Royal Mail in the UK.
