column4: Therapy cats have cuddled with many hospitals patients, offering comfort and companionship]]

column1: A '''therapy cat''' is a cat trained to help ailing humans in a medically beneficial way to take advantage of the human-animal interaction for purposes of relaxation and healing. A therapy cat provides affection and comfort to people in retirement homes, nursing homes, schools, hospices, and other human service care facilities.

Therapy cats come in all sizes and breeds. The most important characteristic of a therapy cat is its temperament. A good therapy cat must be friendly, patient, confident, gentle, and at ease in all situations. Therapy cats must enjoy human contact and be content to be petted and handled, sometimes clumsily. Cats must demonstrate that loud noises and barking dogs do not bother them.

A therapy cat's primary job is to allow unfamiliar people to make physical contact with it and to enjoy that contact. Children in particular enjoy hugging animals; adults usually enjoy simply petting the cat. The cat might need to be lifted onto, or climb onto, an individual's lap or bed and sit or lie comfortably there. In hospice environments, therapy cats can play a role in palliative care by reducing death anxiety.
Therapy cats have been used as companions to help the recovery and well-being of stroke victims,<ref name=twsN515>{{cite news
column3: title= Pet Tales: Paralyzed therapy cat inspires patients
column9: title= Pet therapy for humans who need it most
column15: title= Even hairless Sphynx cats give patients a warm, fuzzy feeling
column19: accessdate= 2012-01-14}}</ref> decrease patient [[anxiety]],<ref name=twsN6567/><ref name=twsN611/> increase sensory stimulation,<ref name=twsN6567/> ward off depression,<ref name=twsN611/> inspire a ""sense of purpose"",<ref name=twsN6567/> and assist teens at juvenile detention centers<ref name=twsN613/><ref name=twsN612>{{cite news
column21: title= Jersey City dance school mourns loss of therapy cat
column25: accessdate= 2012-01-14}}</ref> and children with developmental disabilities<ref name=twsN613>{{cite news
column27: title= Missing NY therapy cat found
column31: accessdate= 2012-01-14}}</ref><ref name=twsN612/> and to help children with language, speech and hearing problems.<ref name=twsNre4e>{{cite news
column33: title= Countywide : Show Cats Just Purrfect for Therapy
column37: accessdate= 2012-01-14}}</ref> Some [[nursing homes]] have therapy cats that are used as companions to their [[elderly]] residents. Therapy cats are also sometimes used in hospitals to relax children who are staying there.<ref>{{cite web
column40: title=The Special Love of Therapy Cats : Feline Relationships : Your Cat's Mind
column43: accessdate=2011-09-20}}</ref> There have been arguments made that therapy animals can work as well as or better than conventional [[pharmaceutical]] medicine for helping people relax,{{Citation needed
column44: date=September 2011}} lowering stress levels and blood pressure decreases,<ref name=twsN611/> causing the heart rate to slow down.{{Citation needed
column45: date=September 2011}} According to one report, the cats can help children and teens with special needs to ""feel relaxed"", and that the human-cat communication is beneficial.<ref name=twsN612/> One researcher reviewing 25 studies found positive effects of pets on patients in [[nursing home]]s, and found evidence that the animals helped patients be more alert, smile more often, and that the presence of the pets helped physically aggressive patients to calm down and allow other humans to be near them.<ref name=twsN6567/>

column1: * [https://www.animallaw.info/topic/table-state-assistance-animal-laws Assistance Animal State Laws] - Michigan State University
* [https://www.tsa.gov/travel/special-procedures Disabilities and Medical Conditions] - TSA (Transport Security Administration)
49538597,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cat_predation_on_wildlife,"[[Cat]]s hunt small prey, and both [[feral cat
column3: domesticated]] cats prey on wildlife. This is sometimes seen as a desirable phenomenon, such as in the case of [[barn cat]]s and other cats kept for the purposes of pest control. In other cases, the effect of cats on wildlife is met with concern.

column1: For thousands of years, cats have been known for their ability to hunt mice and rats and keep their populations under control. This ability is understood as the reason cats became domesticated.<ref name=""Temple Grandin"">Grandin, Temple and Johnson, Catherine (2009) ''Animals Make Us Human: Creating the Best Life for Animals'', Mariner Books, {{ISBN
column3: 68}} The relationship was more of convenience (or mutualistic) than dependence: ""Cats killed mice and rats, and humans provided lots of mice and rats to kill since mice and rats lived in human settlements.""<ref name=""Temple Grandin""/>{{rp
column4: 68}} A 2014 study examining 5,300 years of cat remains in an agricultural village of Quanhucun, [[China]], provides early evidence of this dynamic, where cats protected grain stores by eating rodents.<ref name=""Ancient cat bones"">{{cite news
column6: title=Ancient Chinese cat bones shake up domestication theory
column8: date=17 December 2013}}</ref><ref name=""Hu 2014 on Cat domestication"">

column3: title= Earliest evidence for commensal processes of cat domestication
column4: journal= Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences

column1: If they are well-fed, [[farm cat]]s are more dependable as effective ratters, as they are less likely to stray or hunt further afield.<ref name=""Tabor Wild Life"">Tabor, Roger (1983) ''The Wild Life of the Domestic Cat''. Arrow Books. {{ISBN
column3: 110}} Cats are wary of adult rats, given their size,<ref name=""Tabor Wild Life""/>{{rp
column4: 111}} but are particularly adept at hunting young rats.<ref name=""Tabor Wild Life""/>{{rp

column1: In 2002, feral cats introduced to a flower market in [[Los Angeles]], [[California]], were noted to have helped lower rat populations.<ref name=""Beverly Hills Rats"">{{cite news
column3: title=Up, Down, In and Out in Beverly Hills: Rats
column7: date=17 September 2002}}</ref> In [[Chicago]]'s 47th Ward, feral cats were introduced in 2012 to help the city deal with the rat problem there.<ref>[http://chicago.cbslocal.com/2012/06/28/north-sides-47th-ward-using-feral-cats-to-catch-rats/ ""North Side’s 47th Ward Using Feral Cats To Catch Rats""], CBS Chicago, 28 June 2012.</ref>

column1: Efforts to eradicate feral cats in [[Ventura, California]], were noted in 2002 to have resulted in increasing numbers of rats, which were being monitored for health problems such as [[bubonic plague]].<ref name=""Beverly Hills Rats""/><ref name=""LA rodents have field day"">{{cite news
column3: title=With the Cats Away, Beachfront Rodents Have a Field Day

column1: A 2013 study by Scott R. Loss and others of the [[Smithsonian Conservation Biology Institute]] and the [[United States Fish and Wildlife Service
column2: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service]] suggested that free-ranging domestic cats (mostly unowned) are the top human-caused threat to wildlife in the United States, killing an estimated 1.3 to 4 billion birds and 6.3 to 22.3 billion mammals annually.<ref name=""Loss 2013"">{{cite journal
column4: title=The impact of free-ranging domestic cats on wildlife of the United States
column18: title = Cats killing billions of animals in the US
column23: work = BBC News}}</ref> These figures were much higher than previous estimates for the U.S.<ref name=""Loss 2013""/>{{rp
column24: 2}} Unspecified species of birds native to the U.S. and mammals including [[mouse
column25: mice]], [[shrew]]s, [[vole]]s, [[squirrel]]s and [[rabbit]]s were considered most likely to be preyed upon by cats.<ref name=""Loss 2013""/>{{rp

column1: Perhaps the first U.S. study that pointed to predation by cats on wildlife as a concern was ornithologist [[Edward Howe Forbush]]'s 1916 report for the Massachusetts State Board of Agriculture, ''The Domestic Cat: Bird Killer, Mouser and Destroyer of Wildlife: Means of Utilizing and Controlling It''.<ref>Edward Howe Forbush, [https://archive.org/details/domesticcatbirdk00forbrich ""The Domestic Cat: Bird Killer, Mouser and Destroyer of Wildlife: Means of Utilizing and Controlling It""], Commonwealth of Massachusetts, State Board of Agriculture, Economic Biology Bulletin 42, 1916.</ref>

U.K. biologist and cat behaviour expert Roger Tabor states that ""studies from all around the world have found that cats catch relatively few birds compared to small mammals.""<ref name=""Tabor Cat Behavior"">Tabor, Roger (2003) ''Understanding Cat Behavior''. David & Charles Ltd. {{ISBN
column3: 135}} The [[Royal Society for the Protection of Birds]] states that there is no scientific evidence that cat predation ""is having any impact on bird populations UK-wide.""<ref name=""Are cats causing bird declines?"">

column1: [http://www.rspb.org.uk/advice/gardening/unwantedvisitors/cats/birddeclines.aspx ""Are cats causing bird declines?""] The Royal Society for the Protection of Birds, accessed 23 June 2014.</ref> Moreover, city cats have smaller ranges. In his research, Tabor found ""the average annual catch of the average London cat to be two items instead of the fourteen of a village cat.""<ref name=""Tabor Cat Behavior""/>{{rp
column2: 135}} Tabor comments about some of the challenges of stalking birds for cats: ""From the cat's point of view not only do birds not play fair by flying and having eyes that can see beyond the back of their heads, but they can positively cheat by using loud alarm calls and throw the cat's chances of catching any others.""<ref name=""Tabor Wild Life""/>{{rp

column1: Island settings pose particular challenges for wildlife. A 2001 study identified cats alone as responsible for the plight of some island bird species, such as the [[Townsend's shearwater]], [[socorro dove]], and the [[Marquesan ground dove]].<ref name=""Endangered birds"">

column10: page=400}} in ''Encyclopedia of Biodiversity''</ref><ref name=""Endangered birds""/>{{rp
column11: 400}} The same study identified the greatest cause of endangerment of birds as habitat loss and degradation, with at least 52% of endangered birds affected,<ref name=""Endangered birds""/>{{rp
column12: 399}} while [[introduced species]] on islands, such as domestic cats, [[rat]]s and [[Mustelidae
column14: 403}} affected only 6% of endangered birds.<ref name=""Endangered birds""/>{{rp
column15: 399}} Other studies caution that removing domestic cats from islands can have unintended consequences, as increasing rat populations can put native bird<ref>{{cite journal
column27: first3 = Z}}</ref> and mammal species<ref>{{cite journal
column33: title = Island mammal extinctions are determined by interactive effects of life history, island biogeography and mesopredator suppression
column41: title=Feral cats help some endangered mammals survive, report says

column1: Cats in Australia have been found to have European origins.<ref>{{Cite journal
column2: title = The Population Origins and Expansion of Feral Cats in Australia
column9: pages=104–114}}</ref>  This is important to note because of their effect on native species. Feral cats in Australia have been linked to the decline and extinction of various native animals. They have been shown to cause a significant impact on ground nesting birds and small native mammals.<ref name=""Dickman"">{{cite book
column12: title = Overview of the Impacts of Feral Cats on Australian Native Fauna
column13: publisher = The Director of National Parks and Wildlife – Australian Nature Conservation Agency – Institute of Wildlife Research

column1: Feral cats have also hampered any attempts to re-introduce threatened species back into areas where they have become extinct as the cats have hunted and killed the newly released animals.<ref>[http://www.environment.nsw.gov.au/pestsweeds/TheThreatOfFeralCats.htm The Threat Of FeralCats]. Environment.nsw.gov.au (28 October 2011). Retrieved on 5 May 2013.</ref> Numerous Australian environmentalists claim the feral cat has been an ecological disaster in Australia, inhabiting most ecosystems except dense [[rainforest]], and being implicated in the [[extinction]] of several [[marsupial]] and [[Placentalia
column3: title = Interactions between feral cats, foxes, native carnivores, and rabbits in Australia
column4: journal = CSIRO Sustainable Ecosystems / Arthur Rylah Institute for Environmental Research
column6: authors = Robley, A. Reddiex, B. Arthur T. Pech R. Forsyth, D.

column1: The fauna of [[New Zealand]] has evolved in isolation for millions of years without the presence of mammals (apart from a few bat species). Consequently, birds dominated the niches occupied by mammals and many became flightless. The introduction of mammals after settlement by [[Māori people
column2: Māori]] from about the 12th century had a huge effect on the indigenous [[biodiversity]]. [[Europe]]an explorers and settlers brought cats on their ships and the presence of feral cats were recorded from the latter decades of the 19th century.<ref>King, Carolyn (1984) ''Immigrant Killers''. Auckland: Oxford University Press. {{ISBN

column1: It is estimated that feral cats have been responsible for the extinction of six endemic bird species and over 70 localised subspecies as well as depleting bird and lizard species.<ref>{{Cite conference
column2: authors = Eason, Charles T.; Morgan, David R. and Clapperton, B. Kay
column3: title = Toxic bait and baiting strategies for feral cats
column4: publisher = Proceedings of the Fifteenth Vertebrate Pest Conference 1992

column2: U.K.]], The [[Royal Society for the Protection of Birds]] states that there is no scientific evidence that cat predation ""is having any impact on bird populations UK-wide. This also means there is no scientific evidence that cat predation is not having an impact of bird populations UK-wide. However the article goes on to say ""This may be surprising, but many millions of birds die naturally every year, mainly through starvation, disease, or other forms of predation. There is evidence that cats tend to take weak or sickly birds"".

column1: ... Those bird species that have undergone the most serious population declines in the UK (such as [[Alauda
column3: tree sparrows]] and [[corn bunting]]s) rarely encounter cats, so cats cannot be causing their declines. Research shows that these declines are usually caused by habitat change or loss, particularly on farmland.""<ref name=""Are cats causing bird declines?""/> This evidence is despite the common practice in the U.K. of allowing owned cats access to the outdoors,<ref>""In the UK, the vast majority of pet cats have free access to the outside world, or are at least allowed to go outside unsupervised for large parts of the day."" [http://www.pets4homes.co.uk/pet-advice/a-world-of-difference-how-cat-ownership-in-america-differs-to-the-uk.html ""A world of difference – How cat ownership in America differs to the UK""], Pets4Homes, accessed 1 September 2014.</ref> which is recommended to prevent feline obesity (p. 138) and behavior problems and other health problems arising from confinement stress (p. 121).<ref name=""Tabor Cat Behavior""/>

column1: [[SongBird Survival]] considers that ""The prevailing line that “there is no scientific evidence that predation by cats is having any impact on bird populations in UK” is simply no longer tenable."",<ref>https://www.songbird-survival.org.uk/cats.html</ref> noting ""No study has ever examined the impact of cats on songbirds at the population level; Evidence shows that the recovering sparrowhawk population in the 1970-80s resulted in the decline of some songbird populations; Cats kill around 3 times as many songbirds as sparrowhawks; The mere presence of cats near birds’ nests was found to decrease provision of food by a third while the resultant mobbing clamour from parent birds led in turn to increased nest predation by crows and magpies; [and that] It is therefore far more likely that cats have an even greater impact on songbird populations than sparrowhawks""

[[Sir David Attenborough]] in his Christmas Day edition of [[BBC Radio 4]] programme Tweet Of The Day said """"Cats kill an extraordinarily high number of birds in British gardens,"".<ref>https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2013/dec/10/cats-killing-birds-gardens-david-attenborough</ref> Asked whether cat owners should buy bell collars for their pets at Christmas, he replied: ""That would be good for the robins, yes.""

column4: [[Lyall's wren]] became extinct within two years of the introduction of cats to [[Stephens Island, New Zealand

column2: ecologically naive]] animal species. That is, animals that do not have predator responses for dealing with predators such as cats.<ref name=""Moors"">Moors, P.J.; Atkinson, I.A.E. (1984). ""Predation on seabirds by introduced animals, and factors affecting its severity"" in ''Status and Conservation of the World's Seabirds''. Cambridge: ICBP. {{ISBN
column4: introduced]] to such islands have had a devastating impact on these islands' [[biodiversity]].<ref name=""NYT""/>

column1: They have been implicated in the extinction of several species and local extinctions, such as the [[hutia]]s from the [[Caribbean]], the [[Guadalupe storm petrel]] from the [[Pacific Ocean
column2: Pacific]] coast of [[Mexico]], and [[Lyall's wren]]. In a statistical study, they were a significant cause for the extinction of 40% of the species studied.<ref name=""NYT"">{{cite news
column5: title=Kill the Cat That Kills the Bird?
column8: date=2 December 2007}}</ref> Moors and Atkinson wrote, in 1984, ""No other alien predator has had such a universally damaging effect.""<ref name=""Moors""/>

column1: Feral cats, along with rabbits, some sea birds, and [[sheep]], form the entire large animal population of the remote [[Kerguelen Islands]] in the southern [[Indian Ocean]]. Although exotic mammals form the bulk of their diet, cats' impact on seabirds is very important.<ref name=""Kerguelen"">{{cite journal
column3: title=The diet of feral cats (''Felis catus'' L.) at ﬁve sites on the Grande Terre, Kerguelen archipelago
column4: author=Pontier, D., L. Say, F. Debias, J. Bried, J. Thioulouse, T. Micol & E. Natoli

column1: Because of the damage cats cause in islands and some ecosystems, many conservationists working in the field of [[island restoration]] have worked to remove feral cats. (Island restoration involves the removal of introduced species and reintroducing native species.) As of 2004, 48 islands have had their feral cat populations eradicated, including [[New Zealand]]'s network of offshore island bird reserves<ref>{{cite journal
column3: title=A review of feral cat eradication on islands

column1: Larger projects have also been undertaken, including their complete removal from [[Ascension Island]]. The cats, introduced in the 19th century, caused a collapse in populations of nesting [[seabird]]s. The project to remove them from the island began in 2002, and the island was cleared of cats by 2004. Since then, seven species of seabird that had not nested on the island for 100 years have returned.<ref>[http://petsaspests.blogspot.com/search?q=ascension Cat eradication from Ascension Island]. Petsaspests.blogspot.com (2014-01-23). Retrieved on 2015-11-01.</ref>

In some cases, the removal of cats had unintended consequences. An example is Macquarie Island, where the removal of cats caused an explosion in the number of rabbits, rats, and mice that harm native seabirds<ref>{{cite news
column4: title=Up against rats, rabbits and costs
column5: date=12 April 2007}}</ref><ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20060720104709/http://www.abc.net.au/news/newsitems/200607/s1687413.htm Fears for sub-antarctic island plagued by rabbits]. ABC News (15 July 2006).</ref><ref>Draper, Michelle and La Canna, Xavier (14 January 2009) [https://web.archive.org/web/20110706111235/http://news.ninemsn.com.au/article.aspx?id=718505 Cat kill devastates Macquarie Island]. Nine News</ref> even if the eradication was positioned within an integrated pest management framework.<ref>[http://petsaspests.blogspot.com.es/2013/05/controversy-on-cats-eradication-on.html Controversy on feral cat removal on Macquarie Island]. Petsaspests.blogspot.com.es (2013-05-14). Retrieved on 2015-11-01.</ref> The removal of the rats and rabbits was scheduled for 2007 and it could take up to seven years and cost $24 million.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20070812004625/http://www.parks.tas.gov.au/macquarie/rabbitsfaq.html Macquarie Island World Heritage Area. Plan for the Eradication of Rabbits and Rodents on Macquarie Island]. Parks and Wildlife Service, Tasmania. parks.tas.gov.au</ref>

column1: '''List of cat documentaries, television series and cartoons''' includes ''serious'' [[documentaries]], [[Television_program#series
# Cats: Caressing the Tiger. (2014). [[National Geographic Society
# CATS - Choosing, Caring and Training. (2008). [[Revolution LLC]].
