column4: reason=MessyBeast isn't ""known unreliable"", but try to find something more reliable than a blog, such as a professionally edited and published book or magazine from a reputable publisher.}}</ref> The world record for the largest cat is {{convert

column2: date=December 2011}}</ref> The smallest adult cat ever officially recorded weighed around {{convert
column7: sigfig=1}}.<ref name=""World Records"" /> Feral cats tend to be lighter as they have more limited access to food than house cats. In the [[Boston]] area, the average feral adult male will weigh {{convert
column19: title=Feline Veterinary care by The Boston Cat Hospital/Feline Fast Cats
column33: abbr=on}} in head/body length (males being larger than females), with tails averaging {{convert
column38: abbr=on}} in length.<ref name=""Animal Bytes"">{{cite web

column1: Cats have seven [[cervical vertebrae]], as do almost all [[mammals]]; 13 [[thoracic vertebrae]] (humans have 12); seven [[lumbar vertebrae]] (humans have five); three [[sacrum
column2: sacral vertebrae]] like most mammals (humans have five); and a variable number of [[caudal vertebrae]] in the tail (humans retain three to five caudal vertebrae, fused into an internal [[coccyx]]).<ref name=""Walker"">{{Cite book
title=Study of the Cat with Reference to Human Beings
11}} The extra lumbar and thoracic vertebrae account for the cat's spinal mobility and flexibility. Attached to the spine are 13 ribs, the shoulder, and the [[pelvis]].<ref name=""Walker"" /> {{rp
column3: 16}} Unlike human arms, cat forelimbs are attached to the shoulder by free-floating [[clavicle]] bones which allow them to pass their body through any space into which they can fit their head.<ref name=""Gillis 2002"">{{cite web

column2: work=Zoolab: A Website for Animal Biology

column1: The cat skull is unusual among mammals in having very large [[eye socket]]s and a powerful and specialized jaw.<ref name=""Case"">*{{Cite book

column2: title=The Cat: Its Behavior, Nutrition, and Health
35}} Within the jaw, cats have teeth adapted for killing prey and tearing meat. When it overpowers its prey, a cat delivers a lethal neck bite with its two long [[Canine tooth
column3: canine teeth]], inserting them between two of the prey's vertebrae and severing its [[spinal cord]], causing irreversible [[paralysis]] and death.<ref name=""Smith1992"">{{Cite book

column2: title=Structure, Function and Evolution of teeth

column1: }}</ref> Compared to other felines, domestic cats have narrowly spaced canine teeth, which is an adaptation to their preferred prey of small rodents, which have small vertebrae.<ref name=""Smith1992"" /> The [[premolar]] and first [[Molar (tooth)
column2: molar]] together compose the [[carnassial]] pair on each side of the mouth, which efficiently shears meat into small pieces, like a pair of scissors. These are vital in feeding, since cats' small [[molar (tooth)
column3: molars]] cannot chew food effectively, and cats are largely incapable of mastication.<ref name=""Case"" />{{rp
column4: 37}}  Though cats tend to have better teeth than most humans, with decay generally less likely because of a thicker protective layer of enamel, a less damaging saliva, less retention of food particles between teeth, and a diet mostly devoid of sugar, they are nonetheless subject to occasional tooth loss and infection.<ref name=""Carr1978"">{{cite book
column6: title=The New Basic Book of the Cat

column1: Cats, like dogs, are [[digitigrade]]s. They walk directly on their toes, with the bones of their feet making up the lower part of the visible leg.<ref name=""Lacquaniti 1999"">{{Cite journal
}}</ref> Cats are capable of walking very precisely because, like all [[Felinae
column2: felines]], they directly register; that is, they place each hind paw (almost) directly in the print of the corresponding fore paw, minimizing noise and visible tracks. This also provides sure footing for their hind paws when they navigate rough terrain. Unlike most mammals, when cats walk, they use a ""pacing"" [[gait]]; that is, they move the two legs on one side of the body before the legs on the other side. This trait is shared with [[camel]]s and [[giraffe]]s. As a walk speeds up into a trot, a cat's gait changes to be a ""diagonal"" gait, similar to that of most other mammals (and many other land animals, such as [[lizard]]s): the diagonally opposite hind and fore legs move simultaneously.<ref name=""Christensen 2004"">{{Cite book

column1: Like almost all members of the Felidae, cats have protractable and retractable [[claw]]s.<ref name=""Russell 2001"">{{Cite journal

column2: title=Claw Retraction and Protraction in the Carnivora: The Cheetah (Acinonyx Jubatus) as an Atypical Felid

column1: }}</ref> In their normal, relaxed position, the claws are sheathed with the skin and [[fur]] around the [[paw]]'s toe pads. This keeps the claws sharp by preventing wear from contact with the ground and allows the silent stalking of prey. The claws on the fore feet are typically sharper than those on the hind feet.<ref name=""Armes 1900"">{{Cite journal
}}</ref> Cats can voluntarily extend their claws on one or more paws. They may extend their claws in hunting or self-defense, climbing, [[kneading (cats)
column2: kneading]], or for extra traction on soft surfaces. Most cats have five claws on their front paws, and four on their rear paws.<ref name=""Danforth1947"">{{cite journal
column4: title=Heredity of polydactyly in the cat
column11: url=http://jhered.oxfordjournals.org/content/38/4/107.full.pdf}}</ref> The fifth front claw (the [[dewclaw]]) is [[proximal]] to the other claws. More proximally is a protrusion which appears to be a sixth ""finger"". This special feature of the front paws, on the inside of the wrists, is the carpal pad, also found on the paws of [[big cat]]s and dogs. It has no function in normal walking, but is thought to be an antiskidding device used while jumping. Some breeds of cats are prone to [[Polydactyl cat
column12: polydactyly]] (extra toes and claws).<ref name=""Danforth1947"" /> These are particularly common along the northeast coast of North America.<ref name=""Lettice 2008"">{{cite journal
column13: vauthors=Lettice LA, Hill AE, Devenney PS, Hill RE
column14: title=Point mutations in a distant sonic hedgehog cis-regulator generate a variable regulatory output responsible for preaxial polydactyly

column1: Cats are familiar and easily kept animals, and their physiology has been particularly well studied; it generally resembles those of other carnivorous mammals, but displays several unusual features probably attributable to cats' descent from desert-dwelling species.<ref name=""MacDonald"" /> For instance, cats are able to tolerate quite high temperatures: Humans generally start to feel uncomfortable when their skin temperature passes about {{convert
column5: abbr=on}}, but cats show no discomfort until their skin reaches around {{convert
column10: 46}} and can tolerate temperatures of up to {{convert
column14: abbr=on}} if they have access to water.<ref name=""SDCN"">{{Cite book

column4: title=Nutrient Requirements of Dogs and Cats

column2: title=The Merck/Merial Manual for Pet Health

column1: [[File:Cold nose, warm touch - Thermography of Cat.jpg
column4: Thermograph of various body parts of a cat]]

column1: Cats conserve heat by reducing the flow of blood to their skin and lose heat by evaporation through their mouths. Cats have minimal ability to sweat, with glands located primarily in their paw pads,<ref>{{cite web
column6: pant for heat relief]] only at very high temperatures<ref name=""Adams 1970"">{{Cite journal

column2: title=Temperature Regulation of the Unanesthetized Cat During Mild Cold and Severe Heat Stress

column1: }}</ref> (but may also pant when stressed). A cat's body temperature does not vary throughout the day; this is part of cats' general lack of [[circadian rhythm]]s and may reflect their tendency to be active both during the day and at night.<ref name=""CAN"">{{Cite book

column2: 1}} Cats' feces are comparatively dry and their urine is highly concentrated, both of which are adaptations to allow cats to retain as much water as possible.<ref name=""MacDonald"" /> Their kidneys are so efficient, they can survive on a diet consisting only of meat, with no additional water,<ref name=""Prentiss 1959"">{{Cite journal
title=Hydropenia in Cat and Dog: Ability of the Cat to Meet its Water Requirements Solely from a Diet of Fish or Meat

column1: }}</ref> and can even rehydrate by drinking [[seawater]].<ref name=""CAN"" />{{rp

column2: title=Potability of Sea Water with Special Reference to the Cat

column1: }}</ref> While domestic cats are able to swim, they are generally reluctant to enter water as it quickly leads to exhaustion.<ref name=""Fraser2012"">{{cite book
Cats are [[obligate carnivores]]: their [[physiology]] has evolved to efficiently process meat, and they have difficulty digesting plant matter.<ref name=""MacDonald"">{{Cite journal

column2: title=Nutrition of the domestic cat, a mammalian carnivore

column1: }}</ref> In contrast to [[omnivore]]s such as [[rat]]s, which only require about 4% protein in their diet, about 20% of a cat's diet must be protein.<ref name=""MacDonald"" /> Cats are unusually dependent on a constant supply of the [[amino acid]] [[arginine]], and a diet lacking arginine causes marked weight loss and can be rapidly fatal.<ref name=""Morris 1978"">{{Cite journal

column2: title=Arginine: An Essential Amino Acid for the Cat

column1: }}</ref> Another unusual feature is that the cat cannot produce [[taurine]], with taurine deficiency causing [[macular degeneration]], wherein the cat's retina slowly degenerates, causing irreversible blindness.<ref name=""MacDonald"" />

column2: gastrointestinal tract]] is adapted to meat eating, being much shorter than that of omnivores and having low levels of several of the [[digestive enzyme]]s needed to digest carbohydrates.<ref name=""Zoran"">{{Cite journal
column5: title=The Carnivore Connection to Nutrition in Cats
column6: journal=Journal of the American Veterinary Medical Association
column16: archivedate=26 May 2010 }}</ref> These traits severely limit the cat's ability to digest and use plant-derived nutrients, as well as certain [[fatty acid]]s.<ref name=""Zoran"" /> Despite the cat's meat-oriented physiology, several vegetarian or vegan cat foods have been marketed that are supplemented with [[chemical synthesis
column17: chemically synthesized]] taurine and other nutrients, in attempts to produce a complete diet. However, some of these products still fail to provide all the nutrients cats require,<ref name=""Gray 2004"">{{Cite journal

column2: title=Nutritional Adequacy of Two Vegan Diets for Cats
journal=Journal of the American Veterinary Medical Association

column1: }}</ref> and diets containing no animal products pose the risk of causing severe nutritional deficiencies.<ref name=""Zaghini"">{{Cite journal

column2: title=Nutritional Peculiarities and Diet Palatability in the Cat

column1: }}</ref> However, vets in the United States have expressed concern that many domestic cats are overfed.<ref name=""How Cats Clawed Their Way Into Our Hearts"">{{cite web
column6: title=How Cats Clawed Their Way Into Our Hearts

column1: Cats do eat [[grass]] occasionally. A proposed explanation is that cats use grass as a source of [[folic acid]]. Another proposed explanation is that it is used to supply [[dietary fiber]], helping the cat [[defecation
column2: defecate]] more easily and expel parasites and other harmful material through feces and [[vomit]].<ref name=""EatGrass"">{{cite web

column4: Reflection of camera flash from the [[tapetum lucidum]]]]

column1: Cats have excellent [[night vision]] and can see at only one-sixth the light level required for human vision.<ref name=""Case"" />{{rp
column2: 43}} This is partly the result of cat eyes having a [[tapetum lucidum]], which reflects any light that passes through the [[retina]] back into the eye, thereby increasing the eye's sensitivity to dim light.<ref name=""Olliver 2004"">{{Cite journal
title=Comparative Morphology of the Tapetum Lucidum (among Selected Species)

column1: }}</ref> Another adaptation to dim light is the large pupils of cats' eyes. Unlike some big cats, such as tigers, domestic cats have [[Pupil#In other animals
column2: slit pupils]].<ref name=""Malmstrom"" /> These slit pupils can focus bright light without [[chromatic aberration]], and are needed since the domestic cat's pupils are much larger, relative to their eyes, than the pupils of the big cats.<ref name=""Malmstrom"">{{Cite journal
column4: title=Pupil shapes and lens optics in the eyes of terrestrial vertebrates
column11: doi=10.1242/jeb.01959}}</ref> At low light levels a cat's pupils will expand to cover most of the exposed surface of its eyes.<ref name=""Hammond 1985"">{{Cite journal

column2: title=The relationship between feline pupil size and luminance

column1: }}</ref> However, domestic cats have rather poor [[color vision]] and (like most nonprimate mammals) have only two types of [[Cone cell
column2: cones]], optimized for sensitivity to blue and yellowish green; they have limited ability to distinguish between red and green.<ref name=""Loop 1978"">{{Cite journal
title=Cat Color Vision: The Effect of Stimulus Size

column1: }}</ref> A 1993 paper reported<!-- the paper didn't find anything, the researchers did --> a response to middle wavelengths from a system other than the [[Rod cell
column2: rods]] which might be due to a third type of cone. However, this appears to be an adaptation to low light levels rather than representing true [[Trichromacy
title=The Spectral Sensitivity of Dark- and Light-adapted Cat Retinal Ganglion Cells

column1: Cats have excellent hearing and can detect an extremely broad range of frequencies. They can hear higher-pitched sounds than either dogs or humans, detecting frequencies from 55 Hz to 79,000 Hz, a range of 10.5 octaves, while humans and dogs both have ranges of about 9 octaves.<ref name=""PMID15472899"">{{Cite journal

column2: title=Primate hearing from a mammalian perspective
journal=The Anatomical Record Part A: Discoveries in Molecular, Cellular, and Evolutionary Biology

column1: }}</ref> Cats can hear [[ultrasound]], which is important in hunting<ref name=""Sunquist"">{{Cite book
column10: isbn=0-226-77999-8}}</ref> because many species of rodents make ultrasonic calls.<ref name=""Blumberg 1992"">{{Cite journal

column2: title=Rodent ultrasonic short calls: locomotion, biomechanics, and communication

column1: }}</ref> However, they do not communicate using ultrasound like rodents do. Cats' hearing is also sensitive and among the best of any mammal,<ref name=""PMID15472899"" /> being most acute in the range of 500 Hz to 32 kHz.<ref>{{Cite journal

column2: title=Hearing range of the domestic cat

column1: }}</ref> This sensitivity is further enhanced by the cat's large movable outer ears (their [[Pinna (anatomy)
column2: pinnae]]), which both amplify sounds and help detect the direction of a noise.<ref name=""Sunquist"" />

column1: Cats have an acute sense of smell, due in part to their well-developed [[olfactory bulb]] and a large surface of [[olfactory mucosa]], about {{convert
column5: abbr=on}} in area, which is about twice that of humans<!-- impossible logic and only 1.7-fold less than the average dog. -->.<ref name=""Moulton 1967"">{{Cite journal

column2: title=A major urinary protein of the domestic cat regulates the production of felinine, a putative pheromone precursor

column1: }}</ref> which they use to communicate through [[urine spraying]] and marking with [[scent glands]].<ref name=""Sommerville"" /> Many cats also respond strongly to plants that contain [[nepetalactone]], especially [[catnip]], as they can detect that substance at less than one part per billion.<ref>{{Cite journal

column2: title=Catnip: Its uses and effects, past and present

column1: }}</ref>  About 70–80% of cats are affected by nepetalactone.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=How does catnip work its magic on cats?
column7: publisher=Scientific American }}</ref> This response is also produced by other plants, such as silver vine (''[[Actinidia polygama]]'') and the herb [[Valerian (herb)
column8: valerian]]; it may be caused by the smell of these plants mimicking a pheromone and stimulating cats' social or sexual behaviors.<ref name=""Tucker"">{{Cite journal

column1: Cats have relatively few taste buds compared to humans (470 or so versus more than 9,000 on the human tongue).<ref name=sch>{{cite web
column2: title=Do Cats Have a Sense of Taste?
column6: first=Christianne}}</ref> Domestic and wild cats share a gene mutation that keeps their sweet taste buds from binding to sugary molecules, leaving them with no ability to taste [[sweetness]].<ref>{{cite web
column14: archivedate=25 January 2013 }}</ref> Their [[taste bud]]s instead respond to amino acids, bitter tastes, and acids.<ref name=""Bradshaw2006"">{{Cite journal

column2: title=The Evolutionary Basis for the Feeding Behavior of Domestic Dogs (Canis familiaris) and Cats (Felis catus)

column1: }}</ref>  Cats and many other animals have a [[Jacobson's organ]] located in their mouths that allows them to taste-smell certain aromas in a way of which humans have no experience. Cats also have a distinct temperature preference for their food, preferring food with a temperature around {{convert
column4: abbr=on}} which is similar to that of a fresh kill and routinely rejecting food presented cold or refrigerated (which would signal to the cat that the ""prey"" item is long dead and therefore possibly toxic or decomposing).<ref name=sch/>
The whiskers of a cat are highly sensitive to touch.]]

column1: To aid with navigation and sensation, cats have dozens of movable [[vibrissa
column2: whiskers (vibrissae)]] over their body, especially their faces. These provide information on the width of gaps and on the location of objects in the dark, both by touching objects directly and by sensing air currents; they also trigger protective [[blink reflex]]es to protect the eyes from damage.<ref name=""Case"" />{{rp

column1: Most breeds of cat have a noted fondness for settling in high places, or perching. In the wild, a higher place may serve as a concealed site from which to hunt; domestic cats may strike prey by pouncing from a perch such as a tree branch, as does a [[leopard]].<ref name=""Nash FS"">{{cite web

column2: title=Why Do Cats Like High Places?

column1: }}</ref> Another possible explanation is that height gives the cat a better observation point, allowing it to survey its territory. During a fall from a high place, a cat can reflexively twist its body and right itself using its acute [[equilibrioception
column2: sense of balance]] and flexibility.<ref name=""falling"">{{cite web

column1: }}</ref> This is known as the [[cat righting reflex]]. An individual cat always rights itself in the same way, provided it has the time to do so, during a fall. The height required for this to occur is around {{convert
column6: Manx cats]]) also have this ability, since a cat mostly moves its hind legs and relies on conservation of [[angular momentum]] to set up for landing, and the tail is little used for this feat.<ref name=""Nguyen 1998"">{{cite web

column2: title=How Does a Cat Always Land on Its Feet?
publisher=Georgia Institute of Technology, School of Medical Engineering

column1: The average lifespan of pet cats has risen in recent years. In the early 1980s, it was about seven years,<ref name=""Kraft 1998""/>{{rp
column2: 33}}<ref name=""Nassar 1984""/> rising to 9.4 years in 1995<ref name=""Kraft 1998""/>{{rp
column5: title=What Is the Life Span of the Common Cat?

column1: However, cats have been reported as surviving into their 30s,<ref name=""30yo"">Example: {{cite web

column2: title=Me-wow! Texas Woman Says Cat is 30 Years Old – Although She Can't Hear or See Very Well, Caterack the Cat Is Still Purring

column1: }}</ref> with the oldest known cat, [[Creme Puff (cat)
column2: Creme Puff]], dying at a verified age of 38.<ref name=""G2010"">{{cite book
quote=The oldest cat ever was Creme Puff, who [sic] was born on August 3, 1967 and lived until August 6, 2005 – 38 years and 3 days in total.

column1: Spaying or neutering increases life expectancy: one study found neutered male cats live twice as long as intact males, while spayed female cats live 62% longer than intact females.<ref name=""Kraft 1998""/>{{rp
column3: neutered]] confers health benefits, because castrated males cannot develop [[testicular cancer]], spayed females cannot develop [[Uterine cancer
column4: uterine]] or [[ovarian cancer]], and both have a reduced risk of [[Mammary tumor

column2: publisher=[[American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals]]

column1: Despite widespread concern about the welfare of free-roaming cats, the lifespans of neutered feral cats in managed colonies compare favorably with those of pet cats.<ref name=""Levy 2003""/>{{rp
column3: 1358}} <ref name=""Globe interview Parliament Hill Cat sanctuary closing""/><ref name=""Remfry 1996""/><ref name=""TNR Works Merrimack River""/><ref name=""TNR Works Washington DC""/>

column1: Cats can suffer from a wide range of health problems, including infectious diseases, parasites, injuries, and chronic disease. [[Feline vaccination
column2: Vaccinations]] are available for many of these diseases, and domestic cats are regularly given treatments to eliminate parasites such as worms and fleas.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Veterinary Care for Your New Cat

column1: In addition to obvious dangers such as [[rodenticide]]s, [[insecticide]]s, and [[herbicide]]s, cats may be poisoned by many chemicals usually considered safe by their human guardians,<ref name=""vetinfo"" /> because their livers are less effective at some forms of [[detoxification]] than those of many other animals, including humans and dogs.<ref name=""MacDonald"" /><ref name=""Williams 1978"">{{Cite journal

column2: title=Species Variations in the Pathways of Drug Metabolism

column1: }}</ref> Some of the most common causes of poisoning in cats are antifreeze and rodent baits.<ref name=""Rowland 1987"">{{Cite journal

column2: title=Incidence of Ethylene Glycol Intoxication in Dogs and Cats Seen at Colorado State University Veterinary Teaching Hospital

column1: }}</ref> Cats may be particularly sensitive to environmental pollutants.<ref name=""vetinfo"" /><ref name=""Potera 2007"">{{Cite journal

column2: title=Chemical Exposures: Cats as Sentinel Species

column1: }}</ref> When a cat has a sudden or prolonged serious illness without any obvious cause, it has possibly been exposed to a toxin.
Many human medicines should never be given to cats. For example, the painkiller [[paracetamol]] (or acetaminophen, sold as [[Tylenol (brand)
column3: Panadol]]) is extremely toxic to cats: even very small doses need immediate treatment and can be fatal.<ref name=""CanVetJ2003-Allen"">{{Cite journal

column2: title=The Diagnosis of Acetaminophen Toxicosis in a Cat
title=Ibuprofen, Aspirin and Acetaminophen Toxicosis and Treatment in Dogs and Cats

column1: }}</ref> Even [[aspirin]], which is sometimes used to treat [[arthritis]] in cats, is much more toxic to them than to humans<ref name=""VetHumToxicol1998-Villar"" /> and must be administered cautiously.<ref name=""vetinfo"" /> Similarly, application of [[minoxidil]] (Rogaine) to the skin of cats, either accidentally or by well-meaning guardians attempting to counter loss of fur, has sometimes been fatal.<ref name=""DeClementi 2004"">{{Cite journal

column2: title=Suspected Toxicosis after Topical Administration of Minoxidil in Two Cats
journal=Journal of Veterinary Emergency and Critical Care

column1: }}</ref> [[Essential oil]]s can be toxic to cats and cases have been reported of serious illnesses caused by [[tea tree oil]], including flea treatments and shampoos containing it.<ref name=""Bischoff 1998"">{{cite journal
column3: title=Australian tea tree (Melaleuca alternifolia) oil poisoning in three purebred cats

column1: Other common household substances that should be used with caution around cats include [[mothball]]s and other [[naphthalene]] products.<ref name=""vetinfo"">{{cite web

column2: date=December 2011}}</ref> [[Phenol]]-based products (e.g. [[Pine-Sol]], [[Dettol]]/Lysol or [[hexachlorophene]])<ref name=""vetinfo"" /> are often used for cleaning and disinfecting near cats' feeding areas or [[litter box]]es, but these can sometimes be fatal.<ref name=""Rousseaux 1986"">{{Cite journal
title=Acute Pine-Sol Toxicity in a Domestic Cat

column1: }}</ref> [[Ethylene glycol]], often used as an automotive [[antifreeze]], is particularly appealing to cats, and as little as a teaspoonful can be fatal.<ref name=""CFA antifreeze"">{{cite web
}}</ref> Some human foods are toxic to cats; for example chocolate can cause [[theobromine poisoning]], although (unlike dogs) few cats will eat chocolate.<ref name=""VT chocolate"">{{cite web
column9: archivedate=25 July 2011 }}</ref> Large amounts of onions or garlic are also poisonous to cats.<ref name=""vetinfo"" /> Many [[houseplant]]s are also dangerous,<ref name=""CFA plants"">{{cite web

column1: }}</ref> such as ''[[Philodendron]]'' species and the leaves of the Easter lily (''[[Lilium longiflorum]]''), which can cause permanent and life-threatening kidney damage.<ref name=""Langston 2002"">{{Cite journal

column2: title=Acute Renal Failure Caused by Lily Ingestion in Six Cats
journal=Journal of the American Veterinary Medical Association

column1: The domesticated cat and its closest wild ancestor are both [[diploid]] organisms that possess 38 [[chromosome]]s<ref name=""Nie 2002"">{{Cite journal

column2: title=The Genome Phylogeny of Domestic Cat, Red Panda and Five Mustelid Species Revealed by Comparative Chromosome Painting and G-banding
title=Initial Sequence and Comparative Analysis of the Cat Genome

column1: }}</ref> About 250 heritable [[genetic disorder]]s have been identified in cats, many similar to human [[Inborn error of metabolism
}}</ref> The high level of similarity among the [[metabolism]] of mammals allows many of these feline diseases to be diagnosed using [[Genetic testing
column2: genetic tests]] that were originally developed for use in humans, as well as the use of cats as [[animal model]]s in the study of the human diseases.<ref name=""Sewell 2007"">{{Cite journal
title=Inherited Metabolic Disease in Companion Animals: Searching for Nature's Mistakes
alt=A black-and-white cat on a fence

column1: Outdoor cats are active both day and night, although they tend to be slightly more active at night.<ref name=""Germain"">{{Cite journal

column2: title=Spatio-temporal Sharing between the European Wildcat, the Domestic Cat and their Hybrids
title=Home Range Size, Habitat Utilisation and Movement Patterns of Suburban and Farm Cats ''Felis catus''

column1: }}</ref> The timing of cats' activity is quite flexible and varied, which means house cats may be more [[crepuscular
column2: active in the morning and evening]], as a response to greater human activity at these times.<ref name=""Randall 1985"">{{Cite journal
title=Circadian rhythms in food intake and activity in domestic cats

column1: }}</ref> Although they spend the majority of their time in the vicinity of their home, housecats can range many hundreds of meters from this central point, and are known to establish [[Territory (animal)
column2: territories]] that vary considerably in size, in one study ranging from {{convert

column1: Cats conserve energy by sleeping more than most animals, especially as they grow older. The daily duration of sleep varies, usually between 12 and 16 hours, with 13 and 14 being the average. Some cats can sleep as much as 20 hours. The term ""[[wikt:cat nap
column2: cat nap]]"" for a short rest refers to the cat's tendency to fall asleep (lightly) for a brief period. While asleep, cats experience short periods of [[rapid eye movement sleep]] often accompanied by muscle twitches, which suggests they are [[dream]]ing.<ref name=""Jouvet 1979"">{{Cite journal
title=What Does a Cat Dream About?

column1: [[File:Listen, do you want to know a secret.jpg
Although wildcats are solitary, the social behavior of domestic cats is much more variable and ranges from widely dispersed individuals to [[Feral cat colony
column2: feral cat colonies]] that form around a food source, based on groups of co-operating females.<ref name=""Pontier 1996"">{{Cite journal
title=Male Reproductive Success in the Domestic Cat (''Felis catus'' L.): A Case History
title=Social Organization in the Cat: A Modern Understanding
column10: journal=Journal of Feline Medicine and Surgery
column20: archivedate=20 July 2011 }}</ref> Within such groups, one cat is usually dominant over the others.<ref name=""Baron"">{{Cite journal

column2: title=Patterns of Social Interaction in Cats (''Felis domestica'')

column1: }}</ref> Each cat in a colony holds a distinct territory, with sexually active males having the largest territories, which are about 10 times larger than those of female cats and may overlap with several females' territories.<ref name=""Sommerville"">{{Cite journal

}}</ref> These territories are marked by [[urine spraying]], by rubbing objects at head height with secretions from facial glands, and by defecation.<ref name=""Sommerville"" /> Between these territories are neutral areas where cats watch and greet one another without territorial conflicts. Outside these neutral areas, territory holders usually chase away stranger cats, at first by staring, hissing, and [[growling]], and if that does not work, by short but noisy and violent attacks. Despite some cats cohabiting in colonies, they do not have a social survival strategy, or a [[Herd behavior
column2: pack mentality]], and always hunt alone.<ref name=""Bradshaw"" />

column1: However, some pet cats are poorly socialized. In particular, older cats may show aggressiveness towards newly arrived kittens, which may include biting and scratching; this type of behavior is known as feline asocial aggression.<ref name=""Levine 2005"">{{Cite journal
column2: title=Intercat Aggression in Households Following the Introduction of a New Cat

column1: Though cats and dogs are [[Dog–cat relationship
column2: often characterized as natural enemies]], they can live together if correctly socialized.<ref>{{cite web

column1: Life in proximity to humans and other domestic animals has led to a symbiotic social adaptation in cats, and cats may express great affection toward humans or other animals. [[Ethology
column2: Ethologically]], the human keeper of a cat may function as a sort of surrogate for the cat's mother,<ref>{{cite book
column9: title=Encyclopedia of Applied Animal Behaviour and Welfare
column11: ISBN=978-0-85199-724-7}}</ref> and adult housecats live their lives in a kind of extended kittenhood,<ref name=""Animal Planet"">{{cite web

column2: title=The Cat Body: Adolescence and Sexual Maturity

column1: }}</ref> a form of behavioral [[neoteny]]. The high-pitched sounds housecats make to solicit food may mimic the cries of a hungry human infant, making them particularly hard for humans to ignore.<ref name=""McComb 2009"">{{Cite journal

column2: title=The Cry Embedded within the Purr

column4: grunting]], and several different forms of [[meow]]ing.<ref name=""Moelk"">{{Cite journal

column2: title=Vocalizing in the House-cat; A Phonetic and Functional Study

column1: }}</ref> (By contrast, feral cats are generally silent.)<ref name=""Jensen"">{{Cite book

column3: body language]], including position of ears and tail, relaxation of the whole body, and kneading of the paws, are all indicators of mood. The tail and ears are particularly important social signal mechanisms in cats;<ref name=""behaviourguide"" /><ref name=""Cafazzo"">{{Cite journal

column2: title=The Social Function of Tail Up in the Domestic Cat (''Felis silvestris catus'')

column1: }}</ref> for example, a raised tail acts as a friendly greeting, and flattened ears indicates hostility. Tail-raising also indicates the cat's position in the group's [[social hierarchy]], with dominant individuals raising their tails less often than subordinate animals.<ref name=""Cafazzo"" /> Nose-to-nose touching is also a common greeting and may be followed by [[social grooming]], which is solicited by one of the cats raising and tilting its head.<ref name=""Crowell-davis2004"" />
Purring may have developed as an evolutionary advantage as a signalling mechanism of reassurance between mother cats and [[Breastfeeding
column2: nursing]] kittens. Post-nursing cats often purr as a sign of contentment: when being petted, becoming relaxed,<ref name=BruelKjaer>{{cite web
column4: title=Solving The Cat's Purr Mystery using Accelerometers
column13: accessdate = 6 August 2008}}</ref> or eating. The mechanism by which cats purr is elusive. The cat has no unique anatomical feature that is clearly responsible for the sound.<ref name=""CPEM"">{{cite web
column15: title=Why and How Do Cats Purr?
column17: accessdate=10 April 2011}}</ref> It was, until recent times, believed that only the cats of the ''[[Felis]]'' [[genus]] could purr. However, felids of the ''[[Panthera]]'' genus ([[tiger]], [[lion]], [[jaguar]], and [[leopard]]) also produce sounds similar to purring, but only when exhaling.<ref>{{cite web

column4: papillae]] on a cat's tongue act like a [[hairbrush]] to help clean and detangle fur.]]

column3: A tabby housecat uses its brush-like tongue to groom itself, licking its fur to straighten it.]]

column1: Cats are known for spending considerable amounts of time licking their coat to keep it clean.<ref name=""hairballs"" /> The cat's [[tongue]] has backwards-facing spines about 500 [[micrometre
column2: μm]] long, which are called [[Filiform papilla
column3: papillae]]. These contain [[keratin]] which makes them rigid<ref name=""Boshel 1982"">{{Cite journal

column1: }}</ref> so the papillae act like a hairbrush. Some cats, particularly longhaired cats, occasionally regurgitate [[hairball]]s of fur that have collected in their stomachs from grooming. These clumps of fur are usually sausage-shaped and about {{convert
column7: abbr=on}} long. Hairballs can be prevented with remedies that ease elimination of the hair through the [[gut (anatomy)
column8: gut]], as well as regular grooming of the coat with a comb or stiff brush.<ref name=""hairballs"">{{cite web

column2: title=Everything You Need to Know About Hairballs

column1: Among domestic cats, males are more likely to fight than females.<ref name=""Lindell"">{{Cite journal

column2: title=Intercat Aggression: A Retrospective Study Examining Types of Aggression, Sexes of Fighting Pairs, and Effectiveness of Treatment

column1: }}</ref> Among feral cats, the most common reason for [[Catfight (animal behavior)
column2: cat fighting]] is competition between two males to mate with a female. In such cases, most fights are won by the heavier male.<ref name=""courtship"">{{cite journal
title=Mating Behaviors, Courtship Rank and Mating Success of Male Feral Cat (''Felis catus'')

column1: }}</ref> Another common reason for fighting in domestic cats is the difficulty of establishing territories within a small home.<ref name=""Lindell"" /> Female cats also fight over territory or to defend their kittens. Neutering will decrease or eliminate this behavior in many cases, suggesting that the behavior is linked to [[sex hormone]]s.<ref>{{cite journal
column3: title=Determining the Optimal age for Gonadectomy of Dogs and Cats
column8: journal= Journal of the American Veterinary Medical Association

column3: An arched back, raised fur, and an open-mouthed hiss can all be signs of aggression in a domestic cat.]]

column1: When cats become aggressive, they try to make themselves appear larger and more threatening by raising their fur, arching their backs, turning sideways and hissing or spitting.<ref name=""behaviourguide"">{{cite web

column2: accessdate=7 September 2012}}</ref> Often, the ears are pointed down and back to avoid damage to the inner ear and potentially listen for any changes behind them while focused forward. They may also vocalize loudly and bare their teeth in an effort to further intimidate their opponent. Fights usually consist of grappling and delivering powerful slaps to the face and body with the forepaws as well as bites. Cats also throw themselves to the ground in a defensive posture to rake their opponent's belly with their powerful hind legs.<ref name=""HSUS"">{{cite web
column7: publisher=The Humane Society of the United States

column1: Serious damage is rare, as the fights are usually short in duration, with the loser running away with little more than a few scratches to the face and ears. However, fights for mating rights are typically more severe and injuries may include deep puncture wounds and lacerations. Normally, serious injuries from fighting are limited to infections of scratches and bites, though these can occasionally kill cats if untreated. In addition, bites are probably the main route of transmission of [[feline immunodeficiency virus]].<ref name=""Pederson 1989"">{{Cite journal
}}</ref> Sexually active males are usually involved in many fights during their lives, and often have decidedly battered faces with obvious scars and cuts to their ears and nose.<ref>{{cite book
column2: title=Understanding and Training Your Cat or Kitten

column4: A cat that is playing with a caught mouse. Cats play with their prey to weaken or exhaust them before making a kill.]]

column1: Cats hunt small prey, primarily birds and rodents,<ref name=""Woods"" /> and are often used as a form of pest control.<ref>Clones, Cats, And Chemicals: Thinking Scientifically About Controversial Issues – Page 9, Irwin L. Slesnick – 2004</ref><ref>Pests of Crops in Warmer Climates and Their Control – Page 120, Dennis S. Hill – 2008</ref> Domestic cats are a major predator of wildlife in the United States, killing an estimated 1.4–3.7 billion birds and 6.9–20.7 billion mammals annually.<ref name=""NC012913"">{{cite journal
column8: title=The impact of free-ranging domestic cats on wildlife of the United States
column14: quote=We estimate that free-ranging domestic cats kill 1.4–3.7 billion birds and 6.9–20.7 billion mammals annually.
column17: title=That Cuddly Kitty Is Deadlier Than You Think
column22: author=Natalie Angier}}</ref> The bulk of predation in the United States is done by 80 million feral and stray cats. Effective measures to reduce this population are elusive, meeting opposition from cat enthusiasts.<ref name=""NC012913"" /><ref name=""NYT012913"" /> In the case of free-ranging pets, equipping cats with bells and not letting them out at night will reduce wildlife predation.<ref name=""Woods"" />

column1: Free-fed feral cats and house cats tend to consume many small meals in a single day, although the frequency and size of meals varies between individuals.<ref name=""Bradshaw"">{{Cite journal
column2: vauthors=Bradshaw JW, Goodwin D, Legrand-Defrétin V, Nott HM
column3: title=Food selection by the domestic cat, an obligate carnivore
column10: doi=10.1016/0300-9629(95)02133-7}}</ref> Cats use two hunting strategies, either stalking prey actively, or [[Ambush predator
column11: waiting in ambush]] until an animal comes close enough to be captured.<ref name=""How Cats Evolved to Win the Internet"">{{cite web
column14: title=How Cats Evolved to Win the Internet
column17: accessdate=13 November 2016}}</ref> Although it is not certain, the strategy used may depend on the prey species in the area, with cats waiting in ambush outside burrows, but tending to actively stalk birds.<ref name=""Turner 2000"">{{Cite book
column22: title=The Domestic Cat: The Biology of its Behaviour

column1: Perhaps the best known element of cats' hunting behavior, which is commonly misunderstood and often appalls cat owners because it looks like torture, is that cats often appear to ""play"" with prey by releasing it after capture. This behavior is due to an instinctive imperative to ensure that the prey is weak enough to be killed without endangering the cat.<ref>{{cite web
column2: title=Why do cats play with their food?
column5: accessdate=15 August 2011}}</ref> This behavior is referred to in the [[idiom]] ""cat-and-mouse game"" or simply ""[[cat and mouse]]"".

column1: Another poorly understood element of cat hunting behavior is the presentation of prey to human guardians. [[Ethology
column2: Ethologist]] Paul Leyhausen proposed that cats adopt humans into their social group and share excess kill with others in the group according to the [[dominance hierarchy]], in which humans are reacted to as if they are at, or near, the top.<ref name=""Leyhausen 1978"">{{Cite book
title=Cat Behavior: The Predatory and Social Behavior of Domestic and Wild Cats

column1: }}</ref> Anthropologist and zoologist [[Desmond Morris]], in his 1986 book ''Catwatching'', suggests, when cats bring home mice or birds, they are attempting to teach their human to hunt, or trying to help their human as if feeding ""an elderly cat, or an inept kitten"".<ref name=""Morris Catwatching 1"">{{Cite book

column2: title=Catwatching: Why Cats Purr and Everything Else You Ever Wanted to Know

column5: title=Why Do Cats Bring Home Dead Animals - Cats Dead Mice
column8: accessdate=2 September 2015}}</ref> Morris's hypothesis is inconsistent with the fact that male cats also bring home prey, despite males having negligible involvement with raising kittens.<ref name=""Turner 2000"" />{{rp
column9: 153}}<!--Need to add theory that it's a form of gift-giving to seek approval and attention, with sources for this.-->

column1: Domestic cats select food based on its temperature, smell and texture; they dislike chilled foods and respond most strongly to moist foods rich in amino acids, which are similar to meat.<ref name=""Zaghini"" /><ref name=""Bradshaw"" /> Cats may reject novel flavors (a response termed [[neophobia]]) and learn quickly to [[taste aversion
column2: avoid foods that have tasted unpleasant]] in the past.<ref name=""Bradshaw"" /> They may also avoid sugary foods and milk. Most adult cats are [[lactose intolerant]]; the sugars in milk are not easily digested and may cause soft stools or [[diarrhea]].<ref name=""Bradshaw"" /><ref name=""Kienzle 1994"">{{Cite journal
title=Blood Sugar Levels and Renal Sugar Excretion after the Intake of High Carbohydrate Diets in Cats

column1: }}</ref> They can also develop odd eating habits. Some cats like to eat or chew on other things, most commonly wool, but also plastic, cables, paper, string, aluminum foil, or even coal. This condition, [[pica (disorder)
column2: pica]], can threaten their health, depending on the amount and toxicity of the items eaten.<ref name=""Bradshaw 1997"">{{Cite journal
title=Factors affecting pica in the domestic cat
title=Pica: The Un-finicky Feline – Chewing or Eating Cords, Fabric, Houseplants, Etc.
publisher=University of California School of Veterinary Medicine

column1: Though cats usually prey on animals less than half their size, a feral cat in Australia has been photographed killing an adult [[pademelon]] of around the cat's weight at {{convert
column7: title=Scientists catch a feral cat killing a large mammal on camera 'for the first time'

column1: Since cats lack lips<ref name=""elsevier"">{{cite journal
column4: title=Acute and Chronic Faucitis of Domestic Cats: A Feline Calicivirus–Induced Disease
column12: doi=10.1016/s0195-5616(92)50131-0}}</ref> to create suction, they use a lapping method with the tongue to draw liquid upwards into their mouths. Lapping at a rate of four times a second, the cat touches the smooth tip of its tongue to the surface of the water, and quickly retracts it, drawing water upwards.<ref name=""Wade 2010"">{{Cite news

column2: title=For Cats, a Big Gulp With a Touch of the Tongue

column4: alt=Play fight between kittens, age 14 weeks
column5: Play fight between kittens, age 14 weeks]]

column1: Domestic cats, especially young kittens, are known for their love of play. This behavior mimics hunting and is important in helping kittens learn to [[predation
column2: stalk, capture, and kill]] prey.<ref name=""Poirier 1982"">{{Cite journal
title=Nonhuman Primate Learning: The Importance of Learning from an Evolutionary Perspective

column1: }}</ref> Cats also engage in play fighting, with each other and with humans. This behavior may be a way for cats to practice the skills needed for real combat, and might also reduce any fear they associate with launching attacks on other animals.<ref name=""Byers 1998"">{{Cite book

column2: title=Animal Play: Evolutionary, Comparative, and Ecological Perspectives
location=Cambridge, England<!--This is not redundant; there's a Cambridge, Massachusetts, also, with academic publishers.-->

column1: Owing to the close similarity between play and hunting, cats prefer to play with objects that resemble prey, such as small furry toys that move rapidly, but rapidly lose interest (they become [[habituation
column2: habituated]]) in a toy they have played with before.<ref name=""Hall 2002"">{{Cite journal
title=Object Play in Adult Domestic Cats: The Roles of Habituation and Disinhibition

column1: }}</ref> Cats also tend to play with toys more when they are hungry.<ref name=""Hall 1998"">{{Cite journal

column2: title=The Influence of Hunger on Object Play by Adult Domestic Cats

column1: }}</ref> String is often used as a toy, but if it is eaten, it can become caught at the base of the cat's tongue and then move into the [[intestine]]s, a medical emergency which can cause serious illness, even death.<ref name=""MacPhail 2002"">{{Cite journal

column2: journal=Clinical Techniques in Small Animal Practice

column1: }}</ref> Owing to the risks posed by cats eating string, it is sometimes replaced with a [[laser pointer]]'s dot, which cats may chase.<ref name=""Pocono 2006"">{{Cite news
column6: date=September 2012}}</ref> There are several important issues related to using a laser with a cat. Lasers can cause blindness in cats. Even lasers that are sold as ""eye safe""<ref name=""Lasers Ranking"">""[https://www.rli.com/resources/articles/classification.aspx Laser Standards and Classifications]""</ref> can actually be much higher powered than claimed, and can cause damage to cats' eyes.<ref name=""Amazon Illegal Pointers"">""[http://www.laserpointersafety.com/illegalpointers/illegalpointers.html A Review of illegal laser pointers on Amazon.com]""</ref> In addition, the cat thinks of the laser dot as prey, but gets frustrated when unable to catch it.<ref name=""Cat Laser"">""[http://www.catster.com/lifestyle/cat-behaior-cats-laser-pointers-good-toys Cats can get frustrated from lasers]""</ref>

column3: When cats mate, the tomcat (male) bites the scruff of the female's neck as she assumes a position conducive to [[mating]] known as [[lordosis behavior]].]]
Radiography of a pregnant cat (about one month and a half)]]

column1: Female cats are seasonally [[polyestrous]], which means they may have many periods of [[Estrus
column2: heat]] over the course of a year, the season beginning in spring and ending in late autumn. Heat periods occur about every two weeks and last about 4 to 7 days.<ref name=""compendium"" /> Multiple males will be attracted to a female in heat. The males will fight over her, and the victor wins the right to mate. At first, the female rejects the male, but eventually the female allows the male to mate. The female utters a loud yowl as the male pulls out of her because a male cat's penis has a band of about 120–150 backwards-pointing [[penile spines]], which are about 1 mm long; upon withdrawal of the penis, the spines rake the walls of the female's [[vagina]], which is a trigger for [[ovulation]]. This act also occurs to clear the vagina of other sperm in the context of a second (or more) mating, thus giving the later males a larger chance of conception.<ref name=""Aronson 1967"">{{Cite journal
title=Penile Spines of the Domestic Cat: Their Endocrine-behavior Relations

column1: After mating, the female washes her [[vulva]] thoroughly. If a male attempts to mate with her at this point, the female will attack him. After about 20 to 30 minutes, once the female is finished grooming, the cycle will repeat.<ref name=""compendium"" />
Because ovulation is not always triggered by a single mating, females may not be impregnated by the first male with which they mate.<ref name=""Wildt 1980"">{{Cite journal

column2: title=Effect of Copulatory Stimuli on Incidence of Ovulation and on Serum Luteinizing Hormone in the Cat

superfecund]]; that is, a female may mate with more than one male when she is in heat, with the result that different kittens in a litter may have different fathers.<ref name=""compendium"">{{cite web

column1: At 124 hours after conception, the morula forms. At 148 hours, early blastocysts form. At 10–12 days, implantation occurs.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=In Vivo Embryogenesis, Embryo Migration and Embryonic Mortality in the Domestic Cat

column1: The [[gestation]] period for cats is between 64 and 67 days, with an average of 66 days.<ref name=""Tsutsui 1993"">{{Cite journal

column2: title=Biology of Ovarian Cycles, Pregnancy and pseudopregnancy in the Domestic Cat

litter]] usually is three to five kittens, with the first litter usually smaller than subsequent litters. Kittens are weaned between six and seven weeks old, and cats normally reach sexual maturity at 5–10 months (females) and to 5–7 months (males), although this can vary depending on breed.<ref name=""compendium"" /> Females can have two to three litters per year, so may produce up to 150 kittens in their breeding span of around ten years.<ref name=""compendium"" />

column1: Cats are ready to go to new homes at about 12 weeks of age,<ref>{{Cite book
column2: title=The Complete Book of Cat Care: How to Raise a Happy and Healthy Cat
column7: others= translated from German by Elizabeth D. Crawford
column12: page=28}}</ref> when they are ready to leave their mother. They can be surgically [[neutering
column14: castrated]]) as early as 7 weeks to limit unwanted reproduction.<ref name=""Olson 2001"">{{Cite journal

column2: title=Early-age Neutering of Dogs and Cats in the United States (A Review)

column1: }}</ref> This surgery also prevents undesirable sex-related behavior, such as aggression, [[spraying (animal behavior)
column2: territory marking]] (spraying urine) in males and yowling (calling) in females. Traditionally, this surgery was performed at around six to nine months of age, but it is increasingly being performed prior to [[puberty]], at about three to six months.<ref name=""Root Kustritz 2007"">{{cite journal
column3: title=Determining the optimal age for gonadectomy of dogs and cats
column16: archivedate=13 July 2010 }}</ref> In the US, about 80% of household cats are neutered.<ref name=""Chu 2009"">{{Cite journal

column2: title=Population characteristics and neuter status of cats living in households in the United States
journal=Journal of the American Veterinary Medical Association

column1: Cats are a [[cosmopolitan species]] and are found across much of the world.<ref name=""Lipinski"" /> Geneticist Stephen James O'Brien, of the [[National Cancer Institute]] in [[Frederick, Maryland]], remarked on how successful cats have been in evolutionary terms: ""Cats are one of evolution's most charismatic creatures. They can live on the highest mountains and in the hottest deserts.""<ref>{{cite news
column4: title= From Lion to Moggie: How Cats Climbed their Family Tree
column8: url=}}</ref> They are extremely adaptable and are now present on all continents except [[Antarctica]], and on 118 of the 131 main groups of islands—even on isolated islands such as the [[Kerguelen Islands]].<ref name=""Say 2002"">{{Cite journal

column2: title=Spatio-temporal variation in cat population density in a sub-Antarctic environment
title=Biological Invasions in the Antarctic: Extent, Impacts and Implications

column1: Feral cats can live in forests, grasslands, tundra, coastal areas, agricultural land, scrublands, urban areas, and wetlands.<ref name=""ISSG 2006"">{{cite web

}}</ref> Their habitats even include small oceanic islands with no human inhabitants.<ref name=""Nogales"" />  Further, the close relatives of domestic cats, the [[African wildcat]] (''Felis silvestris lybica'') and the Arabian [[sand cat]] (''Felis margarita'') both inhabit desert environments,<ref name=""Driscoll"" /> and domestic cats still show similar adaptations and behaviors.<ref name=""MacDonald"" /> The cat's ability to thrive in almost any terrestrial habitat has led to its designation as one of the world's worst [[invasive species]].<ref name=""ISSG 2000"">{{cite web

column2: title=100 of the World's Worst Invasive Alien Species: A Selection from the Global Invasive Species Database

column1: As domestic cats are little altered from wildcats, they can readily interbreed. This [[hybrid (biology)
column2: hybridization]] poses a danger to the genetic distinctiveness of some wildcat populations, particularly in [[Scotland]] and [[Hungary]] and possibly also the [[Iberian Peninsula]].<ref name=""Oliveira"">{{Cite journal
column8: title=Hybridization Versus Conservation: Are Domestic Cats Threatening the Genetic Integrity of Wildcats (''Felis silvestris silvestris'') in Iberian Peninsula?
column9: journal=Philos. Trans. R. Soc. Lond., B, Biol. Sci.

column1: Feral cats are domestic cats that were born in or have reverted to a wild state. They are unfamiliar with and wary of humans and roam freely in urban and rural areas.<ref name=""Rochlitz"" /> The numbers of feral cats is not known, but estimates of the US feral population range from 25 to 60 million.<ref name=""Rochlitz"" /> Feral cats may live alone, but most are found in large [[feral cat colony
column2: colonies]], which occupy a specific territory and are usually associated with a source of food.<ref name=""hsus-feral"">{{cite web
column6: title=What is the difference between a stray cat and a feral cat?
column7: publisher=Humane Society of the United States}}</ref> Famous feral cat colonies are found in Rome around the [[Colosseum]] and [[Forum Romanum]], with cats at some of these sites being fed and given medical attention by volunteers.<ref>{{cite web

column1: Public attitudes towards feral cats vary widely, ranging from seeing them as free-ranging pets, to regarding them as vermin.<ref>{{Cite book

column2: title=The State of the Animals II: 2003

column1: }}</ref> One common approach to reducing the feral cat population is termed 'trap-neuter-return', where the cats are trapped, [[neutering
column3: immunized]] against rabies and the [[feline leukemia virus]], and then released. Before releasing them back into their feral colonies, the attending veterinarian often nips the tip off one ear to mark it as neutered and inoculated, since these cats may be trapped again. Volunteers continue to feed and give care to these cats throughout their lives. Given this support, their lifespans are increased, and behavior and nuisance problems caused by competition for food are reduced.<ref name=""hsus-feral"" />

column1: To date, little scientific data is available to assess the impact of cat predation on prey populations. Even well-fed domestic cats may hunt and kill, mainly catching small mammals, but also birds, amphibians, reptiles, fish, and invertebrates.<ref name=""Woods"">{{Cite journal
column2: vauthors=Woods M, McDonald RA, Harris S
column3: title=Predation of wildlife by domestic cats Felis catus in Great Britain

column2: title=Survey of Predation by Domestic Cats

column1: }}</ref> Hunting by domestic cats may be contributing to the decline in the numbers of birds in urban areas, although the importance of this effect remains controversial.<ref name=""Beckerman 2007"">{{Cite journal

column2: title=Urban Bird Declines and the Fear of Cats

column1: }}</ref> In the wild, the introduction of feral cats during human settlement can threaten native species with extinction.<ref name=""Nogales"">{{Cite journal

column2: title=A Review of Feral Cat Eradication on Islands

column1: }}</ref> In many cases, controlling or eliminating the populations of non-native cats can produce a rapid recovery in native animals.<ref name=""pmid14558589"">{{Cite journal

column2: title=Mammal Invaders on Islands: Impact, Control and Control Impact

column1: }}</ref> However, the ecological role of introduced cats can be more complicated. For example, cats can control the numbers of rats, which also prey on birds' eggs and young, so a cat population can protect an endangered bird species by suppressing [[Mesopredator release hypothesis

column2: title=Spatial Heterogeneity of Mesopredator Release within an Oceanic Island System
journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America

column1: In isolated landmasses, such as  [[Australasia]], there are often no other native, medium-sized [[quadruped]]al predators (including other feline species); this tends to exacerbate the impact of feral cats on small native animals.<ref name=""AusGovReport"">{{cite web
column4: title=Overview of the Impacts of Feral Cats on Australian Native Fauna
column5: publisher=Australian Department of the Environment, Water, Heritage and the Arts
column9: archivedate=13 September 2007}}</ref> Native species such as the New Zealand [[kakapo]] and the Australian [[bettong]], for example, tend to be more ecologically vulnerable and behaviorally ""naive"", when faced with predation by cats.<ref name=""pmid12085522"">{{Cite journal
column10: vauthors=James H, Acharya AB, Taylor JA, Freak MJ
column17: pmid=12085522}}</ref> Feral cats have had a major impact on these native species and have played a leading role in the endangerment and extinction of many animals.<ref name=""pmid16094805"">{{Cite journal
column19: title=Complex interactions among mammalian carnivores in Australia, and their implications for wildlife management

column1: Even in places with ancient and numerous cat populations, such as [[Western Europe]], cats appear to be growing in number and independently of their environments' [[carrying capacity]] (such as the numbers of prey available).<ref name=""Liberg 1982"">{{Cite journal

column2: title=Food Habits and Prey Impact by Feral and House-based Domestic Cats in a Rural Area in Southern Sweden

column1: }}</ref> This may be explained, at least in part, by an abundance of food, from sources including feeding by pet owners and scavenging. For instance, research in [[Great Britain
column2: Britain]] suggests that a high proportion of cats hunt only ""recreationally"".<ref name=""May, R., 1988""/> And in [[South Sweden]], where research in 1982 found that the population density of cats was as high as {{convert

column3: A black cat eating a [[house sparrow]]]]

column1: The domestic cat is a significant predator of birds. UK assessments indicate they may be accountable for an estimated 64.8 million bird deaths each year.<ref name=""Woods"" /> A 2012 study suggests feral cats may kill several billion birds each year in the United States.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=You thought watching cat videos was harmless fun? Think AGAIN.
column5: accessdate=9 September 2014}}</ref> Certain species appear more susceptible than others; for example, 30% of [[house sparrow]] mortality is linked to the domestic cat.<ref name=""Chucher 1987"">{{Cite journal

column2: title=Predation by Domestic Cats in an English village

column1: }}</ref> In the recovery of ringed robins (''[[Erithacus rubecula]]'') and dunnocks (''[[Prunella modularis]]''), 31% of deaths were a result of cat predation.<ref name=""Mead 1982 183–186"">{{Cite journal

}}</ref> In parts of North America, the presence of larger carnivores such as [[coyote]]s which prey on cats and other small predators reduces the effect of predation by cats and other small predators such as [[opossum]]s and [[raccoon]]s on bird numbers and variety.<ref name=""Crooks 1999"">{{cite journal

column2: title=Mesopredator Release and Avifaunal Extinctions in a Fragmented System
bibcode=1999Natur.400..563C}}</ref> The proposal that cat populations will increase when the numbers of these top predators decline is called the mesopredator release hypothesis.

column1: On islands, birds can contribute as much as 60% of a cat's diet.<ref name=""Fitzgerald"">{{Cite book
column5: chapter=Hunting Behaviour of Domestic Cats and Their Impact on Prey Populations
column6: title=The Domestic Cat: The Biology of its Behaviour
column8: pages=151–175}}</ref> In nearly all cases, however, the cat cannot be identified as the sole cause for reducing the numbers of island birds, and in some instances, eradication of cats has caused a 'mesopredator release' effect;<ref>{{Cite journal
column16: title=Cats protecting birds: modelling the mesopredator release effect
column21: pages=282–292 }}</ref> where the suppression of top carnivores creates an abundance of smaller predators that cause a severe decline in their shared prey. Domestic cats are, however, known to be a contributing factor to the decline of many species, a factor that has ultimately led, in some cases, to extinction. [[Turnagra capensis
column23: Chatham rail]],<ref name=""Mead 1982 183–186"" /> the [[New Zealand merganser]],<ref>{{Cite book
column33: title=Endemic Bird Areas of the World: Priorities for Biodiversity Conservation
column42: title=Status and Conservation of Seabirds at some Islands in the African Sector of the Southern Ocean. In: Status and Conservation of the World's Seabirds, ed Croxall, J. P., Evans, P. G. H. & Schreiber, R. W. International Council for Bird Preservation.
column44: location=Cambridge.}}</ref> are a few from a long list, with the most extreme case being the flightless [[Lyall's wren]], which was driven to extinction only a few years after its discovery.<ref>{{Cite book
column45: title=New Zealand Bird Life Past and Present
column56: title= The Tale of the Lighthouse-keeper's Cat: Discovery and Extinction of the Stephens Island Wren (''Traversia lyalli'')

column1: Some of the same factors that have promoted [[adaptive radiation]] of island [[Bird
column2: avifauna]] over evolutionary time appear to promote vulnerability to non-native species in modern time. The susceptibility of many island birds is undoubtedly due to evolution in the absence of mainland predators, competitors, diseases, and parasites, in addition to lower reproductive rates and extended incubation periods.<ref name=""dowd"">{{Cite journal
column8: title=The Impact of Predation be Introduced Mammals on Endemic Shorebirds in New Zealand: A Conservation Perspective
column12: doi=10.1016/S0006-3207(00)00187-7}}</ref> The loss of flight, or reduced flying ability is also characteristic of many island endemics.<ref>{{Cite journal
column20: title=Loss and Recovery of Wings in Stick Insects
column27: bibcode=2003Natur.421..264W}}</ref> These biological aspects have increased vulnerability to extinction in the presence of [[introduced species]], such as the domestic cat.<ref>{{Cite book
column30: title=Global Biodiversity: Status of the Earth's Living Resources
column34: publisher=[[Chapman & Hall]]}}</ref> Equally, behavioral traits exhibited by island species, such as ""predatory naivety""<ref>{{Cite journal
column40: title=The Late Quaternary Extinction and Future Resurrection of Birds on Pacific Islands
column45: bibcode=2003ESRv...61..133S}}</ref> and ground-nesting,<ref name=""dowd"" /> have also contributed to their susceptibility.

column1: [[File:FEMA - 34984 - Humane Society worker holding rescued cats.jpg

Cats are common [[pet]]s throughout the world, and their worldwide population exceeds 500 million.<ref name=""NYT"" /> Although cat guardianship has commonly been associated with women,<ref name=""Ellin"">{{Cite news
column3: title=More Men Are Unabashedly Embracing Their Love of Cats
column7: date=5 October 2008}}</ref> a 2007 [[Gallup poll]] reported that men and women in the United States of America were equally likely to own a cat.<ref name=""Gallup"">{{cite web
column9: title=Companionship and Love of Animals Drive Pet Ownership

column1: As well as being kept as pets, cats are also used in the international [[fur trade
column7: publisher=Humane Society of the United States
column8: accessdate=22 October 2009}}</ref> and [[leather]] industries for making coats, hats, blankets and stuffed toys;<ref>A Primer on Animal Rights: Leading Experts Write about Animal Cruelty and Exploitation, Kim W. Stallwood, Lantern Books, 2002</ref> and shoes, gloves and musical instruments respectively<ref>{{cite web
column10: title=Japan: Finale for the world's most elegant use of a dead cat
column12: publisher=}}</ref> (about 24 cats are needed to make a cat fur coat).<ref>{{Cite news
column14: title=EU proposes cat and dog fur ban
column17: date=20 November 2006}}</ref> This use has now been outlawed in the United States, Australia, and the European Union.<ref>{{cite web
column21: title=EU Announces Strict Ban on Dog and Cat Fur Imports and Exports
column27: accessdate=14 December 2011}}</ref> Cat pelts have been used for superstitious purposes as part of the practise of [[witchcraft]],<ref>Witchcraft and Magic in Europe, Volume 3: The Middle Ages. Karen Jolly, A&C Black, 2002</ref> and are still made into blankets in [[Switzerland]] as [[traditional medicine
column28: folk remedies]] believed to help [[rheumatism]].<ref>{{Cite news
column30: title=Switzerland Finds a Way to Skin a Cat for the Fur Trade and High Fashion
column36: date=25 April 2008}}</ref> In the Western intellectual tradition, the idea of cats as everyday objects have served to illustrate problems of [[quantum mechanics]] in the [[Schrödinger's cat]] thought experiment.

column1: A few attempts to build a cat census have been made over the years, both through associations or national and international organizations (such as the [[Canadian Federation of Humane Societies]]'s one<ref name=""Canadian"">{{cite news
column3: title=Humane society launches national cat census
column5: work=CBC News}}</ref>) and over the net,<ref name=""catsbe"">{{cite web
column14: fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> but such a task does not seem simple to achieve. General estimates for the global population of domestic cats range widely from anywhere between 200 million to 600 million.<ref>{{cite web
column20: title=Sur une tentative d'estimation du nombre total de chats domestiques dans le monde
column21: trans_title=Tentative estimation of the total number of domestic cats in the world
column23: journal=Comptes Rendus De l'Académie Des Sciences. Série III, Sciences De La Vie
column31: title=Cats: most interesting facts about common domestic pets
column35: title=Study Traces Cat's Ancestry to Middle East
column43: title=Urban Carnivores: Ecology, Conflict, and Conservation

column1: Cats may bite humans when provoked, during play or when aggressive. Complications from cat bites can develop.<ref name = kidshealth>{{Cite web
column7: date = 2017}}</ref> A cat bite differs from the bites of other pets. This is because the teeth of a cat are sharp and pointed causing deep [[wound
column8: punctures]]. Skin usually closes rapidly over the bite and traps [[microorganisms]] that cause [[infection]].<ref name = assh>{{cite web
column11: publisher = American Society for Surgery of the Hand

column3: bacteria]], [[fungus]], [[protozoans]], [[arthropod]]s or worms that can transmit diseases to humans.<ref name=""Chomel2014""/> In some cases, the cat exhibits no [[symptoms]] of the disease,<ref name=Ohio2016>{{cite web
column8: date=21 January 2015 }}</ref> However, the same disease can then become evident in a human.  The likelihood that a person will become diseased depends on the age and [[immunity (medical)
column9: immune]] status of the person. Humans who have cats living in their home or in close association are more likely to become infected, however, those who do not keep cats as pets might also acquire infections from cat [[feces]] and [[parasite]]s exiting the cat's body.<ref name=""Chomel2014"">{{cite journal
column12: title=Emerging and Re-Emerging Zoonoses of Dogs and Cats
column28: title=Reducing the risk of pet-associated zoonotic infections
column37: pmc=4500695}}</ref> Some of the infections of most concern include [[salmonella]], [[cat scratch disease]] and [[toxoplasmosis]].<ref name=""Ohio2016""/>

column4: A 19th century drawing of a tabby cat]]

column1: Traditionally, historians tended to think [[ancient Egypt]] was the site of cat domestication, owing to the clear depictions of house cats in Egyptian paintings about 3,600 years old.<ref name=""Driscoll"" /> However, in 2004, a Neolithic grave excavated in [[Shillourokambos]], [[Cyprus]], contained the skeletons, laid close to one another, of both a human and a cat. The grave is estimated to be 9,500 years old, pushing back the earliest known feline–human association significantly.<ref name=""9500 years"" /><ref name=""Muir 2004"">{{Cite news

column2: title=Ancient Remains Could Be Oldest Pet Cat
title=Ancient Burial Looks Like Human and Pet Cat

column1: }}</ref> The cat specimen is large and closely resembles the African wildcat, rather than present-day domestic cats. This discovery, combined with genetic studies, suggests cats were probably domesticated in the Middle East, in the [[Fertile Crescent]] around the time of the [[History of agriculture
column2: development of agriculture]], and then were brought to Cyprus and Egypt.<ref name=""DriscollMenotti-Raymond2007""/><ref name=""OttoniVan Neer2017""/>

column1: Direct evidence for the domestication of cats 5,300 years ago in Quanhucun, [[China]] has been published by archaeologists and paleontologists from the [[University of Washington]] and [[Chinese Academy of Sciences]]. The cats are believed to have been attracted to the village by rodents, which in turn were attracted by grain cultivated and stored by humans.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Gatos fueron domesticados en China hace 5.300 años

column1: In ancient Egypt, cats were [[animal worship
column2: sacred animal]]s, with the goddess [[Bastet]] often depicted in cat form, sometimes taking on the war-like aspect of a lioness.<ref name=""Mason"">{{Cite book
column10: Romans]] are often credited with introducing the domestic cat from Egypt to Europe;<ref name=""Mason"" />{{rp
column12: Roman Aquitaine]], a first- or second-century [[engraving]] of a young girl holding a cat is one of two earliest depictions of the Roman domesticated cat.<ref>{{cite book
column23: chapter=The Household and Its Freed Slaves
column25: url=https://books.google.com/?id=JmpOH8AVV4EC}}</ref> However, cats possibly were already kept in Europe prior to the [[Roman Empire]], as they may have been present in Britain in the late [[Iron Age]].<ref name=""OConnor"" /> Domestic cats were spread throughout much of the rest of the world during the [[Age of Discovery]], as they were carried on [[sailing ship]]s to control shipboard rodents and as good-luck charms (see [[Ship's cat]]).<ref name=""Mason"" />{{rp

column1: Several ancient religions believed cats are exalted souls, companions or guides for humans, that are all-knowing but mute so they cannot influence decisions made by humans. In Japan, the ''[[maneki neko]]'' cat is a symbol of good fortune.<ref>{{cite web
Although no species are sacred in Islam, [[Islam and cats
column2: cats are revered by Muslims]]. Some Western writers have stated [[Muhammad]] had a favorite cat, [[Muezza]].<ref>{{Cite book
column5: title=When Cats Reigned Like Kings: On the Trail of the Sacred Cats
column9: isbn=0-7407-4697-9}}</ref> He is reported to have loved cats so much, ""he would do without his cloak rather than disturb one that was sleeping on it"".<ref name=""Reeves"">{{Cite book
column15: year=2000}}</ref> The story has no origin in early Muslim writers, and seems to confuse a story of a later [[Sufi]] saint, [[Ahmed ar-Rifa'i]], centuries after Muhammad.<ref>{{cite web

column1: [[Freyja]], the goddess of love, beauty, and fertility in [[Norse mythology]], is depicted as riding a chariot drawn by cats.<ref>{{cite book
Many cultures have negative [[superstition]]s about cats. An example would be the belief that a [[black cat]] ""crossing one's path"" leads to bad luck, or that cats are witches' [[familiar spirit
column2: familiar]]s used to augment a witch's powers and skills. The killing of cats in Medieval [[Ypres]], [[Belgium]], is commemorated in the innocuous present-day [[Kattenstoet]] (cat parade).<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Are Black Cats Really Bad Luck? [Hoax]

column1: In medieval France, cats would be burnt alive as a form of entertainment. According to [[Norman Davies]], the assembled people ""shrieked with laughter as the animals, howling with pain, were singed, roasted, and finally [[Carbonization

It was the custom to burn a basket, barrel, or sack full of live cats, which was hung from a tall mast in the midst of the bonfire; sometimes a [[fox]] was burned. The people collected the embers and ashes of the fire and took them home, believing that they brought good luck. The French kings often witnessed these spectacles and even lit the bonfire with their own hands. In 1648 [[Louis XIV]], crowned with a wreath of roses and carrying a bunch of roses in his hand, kindled the fire, danced at it and partook of the banquet afterwards in the town hall. But this was the last occasion when a monarch presided at the midsummer bonfire in Paris. At [[Metz]] midsummer fires were lighted with great pomp on the esplanade, and a dozen cats, enclosed in [[wicker]] cages, were burned alive in them, to the amusement of the people. Similarly at [[Gap, Hautes-Alpes
column3: department]] of the [[Hautes-Alpes]], cats used to be roasted over the midsummer bonfire.""<ref>[[James Frazer
column4: Frazer, Sir James George]]. ''The Golden Bough'', (1922). [http://www.bartleby.com/196/164.html Online version.]</ref>

column1: According to a myth in many cultures, cats have multiple lives. In many countries, they are believed to have nine lives, but in Italy, Germany, Greece, Brazil and some Spanish-speaking regions, they are said to have seven lives,<ref>{{Cite news
column12: title=Qual é a origem da lenda de que os gatos teriam sete vidas?
column16: accessdate=15 November 2015}}</ref> while in Turkish and Arabic traditions, the number of lives is six.<ref>{{Cite news
column23: date=19 March 2010}}</ref> The myth is attributed to the natural suppleness and swiftness cats exhibit to escape life-threatening situations. Also lending credence to this myth is the fact that falling cats often land on their feet, using an instinctive [[cat righting reflex
column24: righting reflex]] to twist their bodies around. Nonetheless, cats can still be injured or killed by a high fall.<ref>{{cite web
column26: title=The ASPCA Warns About High-Rise Falls by Cats

column1: <ref name=""Globe interview Parliament Hill Cat sanctuary closing"">

A number of the four remaining colony cats at the Parliament Hill Cat Sanctuary in Ottawa, Ontario, Canada were 15 and 16 years old in 2013. [http://www.theglobeandmail.com/life/travel/travel-news/a-beloved-parliament-hill-attraction-uses-up-its-nine-lives/article8103874/ ""A beloved Parliament Hill attraction uses up its nine lives""], Karan Smith, The Globe and Mail, 1 February 2013.</ref>

<ref name=""TNR Works Merrimack River"">Zorro, the last cat of a colony at the Merrimack River in Newburyport, Massachusetts, died in 2009 at age 16. [http://www.alleycat.org/TNRworks ""Trap-Neuter-Return Effectively Stabilizes and Reduces Feral Cat Populations: Trap-Neuter-Return Humanely Stabilized and Reduced in Size the Merrimack River Colony""], Alley Cat Allies, accessed 18 August 2014; an earlier article in the LA Times was written when Zorro was the last remaining living cat: [http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/unleashed/2009/09/advocates-report-success-with-trap-neuter-return-approach-to-stray-cats.html ""Advocates report success with trap, neuter, return approach to stray cats""], Los Angeles Times, 29 September 2009.</ref>

<ref name=""TNR Works Washington DC"">The last cat in a managed colony in Washington, D.C. died at age 17. [http://www.alleycat.org/TNRworks ""Trap-Neuter-Return Effectively Stabilizes and Reduces Feral Cat Populations: Washington, D.C. Cat Colony Stabilized and Eventually Reduced to Zero""], Alley Cat Allies, accessed 18 August 2014.</ref>

<ref name=""Remfry 1996"">J. Remfry, Feral Cats in the United Kingdom (JAVMA Vol. 208, No. 4, 15 February 1996, pp. 520–523), at p. 522, available online at pp. 24–27 of [https://ecfvg.avma.org/Files/ProductDownloads/1995_the_welfare_of_cats.pdf ""AVMA Animal Welfare Forum: The welfare of cats""], 3 November 1995.</ref>
